name: Pyhän Henrikin katedraali
description:
St. Henry's Cathedral is a Roman Catholic cathedral located in the Ullanlinna district of Helsinki. It was built between 1858 and 1860, during the time when Finland was a Grand Duchy under Imperial Russia. The cathedral was designed by the German-born architect Ernst Bernhard Lohrmann and represents Neo-Gothic architecture. Statues of Bishop Henry, Saint Peter, and Saint Paul adorn the exterior of the church.

Initially, the church served Polish soldiers in the Russian army, as well as Catholic merchants and artists in Finland. It became the cathedral of the Diocese of Helsinki in 1955. The church is one of the oldest Neo-Gothic churches in Finland.

name: Pyhän Joosefin kirkko
description: Saint Joseph's Church in Kuopio, Finland, is a Catholic church located in the Männistö district. Originally built as a Lutheran church between 1912 and 1913, it was later sold to the Catholic Church in June 2013 and consecrated as a Catholic church on May 3, 2014. The church building is made of wood, creating a warm and sacred atmosphere. Today, it serves as the center for the local Catholic community, previously part of the Parish of St. Olav in Jyväskylä.

name: Pyhän Marian kirkko
description:
St. Mary's Church is a Catholic church located in Meilahti, Helsinki. Designed by architect Kaj Salenius, it was completed in 1954. The church can accommodate 300 people, with seating for 150.

The church is the focal point of St. Mary's Parish. The church interior features a mosaic work of natural stone by German artist Claus Kilian. The church also has a separate baptistery. The church's old altar contains relics of Pius X and Maria Goretti, while the new altar has relics of Saint Birgitta and her daughter Catherine. The stained-glass windows depict the seven corporal and seven spiritual works of mercy. The church organ dates back to 1965 and was built by Richard Jacoby.

name: Pyhän Birgitan ja Autuaan Hemmingin kirkko
description: The Church of Saint Birgitta and Blessed Hemming is a Catholic church in Turku, Finland. It is located in the city center on Ursininkatu street. The church building was completed in 1966. The church is part of the Catholic Church in Finland. In addition to church, there is also Bridgettine Convent. The parish was founded in 1926.

name: Pyhän Olavin kirkko
description:
St. Olaf's Church, also known as Tyrvää Old Church, is a late medieval grey stone church built around 1506–1516 in Tyrvää, Sastamala. It's situated on the shore of Lake Rautavesi. The church stands on a site of national scenic beauty, forming a nationally significant built cultural environment.

Originally built on an old worship site, the church burned down in the early 17th century, requiring a complete reconstruction of the interior. The church fell into disuse in the mid-19th century after a new church was built in Tyrvää. In 1997, a burglar set the church on fire, causing extensive damage. It was rebuilt between 1997 and 2003, with artists Osmo Rauhala and Kuutti Lavonen painting the interior.

name: Pyhän Ursulan kirkko
description: The Church of Saint Ursula is a Catholic church located in Kouvola. It belongs to the Catholic Parish of Saint Ursula. The church was designed by architect Benito Casagrande and was completed and consecrated in 1993. The parish itself was established as a chapel parish in 1985 and became independent in 1991, after which the construction of its own church began. German Catholics significantly aided in the construction of the church. Masses are held almost daily at the church.

name: Nasaretin pyhän perheen kirkko
description:
The Church of the Holy Family in Nazareth is a Catholic church in Oulu, Finland, belonging to the Catholic Diocese of Helsinki. The parish was founded in 1992 and covers the regions of Northern Ostrobothnia, Kainuu and Lapland.

The church building is located in the Koskela district, about 4-5 kilometers from the center of Oulu. It was designed by the Italian-Swiss architect Gabriele Geronzi. Pope John Paul II blessed the foundation stone of the church during his visit to Finland in 1989. The first part of the building was completed in 1991, and the second part in 2000. The church's address is Liisantie 2, 90560 Oulu.

name: Ahveniston pyhän Johannes Kastajan mestauksen kirkko
description:
The Ahvenisto Church, also known as the Church of the Beheading of St. John the Baptist, is one of two churches belonging to the Orthodox Parish of Hämeenlinna. This wooden, long church with a western tower was completed in 1894 and consecrated by Archbishop Antoni on June 2 of the same year.

Located in Ahvenisto, Hämeenlinna, opposite the Kanta-Häme Central Hospital, it now serves as a summer church due to the lack of electricity and heating. The church's activities diminished in the 1920s, but it was restored for summer use in the late 1990s. The iconostasis of the church originates from a Russian warship from the 1840s.

name: Espoon pyhittäjä Herman Alaskalaisen kirkko
description:
The Church of St. Herman of Alaska is an Orthodox church located in Tapiola, Espoo. It belongs to the Orthodox Parish of Helsinki. The church was built between 1997 and 1998 and consecrated in October 1998. Architect Paul Hesse designed the church, and it is situated in a pine landscape in Tapiola.

The architecture represents a blend of classical Byzantine and modern styles. The church is dedicated to Saint Herman of Alaska, a monk who traveled to Alaska in 1793 to do missionary work and became a significant spiritual teacher and defender of the local population. Alexander Wikström painted the frescoes in the church hall, and Ulla Vaajakallio's icons are displayed in the community hall.

name: Haminan Jumalanäidin kaikkien murheellisten ilon ikonin kirkko
description: The Church of the Icon of the Mother of God "Joy of All Who Sorrow" is located in Hamina, Finland, at the Orthodox cemetery. Designed by architect Berndt Ivar Aminoff and completed in 1901, the church is dedicated to the "Joy of All Who Sorrow" icon. The church resembles garrison churches of its time. The iconostasis and two other icons within the church were brought to Hamina from Vyborg. A few services are held there annually. Near the church is the Aladin family's burial chapel, designed by Karl August Wrede and built around 1900.

name: Haminan Pyhien apostolien Pietarin ja Paavalin kirkko
description:
The Church of St. Peter and St. Paul in Hamina is an Orthodox church completed in 1837. It is located in the heart of Hamina, a city known for its circular layout. This rare rotunda church exhibits a neoclassical style with Byzantine influences and was likely designed by Louis Visconti.

Inside, the church features a spacious central dome, creating a light and airy atmosphere. The walls are adorned with approximately sixty icons, with the most important being one depicting the church's patron saints, Peter and Paul. Wall paintings, believed to be original, and inscriptions in Church Slavonic further enrich the interior. A separate bell tower, built in 1862, stands alongside the church.

name: Hangon pyhien apostolienvertaisten Vladimirin ja Maria Magdaleenan kirkko
description: The Church of Holy Equals-to-the-Apostles Vladimir and Maria Magdalene is an Orthodox wooden church in Hanko, Finland. It belongs to the Helsinki Orthodox Parish and is considered a culturally and historically significant building. The church was built in 1895 by Russian spa visitors. Architect Barankejev designed the church, and most of the icons and inventory were donated by visitors. During the Soviet lease period in 1940-1941, the church served as a club room but was spared from major damage. The church commemorates Saint Vladimir of Kiev and Mary Magdalene.

name: Hattuvaaran pyhien apostolien Pietarin ja Paavalin tsasouna
description:
The Hattuvaara Tsasouna, dedicated to Saints Peter and Paul, is located in Hattuvaara, Ilomantsi. It is considered the oldest Karelian-style village chapel in Finland.

Local tradition suggests that the "tsasouna has always been there," with current estimates dating its construction to 1792. The large icons within the chapel were painted in the late 1800s and brought from Terijoki. The namesake icon, "Apostles Peter and Paul," was painted by the renowned icon painter Petros Sasaki in the 1980s.

Near the Tsasouna are museum buildings and a memorial stone for Arhippa Buruskainen, a famous local rune singer (1781–1846). The village's old cemetery is located in a nearby atmospheric evergreen forest. The chapel has been in continuous use for over 200 years.

name: Heinolan Kristuksen taivaaseen astumisen kirkko
description: The Church of the Ascension of Christ in Heinola, also known as the Heinola Orthodox Church, is an Orthodox church building located in Heinola. It was completed in 1956 and was originally consecrated as a chapel. Bishop Alexander performed the consecration on December 6, 1956. It was consecrated as a church by Metropolitan Johannes on August 31, 1986. The church is located at Hämeenkatu 6, Heinola.

name: Helsingin pyhän Kolminaisuuden kirkko
description:
The Holy Trinity Church in Helsinki is the oldest Orthodox church in the city, completed in 1826 and consecrated in 1827. Designed by Carl Ludvig Engel in the Empire style, it is located on Unioninkatu street. Initially, the church was intended to be built after the Lutheran Cathedral, but private donations from Helsinki's Orthodox community expedited its construction.

Today, the church primarily holds services in Church Slavonic, catering to the large Russian-speaking minority within the Helsinki Orthodox community. Other Orthodox churches in Helsinki, such as the Uspenski Cathedral, mainly conduct services in Finnish. The church is known for blending eastern and western influences, with its Western-style exterior concealing a traditional Orthodox interior.

name: Hyvinkään ortodoksinen kirkko
description:
The Orthodox Church of Hyvinkää, also known as the Church of the Enlighteners of Karelia, is part of the Orthodox Parish of Lahti. It is located in Hyvinkää. Originally consecrated as a chapel in 1963, it was expanded and consecrated as a church in 1996.

The building was designed by Laura Järvi-Larkas, with the expansion and parish center designed by Sakari Siitonen. The church received a new iconostasis painted by Anatoli Dofgij in the summer of 2005. The church serves as a home church for about 700 members, slightly over half of whom reside in Hyvinkää.

name: Hämeenlinnan pyhien Aleksanteri Nevskin ja Johannes Krysostomoksen kirkko
description:
The Orthodox Church of Hämeenlinna, previously known as the Church of Saints Alexander Nevsky and John Chrysostom, is a shrine of the Orthodox Parish of Helsinki. Located in the Kauriala district of Hämeenlinna, near the old cemetery, the church was consecrated in 1962.

Designed by architect Mika Erno, it is a simple red-brick structure featuring a concrete bell tower at the end. The church houses furnishings from the old wooden Orthodox Church of Hämeenlinna, which was located in Rantatori, including a Russian-made iconostasis. It also contains some items from the former Orthodox garrison church that was converted into a town library in the 1920s. In 2021 the church was renovated and re-consecrated and its name was changed to Church of the Tikhvin Icon of the Mother of God.

name: Ilomantsin pyhän profeetta Elian kirkko
description:
The Church of Prophet Elijah in Ilomantsi is the largest Orthodox wooden church in Finland. The five-domed church was completed in 1892 and designed by architect S.V. Sadovnikov from St. Petersburg. It is the main church of the Ilomantsi Orthodox Chapel Parish.

The church represents late Neoclassical style. The iconostasis, the screen of icons, was made in St. Petersburg. The annual feast day of the Church of Prophet Elijah is on July 20th, celebrating Iljan praasniekka. The church is the sixth Orthodox church in Ilomantsi.

name: Ivalon pyhän Nikolaoksen kirkko
description: The Ivalo Orthodox Church, dedicated to St. Nicholas, is located in the village of Ivalo at Rantatie 22. Originally built as a prayer house, it was consecrated in 1960 by Reverend Yrjö Räme. After undergoing a renovation, it was re-consecrated as a church in 1996 by Metropolitan Leo. The church was designed by architect Ilmari Ahonen. The Orthodox parish of Lapland, which is the northernmost in Finland, encompasses almost all of Lapland. Most of the parishioners in the northern Lapland region are Skolt Sámi.

name: Joensuun pyhän Nikolaoksen kirkko
description:
The Church of St. Nicholas in Joensuu is the main church of the Joensuu Orthodox parish. Completed in 1887, it is located in the center of Joensuu, at the northern end of Kirkkokatu. The church is considered a prime example of 19th-century Orthodox wooden church architecture, with its decorations and details.

Designed by G.I. Karpov, the most valuable part of the church is its iconostasis, painted in the Alexander Nevsky Lavra in St. Petersburg. The church's six bells are original, also cast in St. Petersburg. The church is open daily to parishioners and tourists interested in the church. In addition to weekend services, prayer meetings and sacraments are held in the church almost daily.

name: Joensuun Pyhän Johannes Teologin kirkko
description:
The Church of St. John the Theologian is an Orthodox church in Joensuu, Finland, part of the Joensuu Orthodox Seminary. It also serves as a church for the Orthodox theology program at the University of Eastern Finland. The church was completed in 1995, a few years after the seminary building.

The architectural style is Byzantine, modeled after the 11th-century Church of Panagia Chalkeon in Thessaloniki, Greece. A distinctive feature is the interior frescoes painted by Konstantinos Xenopoulos from Athens, illustrating the Orthodox liturgical year with its events and saints. During the summer, the church is open for guided tours.

name: Juankosken Jumalansynnyttäjän suojeluksen kirkko
description: The Church of the Protection of the Mother of God in Juankoski is an Orthodox church located in Juankoski, Kuopio. It belongs to the Orthodox Parish of Kuopio and is dedicated to the Protection of the Mother of God. The church's iconostasis was created by Petros Sasaki, and the new icons were painted by Marja Sasaki. The church is located at Patruunantie 59, 73500 Juankoski.

name: Jyväskylän Kristuksen ylösnousemuksen kirkko
description:
The Church of the Resurrection of Christ in Jyväskylä is the main church of the Jyväskylä Orthodox Parish. Completed in 1954, it was the first Orthodox church built in Finland during the reconstruction period. The church is located in the Nisula district of Jyväskylä, near the Taulumäki Church.

The church was designed by architect Toivo Paatela. The icons in the iconostasis were painted by writer Tito Colliander and Petros Sasaki. Much of the church's older artifacts come from churches in Karelia, including Käkisalmi, Valamo, Salmi, and Viipuri. The church celebrates its feast day on Easter, the Feast of the Resurrection of Christ.

name: Järvenpään Jumalansynnyttäjän kasanilaisen ikonin kirkko
description: The Järvenpää Church of the Kazan Icon of the Mother of God is an Orthodox church located in the Pöytäalho district of Järvenpää, opposite the Kartano School. It belongs to the Helsinki Orthodox Parish and was completed in 1980. The church has an active and welcoming community, and regular services are held there. You can explore the interior of the church through a panoramic image. The church's address is Kartanontie 45, Järvenpää.

name: Kajaanin Kristuksen kirkastumisen kirkko
description:
The Church of the Transfiguration of Christ in Kajaani is the main church of the Kainuu Orthodox chapel parish. In the beginning of 2009, the parish had approximately 1,850 members. The church is adorned with large Byzantine-style frescoes. It is located in the center of Kajaani, in Sammonpuisto park.

The church building, designed by architect Ilmari Ahonen, was completed in 1959. The church is located at Kirkkokatu 17a.

name: Kausalan Neitseen Marian syntymän tsasouna
description: The Kausala Chapel, dedicated to the Nativity of the Virgin Mary, belongs to the Orthodox Parish of Lahti and is located in Kausala, Iitti. Archbishop Leo consecrated the chapel on October 12, 2003. Aarre Laiho, a construction engineer, designed the chapel, drawing inspiration from the chapel in Salo. The chapel's temple festival, or praasniekka, is celebrated on September 8, the day commemorating the Birth of the Theotokos. The chapel is located at Keskikatu 4, 47400 Iitti and is open during services.

name: Keiteleen pyhittäjä Arseni Konevitsalaisen kirkko
description:
The Church of St. Arsenius of Konevitsa in Keitele is an Orthodox church building located in Keitele and belongs to the Orthodox parish of Kuopio. It was designed by Vilho Koistinen, originally as a chapel. Archbishop Paavali consecrated it as a chapel dedicated to St. Nicholas on May 17, 1965.

After a thorough renovation between 1998 and 2000, Assistant Bishop Panteleimon consecrated the building as a church dedicated to Arseni Konevitsalainen on June 11, 2000. This was to honor the fact that the Konevitsa Monastery operated in Keitele in evacuation between 1940 and 1956. Icons from the Konevitsa Monastery have been placed in the iconostasis of the Keitele church.

name: Kemin Johannes Kastajan syntymän kirkko
description:
The Orthodox Church of Kemi, also known as the Church of the Birth of St. John the Baptist, is located in the Koivuharju district of Kemi, specifically in Ruutiranta. It's one of the three churches belonging to the Orthodox Parish of Oulu.

Initially built as a prayer house in the early 1960s to serve the needs of Karelian and Petsamo evacuees, it was later consecrated as a church in the 1970s. The icons on the iconostasis were painted by Nina Vanas, a visual artist from Kemi. The building itself was designed by architect Ilmari Ahonen. The church celebrated its 50th anniversary in 2012.

name: Kiteen pyhän Kolminaisuuden ja pyhän Nektarios Eginalaisen kirkko
description:
The Church of the Holy Trinity and St. Nektarios of Aegina, consecrated in 2000, is located in Kitee. The architecture is Byzantine-Karelian in style. Architect Sirkka Sortti designed the building.

The beautiful iconostasis was created by the Wickström, Sasaki, and Salonen team. Adjacent to the sanctuary are Nektarios Hall and a terrace. The church is a place for quiet contemplation. It is surrounded by a park, offering a place of natural beauty that leads to the history of Orthodox Christianity. The park has a path named Georgios Path.

name: Kiuruveden pyhän Nikolaoksen kirkko
description:
The Church of St. Nicholas in Kiuruvesi is an Orthodox church belonging to the Iisalmi Orthodox Parish. Originally, the building was constructed as a pharmacy in 1918, and it was later acquired by the parish and consecrated as a church in 1957.

The church is known for its frescoes, which began to be painted in the summer of 1982. It was the first church built after the war, according to the reconstruction law, where the walls and ceiling of the entire church began to be filled with iconographic themes. In front of the church is a memorial to the deceased who remained in Karelia, erected in 1959.

name: Klaukkalan pyhän Nektarios Eginalaisen kirkko
description: The Klaukkala Orthodox Church, officially known as the Church of St. Nectarios of Aegina, is located in Klaukkala, Nurmijärvi. This wooden church was built by an Orthodox group in 1995 and consecrated as a church in 1997. The church was designed by Ritva Westermark and is a display of traditional log construction. Carpenter Johannes Andrejev crafted the domes, bell tower, porch pillars, and the traveler's cross in the yard. The icons for the iconostasis and the altar icon were painted by Aleksander Wikström. The church keeps a relic of Nectarios, who was canonized in 1961. The church is located at Kuonomäentie 80.

name: Kokkolan Pyhien Simeonin ja Hannan rukoushuone
description:
The Orthodox Chapel of Saints Simeon and Hanna in Kokkola is located at the corner of Katariinankatu and Pormestarinkatu in the city center. It is a small chapel, rebuilt in an old two-story wooden house between 1955 and 1957.

The iconostasis was designed by W. Froloff and Maria Beskoff. The church's Virgin Mary icon comes from the late 1800s from the Viipuri Cathedral of the Transfiguration of Christ. The icons of Saint Simeon and Saint Hanna originate from the Valamo Monastery. The chapel belongs to the Orthodox Parish of Vaasa.

name: Kontiolahden Kristuksen taivaaseenastumisen kirkko
description: The Church of the Ascension of Christ in Kontiolahti is an Orthodox church belonging to the Orthodox Parish of Joensuu. It's located at Keskuskatu 53, Kontiolahti. The church was originally built as a chapel but was consecrated as a church in 1985. Erkki Helasvuo designed the church. The temple festival is on Ascension Day. The church provides a place for the local Orthodox community to gather and practice their faith. Services are held regularly, especially during major religious holidays.

name: Kolhon Karjalan valistajain kirkko
description:
The Kolho Orthodox Church, also known as the Church of the Karelian Enlighteners or the Church of Saints Sergius and Herman of Valaam, is a small Orthodox church located in Kolho, Mänttä-Vilppula. It was originally built of wood as a prayer room in 1954 and was converted into a church in 1977–1978, when a wooden altar table was built.

The church's drawings are by building advisor Heimo Kautonen. The church has a rectangular floor plan, with the space divided into two parts: the altar room and the actual church hall. The church's iconostasis is the work of Archpriest M. Miikkola. The church's icons of St. Sergius and Herman of Valaam come from the Valamo Monastery. A gable-roofed bell tower rises from the west end of the church. The church belongs to the Orthodox Parish of Tampere.

name: Kotkan pyhän Nikolaoksen kirkko
description: Kotkan Pyhän Nikolaoksen kirkko, or St. Nicholas Church in Kotka, is the oldest building in the city. It is located in Isopuisto park in the city center. The neoclassical church was built between 1799 and 1801, designed by Jakov Perrin. The building originally served the Ruotsinsalmi sea fortress. The church has a striking facade with columns at each of the three entrances, as well as a bell tower. A small portion of the cemetery, with its memorials, that once surrounded the church has been preserved.

name: Kouvolan Pyhän Ristin kirkko
description: The Church of the Holy Cross in Kouvola is an Orthodox church that belongs to the parish of Hamina. It was originally built as a Russian garrison church between 1913 and 1915 and consecrated in 1916. After Finland gained independence, the church was transferred to the ownership of the Finnish state and reconsecrated as a Lutheran church. It served as a Lutheran church until 1978. In 1981, the Lutheran parish of Kouvola donated the church to the Orthodox parish of Hamina, and it was converted back into an Orthodox church. The iconostasis of the church was painted by Margit Lintu.

name: Kuivajärven Pyhän Nikolaoksen tsasouna
description:
The Kuivajärvi Holy Nicholas Chapel represents a western architectural style that became common in Karelian church architecture in the latter half of the 1700s, drawing inspiration from St. Petersburg. The chapel features a western tower connected to the main structure, reminiscent of separate bell towers used in medieval sanctuaries.

The current chapel, completed in 1958, is the third in the Kuivajärvi village and is modeled after the Ägläjärvi village chapel in Korpiselkä, which was destroyed in the wars. Deacon Olavi Lehmuskoski, a teacher at the Kuivajärvi school, played a significant role in its construction. Archbishop Paavali consecrated the chapel in June 1958. The building was commissioned by the Finnish Orthodox Church under a reconstruction law, as the previous chapel was destroyed during military operations. The chapel exemplifies the carpentry skills of the village men. The icons inside were painted by the artist Martha Neiglick-Platonov.

name: Lahden pyhän Kolminaisuuden kirkko
description: The Church of the Holy Trinity in Lahti is an Orthodox church designed by architect Toivo Paatela and completed in 1955. It serves as the main church for the Orthodox community in Lahti. Consecrated on December 9, 1956, by Bishop Alexander, the church contains several items and icons originating from areas of Karelia that Finland lost. Notably, the chandeliers are from the old Valamo monastery. In 2006, the church underwent a renovation, giving it its current appearance. The church building was protected by the town plan in 1988. It is located at Harjukatu 5. Currently, there are ongoing repairs to the roof and bell tower.

name: Lapinlahden kaikkien pyhien kirkko
description: The Church of All Saints in Lapinlahti is an Orthodox church building. It belongs to the Orthodox parish of Iisalmi. Originally built as a prayer house, it was designed by architect Ilmari Ahonen, and Archbishop Paavali consecrated the prayer house on August 2, 1959. Later, the prayer house was consecrated as a church on September 6, 1987, by Bishop Tiihon. The iconostasis was painted by Martha Neiglick-Platonoff. The church's temple festival is celebrated on All Saints' Sunday (the Sunday following Pentecost). In 2009, the church tower got its flame dome. The address of the church is Pekka Halosentie 18, Lapinlahti.

name: Lappeenrannan Jumalansynnyttäjän suojeluksen kirkko
description:
The Church of the Protection of the Mother of God in Lappeenranta, also known as Pokrova Church, is the oldest Orthodox church in Finland, dating back to 1785. It is located in the Linnoitus district of Lappeenranta. The church's icon depicts the appearance of the Virgin Mary.

Initially built on the site of a former church, it was expanded in the early 1900s, while preserving the vestibule with the bell tower and the altar room. The church celebrates its feast day on October 1st. A renovation in the 1980s had some issues with the exterior paint, which has been difficult to remedy due to the concrete surface.

name: Lintulan Jumalansynnyttäjän Jerusalemin ikonin tsasouna
description: The Chapel of the Jerusalem Icon of the Mother of God is located in the cemetery of the Lintula Holy Trinity Convent. This wooden chapel, built in the Karelian style, was designed by architect Antero Turkki. It was consecrated in 1996 and is dedicated to the Jerusalem Icon of the Mother of God. Inside the chapel, behind the altar, there is a large icon of the Mother of God of Jerusalem. On either side of it are event icons depicting the Resurrection of Christ and the Dormition of the Mother of God. Above them is an icon of Christ Pantocrator. During the summer, an Akathistos service is held in the chapel once a week.

name: Lintulan pyhittäjämarttyyri Paraskevan tšasouna
description: The Chapel of Saint Paraskeva is a small chapel dedicated to the Holy Martyr Paraskeva. It's located about half a kilometer from the main Lintula Convent area, near Lake Koskijärvi. A forest path leads to the chapel, offering a place for private contemplation and prayer. The chapel was consecrated in 1999, and it was built according to the wishes of Säde (Paraskeva) Ruhanen, who dedicated it to the memory of Saint Paraskeva. A procession is held to the chapel every year on July 26th, the Saint's feast day, where a water blessing ceremony is performed.

name: Lintulan pyhän Kolminaisuuden kirkko
description:
Lintulan Holy Trinity Church is an Orthodox church located in the Lintula Convent in Heinävesi. The church was designed by architect Vilho Suonmaa and built in 1973 using lightweight concrete blocks. The church is dedicated to the Holy Trinity, just like the original Lintula Monastery church in Kivennapa before the wars.

The church has a flat roof and is almost square in shape. Above the front door is an open bell tower with seven bells. From the vestibule, stairs descend to the church hall. The church hall has a dome with windows that let light into the hall. Many of the icons in the church hall contain relics. The dome and ceiling of the church feature murals painted by Greek icon painter Konstantinos Ksenopoulos in 2012 and 2021. Services are held in the church in the mornings and evenings.

name: Lohjan kaikkien pyhien tšasouna
description: The Chapel of All Saints is located in Lohja, at the Metsola Cemetery. It belongs to the Helsinki Orthodox Parish. The chapel was designed by Sakari Siitonen and completed in 1995, mainly through volunteer work. The construction project began with the erection of the Traveler's Cross in 1992. Bishop Arseni and Sakari Siitonen collaborated on the design of the icons. The project was a joint effort, demonstrating the strength and love of the community.

name: Lohjan Karjalan Valistajien kirkko
description: The Lohja Orthodox Church, also known as the Church of the Karelian Enlighteners, is located in the center of Lohja. By the early 1960s, around two hundred members of the Orthodox Church had moved to the Lohja area, mainly Karelian evacuees or their descendants. As the congregation grew, they needed their own space. In 1968, the Helsinki Orthodox Parish purchased a house in the center of Lohja, which became the Lohja Orthodox Work Center. In 2000, the building was renovated, and a new church was consecrated to the memory of the Karelian Enlighteners. The church's iconostasis was painted by Irene Schütz and Sakari Siitonen.

name: Maaningan Karjalan Valistajien kirkko
description:
The Maaningan Karjalan Valistajien kirkko, also known as the Church of the Karelian Enlighteners, is an Orthodox church located in the village of Maaninka, Kuopio. Architect Ilmari Ahonen designed the church. It was initially consecrated as a chapel by Archbishop Paavali in November 1960.

In 2005, the building underwent a thorough renovation. Subsequently, it was reconsecrated as a church by Archbishop Leo. The church serves as a place of worship for the Maaninka area of the Kuopio Orthodox Parish, which belongs to the Orthodox Church of Finland's Diocese of Kuopio and Karelia.

name: Mikkelin pyhän ylienkeli Mikaelin kirkko
description:
The Church of St. Michael the Archangel in Mikkeli is the central church of the local Orthodox parish. It was established on January 1, 1950, and consecrated in 1958. The red-brick church was designed by architect Ilmari Ahonen. The interior design and icons for the original iconostasis were created by the artist Veikko Marttinen. 

Over the years, the interior has undergone significant changes. Between 1990 and 1992, a new iconostasis and frescoes were added to the altar apse, designed and painted by Petros Sasaki. The church also has a separate office building and a 26-meter-high bell tower. The church is dedicated to Archangel Michael, the patron saint of the city of Mikkeli since the Middle Ages.

name: Nellimin Pyhän kolminaisuuden ja pyhittäjä Trifon Petsamolaisen kirkko
description:
The Church of the Holy Trinity and Saint Trifon of Petsamo is an Orthodox church located in the village of Nellim, Inari. It belongs to the Orthodox Parish of Lapland. Initially built as a chapel in 1987, it was consecrated as a church in 1988.

The church's design, by Seppo Latvala, was inspired by the old section of the Upper Monastery church in Petsamo. The church is dedicated to the Holy Trinity and Saint Trifon of Petsamo. A cemetery is located in connection with the church, which also features a memorial to four Soviet soldiers.

name: Nilsiän pyhän Johannes Kastajan kirkko
description:
The Church of St. John the Baptist in Nilsiä is an Orthodox church located in the Nilsiä district of Kuopio. Originally built as a chapel, its blueprints were designed by Toivo Paatela. The construction was funded by reconstruction funds and donations of timber. Veikko Toivanen and Santeri Burge, along with numerous volunteers, carried out the construction. Nikolai Karpin painted the icons for the chapel, which Archbishop Herman consecrated on October 31, 1954.

The chapel was renovated and converted into a church in 1990-1991, with the renovation designed and managed by engineer Leo Tuutti. Archbishop Johannes consecrated the building as a church on June 13, 1991. Tuulikki Likitalo painted the iconostasis and feast day icons. Marjatta Huuhtanen painted the feast icon of the Birth of St. John the Baptist, and Pirkko-Anneli Peltola painted the icon of St. John the Baptist. The church has a capacity of 120 people and a bell tower with seven bells.

name: Nivalan Kristuksen kirkastumisen kirkko
description: The Church of the Transfiguration of Christ in Nivala, also known as the Nivala Orthodox Church, is an Orthodox church building in Nivala. Originally built as a prayer house in 1961 and consecrated the following year, it underwent expansion in 2001 with architect Pekka Taskinen's designs, widening both sides. In 2005, an extension to the altar was completed, leading to the construction of a new iconostasis, which was finished in the summer of 2007. On August 6, 2007, Metropolitan Panteleimon of Oulu consecrated the prayer house as a church. The church is known to be beautiful and well-maintained, both inside and out.

name: Nummelan Jumalansynnyttäjän Neitseen Marian syntymän rukoushuone
description: The Nummelan Jumalansynnyttäjän Neitseen Marian syntymän rukoushuone, also known as the Nummela Orthodox Prayer House, is a prayer house of the Finnish Orthodox Church located in Nummela, Vihti. The association Vihdin-Nummelan Ortodoksit ry was founded in 1997 to build and maintain the prayer house. The prayer house is dedicated to the Nativity of the Theotokos, celebrated on September 8th. In 2023, the Vihdin Rotary Club visited the "Blue Church", where they saw new murals and learned about the activities of the Vihti-Nummela Tuesday Society over 30 years, followed by coffee. The prayer house celebrates its temple festival on September 8th.

name: Nurmeksen apostolien Pietarin ja Paavalin kirkko
description:
The Orthodox Church of Nurmes, more precisely the Church of the Holy Apostles Peter and Paul, is the main church of the Orthodox parish of Nurmes. It is located at Kirkkokatu 31, Nurmes.

Built in 1958-59 with reconstruction funds, the church was designed by architect Ilmari Ahonen. The church's impressive peak, reaching a height of 25 meters, easily stands out in the cityscape. Consecrated in 1959 by Auxiliary Bishop Paul, the church is dedicated to the memory of the Apostles Peter and Paul.

Inside, one can admire the silence and peace, and the icons, some of which may seem a little different. The original icons of the iconostasis, painted by Veikko Marttinen, represent an exceptional style of icon painting characteristic of the church's construction period. The church also houses large icons from the former main church of the Korpiselkä parish and icons painted by Kauko Rysä in the 1960s.

name: Outokummun Pyhän Hengen kirkko
description:
The Orthodox Church of the Holy Spirit in Outokumpu, also known as Outokummun Pyhän Hengen kirkko, is located in Partalanmäki. It is one of the three churches belonging to the Taipale Orthodox parish.

Initially, the church was built as a prayer house, or tsasouna. Uuno Korhonen, a builder, designed it, drawing inspiration from the old church in Kitelä village, Impilahti. Orthodox individuals who relocated to the Outokumpu area due to the war, including those from Impilahti, contributed significantly to the construction through voluntary work. Archbishop Herman consecrated the traditional Karelian-style tsasouna on June 7, 1954. In 1984, Bishop Tiihon of Joensuu consecrated the Holy Spirit dedicated tsasouna as a church. The church also features a parish hall in the basement with a capacity of approximately 50 people.

name: Pieksämäen Neitsyt Marian syntymän kirkko
description:
The Church of the Nativity of the Virgin Mary in Pieksämäki is an Orthodox church belonging to the Orthodox Parish of Mikkeli. It is located in Pieksämäki, and it was built in 1955. The church was originally designed as a prayer house by architect Toivo Paatela.

In 1985, the prayer house was thoroughly renovated, and an iconostasis was installed. The church is dedicated to the Nativity of the Virgin Mary. The church is open during services. The address of the church is Vanha Mikkelintie 18.

name: Pielaveden apostolien Pietarin ja Paavalin kirkko
description: The Orthodox Church of the Apostles Peter and Paul is located in Pielavesi. The church was completed in 1957 and its style resembles the churches that remained beyond the eastern border. It was modeled after the Church of St. John the Baptist Skete of the Valamo Monastery. The church's iconostasis frame comes from the former garrison church in Mikkeli. The church is subordinated to the Kuopio Orthodox Parish. The church's dedication feast is celebrated annually on June 29th. The church was renovated in the summer of 2008, and Archbishop Leo rededicated it on November 9, 2008.

name: Polvijärven Johannes Kastajan kirkko
description:
The Saint John the Baptist Church in Polvijärvi is an orthodox church located in the Polvijärvi village. It belongs to the Orthodox Church of Finland, specifically the Kuopio and Karelia diocese and the Taipale Orthodox parish. The church was built in 1914, after a previous church on the site burned down in 1909. Ivan Kanninen, who was from Sortavala, designed the church.

Funds for the church's construction came from local Orthodox residents, with a contribution from Tsar Nicholas II, the Grand Duke of Finland. Archbishop Sergei consecrated the church on July 26, 1914. The church combines Jugend and Pan-Slavic architectural styles, featuring a single large cupola and a bell tower. The temple feast or praasniekka, is celebrated on June 24th.

name: Porin apostoli Johannes Teologin kirkko
description:
The Orthodox Church of Pori, also known as the Church of the Holy Apostle and Evangelist John the Theologian, was completed in 2002. It is located in the Käppärä district of Pori. The brick-built church was designed by architect Matti Porkka and is dedicated to the memory of John the Theologian, or John the Evangelist.

The architecture features neo-Byzantine and neo-Russian influences. Inside, the iconostasis was painted by Margit Lintu from Tampere, while the other icons were created by Harri Stefanius from Pori. Liturgies are held twice a month, generally on the second and fourth Sundays.

name: Porvoon Kristuksen kirkastumisen kirkko
description:
The Church of the Transfiguration of Christ in Porvoo is an Orthodox church belonging to the Helsinki Orthodox Parish. It was built in the late 1980s and consecrated on August 5, 1989, by Metropolitan Tiihon of Helsinki. The church is dedicated to the Feast of the Transfiguration of Christ.

The church was designed by architect Juhani Sorsa. Bulgarian Jordan Ivanov created the decorative carvings for the iconostasis. Icon painter Ritva Westermark painted most of the icons in the church. The churchyard has a few parking spaces, and the church is accessible. There is a low stone step and threshold at the entrance. The church also has an induction loop and accessible restrooms.

name: Pyhän kolminaisuuden katedraali
description: The Holy Trinity Cathedral in Oulu is the main church of the Oulu Orthodox Parish and the cathedral of the Oulu Diocese. Designed by architect Mikko Huhtela, it was completed in 1957 and consecrated in 1958. In 1980, it became a cathedral when the Oulu Diocese was established. The church is located in the Hollihaka district, about one kilometer south of the city center. The icons in the iconostasis came mostly from the Ägläjärvi church in Korpiselkä, which was left in the ceded Karelia.

name: Pyhän Nikolaoksen katedraali
description:
The Pyhän Nikolaoksen katedraali, or St. Nicholas Cathedral, is the main church of the Orthodox Parish of Kuopio and the entire Diocese of Kuopio and Karelia. Located in Kuopio, Finland, it was built between 1902 and 1903 and consecrated in 1904 in memory of St. Nicholas. The church was designed by Aleksander Isakson from Vyborg.

The facade is plastered and painted to resemble red brick, but there is also genuine brick under the plaster. Its exterior resembles red-brick garrison churches of the same era. The iconostasis was made in St. Petersburg at the Alexander Nevsky Lavra and donated by Governor-General Bobrikov. The church has eight bells. It was renovated in 2003-2004 and re-consecrated in 2004.

name: Rauman pyhän Nikolaoksen tsasouna
description:
The Chapel of Saint Nicholas in Rauma is an Orthodox chapel located in the Old Rauma area. It is built into a house, with the oldest parts of the building dating back to the 17th century. The chapel occupies one wing of the house.

The chapel was constructed in 1955 and consecrated on November 2, 1956. It is dedicated to Saint Nicholas. The icons on the iconostasis and some other icons originate from the Turku military church. The chapel belongs to the Orthodox Parish of Turku. The chapel's 60th anniversary was celebrated in 2016, coinciding with the 65th anniversary of the Rauma Tuesday Society.

name: Rautalammin pyhän Nikolaoksen kirkko
description:
The St. Nicholas Church in Rautalampi is an Orthodox church located in the center of Rautalampi village. It belongs to the Orthodox parish of Rautalampi. The church was built in 1959 and consecrated on June 12, 1960, dedicated to St. Nicholas.

The church was designed by architect Ilmari Ahonen, and it is the only wooden church among the central-domed churches he designed. In the spring of 1960, the church received icons painted by Veikko Marttinen. In 1985, the icons of the iconostasis and the royal doors were renewed, with Margit Lintu painting the new icons. The church hall also features four old icons from the Orusjärvi church in Salmi. The church was renovated internally in 2003 and repainted externally in the summer of 2006, restoring its original white color.

name: Rovaniemen apostoli Andreaksen kirkko
description: The Rovaniemi Apostle Andreas Church is an Orthodox church located in Rovaniemi, belonging to the Orthodox Parish of Northern Finland. It was consecrated as a prayer room by Bishop Aleksanteri and consecrated as a church in 1962. The church is dedicated to Apostle Andreas. The church was designed by Toivo Paatela. It was renovated in 2016, when Metropolitan Elia re-consecrated it. The church is located at Ounasvaarantie 16.

name: Salon pyhän Ristin tšasouna
description: The Chapel of the Holy Cross in Salo is an Orthodox prayer house. It's a Karelian-style round log chapel, completed in 1989 and consecrated on September 9, 1990, in memory of the Holy Cross. Arvo Happo from Salo, a member of the Turku Orthodox parish, designed the prayer house and also made the wood carvings. Margit Lintu painted the icons. The prayer house is part of the Orthodox Parish of Turku. There was a risk of the chapel being affected by a railway project between Turku and Helsinki.

name: Savonlinnan Pikkukirkko
description: The Savonlinna Pikkukirkko, or Little Church, was built in 1846 by the Orthodox community of Savonlinna, designed by architect L. T. J. Visconti. It was consecrated to Saints Zachariah and Elizabeth. In 1938, the Lutheran congregation of Savonlinna purchased the church, using it as their main church during the 1940s after the cathedral was destroyed in the Winter War bombings. From 1973, it served as a joint church for the parishes of Savonlinna and Sääminki, until it was purchased by the Orthodox Savonlinna Pikkukirkko Cultural Association in 2017. After the association faced liquidation, the church was again for sale in 2021. The church also has a pipe organ that was built in 1985.

name: Sevettijärven pyhittäjä Trifon Petsamolaisen kirkko
description:
The Orthodox Church of Sevettijärvi, also known as the Church of Saint Trifon of Petsamo, is located in the village of Sevettijärvi, in the Inari municipality's Skolt Sami area. Dedicated to Saint Trifon of Petsamo, who lived in the 16th century, the church was originally built as a chapel in 1951. After renovations, it was consecrated as a church in 1992.

This simple wooden church exemplifies functionalist architecture. It serves as one of the four churches belonging to the Lapland Orthodox parish, with two others also located in Inari. A memorial dedicated to Skolt Sami who lost their lives for their country stands in the yard. An Orthodox cemetery is located near the church. The church also functions as a road church.

name: Siilinjärven suurmarttyyri Georgios Voittajan kirkko
description: The Great Martyr Georgios the Victorious Church, also known as the Siilinjärvi Orthodox Church, is located in Siilinjärvi. It was originally consecrated as an Orthodox prayer house (tsasouna) in May 1959. After renovations, it was re-consecrated as a church in April 1979. The church was designed by architect Ilmari Ahonen, and the iconostasis is by Petros Sasaki. The church belongs to the Orthodox Parish of Kuopio and is one of its sanctuaries. The church is located at Harjamäentie 2, 71800 Siilinjärvi.

name: Sonkajanrannan profeetta Hannan kirkko
description:
The Church of the Holy Prophet Hanna in Sonkajanranta is an Orthodox church located in the village of Sonkajanranta, in the Joensuu region. It is officially named the Church of the Holy Prophet Hanna and the Dormition of the Mother of God.

The church has a unique location in the Vaara-Karelia landscape, nestled between hills on the shore of a beautiful lake. It was designed by Gennadi, a monk from Valamo Monastery, and completed in 1915. The construction of the church was promoted by Johannes Karhapää, a religious teacher, and financed by merchant P.F. Nesterov.

Next to the church stands a reconciliation cross, designed in 1988 by icon painter Petros Sasaki, which tells the story of the place. In 2019, Johannes Karhapää was canonized as a martyr and confessor, and his memory day is celebrated annually on March 8th.

name: Sotkuman pyhän Elian tšasouna
description:
The Sotkuma Tsasouna, also known as the Chapel of the Holy Prophet Elijah, is an Orthodox shrine located in the village of Sotkuma, in the southern part of Polvijärvi. The prayer house was completed in 1914, partly from leftover logs from the construction of the Polvijärvi Orthodox Church, which was completed in the same year. Governor-General F. A. Seyn's donation also helped in the construction of the chapel. Auxiliary Bishop Serafim consecrated the chapel on September 19, 1916.

The chapel's temple festival, or Ilja's Praasniekka, is celebrated on July 20, which is the day of remembrance for the Prophet Elijah. Next to the prayer house is a cemetery with a rare memorial to the village's Orthodox war heroes, designed by U. Vilmann. It is one of the two Orthodox war memorials in Finland.

name: Suonenjoen Kristuksen kirkastumisen kirkko
description:
The Church of the Transfiguration of Christ in Suonenjoki is an Orthodox church belonging to the parish of Rautalampi. Originally built as a prayer house in 1957 based on the plans of architect Ilmari Ahonen, it was consecrated as a chapel by Bishop Paavali in 1958.

In 2007, after fifty years, the building was renovated and transformed into a church. Archbishop Leo consecrated it as a church on August 6, 2007. The church is located in Ritomäki, Suonenjoki. Next to the church is an Orthodox cemetery. The church hall can accommodate approximately 250-300 people.

name: Tampereen pyhän Aleksanteri Nevalaisen ja pyhän Nikolaoksen kirkko
description:
The Orthodox Church of Tampere, officially named the Church of Saint Alexander Nevsky and Saint Nicholas, is the main church of the Orthodox Parish of Tampere. It was built between 1896 and 1899 and designed by T.U. Yazukov. Situated in the heart of Tampere, east of Tammerkoski rapids, the church is considered one of Tampere's most historically significant buildings.

The cross-shaped church showcases Neo-Byzantine architecture, adorned with seven onion domes, the main dome reaching a height of 17 meters. The church's construction was funded by donations, with support from the Holy Synod of Russia and the state. The icons of the iconostasis were brought from St. Petersburg and painted in the romantic Western style prevalent in Russia during the 19th century.

name: Tornion apostolien Pietarin ja Paavalin kirkko
description:
The Church of the Apostles Peter and Paul in Tornio is an Orthodox church and one of the three churches belonging to the Orthodox Parish of Oulu. Originally built in 1884 as a garrison church for the local Russian military in the center of Tornio, it was designed in a cross shape with a central tower topped with an onion dome and a small bell tower above the vestibule.

The church suffered fire damage in 1911 and was abandoned the following year but was reopened in 1915. It served as a church until 1918 when the Finnish government confiscated it as war booty. In 1925, the State Council decided to use the building as a provincial museum. The building was moved to its current location near the Swedish border in 1956. From 1970 to 1980, it served as a Pentecostal prayer house. The church was restored in 1985 and has served as an Orthodox church again since 1987. The iconostasis was painted by Margit Lintu.

name: Turun pyhän marttyyrikeisarinna Aleksandran kirkko
description:
The Church of the Holy Martyr Empress Alexandra, also known as Turku Orthodox Church, is the main church of the Turku Orthodox Parish, located next to the Turku marketplace. It is one of the oldest Orthodox church buildings in Finland, consecrated in 1846.

Carl Ludvig Engel designed the church in the Neoclassical style. Emperor Nicholas I ordered its construction in 1838, and the church was built between 1839 and 1845. The church is dedicated to Empress Alexandra, the wife of Emperor Diocletian, likely because she was also the heavenly protector of Nicholas I's spouse, Alexandra Feodorovna. The icons in the iconostasis were painted by Berndt Abraham Godenhjelm, while other icons originated from Valamo Monastery.

name: Tuusniemen apostolien Pietarin ja Paavalin kirkko
description: The Orthodox Church of the Apostles Peter and Paul in Tuusniemi is located at Keskitie 54. The church was originally designed as a prayer house by architect Ilmari Ahonen and was consecrated as a church in February 1993 after renovations. The iconostasis was made in Poland, and the icons were painted by Margit Lintu. The church belongs to the Orthodox Church of Finland, Diocese of Kuopio and Karelia, and serves as a sanctuary in the Tuusniemi area of the Kuopio Orthodox Parish. Its temple feast is celebrated annually on June 29th.

name: Uspenskin katedraali
description: Uspenski Cathedral is a prominent red-brick Orthodox cathedral located on Katajanokka island in Helsinki. Completed in 1868, it stands as the largest Orthodox church in Northern and Western Europe. Its architecture features striking golden onion domes, making it a significant landmark. Dedicated to the Dormition of the Theotokos (the Virgin Mary), the cathedral serves as the main church of the Orthodox Church of Finland and a popular tourist attraction. The church is a clear symbol of Russian influence on Finnish history and culture.

name: Vaasan pyhän Nikolaoksen kirkko
description:
The Church of St. Nicholas in Vaasa is the main church of the Vaasa Orthodox Parish. It is located in Kasarmintori. The church was designed by the county architect Carl Axel Setterberg and was completed in 1862. Metropolitan Isidor consecrated the church in 1866.

Architecturally, the church is a centrally emphasized cross church with short arms. At the altar end, there is a lower apse, and opposite it, at the entrance end, a lower and narrower vestibule with a steeple. The facades are articulated by flat pilasters and numerous arched windows. The interior is plastered with a light mortar, and the cross arms have high barrel vaults rising directly from the floor level.

name: Valamon luostarin pyhittäjä Herman Alaskalaisen tšasouna
description: The chapel of St. Herman of Alaska is located in the Valamo Monastery cemetery. It was completed in 1981 and serves as a place for conducting funeral and memorial services. This wooden chapel, built in the Karelian style, is dedicated to Saint Herman of Alaska, a monk from Valamo who went to Alaska for missionary work in the late 18th century. He was canonized in 1970, and his feast day is celebrated on August 9th. In the chapel, there are icons depicting Saint Tikhon of Zadonsk, the Descent from the Cross, the Intercession of the Theotokos, the Resurrection of Christ, and Saint Herman of Alaska. It is a popular place for peaceful reflection during the summer.

name: Valamon luostarin Pyhän Johannes Edelläkävijän ja Kastajan syntymän tšasouna
description:
The Chapel of the Nativity of St. John the Baptist at Valamo Monastery, consecrated in June 2006, was designed by architect Sakari Siitonen. It was built through the initiative and donations of friends of the monastery and the Society of Friends of Valamo. Located near the monastery cemetery, it is close to the grave of Schema-Igumen John.

The chapel honors the memory of Schema-Igumen John, who lived for a long time in the Skete of St. John the Baptist at the original Valamo Monastery on Lake Ladoga. The icon of the Nativity of St. John the Forerunner was painted by architect Sakari Siitonen. The temple feast of the chapel is celebrated on June 24th.

name: Valamon luostarin pyhän Nikolaoksen tšasouna
description:
The Chapel of St. Nicholas the Wonderworker at Valamo Monastery, completed in 1987, is dedicated to St. Nicholas, known as the helper of seafarers and those in distress. Its feast day is celebrated on May 9th. In Western tradition, St. Nicholas, the 4th-century Archbishop of Myra in Lycia, is also known as the prototype of Santa Claus.

The log chapel, richly decorated with wood carvings, is largely a replica of a prayer house that stood in the village of Mantsinsaari in Salmi, Ladoga Karelia, before the wars. It was built there out of gratitude by islanders who were rescued from a storm on Lake Ladoga in the mid-19th century. Nikolai Jokiniemi built the chapel, and Maila Mäkinen painted the icons on its end wall, depicting Christ Pantocrator, the Valamo Mother of God, and St. Nicholas saving those in distress. The chapel also houses icons of the Transfiguration of Christ and Saints Sergius and Herman of Valamo, as well as two older icons gifted by residents of Salmi, Christ Pantocrator and St. Nicholas, adorned with rizas.

name: Valamon luostarin pääkirkko
description:
The main church of Valamo Monastery is dedicated to the Transfiguration of Christ. Designed by architect Ivan Kudryavtsev, it represents northern Russian stone church architecture. Consecrated in 1977, the church features a square main hall with a rounded apse behind the iconostasis. A slender, onion-shaped dome with windows illuminates the hall.

Reflecting traditional northern Russian monasteries, there's also a winter church dedicated to St. Sergius and Herman of Valaam. The iconostasis showcases both old and new icons from the 16th and 17th centuries. Beside the main church stands a bell tower housing fourteen bells. Most of the icons originate from the 18th and 19th centuries. Also located in the church is a large chandelier made of gilded bronze and a cabinet clock from the mid-1800s.

name: Valamon luostarin talvikirkko
description: The winter church of Valamo Monastery is located in the same building as the main church. It is dedicated to the founders of the monastery, Saints Sergius and Herman of Valamo. The church was built in the style of the 16th and 17th centuries. The annual feast of the church is on September 11th. The iconostasis features both old and new icons, some painted by students of Archimandrite Zinon. Above the iconostasis, the Deesis wall painting is a collaboration between Archimandrite Zinon and Archimandrite Arseny. Traditionally, northern Russian Orthodox monasteries have a separate winter church to allow for services in a smaller, easier-to-heat space during the colder months. Services are conducted there only during the quiet winter months.

name: Valtimon pyhän Kolminaisuuden kirkko
description:
The Valtimon Pyhän Kolminaisuuden kirkko (Holy Trinity Church) is an orthodox church located in Hiekkalahti, Valtimo, which is part of Nurmes in North Karelia. The church belongs to the Nurmes Orthodox parish. It was built in 1960, initially as a prayer house, and designed by architect Ilmari Ahonen.

The building was consecrated as a church in 2005. An orthodox cemetery is located in the vicinity of the church. Regular liturgies and other services are held in the church. The church was established to serve the needs of the numerous Orthodox Karelian evacuees and their descendants who settled in Valtimo.

name: Vantaan Kristuksen taivaaseen astumisen kirkko
description:
The Church of the Ascension of Christ in Vantaa, also known as the Tikkurila Orthodox Church, is located in the Viertola district of Tikkurila. It belongs to the Helsinki Orthodox Parish. The church was built between 1996 and 1997, and its design is by architect Arvo Sorsa.

The icons were created by Juri Mitroshin, and the iconostasis is made of cherry wood. The church can accommodate between 100 and 200 people. The church address is Läntinen Valkoisenlähteentie 48, 01300 Vantaa.

name: Vesannon Johannes Kastajan syntymän rukoushuone
description:
The Vesanto Orthodox Prayer House, also known as the Vesanto Chapel of the Birth of St. John the Baptist, is located in the village of Vesanto. It was completed in June 1960. The prayer house serves as a place of worship for the Vesanto area of the Orthodox Church of Kuopio and Karelia, Rautalampi Orthodox Parish.

The building was designed by architect Ilmari Ahonen. Services are held at the chapel approximately twice a month. The icons in the chapel came from the iconostasis of the Salmi Orusjärvi Church and were restored.

name: Viinijärven Jumalanäidin Tihvinän ikonin kirkko
description:
The Church of the Tihvin Icon of the Mother of God in Viinijärvi is the main church of the Taipale Orthodox parish. Completed in 1906, it was designed by J. O. Leander from Sortavala, featuring a Jugendstil-influenced cruciform design. The church was mainly built with donations from the Russian merchant Ivan Stretskov, and at his request, it was dedicated to the memory of the Tihvin Icon of the Mother of God. Archbishop Sergei consecrated the church on November 9, 1906.

The church's floor plan forms a Latin cross. The altar space in the east end has five sections. Above the church hall is a polygonal lantern tower and four smaller corner towers. The facade, articulated with rich moldings, is mainly in the Carpenter Jugend style. The bell tower houses seven bells, the oldest of which dates back to 1884. The iconostasis was made in St. Petersburg, with icons representing the historical-naturalistic style characteristic of the 19th century.

name: Viitasaaren Kristuksen kirkastumisen tsasouna
description:
The Viitasaari Christ Transfiguration Chapel is an Orthodox chapel located in Viitasaari, belonging to the Jyväskylä Orthodox Parish. It was completed in 1989 and is dedicated to the Transfiguration of Christ. The icons inside the chapel were painted by Jyrki Pouta and Raija Kanninen.

The chapel represents Byzantine-Karelian wooden architecture. Services are held there once a month. The chapel is open during services or by separate agreement. It is considered one of the most beautiful chapels in Finland. The chapel is located near the Evangelical Lutheran Church.

name: Äänekosken Jumalansynnyttäjän kuolonuneen nukkumisen tsasouna
description: Located near the heart of Äänekoski, sheltered by a small forest, stands the Äänekoski Dormition of the Mother of God Church. This Orthodox church, consecrated to the Dormition of the Theotokos, was built in 1992, replacing an earlier prayer house that was destroyed in a fire. The icons within the chapel were painted by Martha Neiglick-Platonoff. The church celebrates its feast day on August 15th. Regular services are held once a month and are a focal point for the local Orthodox community, including Ukrainian refugees who have found solace there.

name: Pyhän Nikolauksen kirkko
description: The Pyhän Nikolauksen kirkko, or St. Nicholas Church, is located in Helsinki's Hietaniemi area. Belonging to the Russian Orthodox Church, it serves the St. Nicholas Parish and is surrounded by a small cemetery. The church was completed in 1938, funded by donations from parishioners, on the site of the former Taivallahti military cemetery. After the wars, the parish grew, and the church was expanded in 1950, designed by architect Ivan Kudrjavzev. The church was constructed using materials from the Rauhankappeli chapel, which was dismantled in Katajanokka.

name: Kazanin Jumalanäidin ikonin kirkko
description: Based on the coordinates, this is likely the Church of the Kazan Icon of the Mother of God located in Säkylä, Finland. It's a relatively small, wooden Orthodox church. The church is dedicated to the Kazan Icon of the Mother of God, one of the most venerated icons in Russia. The parish belongs to the Finnish Orthodox Church. Services are held regularly, providing a place of worship and community for Orthodox Christians in the area. The church's architecture reflects traditional Orthodox design principles, creating a serene and spiritual atmosphere for visitors.

name: Pyhittäjä Serafim Sarovilaisen kirkko
description: The Church of St. Seraphim of Sarov in Stormi, Sastamala, is a Russian Orthodox church. The church construction was started as a house of prayer in 2005 and it was completed in 2007. The church is dedicated to St. Seraphim of Sarov. The church is located in the village of Stormi.

name: Ahlaisten kirkko
description: Ahlaisten kirkko is the oldest church in Pori, Finland. This wooden church was originally built in 1796 by Salomon Köykkä-Köhlström with two naves. Later, in 1832, a bell tower designed by Carl Ludvig Engel was erected separately from the church. In 1908, the church was expanded into a cross church based on designs by Josef Stenbäck, accommodating 720 people. In 1971, restoration work aimed to bring the church back to its original appearance. The altar painting depicts Jesus blessing children and was painted by Elin Danielson-Gambogi in 1888.

name: Aitolahden kirkko
description: Aitolahden kirkko, also known as Suojamuuri (meaning "protective wall"), is located in Tampere, in the former municipality of Aitolahti. The church was consecrated in September 2001. The church building utilizes brick, glass, and steel in its construction. A dominant feature of the newer section is the massive red brick wall, which gives the church its name. Inside, the altar was designed with a wooden, boat-like table resting on two granite pillars. The boat symbolizes the congregation, and the granite represents Finnish permanence and reliability. A glass sheet on the altar depicts a lake or sea, adorned with traditional Christian symbols and the Lord's Prayer. The silver crucifixes on the altar table and in the sacristy, as well as the two-meter-high bronze crucifix on the side altar, were designed by Kari Juva.

name: Aitolahden vanha kirkko
description:
Aitolahden vanha kirkko, or the Old Church of Aitolahti, is a stone church located in Tampere, specifically in Aitoniemi. It was built between 1927 and 1928 and designed by architect Birger Federley. The church resembles a medieval stone church and represents the historicism of the 1910s and 1920s.

Inside, the church is decorated with paintings by artist Kalle Löytänä. A stained glass window depicting the crucified Christ, designed by Fritz Hilbert, adorns the altar. The church also features a 19-stop pneumatic organ built by Kangasala organ factory. The churchyard has a memorial to those lost in Karelia and a war memorial designed by Y. Ekblom.

name: Akaan kirkko
description:
Akaan Church, also known as Toijala Church, is a wooden, Neo-Gothic style cross church located in Akaa, Finland. Designed by Carlo Bassi at the Intendent Office in 1814, it was constructed between 1816 and 1817. The church features a western tower and triangular gables on each arm of the cross. Inside, the intersection of the cross is covered by a faceted conical roof.

Renovations in the late 19th century added more ornate details and a new tower. Further repairs were carried out in 1908-1909, 1924, 1935 and 1967. The church has seating for 800 people. The altarpiece, "Christ's Transfiguration," was painted by Juho Forsell in 1881, and the ceiling paintings are by Kalle Carlstedt from 1935. The church's third organ, with 27 stops, was made by Kangasala organ factory in 1982, and the stained-glass windows in the choir were acquired in 1937.

name: Alahärmän kirkko
description:
Alahärmä Church is a gray granite church designed by Josef Stenbäck, combining Neo-Gothic and National Romantic styles. It stands in place of a wooden church built by Antti Hakola in 1752, which was destroyed by fire in 1898. The current church was constructed between 1901 and 1903, using local gray gneiss.

The first church in Alahärmä was built in 1676, a long church made of wood. It was replaced in 1752, but that church burned down in 1898 during roof tarring. Only a few items were saved from the fire. The current church was inaugurated on the first Advent Sunday in 1903. Alexandra Frosterus-Såltin painted the altarpiece, depicting Christ in Gethsemane. In 2015, Alahärmä Church was voted the most beautiful church in Finland in a poll by Radio Dei.

name: Alajärven kirkko
description:
Alajärvi Church, also known as the Church of Gabriel, is the main Lutheran church in Alajärvi. Designed by Carl Ludvig Engel, a prominent architect of the time, it was completed in 1836 and consecrated in 1841. The church showcases a neoclassical style and is constructed from timber, featuring a tarred wood shingle roof. A separate bell tower stands adjacent to the church.

Inside, the altarpiece, created in 1907 by Verner Thomé, an Alajärvi-born artist, depicts Jesus's agony in the Garden of Gethsemane. In 1896, the church underwent refurbishment, which included the addition of an internal balcony that increased the seating capacity. Currently, the church can accommodate around 1,000 people. The Finnish Heritage Agency has recognized the church, along with the city center's public and administrative buildings designed by Alvar Aalto, as a nationally significant built cultural environment.

name: Alapitkän kirkko
description: The Alapitkä Church is located in the village of Alapitkä in Lapinlahti. It's a wooden structure with a mineral-coated exterior, designed by architect Esko Laitinen and built in 1970. Laitinen also designed the stained glass "Tree of Life" on the altar wall. The church building is almost square, with a stepped altar end rising from one end. Inside, wooden ceiling beams rise towards the altar end. The windows are narrow and tall, located between the wall pillars. The church has 528 square meters of space and seating for 105 people. The bell tower connected to the altar end of the church has bells cast by the Juutila foundry in Kaavi. In 1986, architect Matti Höyhtyä designed an extension to the church, adding club, office, and social spaces, as well as a kitchen, to an additional building next to the church hall.

name: Alastaron kirkko
description: Alastaro Church is a wooden church located in Loimaa, Southwest Finland. Originally built in 1751 in Loimaa, it was moved to its current location in Alastaro in 1841. The church's tower, side wings, and sacristy were added during the relocation. The church received its present appearance in renovations made in 1896-97, overseen by architect Josef Stenbäck. Inside the church, there are balconies for the public. A memorial, sculpted by Wäinö Aaltonen, stands in front of the church. The church is a light-colored wooden structure with a dark tar roof.

name: Alatornion kirkko
description:
Alatornio Church is located in Tornio, and it dominates the landscape near the mouth of the Tornio River. The church was built in 1797, representing a neoclassical style. A wooden church may have existed on the site as early as 1208, but certainly by the early 1300s.

The medieval stone church, constructed around 1400-1500, has its eastern cross arm remaining opposite the main entrance of the current church. Jacob Rijf designed the central altar and the pulpit. The church has approximately 1200 seats. The Alatornio Church is also part of the Struve Geodetic Arc, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

name: Alavan kirkko
description:
Alava Church is located in Kuopio, Finland, and was completed in 1968. Designed by Swiss-born architect André Schütz, the church represents 1960s modernism. The building also includes a parish home, club rooms and function spaces.

The style of the church is quite stark, but the gray stone walls and altar-centeredness are said to evoke something of the timeless simplicity that prevailed in the early church. Opinions are divided on the massive appearance of the church, so much so that many consider it one of the ugliest buildings in the city. The exterior elements of the church were renovated in 2014–2015.

name: Alavetelin kirkko
description:
Alaveteli Church, located in the village of Alaveteli in Kruunupyy, is the first church designed by Matti Honka. This wooden cross-shaped church was constructed on a hill next to the Perhonjoki river between 1751 and 1754. It represents a typical Ostrobothnian chapel parish church environment from the mid-1700s.

The church features an octagonal cupola with a lantern, dating back to renovations in the late 1800s. The bell tower was initially built by Matti Honka in 1764-1767 but was reshaped during a renovation in the late 19th century. The baroque-classicist pulpit, made and painted by Johan Backman in 1752 and 1755, imitates ivory, marble, and ebony. The church also houses unusually large brass lamps from 1766 and a portrait of Anders Chydenius.

name: Alavieskan kirkko
description:
Alavieska Church is the church of the Alavieska parish, located in the central village of Alavieska. The current church, the fourth in order, was completed in 1948. The brick-built, traditional-style church was designed by the J. Karvonen construction office from Oulu.

The previous church was destroyed in a fire caused by lightning in 1916. Only the chandeliers and wall sconces were saved. The parish was only able to build a temporary "wooden church" with the insurance money, which ultimately served as a church for over 30 years.

Instead of an altarpiece, the Alavieska church has a wooden crucifix carved by self-taught artist Hugo Kähtävä in 1948. Kähtävä later made a sculpture called the Good Shepherd for the church. The 18-stop organ was built in 1948 by the Kangasala organ factory.

name: Alavuden kirkko
description: Alavuden kirkko is the fourth church in the area, completed in 1914 and designed by Kauno S. Kallio. The church is a white brick building. The altarpiece, painted by Oskari Paatela, depicts Jesus being taken down from the cross. The church has 35-stop organ from 1970, designed by Pentti Pelto and built by Hans Heinrich's organ workshop. Three chandeliers in the central aisle were rescued from a fire in the previous church, the oldest of which dates back to 1828. The church seats approximately 660 people and is accessible via a wheelchair ramp. The church is a popular roadside church, open to visitors during the summer months and the tower café is open weekends.

name: Aleksanterin kirkko
description:
Aleksanteri Church is located in the city center of Tampere, on the edge of Hämeenpuisto park. It is named after Emperor Alexander II. The church is surrounded by Pyynikki Church Park, which used to be a cemetery.

The church represents primarily Neo-Gothic architecture, with influences from various styles. It was designed by Finnish architect Theodor Decker. Construction finished in 1881 and more than a million bricks from local factories were used. The church's exterior features large round and arched windows and protruding pillars, mainly for decoration. The 58-meter-high tower dominates the church's design.

name: Angelniemen kirkko
description:
The Angelniemi Church was built in 1772 on a beautiful cape in the northern part of Kimito Island. The church is located on a high rock by the sea. It is a long church, and in addition to the nave, it has a sacristy and an armory that are lower and opposite each other.

The church was thoroughly repaired in 1843, when the roof was renewed, the floor was raised, and stairs were built to the pulpit. A new repair was carried out in 1935 according to the plans of architects T. Sora and G.H. Wahlroos. The altarpiece is an oil painting by Alexandra Såltin from 1897, depicting the Transfiguration of Christ. The crucifix above the painting dates back to the 14th century.

name: Anjalan kirkko
description:
Anjala Church is a wooden church located in Kouvola, in the former church village of Anjala. It was built in 1755-1756, replacing an earlier dilapidated church from 1693. The church is a cross-shaped church, and all its walls taper inwards.

The church suffered considerable damage during a Russian attack in 1790, when its bell tower was completely destroyed. Afterwards, the interior was renovated in a neoclassical style. The new altarpiece, "Jesus in Gethsemane," was painted in 1796 by court painter Carl Gustaf Ecksten from Stockholm. The new bell tower, the third in its history, was completed in 1796 and houses the church's two bells. The church was initially known as the Sofia Church, after the Swedish Princess Sofia Albertina.

name: Anttolan kirkko
description:
Anttolan kirkko, originally built in Juva in 1729, is a wooden cross church that was moved to Anttola in 1870. It provides seating for 650 people. The church has undergone several renovations throughout its history, including the addition of a bell tower in 1884 and changes to its roof in 1891.

In 1926, Alvar Aalto designed renovations that included mirrored panels on the interior walls, a redesigned altar, and a crucifix replacing the original altarpiece. Further renovations were carried out in the 1960s and again in 1994, bringing the church to its current appearance. The pulpit and the crucifix on the altar wall originate from the old church of Juva, dating back to the 1660s.

name: Artjärven kirkko
description: Artjärvi Church is located in Artjärvi, Orimattila. It is a wooden, cross-shaped church with a gable tower, completed in 1840. The church, designed by architect Anders Fredrik Granstedt, represents the Empire style. The church can accommodate approximately 600 people. It is the fourth church building in Artjärvi, with the first one built in 1636. The altar painting "Christ in Gethsemane" was created by Matilda Wulffert and donated in 1848. The church also features a pulpit from 1872 made by a local farmer. The church has a onion dome and wooden barrel vaults inside. The old cemetery is located on the other side of the road.

name: Asikkalan kirkko
description: The Asikkala Church, often called "The Church of Million Bricks," was completed in 1880. Designed by architect Georg Wilenius, its bricks were made nearby, requiring a million to complete the structure. The church's architectural style is primarily Romanesque, featuring Gothic details. Inside, the church can seat approximately 1,100 people, with an interior height of 16 meters. The cross on the church tower reaches a height of 54 meters. The church has two organs, one built in 1902 with 32 stops. In 1983, stained glass windows depicting symbols of the Triune God were installed in the choir. The church is a popular venue for weddings and serves as a roadside church during the summer.

name: Askaisten kirkko
description:
Askaisten kirkko is a stone church building that represents the era of Swedish great power in the 17th century. It is located in Askainen, in the present-day Masku municipality in Southwest Finland. Beside the church stands a separate bell tower, which dates back to 1779.

The exact age of the church is unknown, but it was built to replace a wooden church that stood on the same site. Its current appearance dates back to the renovation commissioned by Governor-General Herman Klaunpoika Fleming in 1653. Fleming was the owner of Louhisaari Manor, and the church was built as a chapel for the manor. The churchyard also contains the Mannerheim family chapel, as Louhisaari Manor was for a long time owned by the Mannerheim family.

name: Askolan kirkko
description:
Askola Church is a wooden cross-shaped church located in Askola, Uusimaa. It was built in 1799 by Mats Åkergren and has around 700 seats. The church's bell tower, also built by Åkergren, was completed in 1800. Originally, the exterior walls were bare logs, painted red in 1802. Later, in 1832, the church was clad with boarding, also painted red.

Towards the end of the century, the interior walls and ceiling were painted and paneled, and the exterior walls were painted white. In 1892, the church acquired an 11-stop organ from the Kangasala organ factory, and in 1898, it got its first heating system. Significant restoration work was carried out in 1939. In 2023, the church went through a renovation project to update its technology and make functional changes.

name: Auran kirkko
description:
Auran kirkko is a wooden cross-shaped church located in the municipality of Aura, Southwest Finland. The church was completed in 1804 under the direction of church builder Mikael Piimänen and is the third church built on the same site. The bell tower next to the church dates back to 1774.

The church has been renovated several times, including in 1958 and most recently in 2023, when accessibility was improved. Inside, the church features an altarpiece painted by Arthur Heickell in 1927, depicting Jesus with his disciples on the Mount of Transfiguration. Below the altarpiece is a wooden relief of the Last Supper, presumably made by Mathias Reiman in 1683. The church's hero statue was designed by sculptor Jussi Vikainen in 1956.

name: Aurejärven kirkko
description:
Aurejärvi Church, located in Ylöjärvi, was built in 1924 as a prayer room for the residents of Kuru parish who lived far from the main church. The church construction was funded by the Kuru parish, following a proposal by provost A. M. Numminen. Designed by Oiva Kallio, the construction was managed by J. V. Teikari.

The church is a rectangular long church without a tower. Unusually, the sacristy, which is lower than the main room, is located on the long side of the main room. Both ends of the main room have small additions. The interior features cloverleaf vaulting. In the churchyard, there is an octagonal bell tower covered with shingles. The church has seating for approximately 400 people. The altarpiece, painted by Ilmari Heinonen in 1958, depicts Jesus blessing children.

name: Bergön kirkko
description: Bergö Church is a wooden long church with a west tower, built in Bergö, Malax between 1800 and 1802. Initially, it was built as a prayer room but was converted into a church in 1835. The building was heightened, extended, and broadened with side buildings during renovations in 1852–1853.
