The side buildings with gable roofs are lower than the main building; the sacristy and foyer also branch off from the main building. The tower has a tent roof that ends in a spire, and the bells date from 1813 and 1883. The altarpiece, depicting Jesus and the Samaritan woman, was painted by Teodor Schalin in 1919. The churchyard is surrounded by a stone wall.

name: Björköbyn kirkko
description: Björköbyn kirkko, or Björkö Church, is located in Björköby, Mustasaari. The church was built in 1859 and is named after Maria, the spouse of Emperor Alexander II. A gallery was constructed in the church in 1907, and an organ was installed a few years later. Before the village had its own church, services were held in a reading room. The church has a votive ship and a traditional chandelier. The church is used by the Finnish congregation of Mustasaari, hosting events and services as needed. It is a popular wedding church in the summer.

name: Bromarvin kirkko
description:
The Bromarv Church is located in Bromarv, Raasepori. The current church was designed by Carl-Johan Slotte and André Schütz's architectural firm. It was consecrated on August 23, 1981, by Bishop John Vikström. This building replaced the old church which burned down in 1979.

The church is a replica of the old church. It is an equilateral cruciform church, with the center roof ridge higher than the side arms. The side arms contain the sacristy, entrance halls, and other spaces. The main room serves as the church hall. The church's organ was built by Kangasala organ factory, has 19 stops, and dates back to 1981. There is also a Steinway grand piano from 1956. The altarpiece was made by textile artist Kaarina Heikinheimo.

name: Brändön kirkko
description:
Brändö Church is located in Brändö, in the Åland Islands. Dedicated to Saint James, the wooden church was originally built in the late 1740s but was moved and rebuilt in its current location in 1893, according to the plans by David Lönnroth. The church has a long church shape with a gable tower.

The altarpiece, painted by Alexandra Frosterus-Såltin in 1881, depicts the Ascension of Christ. The church also has a late medieval altarpiece dating back to the 15th century. The nine-voice organ was built in 1912 by the Zachariassen organ factory from Uusikaupunki and renovated by Veikko Virtanen in 1966.

name: Degerbyn kirkko
description:
Degerby Church is located in the village of Degerby, in Ingå, Uusimaa. It was built between 1931 and 1932 and designed by Bertel Liljequist. The church is a long church in shape, with an Empire-style tower.

Interestingly, the church's entrance is in the east and the altar in the west, which is unusual for churches. After World War II, the church was part of the Porkkala area, which was leased to the Soviet Union until 1956. The church was rededicated in 1958 after the area was returned to Finland. During the lease period, the golden cross on the church tower was lost, but a new one was added in 2018. The church acquired a 9-tone mechanical Walker pipe organ in 1965.

name: Dragsfjärdin kirkko
description:
Dragsfjärd Church is located in Dragsfjärd in Kemiönsaari. The wooden church was built between 1753 and 1755 by Anders Piimänen and was named Adolf's Church after the then-reigning King Adolf Frederick. The bell tower was completed in 1763.

The cross-shaped church's altar painting was donated in 1690, and the pulpit dates back to 1753. The yellow church was previously painted with red ochre. The church's organ from 1977 has 16 voices and was made by Kangasala Organ Factory.

Before the current church, there was a chapel, but the year it was built is unknown. The chapel was in poor condition and was demolished. A new one was completed in 1695, but it soon became too small, so the current church was built.

name: Eckerön kirkko
description:
Eckerö Church, also known as S:t Lars, is a medieval graystone church located in Eckerö, Åland. Recent dating suggests it was built between 1380 and 1420. The church was known as the Church of St. Lawrence from the Catholic era.

The church is very bright due to its unusually high and wide windows on the north and south sides. Inside, there is a medieval Gotlandic Madonna sculpture, a small crucifix, and some preserved limestone paintings. The rectangular nave, oriented east-west, features a sacristy on its northern side and an armory on the southern side. At the western end of the nave stands a sturdy bell tower, as wide as the nave itself. The older of the tower's bells dates back to the 13th century. The church has seating for 275 people.

name: Elimäen kirkko
description:
The Elimäki Church is a wooden church in Kouvola, specifically in the former municipality of Elimäki. It is considered one of the oldest wooden cross churches still operating in Finland. The church was originally built in a rectangular shape in 1638, but it was expanded into a cross-shaped church in 1678.

The interior of the church is exceptionally valuable, with furnishings dating back to the 1630s. The altarpiece was donated by Casper Wrede and his wife, Sophia Taube, in 1632. The bell tower was constructed between 1795 and 1797. The churchyard contains graves of estate owners, priests and cantors, a war veterans' burial ground with a statue designed by Aimo Tukiainen, and a memorial grove established in 2014.

name: Enon kirkko
description:
Enon Church, located in Eno, Joensuu, is a wooden double-cruciform church built between 1816 and 1818. It's the fourth church to serve the former municipality of Eno. The church's design is attributed to Anton Wilhelm Arppe, and it exhibits Neoclassical influences. The church can accommodate around 1000 people.

The pulpit is the oldest and most valuable part of the church, dating back to 1757. The altarpiece, depicting Jesus on the cross, was painted in 1930 by local artist Eino J. Härkönen. A separate bell tower, constructed in 1957, stands on the church grounds.

name: Enonkosken kirkko
description:
The Enonkoski Church, located in the center of Enonkoski village, was designed by architect Magnus Schjerfbeck and completed in 1886. It is a wooden church that belongs to the Savonlinna parish. The church was built to replace an older church from 1860 that burned down in 1884.

Stylistically, it is a so-called truncated cruciform church. The church's 21-stop organ was acquired in 1989 and manufactured by the M. Porthan organ building company. The exterior of the church was renovated in 2000. The altar painting depicts Christ's ascension into heaven and was painted by Albert Moliis in 1900. The church can accommodate approximately 600 people.

name: Enontekiön kirkko
description:
The Enontekiö Church is located in the village of Hetta. The church was inaugurated in 1952 and designed by architect Veikko Larkas. It is a plastered brick building with a separate, slender bell tower about 30 meters high. The bell tower is connected to the church building by a canopy.

The previous church was destroyed in Lapland War in 1944, and the current church was built to replace it, largely funded by donations from American Lutheran churches. Inside the church, the altar wall features a large fresco by Uuno Eskola, depicting Christ ascending to heaven and blessing the people of Lapland. The church is a venue for the annual Hetta Music Days.

name: Espoon tuomiokirkko
description:
Espoo Cathedral, located in Espoo's center, is a medieval parish church and cathedral. It serves as the seat for the Evangelical Lutheran Diocese of Espoo, established in 2004. The oldest sections of this stone church were completed in the 1480s, making it Espoo's oldest preserved building.

Originally a three-nave straight church built between 1485 and 1490, it was transformed into a cross church in the 1820s due to the growing congregation. Monk paintings from the 1510s adorn the church's vault. The altar and altar rail were moved to the center of the church in the 1980s, and a new organ was installed in 2012. The church has 540 seats and hosts services every Sunday.

name: Espoonlahden kirkko
description:
Espoonlahti Church, completed in 1980 and expanded in 1997, is located in the Espoonlahti district of Espoo. The church was designed by architects Timo and Tuomo Suomalainen. The copper roof rises high above the surrounding residential buildings, making it a significant landmark.

The church's design emphasizes a connection with nature, blending the built environment with the surrounding natural rocky pine forests. The walls of the church hall are partially made of red granite quarried from the site. The church has 410 seats, but when combined with the parish hall, it can accommodate 580 visitors. The church also features an organ, installed in 1982-1983, designed in collaboration with the architects and Urkurakentamo Veikko Virtanen.

name: Euran kirkko
description:
Eura Church, designed by Josef Stenbäck, was completed in 1898. It is the third church in the parish, replacing two previous wooden churches. The lower part of the church is made of granite, while the gables and the upper part of the tower are made of brick.

The church is a typical example of the revival styles. Inside, there are 700 seats for worshippers. The altarpiece, painted in 1899 by Alexandra Frosterus-Såltin, depicts the Resurrection of Jesus. The church also has a medieval crucifix. The current organ, with 21 stops, was built in 1938. The church tower has three bells, dating from 1681, 1694 and 1897. Eura Church and its surroundings are part of Finland's nationally significant built cultural environments.

name: Eurajoen kirkko
description:
Eurajoki Church, also known as Kustaa Aadolf Church, is located in the church village of Eurajoki, in the middle of the Eurajoki cemetery. The wooden church, built according to the drawings of the Swedish Office of the Superintendent, was completed in 1803. It is a cruciform church with a tower and accommodates about 650 people. The altar painting is by an unknown artist and depicts the triune God. The 30-stop, 3-manual organ was manufactured by Kangasala organ factory in 1970. The facade of the organ is from the Zachariassen organ from 1892. The oldest of the three bells in the bell tower dates back to 1690.

The church is currently closed for renovations, which began in February 2024 and are expected to last until December 2024. During the renovation, services are held at the Tapuli Parish Center.

name: Evijärven kirkko
description: Evijärvi Church is a wooden cross church built between 1758 and 1759. It was designed and constructed by Antti Hakola from Härmä. The church is characterized by its steep roof and a tall, slender tower in the center. It was officially inaugurated on July 26, 1761. About a century later, the bell tower and the church itself were renovated to their current form. A significant sculpture inside the church is the altarpiece crucifix, "Vapahtaja" (Savior), created by Erkki Lahti from Evijärvi. There is also a space reserved for children and youth in the back of the church.

name: Fagervikin kirkko
description:
Fagervik Church is a red-painted wooden church located in the ironworks village of Fagervik in Inkoo. It is one of the few privately owned churches in Finland. The church was completed in 1737, while the bell tower and burial chapel were added in 1766. The church boasts the oldest functioning church organ in Finland, built in Stockholm in 1726.

Throughout its history, the church has received many valuable donations from past generations, including chandeliers and silverware. The church has also hosted distinguished guests, such as King Gustav III of Sweden and Emperor Alexander I of Russia. Today, guided tours are available, and the church can be rented for private events like weddings or baptisms.

name: Finlaysonin kirkko
description:
The Finlayson Church is a neo-Gothic church located in the Finlayson factory area in Tampere. It was built in 1879 by the factory director Wilhelm von Nottbeck as a place of worship for the factory workers.

Due to its central location, small size, and charming architecture, the church is one of the most popular wedding churches in Tampere. It is also a popular concert church because of its good acoustics. The factory handed over the church to the Tampere Evangelical Lutheran parishes in 1981. One condition of the handover was that the church would continue to be called the Finlayson Church. Today, it also serves as a children's cathedral.

name: Finströmin kirkko
description:
Finström Church, or St. Michael's Church, is a medieval church located in Finström on Åland. It is one of the largest churches in Åland, with some parts dating back to the 12th century. The current stone church was largely built in the 15th century.

Inside, the church features impressive stone vaulting, supported by arches and pillars. The murals, created in the 1450s by four different masters, are exceptionally well-preserved. The pulpit dates back to 1703. A glass painting by Lennart Segerstråle, "The Atonement of Sins," serves as the altarpiece. The church also houses several medieval wooden sculptures, including one of St. Michael from around 1180, considered Finland's oldest scientifically dated wooden sculpture.

name: Forssan kirkko
description:
Forssa Church is located in the center of the city, in the Kalliomäki district. It was built between 1914 and 1917, and designed by architect Josef Stenbäck. The red-brick church represents the Neo-Gothic style with national romantic features.

One special feature is the location of the altar in the west end of the church, making the entrance on the east side. Inside the church, the altar is adorned with glass paintings by Eric O.W. Ehrström and his wife, depicting the birth, crucifixion, and resurrection of Jesus. The church tower rises to 45 meters. There are three bells in the tower, donated by K. E. Palmen.

name: Föglön kirkko
description:
Föglö Church, dedicated to St. Maria Magdalena, is a medieval stone church located in Föglö, Åland. Its construction likely began in the 1320s and was expanded in the 15th century. Unlike other Åland churches, it's built with grey granite instead of red.

In the mid-19th century, the church was transformed into a cruciform church. Inside, a medieval golden crucifix, discovered during renovations, is a highlight. The church also features older altarpieces and two bells in the bell tower, one from the 16th century and the other from 1706. The church is surrounded by a sturdy stone wall.

name: Getan kirkko
description:
Geta Church, dedicated to Saint George, is located in Geta on Åland. It is a medieval stone church, likely constructed in the mid to late 15th century. Some research suggests the 1450s.

Notably, the church lacks a tower but has a separate wooden bell tower dating back to the 17th century. The interior features a wooden barrel vault ceiling from the 1800s. The altarpiece, donated in 1685, is divided into four sections depicting the Last Supper, the Ascension, the Adoration of the Shepherds, and the Flagellation of Christ. The churchyard is surrounded by a stone wall.

name: Haapajärven kirkko
description: Haapajärvi Church is located in the center of Haapajärvi. This wooden cross church was built in 1802, designed by architect J. Fr. Engeström, based on Matti Pietilä's plans. The church has undergone renovations, most notably in 1880 by architect Frans Wilhelm Lüchow, when the tower section rising from the center of the cross was built. The church's bell tower was constructed in 1813. The altarpiece, depicting the Transfiguration of Christ, was painted by Adolf von Becker in 1886. The church can accommodate approximately 700 people. The mechanical organ was inaugurated in 2002.

name: Haapajärven kirkko
description:
Haapajärvi Church in Kirkkonummi, Finland, is a wooden cross-shaped church. It was completed in 1823 and is known for its unique atmosphere, making it a popular choice for weddings and baptisms.

During the Porkkala lease period (1944-1956), when Kirkkonummi Church was within the leased area, Haapajärvi Church served as the main church for the parish. The churchyard has limited parking space.

Inside, the sturdy log walls and art pieces donated by villagers bring history close. The church can seat 250 people. Services are held during the summer months and from the first Advent to Epiphany, as well as during Easter.

name: Haapamäen kirkko
description:
Haapamäki Church is located in Haapamäki, Keuruu. Completed in 1953, it was one of the first multipurpose churches in Finland. The church is a long, steep-roofed, brick building designed by architect Mikael Nordenswan. The exterior is plastered and adorned with slate stones. A separate, high bell tower stands next to the main entrance.

Inside, the altar area is lower than the rest of the church hall. The altar wall features a simple cross. In connection with the church hall, there is a parish hall and club rooms. The parish hall was expanded in the 1990s. The church represents typical 1950s church architecture, influenced by classicism, functionalism, and Italian Renaissance architecture.

name: Haapasaaren kirkko
description:
Haapasaari Church is a wooden church located in the outer archipelago of Kotka, on the island of Haapasaari. It was built between 1858 and 1859 according to the plans of the Intendentinkonttori. Jeremias Laavu served as the master builder. The church is situated on a site where a prayer room had previously stood. It belongs to the Kotka-Kymi parish and is only used during the summer.

The church is a long church with a gable tower, with the tower located above the entrance. The church hall has a single nave and is covered by a wooden vault. It has approximately 250 seats. The altarpiece "Jesus and Child" was painted by Frans Lehtinen. There is also a wooden crucifix, likely from the old prayer room. The church's belfry has two bells, the smaller of which was obtained in 1870 from the Jenny, a sailing ship that wrecked near Haapasaari.

name: Haapaveden kirkko
description:
Haapaveden kirkko is located in the center of Haapavesi. The current church was built near the site of the old church, which burned down in 1981. The building functions as a parish center, housing the church hall, parish office, and smaller group spaces. It was consecrated in Advent 1984.

The church hall has 500 seats, with additional space available by incorporating the adjacent parish hall using a movable wall. Architecturally, the church hall is a wide basilica divided by columns into two naves. Natural light enters through diverse upper windows, creating a play of light and shadows. Near the church, by the cemetery, stands the bell tower that survived the fire of the old church.

name: Haappusten kirkko
description: Haapusten kirkko is located in Rauma. Route number 4 goes through the church in Päiväsenkatu - Moisionkatu - Nortamonkatu - Töyryntie - Nummenkatu - Eteläkatu - Savilankatu - Kuninkaankatu - Nortamonkatu. It's a stop in Rauma local transport.

name: Hailuodon kirkko
description:
The Hailuoto Church, also known as the new church of Hailuoto, is located in the Kirkonkylä village. Designed by Irma and Matti Aaltonen, it was built in 1972 to replace the old wooden church from 1620, which was destroyed by a fire in 1968. The church is constructed of reinforced concrete and can accommodate around 160 people.

Its unique design incorporates concrete elements, soft pews, and a large altar window that provides a view of the surrounding nature, flooding the space with natural light. Items salvaged from the old church are displayed, including apostle and saint statues, and a restored 18th-century pulpit. A forest cemetery is located near the church.

name: Hakavuoren kirkko
description:
Hakavuori Church, located in Pohjois-Haaga, Helsinki, was completed in 1963. Architect Eevi Aho designed the church and its adjacent facilities. The church's architecture and furnishings repeat the symbolism of Christ's five wounds, represented by a five-sided design.

The bell tower reaches a height of about thirty meters and contains three bells, each inscribed with the words "Pohjois-Haaga Church." The bells also feature additional inscriptions, with the smallest reading "Faith comes from hearing," the middle one "Hearing the word of God," and the largest "Follow me," beneath which is a depiction of the crucifixion.

Inside the church, you'll find Harry Kivijärvi's bronze sculpture "Crucified" from 1959 on the altar and Toivo Jaatinen's bronze relief "The Sermon on the Mount" on the altar wall. In the community hall, separated from the church hall by a folding wall, is Pekka Kontio's brick relief "Empty Grave" from 1969.

name: Hakunilan kirkko
description:
Hakunilan kirkko is a church located in Hakunila, Vantaa. Originally designed as a parish center in 1975-1976 by architect Pauli Halonen, it became a church in 1994 after expansion and renovation work, also led by Halonen. The building has a reinforced concrete frame and is made of lime-cement brick. Its floor plan is almost circular.

The church is closely connected to the Hakunila shopping center. The church hall has movable furniture, including the altar. The church's total area is 1,321 square meters and it has seating for 280 people. The church has a variety of activities throughout the year, including services, confirmations, and youth evenings.

name: Halikon kirkko
description:
Halikko Church is a partially medieval stone church located in Salo, specifically in the center of Halikko, on top of Kirkkorinne (Church Hill). It is a landmark visible from afar. Tradition says that the church was built around 1440.

The medieval gray stone church has been expanded with lower cross arms and a three-part choir. Its current appearance is the result of expansions started at the end of the 1700s. Inside, on the south wall of the church hall, is an entrance to the Armfelt family's burial chapel, built by Gustaf Mauritz Armfelt. The church tower, representing the southwest Finnish onion dome style, was built in 1773.

name: Halkivahan kirkko
description:
Halkivaha Church is a red-brick church located in Urjala, Finland. It was designed by architect Josef Stenbäck and completed in 1902. The church represents the Gothic Revival style, characterized by its pointed arches and tall spire.

Inside, the church features a traditional basilica layout with a nave and two side aisles. The altar painting, "Jesus blesses children," is by Alexandra Frosterus-Såltin. The organ was built by Kangasala Organ Factory in 1970. Halkivaha Church is an important landmark in Urjala and hosts regular services and events. The surrounding area includes a cemetery and open fields.

name: Halsuan kirkko
description:
Halsua Church is a wooden cross-shaped church located in Halsua, Finland, near Lake Halsua. It was built between 1825 and 1826. Jaakko Kuorikoski constructed it based on the plans of his father, Heikki. The church is situated on the Kauppinen ridge in the middle of the village.

In addition to the church, the surrounding area includes a loan granary, a cemetery, and the church road running along the ridge. The church was renovated in 1968–1969 and again in 2001. Services are generally held every Sunday at 10 am. The church can also be reserved for baptisms, weddings, and funerals.

name: Hammarlandin kirkko
description:
Hammarland Church, also known as St. Catherine's Church, is a medieval grey stone church located in Hammarland, Åland. It stands along the old Post Road, near the area's largest prehistoric burial ground.

The nave of the church was constructed in the 13th century, while the vaults date back to the 14th century. Unusually, the tower is built on the south side of the church. The interior is adorned with painted vine ornamentation and brick imitation paintings on the ceiling and walls. The altarpiece was originally purchased for Eckerö Church in 1734. In 1837, the vault leading from the nave to the chancel was enlarged and medieval limewash paintings were covered.

name: Hangon kirkko
description:
The Church of Hanko is located on Vartiovuori hill. It was originally built with red bricks and completed in 1892, designed by architect Jac. Ahrenberg. Inside, behind the altar, is a copy of Bertel Thorvaldsen's statue of Christ.

During the war, the church was badly damaged. In 1953, it was thoroughly renovated according to the plans of architect Bertel Liljeqvist. The exterior was simplified and plastered gray. In 1971, an annex was built for a sacristy, including a small chapel for weddings and baptisms. In 1973, the church's interior was renovated.

name: Hankasalmen kirkko
description:
Hankasalmi Church is the third church in Hankasalmi and was designed by Josef Stenbäck, completed in 1892. It is one of the largest wooden churches in Finland, representing the Neo-Gothic style. The church has a gable tower and low transverse arms on the long sides of the nave.

Inside, the church features a wooden vaulted ceiling. The furnishings are partly from the 19th century. The previous altarpiece by G.F. Blom, painted in 1847, has been moved to the local museum. The church has two organs: the older main organ, representing the Romantic style, and the newer organ, inspired by the bright-sounding Baroque organs of the 18th century. North of the church is the oldest cemetery of the parish, surrounded by a stone wall.

name: Harjavallan kirkko
description:
Harjavalta has two notable churches. The newer church, "Kaikkien autuuksien kirkko" (Church of All Beatitudes), was consecrated in 1984 and designed by architect Pekka Pitkänen. It seats 500 people and is known for its octagonal shape, reflecting the eight beatitudes from Jesus' Sermon on the Mount. A stone from the Mount of Beatitudes in Israel is embedded in the church's foundation. Inside, behind the altar, is a crucifix dating back to the 15th century.

The old church in Harjavalta is a wooden church that was renovated into its current Carpenter style in 1870. The renovation plan was created by G.T. Chiewitz, the provincial architect of the Turku and Pori region. Due to fire safety concerns, the old church is only open upon request. The old church features an altarpiece painted in 1878 by Alexandra Såltin, depicting Christ and the Canaanite woman. The old church is no longer in active use.

name: Harjavallan vanha kirkko
description: Harjavallan vanha kirkko, or the old church of Harjavalta, is a wooden church that was renovated in 1870 to reflect a Carpenter style architecture. The renovation plans were made by G.T. Chiewitz, who was an architect for the province of Turku and Pori at the time. Due to fire safety concerns, the church is only open upon request. Inside, you can find an altarpiece painted in 1878 by Alexandra Såltin, titled "Christ and the Canaanite Woman". The church is not actively used for regular services; instead, it is sometimes used for weddings and concerts in the summer. The structure has been renovated so that it will be preserved for future generations.

name: Hartolan kirkko
description:
Hartola Church is a granite church built between 1911 and 1913. It was designed by the architect Josef Stenbäck, who also oversaw its construction. The church represents National Romanticism but also incorporates elements of Art Nouveau and Gothic Revival styles. Bishop O.I. Colliander consecrated the church on December 16, 1913.

The interior of the church, including the stained-glass window "For You," the lighting fixtures, and the pulpit, were also designed by Stenbäck. The church was renovated in the 1960s by architect Esko Järventaus and again in 2013 by architect Virpi Tervonen. Originally, the church organ was located in the tower section but was moved to the rear gallery in 1932. A chandelier that was already in the old church was moved above the altar.

name: Hattulan Pyhän Ristin kirkko
description:
The Church of the Holy Cross in Hattula is a medieval church dating back to the late 15th century. It is known as the oldest church in the Häme region. Unusually, the church is constructed almost entirely of red brick, a rare material for Finnish medieval buildings, setting it apart from the typical grey stone structures.

Inside, the church is adorned with extensive and well-preserved lime paint frescoes from the early 16th century, depicting biblical scenes and stories. The smaller pulpit is the oldest in Finland, dating back to 1550. The church was a popular pilgrimage site during the Middle Ages. Today, it serves as a Lutheran church.

name: Hattulan uusi kirkko
description:
The new church of Hattula, completed in 1857, is a brick church designed by architect E.B. Lohrmann. It's one of the first neo-Gothic brick churches in Finland. The church has a rectangular shape with a tower in the front and an octagonal upper section.

Inside, the church seats 800 people. The altarpiece, painted by R.W. Ekman in 1864, is a triptych depicting Jesus in Gethsemane, Jesus on the cross and the resurrected Jesus. The church also has three bells, moved from the old Hattula church in 1857.

name: Hauhon kirkko
description:
Hauho Church, dedicated to St. John the Baptist, is a medieval gray stone church likely built in the early 16th century. It is located in Hauho, Hämeenlinna. The church features a rectangular body with a brick sacristy constructed in 1784, replacing an older medieval one. The interior is divided into three naves with star and cross vaults.

Inside, you'll find medieval wooden sculptures and the altarpiece "Jesus in Gethsemane" painted in 1883. Notably, it houses one of Finland's oldest "vaivaisukko" (poor boy) statues, Bartimeus, dating back to the 1700s. A separate bell tower, built in 1864, stands near the church. The churchyard is surrounded by a stone wall dating back to 1794.

name: Haukiputaan kirkko
description:
Haukipudas Church, also known as Ulrika's Church, is a wooden church located in Haukipudas, completed in 1762. Designed by Matti Honka, it's renowned for its vibrant interior paintings by Mikael Toppelius, created between 1774 and 1779. These murals depict biblical scenes with influences from baroque, rococo, and even Chinese art.

The church is a cruciform structure with beveled outer corners and straight inner corners. The bell tower was constructed in 1751. Inside, the altar and pulpit, crafted by Jaakko Suonperä, are notable features. The "Last Judgment" painting, covering an entire wall, is considered one of Finland's most significant baroque compositions.

name: Haukivuoren kirkko
description:
Haukivuori Church stands near Lake Kyyvesi. The first house of prayer was built in 1740, followed by a wooden church. A separate bell tower was erected next to the church in 1838-1839. Unfortunately, the wooden church was destroyed in a fire in 1949.

The current plastered tile church, designed by Veikko Larkas, was completed in 1951, influenced by functionalism and medieval churches. Lutheran churches in America provided financial support for its construction. The altarpiece, painted by Veikko Vionoja, depicts the resurrected Christ consoling John the Apostle on the island of Patmos.

name: Hausjärven kirkko
description:
Hausjärvi Church is the main church of the Hausjärvi parish, located in the village of Hausjärvi. It was built in 1789 by Martti Tolpo. The church is situated near the crossroads of old roads from Helsinki, Hämeenlinna, and Porvoo.

The church is a long church with a tower at the end. It has lower and narrower side additions on both sides. The altar end is outwardly beveled, and behind the altar is a sacristy in its own corner. The church hall has seating for approximately 600 people. The altarpiece is "The Resurrection of Jesus" by Robert Wilhelm Ekman. The church was renovated in the early 2010s, including the installation of geothermal heating, exterior and interior painting and improvements to accessibility.

name: Hautajärven kirkko
description:
Hautajärvi Church is located in Hautajärvi, Salla. This border region church was built in 1963 to continue the traditions of the Paanajärvi border region church in Kuusamo, which was destroyed in the Winter War. The church belongs to the parish of Salla.

The church is located in a beautiful spot on a hill in the village of Hautajärvi. It is known as a rare asymmetrical church. The cross is located in the high belfry next to the church.

name: Heinolan kirkko
description: Heinolan Church, located on Kirkkotie 1, was completed in 1755. It is likely that master builder August Sorsa was involved in building the church. The wooden cross-shaped church represents the Eastern Finnish church style. The floor plan is an equal-armed cross, the arms of which narrow outwards. The church has undergone several significant repairs and alterations, the largest of which was carried out in 1933 under the direction of architect Kauno S. Kallio. At that time, the interior was renovated and the exterior appearance was changed to its current form. The church can accommodate 800-900 people. The shingle roof of the church is a rare model in Finland. One of the special features of the church is the cantor's chair, opposite the pulpit. From there, the cantor led the congregation's singing before the organ. The ceiling paintings on the inside are by Hannes Malin from Heinola. They were made in the 18th century style. The current altarpiece, which depicts Jesus carrying his cross, was donated to the congregation in 1860.

name: Heinolan pitäjänkirkko
description:
Heinolan pitäjänkirkko, completed in 1755, is the older of the two churches in Heinola. It's located in the former Heinola rural municipality, next to the old cemetery. The wooden church has a cross-like floor plan, typical of Eastern Finnish churches. It is believed that August Sorsa was the builder.

The church's unique shingle roof was constructed in 1820, replacing an earlier wooden roof. Significant renovations were carried out in 1933 under architect Kauno S. Kallio, updating both the interior and exterior. One notable feature is the cantor's desk, which was used to lead singing before the church had an organ. The altarpiece, depicting Jesus carrying the cross, was acquired in 1860.

name: Heinäveden kirkko
description:
The Heinävesi Church is a wooden, Neo-Gothic church built in 1890-1891, designed by Josef Stenbäck. It is located in the village of Heinävesi in North Karelia. The church stands on a hill, offering views of Lake Kermajärvi.

The church can accommodate around 2,000 people, making it the second-largest wooden church in Finland. The architectural style features Neo-Gothic forms applied to traditional Finnish wood construction. The churchyard also houses a local history museum and a handicraft center. During the summer, the church hosts music events and art exhibitions.

name: Helsingin Diakonissalaitoksen kirkko
description:
The Helsinki Deaconess Institute Church is located in the Kallio district of Helsinki. It was built in 1897 and consecrated in May 1898. The church building is owned by the Helsinki Deaconess Institute.

Designed in the Neo-Gothic style by architect Karl August Wrede, the red-brick church provides seating for 120 people. The church's historic pneumatic organ, dating back to 1902, is situated above the altar. The silver crucifix on the altar wall is an Italian work and a gift from Aurora Karamzin, the founder of the Deaconess Institute. The church is available for rent for family events and is open on weekdays throughout the year, except in July. A thorough renovation, completed in 2004, aimed to restore the church hall to its original appearance.

name: Helsingin tuomiokirkko
description:
Helsinki Cathedral, originally St. Nicholas Church, is the Finnish Evangelical Lutheran cathedral of the Diocese of Helsinki. Located in the Kruununhaka neighborhood at Senate Square, it's a major landmark and one of Finland's most famous historical structures.

Designed by Carl Ludvig Engel, the neoclassical building features a tall green dome surrounded by four smaller domes. The church was built from 1830 to 1852 as a tribute to the Grand Duke of Finland, Emperor Nicholas I of Russia. Over 500,000 people visit the church annually, making it one of Helsinki's most popular tourist attractions.

name: Henrikinkirkko
description:
Henrikinkirkko is a church in Turku designed with a modern, multi-functional approach, essential for contemporary parish activities. Its design emphasizes accessibility and welcomes everyone. The spacious lobby provides direct access to various facilities, including the parish hall, church hall, meeting and activity rooms, kitchen, offices, and the basement.

The church features a mechanical organ built in 1981, containing two manuals and 25 stops. The church hall can accommodate 450 people and has smaller rooms available. It also has parking areas and is accessible by public transportation.

name: Herttoniemen kirkko
description:
Herttoniemi Church is located in Länsi-Herttoniemi, Helsinki. The red-brick church was completed in 1958. The church has a separate bell tower with three Austrian bells. The church hall is dominated by a white altar wall with a wooden crucifix sculpted by Gunnar Uotila. The church textiles were designed by Dora Jung and the silverware by Bertel Gardberg. The church organ dates back to 1962 and has 25 stops.

The church was closed at the end of May 2019 due to serious indoor air problems. In June 2024, a farewell service was held in front of the church. The congregation plans to demolish the church and return the plot to the City of Helsinki, which plans to build a kindergarten on it.

name: Hervannan kirkko
description: Hervannan kirkko, completed in 1979, is located next to the Hervanta shopping center. Designed by Raili and Reima Pietilä, it is part of a larger complex that includes a leisure center. The red-brick church building is currently undergoing renovations, expected to be completed by the end of 2025. The renovations include re-bricking the exterior due to microbe damage, with custom-made bricks to match the original curved facades. The interior is also being updated, but with care to preserve its cultural and historical significance. Inside, the main entrances to the church hall are located on either side of the altar, and the ceiling features a metal grid that distributes light, primarily from skylights. Smaller rooms, such as those used for confirmation classes and youth work, surround the hall on two floors and can be connected to the main hall if needed.

name: Hietaman kirkko
description: Hietaman Church, completed in 1997, is located in the village of Hietama in Äänekoski. It was designed by architect Timo Suomalainen, who also designed the Temppeliaukio Church in Helsinki. The church hall is about ten meters high, accommodating around 150 people. The altar wall features windows offering views of the surrounding village landscape. Services are held there usually once a month. Adjacent to the church is a cemetery, which is about three years older. The church is made of stone, wood and glass and is surrounded by a park-like cemetery.

name: Hiittisten kirkko
description:
Hiittinen Church, located in Kimitoön, is a wooden cross-shaped church. It stands as the second oldest cross church in Finland.

The church features a massive tower at the intersection of the cross, topped with a tented roof that ends in a spire. The arms of the cross have low hipped roofs, and a small sacristy is located next to the chancel. Entrance halls were added to the southern and western arms during renovations in 1746.

Josef Svensson Brun built the church between 1685 and 1686, and it was named after Andreas Prytz. The bell tower dates back to 1752. The altarpiece is "Christ on the Cross" painted by A.F. Ahlstedt in 1866. The church also has stained glass windows made by Ilmari Launis and G. Forsström in 1923 and 1936.

name: Himangan kirkko
description:
Himangan kirkko, located in Himanka, Kalajoki, is a traditional wooden cruciform church. Designed by Jacob Rijf and completed in 1794, its current appearance dates back to an 1897 restoration. This alteration included heightening the central tower and modifying the windows. The altarpiece, depicting Jesus on the cross, was painted by Johan Gustav Hedman in 1845.

The yellow-painted church seats 500 people. A detached belfry, erected in 1823, stands beside the church, housing two bells cast in 1794 and 1860. The churchyard also contains a war memorial with 103 stones. A parish hall is situated near the church. The church was renovated in 2010-2011, with attention to preserving its original architectural style.

name: Hinnerjoen kirkko
description: Hinnerjoki Church is a wooden church located in Eura, in the village of Hinnerjoki. The church was completed in 1755. In 1799, it was moved to its current location, away from a nearby rapid, and expanded into a cross-shaped church. At that time, a tower was also built. The church can accommodate approximately 400 people. The church's altar features a stained glass window by Ilmari Launis depicting Christ on the Cross. The church has three bells dating back to 1627, 1739 and 1825.

name: Hirvensalon kirkko
description: The old Hirvensalo Church was located in Moikoinen on the island of Hirvensalo, Turku. It was part of a parish center designed by architect Pekka Pitkänen and completed in 1962. The church space had an organ built in 1978. Due to moisture problems, the Hirvensalo parish center was demolished. A new building with church halls was completed in February 2025 and is now in use. The new parish center is larger and updated for today's needs. The design emphasized accessibility.

name: Hoilolan kirkko
description: Hoilolan Church is located in the eastern part of Joensuu, near the Russian border. This Lutheran church was designed by architect Veikko Larkas. The church was built to replace the Korpiselkä Lutheran Church, which was left in the ceded territory. The main funding for construction came from Lutheran churches in America. The church's furnishings mainly originate from churches and parishes in the ceded territories, including items from the Koivisto, Räisälä and Impilahti parishes. The church has approximately 100 seats, and services are held there about once a month. The parish hall can also be used for family celebrations and has tableware for approximately 50 people.

name: Hollolan kirkko
description:
Hollola Church is a medieval gray stone church, and it was the ancient center of Päijät-Häme. Dedicated to St. Mary in the Middle Ages, the church was completed between 1495 and 1510. It is one of the most remarkable monuments of medieval architecture in Finland and the third largest medieval parish church in the country.

The church is famous for its well-preserved wooden sculptures depicting New Testament figures and saints. There are 24 preserved sculptures. The church is surrounded by a garden-like cemetery. Annually, the church is visited by thousands of tourists from various countries.

name: Honkajoen kirkko
description:
The Honkajoki Church, formerly known as Hongonjoki Church, is a wooden cross-shaped church completed in 1812. It is located in Kankaanpää, in the former municipality of Honkajoki. The church features a tower with three sections.

The architecture represents a folk-style wooden construction with classical influences. Inside, the church has a 16-stop, two-manual organ built by Hans Heinrich in 1981. The church also has two bells dating from 1818 and 1841. The yellow-painted wooden church is situated in the center of Honkajoki, surrounded by an old stone fence and a cemetery. The altar painting was painted by J.G. Hedman.

name: Honkilahden kirkko
description:
Honkilahti Church, also known as St. Michael's Church, is a wooden church located in Honkilahti, Eura. It was built in 1759 by Thomas Ravonius. The church represents a typical 18th-century long church design found in southwestern Finland, but without a tower. Later modifications, including the addition of galleries, have given it an almost cruciform appearance.

Adjacent to the church is a separate belfry, constructed in 1771, also by Thomas Ravonius. The belfry houses two bells cast in Stockholm in 1777 and 1781. Inside the church, the altar features a glass painting by Gunnar Forsström from 1934, depicting Jesus in Gethsemane. The church organ, with ten stops, was manufactured by Kangasala organ factory in 1934.

name: Houtskarin kirkko
description:
Houtskari Church is located in the Turku archipelago. This wooden church, painted in red ochre, is a cruciform church. It was built between 1703 and 1704. Erik Nilsson from Ostrobothnia was responsible for its construction. The church is dedicated to the Virgin Mary.

The altar painting, dating from 1887, is painted by Victor Westerholm and depicts Christ in Gethsemane. The lower part of the bell tower near the churchyard was built in 1753, and the upper part in 1871. The rectory, built in 1860, is also part of the church environment. The Houtskari local history museum is located in the old village hall built in 1885.

name: Huhtamon kirkko
description:
Huhtamon Church is located in Huittinen. Designed by Ilmari Launis, it was completed in 1928 and consecrated on January 20, 1929. The altarpiece, depicting Jesus in Gethsemane, was painted by Leo Frang-Pahlama. Services are held approximately every three weeks, along with other church services and concerts. The Christmas morning service is traditionally held at five in the morning.

Adjacent to the church is a cemetery where about 650 people have been buried over the years. Among them are 26 fallen heroes from Huhtamo. A memorial statue commemorates their sacrifices. The church was built with donations from the villagers. A renovation project for the church is underway since 2025, with a condition survey of the facade structures already done in 2015.

name: Huittisten kirkko
description:
Huittisten kirkko, also known as St. Catherine's Church, is a medieval stone church in the center of Huittinen. The oldest part of the church dates back to the late Middle Ages, with other parts constructed in the 18th and 19th centuries. It is located on Karsatinmäki hill, between the Loimijoki and Punkalaitumenjoki rivers.

The oldest section was completed around 1500, and expansions occurred in 1794 and 1860, giving the church its current cross-shaped layout. The northern and southern expansion sections form the main space of the church hall, while the medieval eastern section functions as a chapel. The Huittinen cemetery is located mostly to the west and north of the church. The church and its surroundings are classified as nationally significant built cultural environments by the Finnish Heritage Agency.

name: Humppilan kirkko
description:
Humppila Church was completed in 1922 and designed by architect Josef Daniel Stenbäck. It was constructed from gray granite on the same site as a wooden church that burned down on New Year's Day in 1917.

Inside the church, the vaults are made of concrete and plastered with lime mortar. The altarpiece, painted by Aleksandra Såltin in 1899, depicts Jesus in Gethsemane and was rescued from the fire that destroyed the previous wooden church. The church has 600 seats, with 350 on the main floor and 250 in the gallery. Stained glass windows painted by Josef Stenbäck decorate the sides of the altar and the ends of the church. The church's organ was built in 1969 and has 14 stops.

name: Huopalahden kirkko
description:
Huopalahti Church is a small, red wooden church situated in the heart of Etelä-Haaga in Helsinki. It stands in the middle of a beautiful park. The building was originally constructed for another purpose but was converted for religious services in 1917 and officially consecrated as a church in 1942.

Initially, it served as a meeting place for Finnish speakers and even housed the first Finnish-language elementary school in Haaga from 1908 to 1928. The church has a single nave and a triple-vaulted ceiling. The altar features a sculpture by Harry Kivijärvi called "The Crucified" (1959). Today, Huopalahti Church is the only church of the Haaga parish.

name: Huutoniemen kirkko
description:
Huutoniemi Church, located in Vaasa, is a concrete long church designed by Professor Aarno Ruusuvuori, who won the design competition in 1961. The church was built primarily using concrete and lightweight aggregate blocks, and it was officially inaugurated on May 10, 1964.

The building complex includes several parish facilities. The church has an asymmetrical base, with the pews in a longitudinal direction and the altar on the long side of the building. Light enters the altar and church hall through windows at the highest gable end. The interior features grey-brown brick cladding, and the shape of the sloping exterior roof is repeated inside. The church has a separate bell tower with three bells made in West Germany.

name: Hyrynsalmen kirkko
description:
Hyrynsalmi Church is the central church of the Hyrynsalmi parish, located in the Hyrynsalmi village. Completed in 1786, it is one of the most significant wooden churches from the late 1700s in Finland and one of the best-preserved works by the church builder Jacob Rijf. It represents the Gustavian classicism style.

The church is a cross-shaped building with a relatively low roof, pilastered walls, and arched windows. The interior has a light appearance, dating back to the 1860s. The altarpiece, depicting the Savior on the Cross, was painted by Johan Gustaf Hedman from Oulu. The bell tower was constructed in 1840. During the Winter War, the church served as a collection point for fallen soldiers from the Battle of Suomussalmi.

name: Hyvinkään kirkko
description:
Hyvinkää Church, consecrated in 1961, is a modern church designed by Professor Aarno Ruusuvuori. It is the main church of the Hyvinkää parish and one of Hyvinkää's best-known landmarks. The church is centrally located on Hämeenkatu, the city's main street.

The church is easily recognizable from afar due to its pyramidal shape. In honor of the Holy Trinity, many of the building's forms are triangles. The lighting in the church hall is designed to focus attention on the altar. The altar features a window that offers a view of the churchyard.

The church has undergone renovations, including improvements to the roof and acoustics in the 1980s. The church also has a separate bell tower. The interior decoration was designed by interior architect Antti Nurmesniemi. The church is currently closed for organ renovation until May 31, 2025.

name: Hyvinkään vanha kirkko
description:
Hyvinkää Old Church, originally built as a prayer room in 1895-1896, is located in Hyvinkää. The red wooden church was designed by Yrjö Sadenius.
The need for a prayer room arose when Ossian Donner established a wool factory in the village.
The building served as the prayer room for the Finnish Lutheran Evangelical Association (SLEY).
In 1923, the church was expanded with a side aisle and a new bell tower.
When the new Hyvinkää church was completed in 1961, this church became known as the Old Church.
It was officially consecrated as a church in 1978. The church is a popular wedding venue and the pulpit is unusually located on the left side of the altar.

name: Hyvän Paimenen kirkko
description: The Church of the Good Shepherd is located in Pakila, Helsinki, near the intersection of the Kehä I ring road and Tuusulanväylä highway. Originally built in 1950 and known as Pakila Church, it underwent extensive renovation and expansion in 2002. Architect Juha Leiviskä designed the renovation, seamlessly blending the old and new architecture. The name, Church of the Good Shepherd, comes from a relief in the old church hall, now a parish hall. A key element of the new church hall is light, evident in the lighting and vertical windows. The church also has a children's chapel and features art by Markku Pääkkönen, Taisto Martiskainen, Agneta Hobin, and Juri Saarikoski. Its seven bells play melodies that vary with the church year.

name: Hämeenkosken kirkko
description:
Hämeenkosken kirkko, formerly known as Kosken Hl kirkko until 1994, is a church located in Hämeenkoski, Hollola. Completed in 1870, it's the fourth church in the area. The brick church incorporates a bell tower designed by Carl Ludvig Engel, dating back to 1824 from a previous church.

The church's architecture represents late Empire style and has a rectangular shape. Inside, the church hall features three naves. The altarpiece was painted by Alexandra Såltin in 1891. The entrances are defined by three robust round-arched doorways.

name: Hämeenkylän kirkko
description:
Hämeenkylä Church, located in Vantaa, Finland, was completed in 1992 and designed by architect Olli-Pekka Jokela. It was built around an older, smaller church that was constructed in 1966.

The church is known for its art, particularly the works of painter Martti Aiha and sculptor Silja Rantanen, which depict the events of Easter and reference the "14 stations of the Cross." These artworks guide the viewer from Jesus' condemnation to his burial and resurrection. Katri Haahti designed the church textiles.

Near the church is an urn cemetery designed by landscape architect Gretel Hemgård, featuring urn burial plots, a memorial grove, a scattering area, and a vault.

name: Hämeenkyrön kirkko
description:
Hämeenkyrö Church is a beautiful, cross-shaped wooden church dating back to 1782. It is the main church of the Hämeenkyrö parish, located in Pappila. The church was designed by the Stockholm Superintendent's Office in the early 1780s, and its construction was overseen by Abraham Tennberg. While originally representing neoclassical architecture, later renovations, especially in the 1880s, significantly altered its appearance, including changes to the tower.

Inside, the church has wooden vaults as its ceiling and electric heating. It offers seating for approximately 900 people. The current organ, built in 1942, has 38+3 stops and three manuals. The altarpiece, painted in 1849 by J. Z. Blackstadius, is titled "Jesus in Gethsemane". Note that as of early 2025, the church is undergoing renovations scheduled to be completed by December 15, 2025, and is closed to the public during this time.

name: Hämeenkyrön vanhan hautausmaan kappeli
description: Located in the center of the old cemetery, the chapel was completed in 1895. The chapel's exterior was painted in the summer of 2017, and the interior was renovated, and completed in the summer of 2020. During the interior renovation, a stained-glass window on the eastern wall was revealed, a vestibule was removed, and all surfaces were refurbished. The chapel and the old cemetery are the burial grounds of writer F.E. Sillanpää and Olympic winner Paavo Yrjölä.

name: Hämeenlinnan kirkko
description:
Hämeenlinna Church is the main church of the Hämeenlinna-Vanaja parish. Located in the heart of Hämeenlinna, next to the market square, the white plastered brick church was completed in 1798. It seats approximately 800 people, with an additional 25 seats in the chapel located in the church tower.

The church is one of the most significant examples of Gustavian classicism in Finland. The drawings were made by the painter Louis Jean Desprez, who served King Gustav III of Sweden-Finland. The Roman Pantheon served as a model for the church. The church regularly hosts services, baptisms, confirmations, weddings, and concerts.

name: Härmälän kirkko
description:
Härmälä Church is located in Härmälä, Tampere. Initially, parsonage and parish hall buildings were constructed on the site. The church hall was completed in August 1972, connected to these buildings. A pillar-structured bell tower, standing next to the church, dates back to 1949.

The church's design was based on a winning proposal from an architectural competition by Elma and Erik Lindroos in 1939. The altar cross is a metal embossing work by Ipi and Pekka Pyhältö. When the church hall was completed, a set of church textiles in four colors was also acquired.

name: Hätilän kirkko
description:
Hätilän kirkko, also known as Hätilän seurakuntatalo (parish hall), is a church located in the Hätilä district of Hämeenlinna. Designed by architect Mika Erno, it was completed in 1956. The church features a replica of Leonardo da Vinci's "The Last Supper," donated to the parish in 1859, adorning the altar in the main hall, which is on the second floor.

Besides the church hall, the building also houses other meeting spaces. A 12-stop mechanical organ, built in 1971, is also located in the church. The church was temporarily closed in autumn 2014 due to moisture damage requiring repairs, but it was reopened after renovations.

name: Iin kirkko
description:
Iin kirkko is the church of the Ii Evangelical Lutheran parish, the third oldest parish in Northern Ostrobothnia, founded around 1340. The current church, located in Ii Hamina, was built between 1949 and 1950 and consecrated on June 18, 1950. It is a stone-built long church with low walls, resembling the shape of the previous church, and features a separate bell tower.

Designed by architects Gustav Strandberg and Aarne Hytönen, the church has seating for approximately 500 people. The altarpiece was painted by artist Eero Nelimarkka. The church also has a unique touch: a votive ship hanging from the ceiling, a typical feature in coastal parish churches.

name: Iitin kirkko
description:
The Iitti Church is a wooden church completed in 1693, located in the municipality of Iitti in Northern Kymenlaakso. The church is situated in the Iitti church village. The cruciform church's design was influenced by St. Catherine's Church in Stockholm. The flat vaulted domes are modeled after the Hollola stone church, while the roof has a distinctive high double-pitched style characteristic of Hollola.

It is one of the fifteen wooden churches in Finland that have survived from the 17th century. A thorough renovation was carried out in 1913-14 under the direction of architect Josef Stenbäck, during which Italian stained glass windows were added to the altar wall. The old Iitti cemetery is located near the church, with burials dating back to at least 1515.

name: Iisalmen Kustaa Aadolfin kirkko
description:
The Kustaa Aadolf Church in Iisalmi, also known as the old church of Iisalmi, is the oldest church building still standing in Northern Savonia, having been completed in 1779. The wooden cross-shaped church was designed by Simon Jylkkä-Silvén, and its construction was permitted by a special decree from King Gustav III.

Inside, the church can accommodate around 1200 people. The current altar painting was created by Alexandra Såltin in 1886. The church also features historically valuable 18-stop organs built in 1883 by the Zachariassen organ factory. The bell tower predates the church itself, possibly dating back to the early 18th century. The church is a popular tourist destination and is considered a nationally significant built cultural environment by the Finnish Heritage Agency.

name: Iisalmen Pyhän Ristin kirkko
description:
The Holy Cross Church in Iisalmi, also known as Iisalmi New Church, is located in the city center and is a landmark. Designed by architect Eino Pitkänen, it was consecrated in 1934. This church represents a transition from classicism to functionalism, evident in its bright wall surfaces.

The church is a basilica with a tower at the end, constructed from brick and concrete. Inside, the altarpiece is a mosaic created by artist Uuno Eskola, depicting Jesus crucified. The round pulpit features reliefs of the evangelists by Yrjö Rosvall. The church underwent renovations in 1992, led by architect Hannu Puurunen.

name: Ikaalisten kirkko
description:
The Ikaalinen Church, also known as Fredrika Sophia Church, is likely the third church in the area. The current wooden church was built in 1801, based on drawings from 1788 by architect Thure G. Wennberg. It is a cross-shaped church that seats approximately 1,100 people.

Initially painted red in 1816, it was later changed to yellow twenty years later. The church underwent significant renovations in 1859-1860, including the construction of a new bell tower and a large rectangular lantern structure on the roof. The altarpiece is Berndt Godenhjelm's "Christ's Transfiguration" from 1874. The bell tower, designed by G. Th. Chiewitz, was completed in 1861.

name: Ilmajoen kirkko
description:
Ilmajoki Church is located in Southern Ostrobothnia. It is the third church in Ilmajoki, constructed in 1766 by Matti Honka. This wooden cross-shaped church can accommodate around 900 people. A unique feature of the church is the placement of the altar at the corner of the eastern and southern crosses, providing an even view from all four directions. The belfry was completed in 1804.

The church's interior has been renovated several times. High-quality sculptures of evangelists and angels from 1766, made by the Stockholm sculptor J. Klerck, are attached to the railing. The pulpit opposite the altar dates back to 1765. The current appearance of the interior, including paintings by the decorative artist Urho Lehtinen, is from the 1930s.

name: Ilomantsin kirkko
description: The Ilomantsi Church is a Lutheran church built in 1796. It's the fifth Lutheran church in the area. The interior is richly decorated with colorful paintings by Samuel Elmgren, including over one hundred angels, giving it the nickname "Church of a Hundred Angels". The church has around 800 seats. The bell tower next to the church was built in 1803. The church is considered a rare exception in the typically simple Lutheran world, reflecting the ideals of a new era with its symbolic imagery.

name: Imatran Kolmen Ristin kirkko
description:
The Church of the Three Crosses in Imatra, also known as Vuoksenniska Church, is designed by Alvar Aalto. Completed in 1958, it is a significant example of modern Finnish church architecture and ranks among Aalto's most esteemed works.

The church features a main hall that can be divided into three distinct spaces using movable walls, each with its own entrance. When fully open, the hall accommodates approximately 800 people. The acoustics and lighting are enhanced by the asymmetrical floor plan. Instead of an altarpiece, three white wooden crosses adorn the altar area, with the placement of the crosses and windows carefully planned to cast shadows on the wall during services. The church has 103 windows, with only two being identical. A slender, 34-meter-tall bell tower, resembling a shot arrow, completes the structure. Currently (Spring 2025), the church is closed for renovations.

name: Imatrankosken kirkko
description:
Imatrankoski Church is a church in the Imatrankoski district of Imatra, located by the Vuoksi River. It was completed in 1954 and consecrated on October 31 of the same year. The church was designed by architect Aleksis Lindqvist. Yrjö Vaskinen designed the altar, pulpit, and pews.

The church houses items from the former Jääski Church, including the altarpiece, an oil painting "Come to Me" by Arvid Liljelund from 1888, and communion vessels. The bell tower, slightly detached from the main building, houses the old bell from the Jääski Church. The church has been out of use since 2020 due to indoor air quality issues. The desacralization of the church took place on February 16, 2025, and the church items and altarpiece will be moved to Tainionkoski Church.

name: Iniön kirkko
description:
Iniö Church is located in the beautiful landscapes of the Iniö island in the Turku archipelago. The church was built between 1797 and 1800 from stone and brick.

It was inaugurated in 1801 and named after the newborn Swedish princess Sophia Wilhelmina. In 1880, a fire badly damaged the church, but it was repaired within a year. The interior was renewed in neo-Gothic style. The pulpit was designed by C.J. von Heideken, and the altarpiece is a painting by W. Munsterhjelm from 1907. Today, the church has 120 seats and is part of the Väståbolands svenska församling.

name: Inkeroisten kirkko
description:
The Inkeroinen Church, also known as Tehtaanmäki Church, is a stone church built in Kouvola in the early 1900s, in the former village of Inkeroinen. It was commissioned in 1910 by the owners of the Inkeroinen cardboard factory for the factory workers and local residents.

Designed by architect Birger Federley, the church represents Jugend architecture and is a so-called long church in shape. The altar wall features colorful stained-glass windows designed by Veikko Vionoja, and a bronze crucifix by Viljo Savikurki. Services, baptisms, weddings, blessings, and concerts are regularly held at the Inkeroinen Church.

name: Inkoon kirkko
description: The Inkoo Church is a medieval gray stone church dedicated to Saint Nicholas, the patron saint of seafarers. The oldest parts of the church date back to the 13th century. Inside, there is a crucifix from the 14th century and murals from the late 15th century. A rare painting, "Dance of Death" from the 16th century, depicts the progression of the Black Death. The church has a 21-stop organ built by Åkerman & Lund in 1989. The church has 350 seats.

name: Irjanteen kirkko
description:
Irjanne Church, located in the village of Irjanne in Eurajoki, is a wooden church built in 1731. It is known as one of the oldest wooden churches in the Satakunta region. It serves as a "road church," open only during the summer. The church is part of a tightly knit village environment recognized nationally as a significant cultural landscape.

Adjacent to the church is a bell tower constructed in 1758. Inside the church, there's a 17th-century altarpiece depicting the Last Supper, though its artist is unknown. The church interior also features paintings of apostles on the pulpit and two plaster reliefs. The churchyard includes a war memorial and the sculpture "Tree of Life".

name: Isojoen kirkko
description:
The Isojoki Church is a wooden cross church located in Isojoki, Finland, completed in 1833. It represents the Empire style and was designed by the German architect Carl Ludvig Engel, with Erik Kuorikoski serving as the master builder. The church has 900 seats and is surrounded by an old cemetery.

The church features a central dome that emphasizes the cross center and a lantern on top of the dome. The interior corners are beveled, and wooden vaults cover the cross arms. The altar painting's artist is unknown. The decorations on the pulpit's ceiling and the old hymn board were made by Ananias Andersson in the late 1800s. In 1970, organ builder Veikko Virtanen installed a new 21-stop organ in the church. Next to the church is a bell tower dating back to 1854, built by Mats and Karl Hannus, housing two bells acquired in 1756 and 1765.

name: Isonkyrön kirkko
description:
Isonkyrö Church is located in Southern Ostrobothnia. It actually consists of two churches: the Old Church and the New Church.

The Old Church, dedicated to Saint Lawrence, is a medieval gray stone church. It's believed to have been built sometime in the early 16th century, possibly between 1513 and 1533. One of the most remarkable features of the Old Church is its interior, which is decorated with 114 large-sized murals dating back to the 1560s. These paintings depict biblical stories and were hidden under layers of whitewash for over 200 years before being rediscovered in 1885.

The New Church, completed in 1877, represents a different architectural style. Designed by Georg Th. Chiewitz, this neo-Gothic church is constructed of red brick and features a tower. The altarpiece is a copy of Rubens' "Christ on the Cross", painted by Ida Silverberg in 1878.

name: Isonkyrön vanha kirkko
description:
The Old Church of Isokyrö is a medieval stone church located by the Kyrönjoki river. Dedicated to Saint Lawrence, it was built in place of a former wooden church. The oldest remaining part of the church is the brick-built sacristy on the north side, dating back to 1514.

The nave was constructed in the 1520s. Inside, the church is known for its unique murals from the 1560s, commissioned by Reverend Jaakko Geet. These paintings depict scenes from the Bible and create an atmosphere reminiscent of a Renaissance-era celebration hall. The church also features medieval wooden sculptures and reconstructed altarpieces from the early 16th century. Today, the church is a popular venue for weddings and concerts during the summer.

name: Ivalon kirkko
description:
Ivalo Church, the main church of the Inari parish, is located in the center of the village of Ivalo, on the bank of the Ivalo River. Completed in 1966, it was designed by Kauko Kokko and Laura Järvi-Larkas. The church has a rectangular shape and a distinctive folded sloping roof.

Inside, the side walls are folded to improve acoustics, and the interior ceiling slopes towards the altar in a wavy pattern. The church does not have a traditional altarpiece; instead, a glass cross from 1966 adorns the altar wall. The communion silver and the baptismal font, resembling a gold panning dish, were designed by Tapio Wirkkala. The church organ, built in 1972, has 20 stops.

name: Jaalan kirkko
description:
Jaalan kirkko is a wooden church located in Jaala, Kouvola. Designed by architect August Boman, it was completed in 1878. The church is a long church with a western tower and short transepts, representing mainly the Neo-Gothic style, also featuring some Carpenter Gothic style elements.

The altarpiece dates back to 1885 and was painted by Sigfrid Keinänen, with Robert Kajanus serving as the model for the Savior. The church has two bells in its belfry, a smaller brass bell cast in St. Petersburg in 1878 and a larger bell manufactured by Lokomo in 1956. The church has seating for approximately 465 people. A brick parish hall was added to the east end of the church during renovations in 1935-36.

name: Jakomäen kirkko
description:
Jakomäen Kirkko was a church building located in the Jakomäki district of Helsinki, completed in 1975 and designed by architect Leo Tenhunen. However, it was demolished in late 2023 due to moisture problems. The element-structured church was constructed using wood and concrete, drawing inspiration from the Konalan church's three-part design.

The church underwent renovations in 1998 and again in 2010. The altar featured a painting by Göran Augustson, done in a 1970s pop art style. The church organ was made by Kangasala organ factory in 1976. The main hall could seat 70 people, but when combined with the adjacent hall, it accommodated 150. The church was described as cozy, colorful, warm, and inviting.

name: Jalasjärven kirkko
description:
The Jalasjärvi Church, constructed at the beginning of the 1800s by Salomon Köykkä, stands on the highest hill in the village. This wooden cross-shaped church features a western tower and is the second church in Jalasjärvi. Typically for its designer, the church includes a multi-articulated tower connected to one of its arms, topped with a lantern.

Inside, the church retains some of Mikael Toppelius' ceiling paintings and older altarpieces. The oldest bell dates back to the 1730s. Surrounding the church is an old cemetery and a war cemetery with hundreds of stone crosses, commemorating nearly 500 fallen soldiers. Next to the church is the parish hall, completed just before the Winter War in 1939 and designed by Yrjö Vaskinen.

name: Janakkalan kirkko
description:
Janakkala Church, also known as St. Laurence Church, is a medieval gray stone church in Janakkala, Finland. It is located in Tarinmaa, also known as the church village. It's named after Saint Laurence. The church was presumably consecrated on September 19, 1520, and can accommodate approximately 650 people.

The church was originally a rectangular, single-nave long church with a sacristy and armory on the long sides. In the 1840s, it was expanded into a cruciform church. The interior was renovated in 1933. The pulpit dates back to the 1660s and is supposedly made by Mikael Mikaelinpoika Balt from Ostrobothnia. B.A. Godenhjelm painted the altarpiece "Jesus on the Cross" in 1851. The bell tower in front of the west end of the church was built by master builder Martti Tolpo between 1784 and 1792.

name: Jepuan kirkko
description:
The Jepua Church is a wooden, cruciform church built in the early 1860s. Johan Erik Thomasson Romar was the master builder. Originally, the church had a central tower, but it proved structurally unsound and was replaced in 1878 with the current western tower, designed by L. Kjäldström.

Inside, the church features an altarpiece painted by Alexandra Frosterus-Såltin in 1906, depicting Jesus and Mary Magdalene at the tomb. The pulpit and poor man statue were crafted by Anders Johan Rönnqvist, a local carpenter. One of the church's notable features is its old, ornate organ, built in 1685, which is one of the oldest in Finland and was originally made for Pedersöre Church. In 1963, a new 14-stop organ was acquired.

name: Joensuun kirkko
description:
Joensuu Church is the main church of the Joensuu Evangelical Lutheran Parish. It is located on a small hill rising from the shore of the Pielisjoki River. The church represents Neo-Gothic style but also has features of Art Nouveau.

The church, designed by Josef Stenbäck, was built in 1903 from red brick. The interior paintings were painted by August Grönroos according to Stenbäck's plan. Ilmari Launis painted the altarpiece. Artist Antti Salmenlinna designed the stained-glass windows. The church accommodates 900 people, some in the second-floor gallery. The church is part of the Road Church network, offering guidance during the summer.

name: Johanneksen kirkko
description:
Johanneksen kirkko in Hamina, also known as St. John's Church, is located in the center of the city, on Raatihuone Square. The church was designed by architect Carl Ludvig Engel and built between 1839 and 1843. It represents a neoclassical style with strong influences from Greek temples.

The church is dedicated to John the Baptist. The two previous churches of Hamina parish were located at the site of the current orthodox church. After the Elisabet church burned down, the land was given to the orthodox community, and a new location had to be found for the lutheran church. The church was initially used by the Swedish-speaking population of Hamina. The church has about 500 seats.

name: Johanneksenkirkko
description:
St. John's Church (Johanneksenkirkko) is a Lutheran church in Helsinki, Finland. Designed in the Gothic Revival style by Swedish architect Adolf Melander, it was built between 1888 and 1891. It is the largest stone church in Finland in terms of seating capacity, accommodating 2,600 people.

Located in the Ullanlinna district, the church stands on a hill that was historically a site for Midsummer bonfires. Its twin towers reach a height of 74 meters. The church is known for its excellent acoustics and is used for concerts and events, in addition to religious services. The altarpiece, depicting Saul's conversion, is a painting by Eero Järnefelt.

name: Jokioisten kirkko
description:
Jokioinen Church is likely one of the oldest wooden churches in Finland, built in 1631 by Johan Jesperinpoika Kruus. It's a long church, and in 1862, it received its Neo-Gothic exterior and tower based on drawings by Carl Albert Edelfelt.

The church has a separate, low-walled belfry with a hipped roof construction, which is possibly as old as the church itself or from the early 1700s. The bells date back to 1644 and 1755. The church has also been repaired in 1742, 1779, 1886, and 1895. The altar's wooden cross frame from the 1650s was designed by Rafael Blomstedt in 1931. The church's 15-stop organ was made by Hans Heinrich in 1971.

East of the church is a cemetery. The Finnish Heritage Agency has classified Jokioinen Church, its surrounding cemetery, the belfry, and the parsonage as a nationally significant built cultural environment.

name: Jomalan kirkko
description:
St. Olaf's Church in Jomala, Åland, is likely one of Finland's oldest stone churches, dating back to around 1260-1280. Dedicated to St. Olaf, the patron saint of Åland, it stands near a significant Iron Age graveyard.

Constructed from local red granite and limestone, the church has undergone several alterations. Originally rectangular, it was rebuilt in the 19th century, resulting in a T-shaped plan. Despite these changes, some original features remain, including wall paintings from the 1280s depicting scenes from the Prodigal Son parable.

Inside, the church has a unique atmosphere and is used for church services and concerts because of its good acoustics. A limestone sculpture of a lion's head with a human face in its mouth was found in the church, which is now located in the Åland museum.

name: Jongunjoen rajaseutukirkko
description: The Jongunjoki Border Church, now known as the Nurmijärvi parish house, is located in Nurmijärvi, Lieksa. It was designed by architect Rafael Blomstedt and inaugurated on July 18, 1948. The wooden building lacks a traditional tower. In addition to the church hall, the building includes two parish halls and a former apartment. A unique feature of the church hall is its square-shaped pine veneer panels. The church is 100 square meters and has about 50 seats. A separate wooden bell tower was built in 1956, with the bells dating from the same year. The altar features a crucifix sculpture by Harry Kivijärvi.

name: Joroisten kirkko
description: Joroisten Kirkko, located in Joroinen, is a cross-shaped church that can accommodate approximately one thousand people. It was constructed in 1793 and inaugurated in 1795. The church's design is attributed to Juhana Karppinen, a master builder from Iisalmi. A sacristy is situated behind the altar in the eastern arm of the cross, while vestibules are located at the end of the other cross arms. Atop the church ridge stands a small lantern tower. The current bell tower dates back to 1772 and houses a small church museum. The altar painting is made by Pekka Halonen in 1901.

name: Joutjärven kirkko
description:
Joutjärvi Church is a Lutheran church located in Lahti, Finland, specifically in the Möysä district. Completed in 1962, it was designed by architect Unto Ojonen. The church is known for its steeply pitched roof, a signature element in Ojonen's designs, and a slender bell tower.

The building complex integrates a parish hall and staff quarters, reflecting a modern approach to church design that incorporates diverse spaces for community activities. The exterior is constructed with yellow brick and slate, complemented by a copper roof. Inside, the altar features a relief titled "Golgata" by sculptor Pentti Papinaho, who also created the exterior relief "Ten Virgins". The church underwent a comprehensive refurbishment in 2005-2006.

name: Joutsan kirkko
description:
Joutsan kirkko is the oldest church in the Jyväskylä parish, built in 1813. The wooden church is a centrally planned, internally bevelled cross church.

From the center of the cross rises a twelve-sided attic part, on top of which is an octagonal lantern. Inside, the barrel vaults covering the arms of the cross meet in the center to form a high dome. The interior walls of the church hall are made of log surfaces.

The altarpiece from 1938 by Santeri Salokivi depicts Jesus on the cross. The separate, wooden bell tower dates from 1820 and is decorated as a church museum. The church has 500 seats, a bridal room and toilets, as well as an organ and a piano. The interior of the church includes a baptismal font.

name: Joutsenon kirkko
description:
