The Joutseno Church, designed by Josef Stenbäck, was built in 1921. The church represents the National Romantic style and is made of concrete. Originally consecrated as St. John's Church, its motto is "God is love."

The church features a mosaic altarpiece by Bruno Tuukkanen, titled "Jesus Receives Sinners." The current church is the third in Joutseno. The first church was built around 1640, but it was demolished in 1758 due to its poor condition. The second church was destroyed in a fire during the Civil War in 1918. The church was renovated in 1965 and again in 1996. The church has 600 seats.

name: Juankosken kirkko
description:
Juankoski has two notable churches. One is the Juankoski Factory Church, also known as the old church, located in the Juankoski village in Kuopio. It was built as part of the Juantehdas ironworks community and completed in 1861. The tower's appearance dates back to 1924. The church hall has a flat ceiling and an area of 148 square meters. It also served as a school from 1862 to 1921 and has been renovated several times.

The other one is the Church of the Resurrection in Juankoski which belongs to the Järvi-Kuopio parish. It is located in the Juankoski village in Kuopio and serves as a roadside church in the summer. It was consecrated in May 1990 and designed by architects Erkki Karvala and Matti Silvennoinen. The church has over 300 seats.

name: Juankosken tehtaankirkko
description:
The Juankoski Factory Church, also known as the old church of Juankoski, is located in the Juankoski village in Kuopio. It was built in 1861 as part of the Juantehdas ironworks community, featuring a gable tower and a long church design. The tower's appearance dates back to 1924. The church hall is 148 square meters.

It also served as a school for the factory area from 1862 to 1921, and a parsonage was built in connection with it. The church has been renovated several times. The altarpiece, depicting Jesus carrying the Cross, was painted by Mikko Kiljander in 1885, and the church bell dates back to 1930. Since the new church was completed in Juankoski in 1989, the old factory church has been used as a club room. The Finnish Heritage Agency denied a demolition permit for the church, and it was renovated in 2006. The church is protected under church law.

name: Jumesniemen kirkko-koulu
description:
Jumesniemen Kirkko-koulu is a unique building in Hämeenkyrö. Adam Sasslin, a local landowner, built the original church and school in the village in 1847 and hired a teacher-priest. The current building was constructed in 1909-1910.

The building has a village church suitable for family celebrations, seating 110 people and featuring an organ. On the other side of the building, there are school facilities. Nowadays, the Pomppis daycare center and the church bring life to the school grounds. There is also a village hall built in 1999 and a sports field that is frozen into an ice rink in winter.

name: Jurvan kirkko
description: The Jurva Church is a wooden church built in 1753. It represents Ostrobothnian church building traditions. The church's exterior is characterized by its simple, rectangular shape and tall, shingled roof. Inside, the church features a traditional layout with a central nave and a raised pulpit. The interior is adorned with simple decorations and wooden pews. The altarpiece dates to the 18th century. The Jurva Church stands as a significant landmark in the area, showcasing the architectural styles prevalent during its construction. It's a valuable part of the local cultural heritage.

name: Juuan kirkko
description: Juuan kirkko is a beautiful wooden church built in 1850-1851 and consecrated on July 10, 1859. The church was designed by architect C. A. Gustavsson. However, the bell tower was built independently by the people of Juuka in 1796. The church has seating for 800 people. The church's organ was manufactured by Kangasala organ factory and has 22 stops. The church has been renovated in 1973-74 and repainted inside in 1989. In the summer of 2018, the church and bell tower underwent external cladding and roof renovation.

name: Juupajoen kirkko
description:
Juupajoki Church, located in the village of Kopsamo, is a unique octagonal wooden church built between 1838 and 1846. It represents the Empire style of the 18th century. The church was built by local farm owners.

The exterior features a pyramid-shaped roof, while the interior has a wooden dome. The bell tower was completed in 1861. The cemetery was consecrated in 1853. The church was electrified in 1921, and central heating was installed in 1939. A major renovation was carried out in the 1980s, during which the entrances were widened. Ilmari Launis designed the paintings.

The church can accommodate around 420 visitors and is accessible by wheelchair. Services are held almost every Sunday and on other Christian holidays.

name: Juvan kirkko
description:
Juva Church, completed in 1863, stands as a significant example of 19th-century church architecture. The granite facade and the brickwork around the doors, windows, and tower give it a unique and impressive look. Inside, the church hall, bordered by galleries, is covered by a barrel vault.

Adding to the hall's grandeur are brass empire chandeliers made in St. Petersburg in 1833. The altar painting, depicting Jesus blessing children, was painted by Alexandra Frosterus-Såltin in 1899. The churchyard, with its memorial park, is surrounded by a stone wall featuring a war memorial designed by Ilmari Wirkkala. The church and its leafy cemetery are among the oldest cultural environments in Juva's renewed center.

name: Jyväskylän Kaupunginkirkko
description:
Jyväskylä City Church, completed in 1880, stands as the first stone church in Central Finland. Designed by architect Ludvig Isak Lindqvist, the red-brick church features round-arched windows and elaborate brick ornamentation, incorporating both Neo-Romanesque and Neo-Gothic architectural styles.

Located in Kirkkopuisto, one of Jyväskylä's oldest parks that once served as a market square, the church boasts interior paintings by Bruno Tuukkanen and a notable altarpiece, "Jesus Blesses the Children," painted by Fredrik and Nina Ahlstedt in 1901. The church was renovated in the late 1980s, updating the interior colors while preserving Tuukkanen's choir vault ceiling painting. The 400-seat church is a popular wedding venue and remains open to visitors.

name: Jämijärven kirkko
description: The Jämijärvi Church is a neo-Gothic building constructed between 1859 and 1860. Architect Georg Theodor von Chiewitz designed the tower-topped, symmetrical cruciform church. Inside, the cross arms have flat ceilings, and the center of the cross is covered by a shallow dome. Felix Frang painted the altarpiece in 1897. The church is located on a hill surrounded by a cemetery, and a birch alley leads to it from the center of Jämijärvi. In addition to the church, the church landscape includes a parsonage, the parsonage's storehouse, a parish granary functioning as a museum dating back to 1856, and the building group of the Peijari farm.

name: Jämsänkosken kirkko
description:
Jämsänkoski Church is located in the center of Jämsänkoski, prominently on top of a hill. Architect Wäinö G. Palmqvist designed the church, and it was completed in 1935 on land donated by the paper mill company. The church was consecrated on June 30, 1935.

The Jämsänkoski parish separated from the Jämsä main parish in 1925 and before the church was built, they gathered in the old Seurahuone of Yhtyneet Paperitehtaat Oy, which was renovated into a temporary church. Yhtyneet Paperitehtaat Oy donated the altarpiece "Travelers on the Church Road" to the church. Alvar Cawen painted the painting in 1935. The artist's spouse, Ragni Cawen, finished the altarpiece because the artist himself died before the painting was completed.

name: Jämsän kirkko
description:
Jämsä Church is the main church of the Jämsä parish, located on a prominent hill, creating a valuable atmosphere for the entire area. The stone church was completed in 1929 and designed by architect Kauno S. Kallio. It represents the classicism of its time and has a cruciform structure.

The church was built to replace the previous church, which was destroyed in a fire in 1925. The community wished for the new church to resemble the old one. The interior is dominated by a large dome and a windowed lantern. The altar painting from 1848 by Berndt Godenhjelm was rescued from the fire. The church also features a bell tower built in 1857.

name: Jäppilän kirkko
description:
Jäppilä Church is a wooden long church located in Jäppilä, Pieksämäki. It was designed by architect Ferdinand Öhman and completed in 1872. The church is a long church with a tower, and it has wide transepts on its long sides.

The church hall has a wooden vaulted ceiling. The details and general design resemble other wooden churches from the early neo-Gothic period. The church has been renovated several times, including in 2013. The church has 550 seats.

The altarpiece, dating from 1878, is painted by F. Weurlander and depicts Christ on the Cross. The church's 22+4 stop pneumatic organ was made by Kangasala organ factory in 1948. The church is located in the center of Jäppilä, near the parish hall and cemetery.

name: Järvenpään kirkko
description:
Järvenpää Church, completed in 1968, was designed by architect Erkki Elomaa. The church represents concrete brutalism and is the main church of the Järvenpää parish. The church hall has seats for 625 people and a chapel for 30 people.

The church exemplifies the use of concrete in creating clear and systematic architecture in the 1960s. The bells are hung on a cubic frame on the roof. The architectural expressions of the church hall are the different textures of the concrete surface. The altar crucifix is ​​made of Douglas fir, carved by Erkki Eronen.

name: Kaarinan kirkko
description:
Kaarina Church is located in Hovirinta, near the current center of Kaarina. The church building serves as the main church of the Kaarina parish.

The church was designed by Arkkitehtitoimisto Pitkänen, Laiho & Raunio. The red brick-clad building complex combines different wood materials in its interior. Wood elements, composed of different levels, shapes, and colors, form an image of the suffering Christ on the altar wall. Textile artist Raija Rastas designed the church textiles.

In January 1991, the previous Kaarina parish was divided into two parishes along the border between Kaarina and Turku. The former Kaarina Church became the church of the Turku Katarina parish and was renamed St. Catherine's Church. At that time, the Hovirinta parish center became the new Kaarina Church.

name: Kaarlelan kirkko
description:
Kaarlelan kirkko is a medieval stone church located in Kokkola, Central Ostrobothnia. It was likely built between 1500 and 1530, with its oldest parts dating back to the 1460s. The church serves both the Finnish and Swedish congregations of Kokkola, hosting regular Sunday services in both languages. It is also used for various religious events, concerts, baptisms, weddings, and funerals.

Originally rectangular, the church was expanded into a cross shape in the late 18th century under the guidance of Anders Chydenius. The walls of the original church still form part of the current main building. The pulpit, brought from Sweden by Reverend Jacob Skepperus in 1622, is one of the oldest in Finland. The church also houses one of Finland's oldest poor man statues, dating back to 1784, alongside another one from the 1840s that is still in use.

name: Kaavin kirkko
description:
Kaavin Church is located in the church village of Kaavi. The church was designed by architectural firm Karvala & Silvennoinen and was consecrated on December 18, 1983. It was built to replace the previous church that was destroyed in a fire in 1980.

The glass facade at the entrance of the church reflects the old bell tower, which survived the fire. The bell tower was erected at its current location in 1815. The church is part of the Kuopio parish. As of 2020, there were concerns about the church's structural integrity and potential need for costly repairs or even demolition. There have been discussions about either renovating the existing church or building a new, smaller one.

name: Kajaanin kirkko
description:
Kajaanin kirkko is the main church of the Kajaani parish, located in the city center. The church was built in 1896, and it is designed by architect Jac Ahrenberg. It is a wooden church, representing the Neo-Gothic style of the late 19th century.

The church has a nave flanked by two aisles and a slender bell tower. Inside, the roof structures are visible and decorated with English Gothic-style wood carvings. The church is located on the same site as the first church of Kajaani, which was built in 1656. The current church is considered one of the most significant and diverse examples of constructive wooden architecture from the late 1800s.

name: Kakskerran kirkko
description: Kakskerta Church is a seaside church located on the island of Kakskerta in Turku, Finland. It's one of three churches belonging to the Turku Martin parish. Built between 1765 and 1769, the church was designed by Christian Schroder and dedicated in 1770. The church has a rectangular shape. The altarpiece dates back to the 17th century. In 1940, the interior was largely renovated under the direction of architect Erik Bryggman. The belfry, which stands next to the church, was designed by C. Bassi in 1824. The churchyard is surrounded by a stone wall and includes a chapel in the Empire style belonging to the von Bonsdorff family, dating back to 1831.

name: Kalajoen kirkko
description:
The Kalajoki Church is a red-brick church completed in 1879, being the seventh church in the area. The current church was designed by architect F.W. Lüchow. The construction was carried out by the parishioners, and even the bricks were made in Kalajoki.

Inside the church, the altarpiece painted by Adolf von Becker in 1887 depicts the Resurrection of Christ. The church organ was made in 1931. A separate bell tower has two bells dating back to 1813 and 1830. The church was damaged by fire in 1930 but rebuilt in 1931. The church accommodates 900 people.

name: Kalannin kirkko
description:
Kalannin Church, also known as Uusikirkko Church, is a medieval gray stone church located in Kalanti, Uusikaupunki. It was constructed between 1430 and 1450. The church, dedicated to the Virgin Mary and Saint Olaf, is renowned for its wall and vault paintings, as well as a unique altarpiece held in the National Museum of Finland. The murals are some of the most significant examples of medieval church art in Finland, and the altarpiece is considered one of the most valuable in the Nordic countries.

Originally known as Uusikirkko, meaning "New Church," it replaced older churches. The name Kalanti was adopted in 1936. The church is a roadside church open in the summer and is designated as a nationally significant built cultural environment by the Finnish Heritage Agency. The oldest parts of the church are the sacristy and the lower part of the western tower. The wooden upper part of the tower was completed in 1779.

name: Kalevan kirkko
description:
Kalevan Church is a modern church building located in the Liisankallio district of Tampere, completed in 1966. It was designed by the architect couple Raili and Reima Pietilä. The church is one of the most famous sights in Kaleva and Tampere.

The architecture is characterized by spaciousness, light, arched pillars, verticality, the color of unbleached linen, wooden surfaces, unobstructed views, and non-rectangularity. From above, the church resembles a fish, an early Christian symbol. The church also includes a chapel for small gatherings.

The church's modern appearance stirred much debate upon its completion and continues to do so. It has been jokingly called a grain silo or a silo of souls. However, it is undoubtedly one of the most impressive sights in Tampere.

name: Kalkkisten kirkko
description:
Kalkkisten Church is a wooden church located in the village of Kalkkinen in Asikkala. It was originally built as a prayer room in 1910. The church has 120 seats. The building has a gable tower and a rectangular sacristy protruding from the altar end. The church bell dates back to 1960, and the altarpiece is painted by Arthur Heickell.

The plot for the building was donated by Sipi and Aleksandra Koskinen. The original prayer room was designed by Kalle Nyman, who was also responsible for the construction. The interior and benches were renovated in 1934, and the building was handed over to the Asikkala congregation in 1951. The building was renovated in 2004–2007.

name: Kallaveden kirkko
description:
Kallaveden kirkko is located in Kuopio, in the Jynkkä district. The church was completed in 1983 and consecrated on Michaelmas Day, October 2, 1983. It was designed by architect Pertti Pakkala from Kuopio.

The church serves as the main church for the Kallavesi parish. In addition to the church hall, the building includes facilities for various parish activities, and the parish office is also located there. The church hall has approximately 300 seats, but an additional 200 seats can be added from the parish hall for larger events. The church features traditional mechanical organs made by Oulunsalon Urkurakentamo.

name: Kallion kirkko
description:
Kallio Church, designed by Lars Sonck, is a Lutheran church in Helsinki's Kallio district and a prominent city landmark. Completed in 1912, it exemplifies National Romanticism with Art Nouveau influences. The church stands 65 meters tall, its cross reaching 94 meters above sea level.

Built from grey granite, the church's tower offers views stretching to the Estonian coastline. The interior features Christian symbols and Art Nouveau murals. The altarpiece is a wooden relief called "Come to me, all you who are weary and burdened" by Hannes Autere. The church's excellent acoustics make it a popular concert venue, especially for organ music. The tower has seven bronze bells that play a Sibelius composition daily at noon and 6 pm.

name: Kalvolan kirkko
description:
Kalvola Church is located in Iittala, Hämeenlinna. It was designed by architect Ilmari Launis, who also created the interior decorations and stained glass paintings. The church was constructed between 1919 and 1921, replacing an older church built in 1802, renovated in 1866, and destroyed by fire in 1918.

The church is built from red granite from Kalvola and features a basilica-style design with a tower. The central nave rises above the lower side aisles and the parish hall and sacristy in the chancel area. The interior ceiling is a vaulted concrete structure. The altar features a crucifix made in Oberammergau, Germany. The church has seating for 500 people, with an additional 40 seats in the back hall.

name: Kangasalan kirkko
description:
Kangasala Church, located in the center of Kangasala, is a stone church that was first used in 1767 without a tower. The tower was completed in 1776. However, it collapsed in 1782, and a new tower was erected in 1800.

Inside, the church features a unique ceiling adorned with hundreds of framed stars. The church has a 34-stop organ built in 1988. A stone is set into the wall on the building's left rear side, which, according to legend, served as the execution block for Kaarina of Kuusalo. This event is symbolized by the blood droplets on Kangasala's coat of arms. Kangasala Church is a popular wedding venue and was voted the most accessible church in Finland in 2016 and the most beautiful building in Kangasala in 2021.

name: Kangaslammin kirkko
description:
The Kangaslampi Church is located in Varkaus, in the former municipality of Kangaslampi. The previous church burned down in 1972, and this brick church was built in its place between 1972 and 1973. The church has a flat roof that slopes into a gable roof at the altar end.

The church covers an area of 450 square meters and has seating for 250 people. It was designed by architect Kaj Michael. The concrete bell tower next to the church was built in 1973, and the bells are from 1972-1973. The sculpture "Trees of Life" on the altar was designed by artist Eva Ryynänen, as was the work "Angel's Wing" on the wall of the community hall, which can be connected to the church hall. On the left side of the altar is a window wall, and on the right is the organ and choir area.

name: Kangasniemen kirkko
description:
Kangasniemi Church is located in the center of Kangasniemi. It is a large, wooden double-cruciform church, the third church of the congregation. The church is 47 meters wide and has an interior height of 15 meters. It has approximately 1000 seats, though it previously held up to 1500. The church was inaugurated on New Year's Day in 1815.

The church and bell tower were designed and built by Matti Salonen from Savitaipale. Kangasniemi Church has been renovated four times, most recently in 2019-2020. Church textiles designed by textile artist Helena Vaari were introduced in 2020-2021. The electric-pneumatic organ was made by Kangasala organ factory in 1954 and has 46 stops. The altarpiece "Jesus bids farewell to his mother" is a painting by Berndt Abraham Godenhjelm from 1851.

name: Kankaanpään kirkko
description:
Kankaanpää Church is one of the largest wooden churches in Satakunta. It is a cross-shaped, neoclassical church designed by C.L. Engel. The church was consecrated on June 2, 1839. The 24-meter-high tower dominates the pine forest landscape. The church has about 1000 seats.

The church hall is gathered by a 16-meter-high hanging dome. The murals in the church hall were painted by Urho Lehtinen in 1938–1939, and the altarpiece by Felix Frang in 1922 with the theme of the Transfiguration of Christ. The church's current 40-sound organ was made by Hans Heinrich. Every generation of Kankaanpää has participated in the repair and reconstruction of their home church since then. The most recent renovation work was planned by architect Heikki Elomaa for the church's 150th anniversary.

name: Kannelmäen kirkko
description:
Kannelmäki Church, consecrated on September 1, 1968, was designed by architects Marjatta and Martti Jaatinen. The church is located in the Kannelmäki subdistrict of the Kaarela district in northwestern Helsinki. Its tent-like shape and copper-clad roof, reaching a height of 30 meters, cover the church hall. The windows between the four-part roof form a cross that brings light and a view of the sky to the churchgoers.

The church's 29-stop organ was made by Kangasala organ factory. The altarpiece is a stained-glass painting called "Elämänpuu" (Tree of Life) by Hilkka Toivola from 1972. The furniture includes prototypes of Kari chairs designed by Kari Asikainen. The church is used by both the Kannelmäki parish and the Swedish-speaking Petrus parish. Since 2010, the church has been one of the Finnish Heritage Agency's listed sites of nationally significant built cultural environments.

name: Kannonkosken kirkko
description:
The Kannonkoski Church is a Lutheran church in Kannonkoski, Finland. Designed by Pauli E. Blomstedt, it represents Functionalism in architecture. The church was constructed between 1937 and 1938. Blomstedt passed away in 1935, so his wife Märta Blomstedt and architect Matti Lampén completed the work.

The church is known among experts and was displayed as a model at the Paris World Exhibition in 1937, even before its completion. It is one of the most significant examples of early functionalist church architecture in Finland. Next to the church is a memorial area for heroes designed by Ilmari Wirkkala.

The church has a rectangular shape with a tower. From the side, it resembles a modern ocean liner floating in a peaceful landscape. The altar wall features a wooden crucifix by Hannes Autere.

name: Kannuksen kirkko
description: The church of Kannus, located in the center of the town, has stood since 1817. The cross of the church rises to a height of 33 meters. Heikki Kuorikoski, a church builder, designed and built this third church of Kannus. The church was built in the shape of a cross on the site of a church destroyed in a fire in 1813. The tower part of the church was raised and wooden pillars supporting the roof were added to the interior in the repair work of 1880, which was carried out under the direction of church builder Mikko Karjalahti. The church can seat 900 people, and the interior height at the dome is 15 meters. The altarpiece is in three parts. The upper part depicts the sun, the middle Jesus on the cross and below is a subject depicting communion. The church is a nationally significant built cultural environment.

name: Kanta-Loimaan kirkko
description: The Kanta-Loimaa Church is a cathedral-like church located on the east bank of the Loimijoki River, a prominent landmark in the agricultural landscape. Originally built as a neoclassical stone church designed by Carlo Bassi and completed in 1837, it was destroyed by fire in 1888. The church was rebuilt in a revival style according to plans by Josef Stenbäck in 1892. The brick church features a high baroque-style tower and a central dome. Inside, the spacious church hall's colors were restored to Josef Stenbäck's neo-Renaissance design in the early 2000s. Near the church is a former two-story warehouse building from 1855, which is now a museum. The church is the main church of the Loimaa parish and can accommodate 1,000 people.

name: Karijoen kirkko
description:
Karijoki Church, also known as Helena's Church, is a wooden cross-shaped church built between 1808 and 1812 in Karijoki. Salomon Köhlström, a well-known church builder, designed it. A distinctive multi-tiered tower, typical of Köhlström's churches, is connected to the church.

The church bells date back to 1807 and 1816. The interior features a high wooden vault, and the church has undergone several renovations. The altar painting, "The Good Shepherd," was painted by Kaarlo Lamminheimo in 1954. The church is also known for the story of Helena Kullas, a young girl who saved it from a fire during the Finnish War.

name: Karinaisten kirkko
description: Karinaisten Church, located in Pöytyä, is a wooden church that was completed in 1835. It represents a cross-church style. Contrary to the original plans, a tower was built on the west end by decision of the church meeting. The church is known for its altarpiece "Sinful Woman Before Jesus" painted by Wäinö Aaltonen in 1935, who also designed the altar. It is the only altarpiece painted by Aaltonen. The latest renovation was completed in 1999, restoring the interior to its original colors. The church is located about five kilometers from the center of Kyrö towards Tarvasjoki.

name: Karjaan kirkko
description: Karjaan Church, also known as St. Catherine's Church, is a medieval stone church located in Karjaa, Raseborg. It was likely constructed between 1465 and 1470. The church features a stained glass window by artist Gunnar Forsström. The church has a bell tower that dates back to 1768. The stone foundation is medieval, and two of the bells also date back to the Middle Ages. The church is a hall church with three naves. Inside the church, there is a triumphal crucifix dating back to 1450, wood sculptures and coat-of-arms shields. The church textiles are designed by textile artist Barbro Gardberg in 1976.

name: Karjalan kirkko
description: Karjalan Kirkko, located in Mynämäki, Finland, is a wooden church built in 1869 in the Neo-Gothic style. It was designed by architect Georg Theodor Chiewitz. The church features unique organs built by K.G. Wikström in 1894. The church is part of a nationally significant cultural environment that includes a historic parish granary, which now serves as a local heritage museum. The church has a seating capacity of approximately 300 people. Services are held regularly.

name: Karjalohjan kirkko
description:
Karjalohja Church is a gray stone church completed in 1860, designed by county architect Jean Wik, a student of Carl Ludvig Engel. It is located in the village of Karjalohja in the town of Lohja. The church stands on top of a ridge so that it is visible from both Lake Puujärvi and Lake Lohjanjärvi.

In September 1970, a lightning strike caused a fire that destroyed the wooden bell tower and the interior of the church, leaving only the stone walls. For 20 years, the ruins were left unprotected. In 1990, the ruins were covered with a roof. The church was gradually repaired, and in 1995, a new belfry was built. The altar painting by Alexandra Såltin, "Come to me, all you who labor and are heavy laden", was rescued from the fire and is now prominently displayed in the renovated church.

name: Karjasillan kirkko
description:
Karjasillan kirkko is located in Oulu, in the district of Höyhtyä. Designed by architect Kalevi Lankinen, it was completed in 1963. The church is made of concrete and brick, representing modern church architecture. Its architecture is considered regionally valuable.

The church's roof consists of asymmetrical, successive arches. The windows resemble angel wings, sheltering the congregation. The pews are placed continuously, without a central aisle, to emphasize community. A slender, high bell tower in the shape of a cross stands in front of the church.

Inside, textile artist Dora Jung designed the church textiles. The altar features a bronze sculpture by Essi Renvall, "Christ's Second Coming." The church also has a 30-stop organ made by Sotkamon Urkurakentamo, representing the German Romantic style.

name: Karkkilan kirkko
description:
The Karkkila Church, formerly known as Pyhäjärvi Ul Church, belongs to the Karkkila parish. It's a wooden cross church built in 1781 by Matti Öisti from Laihia. The church features Neoclassical details. Small vestibules and a sacristy lengthen the cross arms.

The exterior has a hipped roof with a small flèche on the ridge. Inside, there are shallow wooden vaults. The church covers an area of 370 square meters and has seating for 650 people. The church was renovated in 1872, 1899, 1925, and 1954. The outer walls of the church were painted red in 1825, yellow in 1873, and red again in 1954. The church's current appearance was designed by architect Jari Reponen. The church has an 18-stop organ made by Kangasala organ factory in 1970.

name: Karkun kirkko
description:
Karkku Church, consecrated as the Church of Christ's Coming, was completed in 1913. It is a grey stone church belonging to the Sastamala parish. Situated in Karkku, Sastamala, it lies on the shore of Lake Riippilänjärvi, near Rautavesi. Bishop Juho Koskimies of the Kuopio diocese, who spent his summers in Karkku, consecrated the church on December 21, 1913.

The church is a long church with a tower at the end, featuring a semicircular apse protruding from the altar end. The tower, which serves as the main entrance, culminates in a truncated pyramid cone. The facade is constructed from granite stones of varying sizes. The low walls have straight-topped paired windows, and the roof slopes feature arched windows. The church hall has three naves and a barrel vault above.

name: Karstulan kirkko
description:
The Karstula Church is a wooden, central church located in Karstula, Central Finland. Constructed from logs, the church features a cubic central space adjoined by entrance-hall-like cross arms on each side. At the center of the church is a square dome with windows. The church represents the late Empire style and was completed in 1853 by Jaakko Heikinpoika Kuorikoski, based on drawings by architect A. F. Granstedt.

The altar painting was painted by Pekka Halonen. The belfry next to the church dates back to 1815 and was built by Simon Juvelin. It was renovated in 1861 under Lauri Heikki Kuorikoski. The church was renovated in 2003, when Allen's digital organs were also acquired. In the churchyard, there is a memorial stone erected in 1975 for the first church of Karstula, which was located on the site of the current church.

name: Karunan kirkko
description: Karuna Church is located in Sauvo. The stone church was built between 1908-1910 and designed by Josef Stenbäck in the National Romantic style, incorporating Nordic Medieval-Gothic revival elements. Another Karuna church, built in 1685, was originally located in Karuna, but it was moved to Seurasaari open-air museum in Helsinki in 1912. In Seurasaari, the church is a popular wedding venue and hosts Finnish-language services and musical evenings during the summer.

name: Karunan vanha kirkko
description:
The Karuna Church is a wooden church that was completed in 1685. Originally located in Karuna, it was moved to the Seurasaari Open-Air Museum in Helsinki in 1912, where it stands today as the oldest building in the museum.

The church was originally built as a private chapel by Arvid Horn, the owner of Karuna Manor. It was named Maria Elisabet after his second wife. In the late 18th century, the church underwent renovations that included a steeper roof and larger arched windows. A weather vane on the roof commemorates these changes with the year 1774. The belfry was constructed in 1767. The church is a popular wedding venue in the summer.

name: Karungin kirkko
description: The Karunki Church is located approximately 25 kilometers north of the city center of Tornio. It is a wooden cross-shaped church built between 1815 and 1817, designed by A.W. Arppe. The church has undergone renovations in 1953-1954 and 1983. The altarpiece, "Jesus on the Cross," was painted by J. Hedman in 1827. The church has seating for approximately 550 people. Services are held on Sundays at 11 am.

name: Kaskisten kirkko
description: The Kaskinen Church was designed by architect Erik Kråkström and completed in 1965. It is the first actual church building in Kaskinen. The church is rectangular in shape and constructed with brick and wood, featuring a tower. The church hall can be connected to an adjacent parish hall. The church was renovated in 1974. Inside, the altar painting "Christ's Removal from the Cross" was painted by Åke Hellman in 1965. The church also houses a 12-stop organ made by Kangasala organ factory in 1966. The load-bearing structures of the church consist of wooden pillars and beams. The wooden parts are pressure-impregnated and their outer surface is stained. The wall surfaces are made of brick up to door height, and the floor of the church is also made of brick.

name: Karvian kirkko
description:
Karvia Church is a wooden church located in Karvia, Finland. It was built by Salomon Köhlström-Köykkä from Jalasjärvi. The construction started in 1789 and was completed in 1798 and consecrated in 1799. The belfry next to the church was completed in 1806.

The church is a valuable monument to the architecture and craftsmanship of folk builders. The altarpiece and beautiful interior paintings are from 1843, painted by Carl Gabriel Diedrichs. Karvia Church is part of the Arts Route. During the summer, the church is open to visitors on weekdays.

name: Kastellin kirkko
description:
Kastellin kirkko is a church located in the Oulunsuu district of Oulu. It belongs to the Karjasilta parish. The church was designed by architect Veijo Kerola and completed in 1962. It was formerly known as the Oulunsuu church.

The church hall can accommodate 300 people and the meeting room 80 people. The altar is decorated with a 78 square meter stained glass painting "Vasten valoa" by artist Unto Pusa. Tapio Wirkkala designed the silverware. Veijo Kerola also designed the baptismal font, church textiles, and furniture. The church is a distinctive landmark in the area.

name: Katukappeli
description: Katukappeli is a chapel located in the Columbus shopping center in Vuosaari, Helsinki. It was established in 1996 and designed by architect Mauri Tommila. The chapel is intended for moments of silence, discussions, and prayer. It is run by parish workers and volunteer parishioners. The chapel is also used for weddings and baptisms and can accommodate 30 people. The altarpiece of the chapel is the work "Parks" by artist Kristian Krokfors.

name: Kauhajoen kirkko
description:
The Kauhajoki Church, consecrated in December 1958, stands in the center of Kauhajoki. Architect Veikko Larkas designed it to replace a burned-down church. It represents a modernized version of Finland's medieval churches. The shape of Kauhajoki's main church resembles an open Bible standing on its covers.

The church's altar features an 18-meter-high mosaic, topped with a 13-meter-high bronze cross. The altar mosaic starts with a black color dotted with red at the bottom, lightening upwards. Stautes made by artist Eino Räsänen on the altar create a link to the old church. A stained-glass window made by Antti Salmenlinna and Gunnar Forsström depicts Christ coming to the Kauhajoki landscape.

name: Kauhajärven kirkko
description: Kauhajärvi Church is located in the village of Kauhajärvi in Lapua. The original church was destroyed in an arson fire in 1981. A bell tower designed by Alvar Aalto in 1923 remained standing. The current church was designed by architects Erkki Karvala, Matti Silvennoinen, and Markku Koskinen and was inaugurated in 1983. The church seats about 262 people, including those in the gallery. The churchyard also includes a war memorial.

name: Kauhajärven kirkko
description: The Kauhajärvi Church is located in the village of Kauhajärvi in Lapua. The original church was destroyed in an arson fire in 1981, with only the bell tower, designed by Alvar Aalto in 1923, surviving. A new church was built and inaugurated in 1983, designed by architects Erkki Karvala, Matti Silvennoinen, and Markku Koskinen. The church seats approximately 262 people. The altar painting is called "Truly this was a righteous man". The eight-stop organ was built by Urkutehdas Hans Heinrich.

name: Kauhavan kirkko
description:
Kauhavan kirkko is a neo-Gothic long church with a tower, located in Kauhava. It was designed by architect Josef Stenbäck. The church can accommodate 950 people. Constructed from red brick and grey granite between 1923 and 1925, it was consecrated on October 4, 1925.

The current church was built on the same location as the previous wooden church from 1756, which burned down in 1921. Due to the concrete slab not withstanding the weight of the church, it had to be re-founded on reinforced concrete piles in 1962. The altar painting "Jesus Blesses the Children" dates back to 1882 and originates from Kauhava's old church.

name: Kaustisen kirkko
description:
Kaustinen Church is a wooden, cruciform church located in the center of Kaustinen. The church's frame incorporates Kaustinen's first church, completed in 1777, which was thoroughly renovated in 1859. The church and separate bell tower are the work of the Kuorikoski church-building family from Kaustinen.

The church represents a neoclassical style. The current form of the church was constructed by Jaakko Heikinpoika Kuorikoski in 1859. The bell tower, completed in 1778, is the work of Matti Kuorikoski, as was the first church completed in 1777. The latest renovation was completed in 2006. The shingle roof was renewed in 2014. The church has approximately 450 seats. The three-part altarpiece was painted by Emanuel Alm in 1794.

name: Kauvatsan kirkko
description:
Kauvatsan Church, located in Kokemäki, was built in 1879. The wooden structure was designed by C.J. von Heideken. The altarpiece, painted by Alexandra Frosterus-Såltin in 1885, depicts Jesus overcoming temptations. Lauri Välke also contributed paintings to the altar wall, pulpit, and stair railings.

The church features a Thulen organ with 17 stops, built in 1902 and electrified in 1947. The church is accessible by wheelchair. The Kauvatsa cemetery surrounds the church, featuring a statue of a praying soldier by Kauko Räike, erected in 1955, at the war hero graves. The church is open during events and by appointment.

name: Keikyän kirkko
description:
Keikyä Church is a wooden church located in the village of Keikyä in Sastamala. The church was designed by Josef Stenbäck and completed in 1912. It represents the Jugend style and is characterized by a cruciform layout with a tower.

The church has a rich history, with previous churches existing on the site. The current church is the third one built in Keikyä. The interior was renovated in 1997 to restore it to its original Stenbäck design. The altar painting, depicting old Simeon with the child Jesus, dates back to 1753 and has been present in all three Keikyä churches. The church also features an 18-stop organ acquired in 1964.

name: Keiteleen kirkko
description:
The Keitele Church is a wooden, neo-Gothic long church located in Keitele, Finland. It was designed by Wolmar Westling and built in 1876. The church features a tower at the end of the building and a cross-shaped layout.

Inside, the church has three naves. The ceiling of the central nave is a pitched roof supported by pillars, while the side naves have flat ceilings. The altar is adorned with a painting of the Crucifixion by Ilmari Heinonen, created in 1941. The church also has a 16-stop organ, manufactured by Kangasala organ factory in 1976.

The church has undergone renovations in 1938, 1966 and 1987. The exterior was repainted in 2002.

name: Kellokosken kirkko
description: Kellokoski Church is a wooden church painted in red ochre, situated in the village of Kellokoski, Tuusula, by the bank of the Kerava River. It was inaugurated in 1800. The church belongs to the Tuusula parish, which arranges services on Sundays. The building has a rectangular shape and can seat approximately 150 people. The church has a pitched roof and a small tower in the northern end. The bell in the tower dates back to 1930. Next to the church is a parish hall.

name: Keltinmäen kirkko
description: Keltinmäki Church, completed in 1992, is located in the Keltinmäki district of Jyväskylä. Designed by architect Olavi Noronen, the modern church has familiar elements, making it easily recognizable as a church. Inside, light is a key theme, exemplified by the round glass altar, which is illuminated from above. The altar artwork, titled "Resurrection of the Dead," is by Penni Rainio. The church also features a stained glass piece called "The Road of the Bible" by Andrij Stasevskij. The church has a 15-stop organ made by Tuomi Organ Workshop and two bells in its tower. The church hall seats 200 people and the building has other spaces as well, including a café in the lobby.

name: Kemin kirkko
description:
Kemin kirkko, designed by Josef Stenbäck, was completed in 1902. It is a long church made of brick with two side naves, reflecting continental neo-Gothic influences. This is especially evident in the large rose window above the main entrance and the large windows on the altar wall. Gothic influences are also visible in the church tower, small towers, and gables.

The vaults and protruding pillars of the church hall are reminiscent of large European cathedrals. The simple furniture and sparse decoration, on the other hand, are related to traditional Finnish stone church construction. The three-part Gothic windows on the altar wall feature stained glass paintings from 1986 by artist Lauri Ahlgren, depicting the Trinity. The church was renovated in 2003.

name: Kemijärven kirkko
description:
The Kemijärvi Church was designed by Bertel Liljeqvist and completed in 1950. It was consecrated the following year. The church has 850 seats. The altar painting, "Jesus on the Cross," was painted by Aale Hakava in 1950.

Kemijärvi's church life began in 1648. The first church was likely similar to the old church in Sodankylä. This church was demolished in the 1690s and replaced with a larger one. The church's bell tower is the oldest building in the parish, built in 1774. During the Lapland War, the Germans set the church on fire when they left. The pastor at the time, Heikki Rosma, managed to save the altarpiece and a few other valuable objects. The church has an organ with 41 stops built by Gerhard Schmid in 1984.

name: Keminmaan vanha kirkko
description:
The Old Church of Keminmaa, also known as St. Michael's Church, is a medieval gray stone church mainly constructed between 1551 and 1553. Alongside the church of Alatornio, it's one of Finland's northernmost medieval stone churches and one of the last religious buildings from the Catholic era in Finland.

The church has been restored several times since the 1920s and is a popular tourist destination and wedding venue. The church interior features ceiling paintings from 1650 depicting the Passion of Christ. Saint images, a baptismal font, and a holy water vessel from the Catholic period adorn the walls. The church also contains a coffin and stocks in the armory, reminders of old parish traditions. The churchyard has been found to contain at least 40 naturally mummified bodies.

name: Keminmaan uusi kirkko
description:
The New Church of Keminmaa, designed by Carl Ludvig Engel, was completed in 1827. It is located in the village of Laurila, near the medieval Church of St. Michael. This yellow-painted church replaced an earlier one from 1797, which had structural weaknesses.

Emperor Alexander I ordered its construction using state funds after hearing about the previous church's poor condition. Built in the Empire style, the long stone church was constructed by local forces under master builder Erik Korpp. The altarpiece, "Jesus on the Cross," was painted by Johan Gustav Hedman in the same year the church was completed. The church is surrounded by a stone fence with grand gates.

name: Kemiön kirkko
description:
Kemiö Church, also known as St. Andrew's Church, is located in Kemiönsaari. The stone church, dedicated to St. Andrew, was likely completed in 1469. A wooden church stood on the same site, with the earliest mention dating back to 1445, though coins from the 1300s have been found during excavations.

The church's interior has been altered over the years, including rebuilding after a devastating fire. The church is open to the public during the summer, and a church museum is located across the road in an old warehouse. The stained glass window was designed by Armas Lindgren in 1922.

name: Kempeleen vanha kirkko
description:
The Old Church of Kempele is one of Finland's oldest wooden churches, completed in 1691. It represents one of the eleven remaining valuable pillar churches in the country. Matti Härmä, a church builder from Liminga Ängeslevä, led its construction. The church is a western-tower pillar church with only one pair of pillars, making it one of the smallest of its type.

The church's 26-meter-high tower once served as a navigation aid for seafarers. The walls and vault feature paintings by Mikael Toppelius from 1785-1795. The belfry was constructed in 1768-1769. Today, the old church, the belfry, and the new church built in the 1990s, create a historically complex group of buildings.

name: Keravan kirkko
description:
Kerava Church, located in Kerava, Finland, was designed by architect Ahti Korhonen and completed in 1963. The church serves as the main church for the Kerava parish. It has approximately 500 seats.

The building has an asymmetrical floor plan, with the altar on the longest wall. A concrete bell tower and sacristy are situated at one corner of the church. Oak is used in the interior to contrast the concrete. The church covers an area of 900 square meters. The altar features a metal relief called "God's Power" designed by Kauko Räsänen, acquired in 1977. Additionally, there is a stained glass window by Lauri Ahlgrén titled "Crown of Thorns".

The church's 25-stop organ was originally built in 1963. The church was renovated in 1993, during which the organ and interior were updated. For the church's 40th anniversary, textile artist Maisa Kaarna designed a tapestry called "Promise," which hangs above the pulpit. The interior also includes a missionary candleholder designed by the church's architect, Ahti Korhonen.

name: Kerimäen kirkko
description:
Kerimäki Church is the largest wooden church in the world, located in Kerimäki, Finland, near the shore of Lake Puruvesi. Designed by Anders Fredrik Granstedt, it was built between 1844 and 1847. The church is a double-cross church, with a length of 45 meters, a width of 42 meters and a height of 37 meters.

It can seat over 3,000 people, and accommodate around 5,000 people in total. There were rumors about the church being a miscalculation and built in inches instead of centimeters, but it was actually intended to be that big to accommodate half of the area's population. During the winter, services are held in a smaller "winter church" because the main building is not heated. The church also has a 42-meter-high belfry with two bells.

name: Keski-Porin kirkko
description:
The Central Pori Church is the largest church in Pori, located near the city center, next to the Kokemäki River. The church was built between 1859 and 1863 and consecrated on New Year's Day in 1864. Architecturally, it represents Neo-Gothic style, while the interior is in the National Romantic style. It was designed by Carl Johan von Heideken and Georg Theodor Chiewitz.

The church is a long church with a tower at the end, and a sacristy apse protruding from the chancel end. The church is built of brick and is one of the first Neo-Gothic churches in Finland. The walls are articulated by large, pointed arch windows and high pillars extending above the eaves. The three-nave church building is 65 meters long and about 30 meters high from its body. The tower, designed by Georg Theodor Chiewitz, is unique.

name: Kestilän kirkko
description:
Kestilä Church is a cross-shaped church located in the Siikalatva municipality. Construction of the church began in March 1854, and it was consecrated on August 24, 1856. The church was designed by architect Ernst Lohrmann and built by Mikko Karjalahti.

The church has an unusual design where the north and south crosses are a little over half the length of the east and west crosses. This design allows all the pews to face the altar. The church can accommodate 400 people. In the lobby there is a statue of a poor man, carved in 1895 by Juho Myllyoja. The old 6-voice organ was made in 1908.

name: Kesälahden kirkko
description:
Kesälahden kirkko is located in Kapankangas, in the former municipality of Kesälahti, now part of Kitee. The church was designed by architects Aili and Niilo Pulkka and completed in 1950, replacing a wooden church destroyed in the war. The old church's bell tower, built by Matti Petrell in 1770, still stands.

The church has approximately 450 seats, with additional space available in the parish hall. The mechanical organ with 23 stops was made in 1984. The church also features a copy of Albert Edelfelt's painting in the old parish hall, and the crucifix on the altar was made by Leo Karppanen. The altar is from 1997. The churchyard includes a war memorial designed by Heikki Häiväoja.

name: Keuruun vanha kirkko
description:
The Old Church of Keuruu, located by the Lapinsalmi, is the third church of the Keuruu parish, built between 1756 and 1759. Antti Hakola from Ala-Härmä served as the master builder. It's the oldest church in Central Finland.

The church represents 18th-century wooden church architecture and retains its original features well. The red-painted, shingle-roofed structure has short transepts connected to its long church layout. The church's interior showcases paintings by Johan Tilén from 1782-1785. The churchyard surrounding the church was a filming location for the movie "Vaivaisukon morsian" (1944).

name: Kihniön kirkko
description:
Kihniö Church is a wooden long church located in Kihniö, built between 1915 and 1917. The church was designed by architect Ilmari Launis. On the altar end of the church, there is a sacristy, which is slightly lower than the rest of the church building. At the opposite end, there are small vestibules on both sides through which the church is entered.

Inside, the church has three naves. The ceiling of the central nave is folded, but the side naves have flat ceilings. The church's interior painting and lighting were renovated in the autumn of 2000. The altarpiece was painted by Germund Paaer and is titled "I Stand at the Door and Knock".

name: Kiikalan kirkko
description:
Kiikalan Church, located in Kiikala, Salo, is a wooden church built in 1859. It is the third church of the Kiikala parish.

The church represents the Neo-Gothic style featuring a long church design with a tower. The three-part bell tower dates back to 1800, and when the current church was completed, the bells were moved to the church's western tower.

A major renovation took place in 1932, which included paintings by Bruno Tuukkanen decorating the gallery railings. The altar is wooden with a Neo-Gothic frame, and above it is a gable with a gilded sun. The altarpiece, painted by Berndt Lagerstam in 1906, depicts the Transfiguration of Christ.

name: Kiikan kirkko
description:
Kiikan Church, located in Sastamala, is a wooden cross-shaped church built in 1807. The church was constructed based on drawings from the Stockholm Intendent Office and led by Mats Åkergren. Over time, the church has undergone several renovations and alterations.

In 1884, a new Gothic Revival bell tower was erected, replacing the old belfry, and its lower section was converted into a mortuary. A major renovation was completed in 1952, which included a complete renovation of the interior according to Bertel Strömmer's plans, and the main tower received its current shape.

The church's original and current color is red, although it was yellow or gray for nearly a century. The altarpiece, painted by Alexandra Såltin in 1884, depicts the Transfiguration of Christ. Carl Fredrik Blom painted 36 biblical figures on the gallery railings in 1819.

name: Kiikoisten kirkko
description:
Kiikoisten Church, located in Kiikoinen, Sastamala, is a wooden, empire-style cross church. It was designed by architect Pehr Johan Gylich and completed in 1851, being consecrated in 1853. The church features a bell tower with two bells, situated at the western end. The interior is covered by wooden vaults.

A renovation in 1924 included raising the bell tower by nine meters. The altarpiece, painted by Felix Frang in 1924, depicts Jesus praying in the Garden of Gethsemane. The church also houses a 14-stop pneumatic organ manufactured by Kangasala organ factory in 1924.

name: Kiimingin kirkko
description: Kiiminki Church is located in the Kiiminki district of Oulu, near the Kiiminkijoki River. The church was built in 1760 and designed by Matti Honka. It is a well-preserved example of Ostrobothnian wooden church architecture from the late 1700s. The church has a cruciform floor plan with beveled outer corners. The roof is relatively gentle and covered with shingles. Inside the church, the ceiling is a barrel vault with a round "heavenly sphere". The choir wall features a triptych painted by Mikael Toppelius. The churchyard is surrounded by an old cemetery and has a bell tower completed in 1777, built by Pentti Paso.

name: Killinkosken kirkko
description:
Killinkosken kirkko is located in the village of Killinkoski, in Virrat. This wooden church was designed by Josef Stenbäck, Finland's most famous church architect, and completed in 1928. It was commissioned by the Killinkoski Prayer House Association and later donated to the Virrat parish in 1977.

The church is one of Stenbäck's few wooden churches, as he strongly believed that churches should primarily be built of stone, especially granite. However, he agreed to design the Killinkoski church out of wood because he was related to the founder of the local ribbon factory. It was also the last church Stenbäck designed. The church combines elements of Jugend, National Romanticism, and Neo-Gothic styles. The church has 150 seats and a 6-stop organ built in 1963.

name: Kinnulan kirkko
description:
Kinnula Church is a wooden cross church located in Kinnula, built during the great famine years from 1864 to 1867. Otto Korkiakoski from Sievi constructed the church. It has 400 seats.

At the intersection of the cross arms, there is a higher, sharp-edged section, and the arms have gentle saddle roofs. The tower at one end is square-shaped and has a folded roof. Inside, the church has a flat ceiling in the center and vaulted ceilings in the arms.

The church's altarpiece, "The Resurrection of Jesus," was painted by Esko Töyrylä in 1950. The church bell dates back to 1666. The church has been renovated several times, including in 1916, 1939, 1962, and 1974.

name: Kirkkonummen kirkko
description:
The Kirkkonummi Church, also known as St. Michael's Church, is a medieval stone church located in the center of Kirkkonummi. Its construction likely began in the 15th century. The church has been expanded several times over the centuries, and it acquired its current cross-shaped form in the mid-19th century.

During the Porkkala period (1944-1956), when the area was leased to the Soviet Union, the church was used as an officer's club and warehouse, resulting in considerable damage. After the area was returned to Finland, the church's interior was renovated in the 1950s under the direction of architect Olof Hansson. The church is known for its extensive collection of glass paintings by Lennart Segerstråle, created in the 1930s.

name: Kiskon kirkko
description:
Kisko Church is located in Salo. The current church, the fourth on the site, was inaugurated in 1810. A stone sacristy remains from the medieval church.

The church is an octagonal wooden church built after a previous cross church burned down in 1807. Johan Sundsten, a city architect from Turku, designed the church based on drawings obtained from Stockholm. The medieval stone sacristy is the only remaining part of the medieval church project, likely built between 1510 and 1530.

name: Kiteen kirkko
description:
The Kitee Church, often called the "stone church," belongs to the Central Karelia Parish. Located in the center of Kitee, this gray stone long church was designed by architect Frans Sjöström and completed in 1886. It was consecrated in 1887.

Unfortunately, the church's interior was destroyed by fire later the same year and it wasn't reopened until 1890 after three years of restoration. The church has 1500 seats. The church and the nearby parsonage are among the nationally significant built cultural environments defined by the Finnish Heritage Agency.

Next to the church is the Empire-style Great Parsonage. The window and door openings of the Kitee natural stone church are bricked with red brick, as are the roof list and other decorative motifs.

name: Kitinojan kyläkirkko
description:
Kitinojan kyläkirkko is a church located in Kitinoja, Ylistaro, Seinäjoki. Designed by architect Kauno S. Kallio, it was built in 1952 mainly through local villagers' work and donations. The church and the adjacent cemetery are owned by the Kitinoja Village Church Association, while the Seinäjoki parish rents the church.

The rectangular church has a saddle roof and a roof rider at the end. Inside, the church has seating for 250 people. It's known for its good acoustics, making it a popular recording venue for choirs and orchestras. The church also has a parish hall and a kitchen in the basement. The current altar painting, depicting Jesus blessing children in the Kitinoja landscape, was painted and donated by Professor Veikko Vionoja.

name: Kittilän kirkko
description:
Kittilä Church, located in the village of Kittilä, was completed in 1831 and designed by C.L. Engel. Originally built as a long church, it was expanded into a cruciform church based on Julius Basilier's plans between 1886 and 1887, when the tower was also raised. The interior dates back to 1986.

The church is one of the few buildings in the village that survived the Lapland War in 1944–1945 when retreating Germans destroyed much of the area. It is the oldest remaining building in Kittilä. The altarpiece, depicting Jesus on the Cross, was painted in 1831 by Johan Gustav Hedman and donated by Johan Abraham Stjernschantz. The church seats approximately 550 people.

name: Kiukaisten kirkko
description: Kiukaisten Church, also known as St. Michael's Church, is a wooden cross church built in 1761. It's located in Eura, in the former municipality of Kiukainen, specifically in the central village of Eurakoski. The church underwent an expansion in 1846. The altarpiece was painted by the court painter Felix Frang. The church was originally built under the direction of Job Höckert, a parish clerk from Lapin. The expansion was based on drawings by P.J. Gyllich. In 1989, religious stained-glass art was added around the altarpiece.

name: Kiuruveden kirkko
description:
The Kiuruvesi Church was designed by architect Bertel Liljequist in 1938. Construction began the following year but was interrupted by the Winter War. Work resumed immediately after the war, and the church was provisionally opened in Advent 1940. Bishop Eino Sormunen consecrated it on May 25, 1941.

The church features a mosaic altarpiece by Uuno Eskola, donated in 1953. The mosaic depicts Christ and two criminals at Golgotha and is made of stones collected from Italy. The church also has stained-glass windows in the choir area. The main organ, made by Kangasala organ factory in 1978, has 34 stops. There is also a smaller 8-stop organ and a piano in the church hall. The church has about 900 seats.

name: Kivijärven kirkko
description:
Kivijärvi Church is a wooden cross church located in Kivijärvi. It was designed by architect Theodor Decker. The church has 950 seats, and a large tower rises from the center of the cross-shaped building. A separate, two-part bell tower dates back to 1824.

The church's altar painting, depicting Peter denying Jesus, was painted by Carl Bengts in 1931. The first church in Kivijärvi was built in the 17th century, with a second wooden cross church constructed in 1778 by Jaakko Suonperä. The current church was built under the direction and interior work of Jaakko Kuorikoski, who also built the church's bell tower 50 years earlier.

name: Kivilahden rajaseutukirkko
description: The Kivilahden rajaseutukirkko is located in the village of Kivilahti in Ilomantsi. It's a wooden long church without a tower, designed by architect Toivo Pelli and built in 1954. The church has a floor area of 134 square meters and provides seating for 120 people. The altarpiece features a wooden crucifix sculpted by Uuno Poikonen. In 1969, a separate bell tower was constructed, housing a bell that originated from the Lavansaari church. Next to the church is the Kivilahden parsonage, which can be rented for celebrations and memorial services.

name: Kivistön kirkko
description:
Located in Kivistö, Vantaa, Kivistö Church is a red-brick church completed in 1967. Architects Raili and Kalevi Hietanen designed it. The church is near a residential area and close to the new Kivistö area and train station.

The church accommodates 150 people. The two-part altarpiece was painted by Sakari Marila; a cross that previously served as the altarpiece is now on the back wall of the church hall. The Vantaankoski parish operates the church, and it is popular, especially among families with children.

name: Klamilan kirkko
description:
Klamilan Church is a village church located in the village of Klamila in Virolahti. The wooden church was designed by architect Veli Klami and completed in 1955. The church hall has 200 seats, and the building includes a club room.

The history of Klamila Church dates back to the 1920s when the Klamila Prayer House Association was founded to raise funds for building its own church due to the long distance to Virolahti Church. Inflation eroded the value of the collected funds, and the parish of Virolahti eventually financed the construction of the church. Veli Klami designed the building free of charge, and merchant Juho Klami donated the land. The church was built through volunteer work using timber donated from the local area and was consecrated in November 1955.

name: Klaukkalan kirkko
description:
Klaukkala Church, completed in 2004, is a modern, copper-plated church in Klaukkala, Nurmijärvi. Designed by Anssi Lassila, the church's architecture was inspired by the image of Christ as a rock, aiming for a strong and stable presence. Its distinctive exterior houses bright, white spaces filled with community life. The church serves as a multi-purpose building, hosting services, activities for all ages, concerts, and gatherings.

The unique design of the church has garnered both praise and less flattering nicknames over the years, but it has become an important part of the village's identity. Inside, light streams in through a roof window above the altar. The church also received an honorable mention in the "Concrete Structure of the Year" competition.

name: Kodisjoen kirkko
description:
The Kodisjoki Church is a wooden church located in Kodisjoki, Rauma. It was built in 1906, and designed by Johan Frederik Lindegren, an organist from Rauma. The church has a traditional long church design with a western tower and a gable roof.

Inside the church, there is art by Edwin Lydén, a painting called "The appearance of the Risen Christ to Mary Magdalene". There is also a sculpture of Christ by Väinö Ylönen on the altar. The current 10-stop organ was built in 1991. The church has seating for approximately 250 people.

The church is surrounded by a cemetery that includes a war heroes' memorial. Next to the church is the Kodistupa parish hall, built in 1992, offering space for various activities. The church is owned and managed by the Kodisjoki sermon hall congregation.

name: Koijärven kirkko
description:
Koijärvi Church is a wooden long church with a gable tower, located in Koijärvi, Forssa. It was built between 1920 and 1922 according to the drawings of forester Mauno Kallio, originally as a community hall. The tower was added in 1923, and the church was consecrated on December 16 of the same year.

The church hall has a single nave and a flat wooden ceiling. The church has a surface area of 315 square meters and seats approximately 250 people. The church's 10-voice organs were manufactured by Kangasala organ factory in 1968. The altarpiece "Jesus in Gethsemane," painted by artist Elias Muukka, was donated in 1924. The church's two bells were cast in Yaroslavl and purchased from a former Russian military church in Tammisaari.

name: Koikkalan kirkko
description:
Koikkala Church, located in Juva, was built in 1959 and designed by architect Martti Välikangas. The church is a rectangular, plastered brick building. It has a saddle roof with differently elevated slopes.

The church has a floor area of 373 square meters and provides seating for 200 people. Adjacent to the church hall, there is a parish hall, a kitchen, and a club room. There is sound equipment in the church hall, but not in the other rooms. The church also features a separate bell tower and a cross on the altar. Services are held there once a month.

name: Koivulahden kirkko
description:
Koivulahden kirkko is a wooden church located in Koivulahti, Mustasaari. It was built between 1691 and 1693 by Hans Larsson Qweflander, a local peasant. Originally, it was a long church without a tower, featuring a hipped roof, a faceted gable, and a large staff with a ball finial on the roof ridge.

In 1795, the church was expanded and renovated according to drawings made in 1793. It was transformed into a cross-shaped church by moving the western part of the nave further out, adding new hipped-roof cross arms. The interior is covered by wooden barrel vaults. The church has been renovated several times, and a bell tower in the Ostrobothnian style, dating back to 1757, stands near the church.

name: Kokemäen kirkko
description:
Kokemäki Church, also known as the Church of Gustav III, is located in the central town of Kokemäki, in Tulkkila. It was completed in 1786. Designed by architect C. F. Adelcrantz, the stone church was originally built as a long church, but was expanded into its current cruciform shape in 1886. The church is named after King Gustav III.

The Kokemäki church represents the Gustavian style and was rare in Finland at the time of its completion. The church's hall is approximately 12x38 meters in size. The tower, located on the west end, is about 18 meters high. It has a baroque-style dome and lantern.

To the west of the church is a cemetery. The surrounding area includes a former parish magazine from the 1830s and a mortuary built in 1886. The Kokemäki church environment is one of the Finnish Heritage Agency's nationally significant built cultural environments.

name: Kokkolan kirkko
description: Kokkola Church, also known as De Profundis, was designed by architect Aarne Nuortila. It is a brick church located in the center of Kokkola. Consecrated in December 1960, the church has 1200 seats. Inside, there is a main hall, an organ loft, and a children's play area separated by glass walls. The church also features a 50-stop organ built by Åkerman & Lundin and a stained-glass window depicting fishermen by Urpo Wainio. The church is the main church of the Finnish congregation of Kokkola, hosting services every Sunday in Finnish and Swedish, as well as other religious events and concerts. Recent renovations have updated the church's technology and functionality, with a renewed entrance hall and a multipurpose space created from the former children's room.

name: Kolarin kirkko
description: Kolari Church, located in the village of Kolari, was completed in 1965 and designed by architect Veikko Larkas. Its exterior resembles a Lappish hut ("kota"). The church has seating for about 400 people. Inside, you'll find a 15-stop organ manufactured by Kangasala organ factory in 1977. The altar painting, depicting Jesus visiting a family in Kolari, was painted by Urpo Wainio in 1965. Adjacent to the church is a parish hall and office building, constructed in 1983.

name: Kolarinsaaren kirkko
description:
Kolarinsaari Church, also known as the old church of Kolari, is a church belonging to the Kolari parish in the Diocese of Oulu. The almost cube-shaped wooden church was built in 1818–1819, designed by A. W. Arppe. Next to the church is a bell tower of the same style.

The Finnish Heritage Agency has designated the old church and bell tower as one of Finland's nationally significant built cultural environments. The altar painting, depicting the Savior on the Cross, was painted by Johan Gustav Hedman in 1832. The church is located on the southern tip of Kolarinsaari, near the center of Kolari. The church is used in the summertime for special events and on Christmas Eve.

name: Konginkankaan kirkko
description:
The Konginkangas Church is a wooden church located in Konginkangas, Äänekoski. It was completed in 1866. The church was designed and built by Jaakko Kuorikoski and his son Lauri Heikki Kuorikoski. It represents one of the last churches in Finland constructed by folk builders, without formal architect training.

The church's style resembles those of Kaustinen and Evijärvi. A renovation in 1899, led by county architect Karl Viktor Reinius, altered the roof of the cross center to a more conventional design. Alexandra Frosterus-Såltin painted the altarpiece, "Christ on the Cross," in 1912. The church organ, built in 1981 by Kangasala organ factory, has 16 stops. The most recent renovation occurred in 1992–1993, which included renewing the exterior roofs and painting the exterior walls and interior spaces.

name: Konneveden kirkko
description:
Konnevesi Church, completed in 1923, is the only grey granite church in Central Finland. Designed by architect Ilmari Launis, it's located about 2 kilometers from the center of Konnevesi along highway 69 towards Kuopio. The three-nave church features a higher central nave.

Inside, the altar painting "Taakankantajat" (Burden Carriers) by Urho Lehtinen, acquired in the 1950s, is a prominent feature. Lehtinen also created the paintings related to the Ten Commandments on the side nave galleries. Pauli Koskinen's sculptures depicting local livelihoods adorn the pillar recesses. The church textiles are designed by Professor Päikki Priha. The round windows in the roof area, choir, and side naves feature colorful stained glass. The church also has two sets of organs.

name: Korian kirkko
description: Korian kirkko is a church located in Kouvola. Designed by Yrjö Vaskinen, it was completed in 1951. The church is part of the Elimäki parish of the Kouvala parish association. The church building is made of brick and the walls are plastered. The church hall has seating for 400 people. A parish hall wing was built in connection with the church in 1976. For a long time, an organ harmonium was used as the organ, but it has been replaced by an electric church organ. The altarpiece, depicting the Savior in Gethsemane, was painted by Robert Wilhelm Ekman in 1871. The altarpiece was formerly the altarpiece of the Elimäki church and was moved to the Korian kirkko in 1978.

name: Korpilahden kirkko
description:
Korpilahti Church, located in Jyväskylä, is a wooden church that belongs to the Korpilahti parish. The church sits high on a hill in Korpilahti, near the northern shore of Kirkkolahti, a narrow part of Lake Päijänne. Completed in 1827, it is the third church built in Korpilahti.

Designed by A.W. Arppe and approved by Carlo Bassi, the ochre-yellow church is a centrally emphasized cross church. Inside, the church features paintings of prophets, apostles, and holy women on the edges of the galleries, created by Blom. The altarpiece, "Come to Me, All Who Labor," was painted by Professor Wiljo Sjöström in 1904-1905. The churchyard has been the location of previous churches and the congregation's cemetery.

name: Korppoon kirkko
description:
Korppoo Church is a medieval stone church, considered one of Finland's most beautiful. It reflects the wealth and maritime connections of the early permanent settlement in the outer archipelago. The church is located on the western shore of the main island of Korppoo, forming the center of the village at a crossroads.

The rectangular church has a massive tower at its western end, decorated with brick-lined niches and rectangular light openings. The chancel is narrower than the nave on the south side. Inside, the single-nave church hall features star vaults supported by pilasters. The vaults and south wall are adorned with primitive nautical-themed paintings. A unique 15th-century wooden rood screen separates the nave from the chancel. The west tower likely served as a sea marker and beacon.

name: Korsnäsin kirkko
description:
Korsnäs Church is a wooden church located in the municipality of Korsnäs. Designed by Carl Ludvig Engel, a German-born architect, it was constructed in 1831 under the direction of Heikki Kuorikoski. The church has a cruciform shape.

The belfry dates back to 1747 but received its current appearance around 1860. The church and rectory were built simultaneously in the 1830s. The plans for the church were made in the Intendentinkonttori, a design office, by C.L. Engel and A.W. Arppe. The altar is exceptionally placed in the center of the church, at the corner of the cross arms.

name: Korson kirkko
description:
Korson kirkko is a church located in Korso, Vantaa. It is an asymmetrical long church, originally built in 1962 based on the design of Olli Kuusi. The church hall narrows towards the altar in the west. A lower wing building, which includes the parish hall, is connected to the main structure.

The church has undergone renovations, with a redesign completed in 2001 by Jari Frondelius and Jaakko Keppo. Korson kirkko also features a unique rotating altarpiece with different styles by various artists displayed at different times of the church year. The address of the church is Merikotkantie 4, and it is located near the Korso train station.

name: Kortepohjan kirkko
description:
Kortepohja Church was completed in 1974 and is located near the Kortepohja shopping center. Architecturally, it represents the element construction style of the 1970s, and it was designed by Antti Eskelinen. In 1975, Uuno Poikonen created the church's altar relief, which is named "Ylösnousemus" (Resurrection).

The church hall can accommodate 200 people. The church does not have its own parking area, but cars can be parked in the nearby shopping center's parking lot. The building suffered from moisture damage and was out of use for renovations from December 2007 to September 2010, during which time the church was practically rebuilt. During the renovation, most of the premises were separated and rented to the City of Jyväskylä's disability services.

name: Kortesjärven kirkko
description:
Kortesjärvi Church, located in Kortesjärvi, Kauhava, is a church designed by Jacob Rijf. The church was built around 1792 and consecrated in 1794. It is an equal-armed, internally beveled cross church. From the center of the cross, a polygonal tower rises from a low base, which got its current shape in the second half of the 19th century.

The church represents the Gustavian neoclassicism style. The altar is located in the eastern part, behind which is the sacristy. The pulpit is likely made by Jacob Rijf himself and is decorated with numerous angel heads.

An old cemetery surrounds the church. A separate wooden bell tower dates back to 1855. The churchyard also includes a loan granary built of logs in 1846, which is now used as a museum.

name: Kosken kirkko
description:
Kosken Tl Church, consecrated in 1935, was designed by architect Toivo Paatela. The church represents the architectural style of the 1930s neoclassicism. It's a long church with a tower at the end.

Inside, the unadorned church hall features paintings by Bruno Tuukkanen on the walls, the pulpit, and the organ loft railing. The altarpiece was painted by C.G. Söderstrand from Turku. The church is located in a scenic spot amidst a park-like pine forest. The belfry, built in 1777 under Mikael Piimänen, stands separately from the current church in the old cemetery along the Hämeen Härkätie road.

name: Kosken kirkko
description: The Koski Tl Church, also known as Kosken kirkko, is located in Koski Tl, Finland. The church was designed by architect Toivo Paatela and inaugurated in 1935. It represents the architectural style of the 1930s. The church is a longitudinal church with a tower at the end, primarily constructed from concrete. The interior features paintings by Bruno Tuukkanen on the walls, pulpit, and organ gallery railing. The altarpiece, a two-part painting, was created by C.G. Söderstrand from Turku and originates from the previous church of the parish. A separate bell tower, built in 1777 under the direction of Mikael Piimänen, stands on the old church grounds.

name: Koskenpään kirkko
description:
Koskenpää Church, located in the village of Koskenpää in Jämsä, is a wooden long church designed by builder Erkki Allenius. The church represents the Neo-Gothic style. Construction took place gradually from 1896 to 1911.

The church lacks a tower but features symmetrically placed small side sacristies. The exterior details, such as the decorative carvings on the door and window boards, are considered Swiss-style. The altar painting, "Jesus Blesses the Children," was painted by Aukust Koivisto in 1915. The church can accommodate approximately 300 people.
