The church underwent interior renovations in 1922 and again in 1952, which involved changes to the support pillars, gallery railings, entrance, and altar.

name: Koskuen kirkko
description: Koskuen kirkko is located in the village of Koskue, in the municipality of Kurikka. Built in 1912, it originally served as a prayer room before becoming a church in the 1940s. The church was constructed through communal work. Inside, the altarpiece is "The Crucified," painted by Mikael Toppelius in 1804. This altarpiece was moved from the Jalasjärvi church in 1906. The churchyard also has a separate bell tower that was built in 1958. The church has 350 seats.

name: Kotkan kirkko
description: Kotkan kirkko, located in the center of Kotka, is a red-brick church built between 1897 and 1898. Designed by Josef Stenbäck, it represents the Neo-Gothic style. The church features a prominent steeple and a spacious interior with approximately 1,500 seats. Inside, pillars support a gallery level, dividing the hall into three naves. Stained glass windows adorn the choir, and the sides of the church feature rose windows composed of over 2,000 pieces of glass. The 54-meter-high tower has a clock. The church is surrounded by a park-like plot, which includes a war veterans' memorial area. The altar is painted by Pekka Halonen.

name: Kouvolan keskuskirkko
description:
The Kouvolan Keskuskirkko is a modern church located in the center of Kouvola. It was designed by Jaakko and Kaarina Laapotti, completed in 1977, and consecrated in 1978. The church represents modern architectural style with constructive elements. The main structure consists of steel trusses, and the facade is made of aluminum and steel.

Inside, white bricks are used, and the ceiling has reinforced concrete elements. The hall has 700 seats. The altarpiece, created by Jaakko Laapotti, is a metal composition placed on the wall's structural grid, featuring red symbols on a white background, symbolizing Jesus and his apostles. After the central church was built, the Kouvola parish handed over its former main church to the Orthodox parish of Hamina.

name: Kristiinankaupungin uusi kirkko
description: Kristiinankaupunki's "new" church, completed in 1897, is a red-brick church designed by architect Johan Jacob Ahrenberg. It stands as a prominent landmark with its 47-meter tower and can accommodate around 1,000 parishioners. The church represents late Gothic Revival style featuring a gable tower and a short transept. The tower has small round towers on its sides. The church hall is divided into three naves; the central nave has a pitched roof supported by columns, while the side naves have flat ceilings. The altar is adorned with a painting of the Resurrection by Lorentz Gottman from 1736. The church windows were donated in 1928.

name: Kristuskyrkan
description:
Kristuskyrkan, or Church of Christ, is located in Helsinki, specifically in Etu-Töölö, at the corner of Fänrik Ståls Street and Apollonkatu Street. It belongs to the Swedish Methodist Church of Finland. Constructed in the Finnish neo-Gothic style, the church was built between 1926 and 1928, designed by architect Atte V. Willberg. Its 59-meter bell tower is a noticeable part of Helsinki's skyline.

Inside, above the main entrance, is a large rose window designed by Lennart Rafael Segerstråle, titled "Praise to Creation". The pipe organ, manufactured in Kangasala, has 15 stops and was designed so that the stained glass window behind it is visible. The church also features a fresco by Carl A H Ericsson symbolizing the tree of spiritual life.

name: Kruunupyyn kirkko
description:
The Kruunupyy Church was completed in 1822. The construction was started in 1799 based on drawings from the Swedish Board of Public Buildings, but the work was abandoned for unknown reasons for a few decades. Heikki Kuorikoski is mentioned as the one who completed the church. The church is most likely the fourth church in the village.

The church is a cruciform church with chamfered corners. Above the chapels and bevels is a large octagonal attic and on top of it a lantern. The exterior roofs of the chapels have gable roofs, and inside there are shallow wooden barrel vaults. The attic part has four small windows. Stylistically, the church belongs to the group of churches with chamfered corners and attics from the turn of the 18th and 19th centuries.

name: Kuhmalahden kirkko
description:
Kuhmalahti Church is a wooden long church located in Kuhmalahti, Kangasala. It was designed by architect Ernst Lohrmann to replace a church built in 1780 and demolished in 1848. The drawings were made in 1843, and the building was completed in 1846.

The church has a rectangular shape and a gabled roof. The facades of the Empire-style church are articulated by pilasters and two-story arched windows. The church hall has three flat-roofed naves separated by columns. The columns supported the stands of the side aisles, which were demolished in 1926. The belfry, which is connected to the previous wooden church, was built in 1780–1782.

name: Kuhmon kirkko
description:
Kuhmo Church is located in a beautiful spot by the Pajakkakoski rapids and the riverside promenade in Kuhmo. It's a large church, accommodating up to 1500 people, and serves as a place for worship and concerts. In the summertime, it functions as a wayside church.

The church was originally built in 1816, designed by Jacob Rijf in the neoclassical style. The bell tower was added later, in 1862, based on Carl Ludvig Engel's designs. The church suffered significant damage during the Winter War bombings and was restored to its current form in 1985. In 1999, a new 38-stop organ, representing the Nordic romantic style, was installed.

name: Kuhmoisten kirkko
description:
Kuhmoinen Church is located in Kuhmoinen, Pirkanmaa. It is a wooden cross church with inner bevels, built in 1784–1785 under the direction of Matti Åkerblom, one of the most significant church builders of his time. The church was named after the ruler of the time, Kustaa III.

The entire interior was renovated in 1932 according to the plans of architect Kauno S. Kallio. Artist Emil Filén created the gallery reliefs in 1935. The church was last renovated in 1986 according to the plans of architect Olli Kuusi. The wooden bell tower was constructed in 1786 by Mats (Matti) Åkergren.

name: Kuivaniemen kirkko
description:
The Kuivaniemi Church is located in the village of Kuivaniemi and belongs to the Ii parish. The church was designed by Ernst Bernhard Lohrmann in 1852, but its construction was completed after his death in 1872. The style is Neo-Gothic, and it is a long church with a western tower. It has approximately 500 seats.

The current church is the second one in Kuivaniemi. The first church was built in 1762. In the mid-1800s, it was deemed too small and unsafe, which led to the planning of a new church building. The altar painting, "Jesus Calming the Storm," was painted by Iivari Halttu in 1941. The original altar painting, a cross with a rose in the center, is behind the new painting. The smaller church bell dates back to 1762 and the larger one was cast in Kokkola in 1909.

name: Kuivannon kirkko
description:
Kuivannon Church, located in the village of Kuivanto in Orimattila, Finland, was completed in 1931. The church was designed by master builder Heikki Tiitola. The villagers had desired their own prayer room since the 1700s due to the long journey to the main church in Orimattila.

Adjacent to the church is a cemetery where villagers have found their final resting place. The cemetery also contains the graves of heroes who fell during 1939-45 and a memorial, as well as a grave and memorial to the victims of the Uudenkylä armory explosion in 1965. The church can accommodate approximately 160 people. Additionally, there is a parish hall connected to the church hall that can accommodate 35-40 people.

name: Kullaan kirkko
description: Kullaa Church is located in the village of Kullaa, in Ulvila, Finland. The church is a must-see stop in the Satakunta region. Kullaa is a former municipality of Finland which joined Ulvila in 2005. The chapel that belonged to Ulvila was founded in 1766. It separated into an independent church order in 1901, which was realized in 1920. Near the church is the Museum of Artifacts which contains a collection of items from the Stone Age, traditional farming equipment, and tools.

name: Kulosaaren kirkko
description:
Kulosaari Church, completed in 1935, is a Lutheran church situated in the Kulosaari suburb of Helsinki. Designed in the Jugendstil style by Bertel Jung, who also planned the urban layout of Kulosaari, the church is located atop the area's highest hill, earning it the local nickname "the Temple on the Hill." The belfry, designed by Armas Lindgren and completed in 1931, stands separately from the main building.

The church's interior features were designed by local artists. Antti Salmenlinna, Lindgren's son-in-law, created the ceiling and stained-glass window. Gunilla Jung, Bertel's daughter, designed the silver baptismal font, and Dora Jung, his niece, crafted the priest's chasuble. The church and its surroundings are protected by the Finnish Heritage Agency as a nationally significant cultural environment.

name: Kumlingen kirkko
description:
Kumlinge Church, dedicated to Saint Anna, is a single-nave hall church. The church's earliest mention dates back to a 1484 testament. It is thought that there may have been a chapel as early as the 15th century. The grey stone church was built around 1510. The church also features a Baroque-style onion dome and a bell tower constructed in 1767.

Kumlinge Church is known for its biblical-themed murals, painted shortly after its completion. The artist of these paintings is unknown, and similar paintings have not been found in other churches in Finland or Sweden. The church also houses an altarpiece from the 13th century, one of the oldest in Finland, and a wooden sculpture of the Virgin Mary and Child from the 15th century.

name: Kuokkalan kirkko
description:
Kuokkala Church is located in the district of Kuokkala in Jyväskylä. It was consecrated in February 2010. The church was designed by architects Anssi Lassila, Teemu Hirvilammi and Jani Jansson.

The exterior resembles medieval gray stone churches, with Spanish slate as the primary stone material. The interior is dominated by a unique roof structure made of Finnish spruce. The church's theme is the Bread of Life, reflected in the altarpiece by artist Pasi Karjula. A 25-meter-high bell tower stands in front of the church. The church organizes events for different age groups and is open during events or by appointment.

name: Kuopion tuomiokirkko
description:
Kuopio Cathedral, located on Vahtivuori hill in Kuopio, is the central church of the Kuopio diocese. It was inaugurated in 1816, though construction was delayed by wars. The cathedral is the fifth church on the "Kuopio peninsula," with the first being completed in 1552.

It is a significant landmark in Kuopio, holding a place in the hearts of generations. Approximately 100,000 people visit the grand, peaceful sanctuary every year, coming from both near and far.

name: Kuoreveden kirkko
description:
Kuorevesi Church, located in Jämsä, is a wooden long church built in 1779 by Matti Åkerblom. The church features a gable tower and a unique two-part onion dome on its bell tower, making it historically distinct. It is one of Finland's three sacrifice churches.

Inside, you'll find a sculpture by Ilmari Launis at the altar, replacing an older altarpiece. The church also houses a painting by Venny Soldan-Brofeldt called "Angel Takes the Soul to God." The second largest of the bell tower's three bells was donated by Queen Christina of Sweden in 1648 and is the oldest historical object in Kuorevesi. The church was repainted red in 1997 to restore its original color.

name: Kuortaneen kirkko
description: The Kuortane Church is a wooden cross church built in 1777 by Antti Hakola. The altar painting, depicting Jesus on the cross, was painted by H.A. Barkman. Next to the church stands a belfry, constructed in 1837 by Olof Häggblad, and is considered one of the most beautiful belfries in Finland. The gilded triangle is at the highest point of the structure. The altar structure and pulpit carvings were decorated by Heikki Mikkilä. The church and its surroundings are among Finland's nationally significant built cultural environments.

name: Kurikan kirkko
description: The Kurikka Church is located in the center of Kurikka and was built between 1845 and 1847. The plastered brick church was designed at the General Buildings Intendant's Office, but the builder, Erkki Kuorikoski, made changes to the approved plans. The church was completed in 1847 and the construction was done by Erik Kuorikoski. The two-part altarpiece from 1857 was painted by Johan Sacarius Blacstadius and depicts the crucifixion of Jesus and the institution of the Eucharist.

name: Kursun kirkko
description:
Kursu Church is a church located in the village of Kursu in Salla. It is a rectangular long church with a gable roof, built of wood in 1964. Iikka Martas designed it. The building functions as a village church and includes a parish center.

The church has an area of 500 square meters and seating for 225 people. A separate cone-shaped bell tower, open at the bottom, was built in the same year as the church, and its bell is also from 1964. The church also has a camp center with accommodation, a kitchen, and saunas. The camp center can host various camps, and accommodation is available for 30 people.

name: Kurun kirkko
description:
The Church of Kuru is a wooden church dating back to 1781. It was designed by Matti Åkerblom. The church is named after Kustaa Aadolf. The construction work was led by Matti Åkergren.

The church is a long church with side chambers on both sides. The belfry is connected to the church building. The tower's cupola shows influences from Dutch Renaissance and Italian Baroque styles. There are two bells in the belfry, the smaller of which was acquired in 1782 from Stockholm and the larger in 1821 from St. Petersburg.

The church is located by Lake Vankavesi. By the main door is a poor man statue made in 1936. The churchyard has a ten-oared church boat from 1877. The sacristy was built in 1848 to the east end of the church.

name: Kustavin kirkko
description:
Kustavi Church is a wooden cross-shaped church without a tower, built in 1783 by Johan Höckert. It's located in Kustavi, and it's one of Finland's five remaining 17th-century wooden cross churches. The church was originally built in 1676, and it was later moved to its current location.

Inside, the church features a wooden vaulted ceiling. The altarpiece, depicting the Holy Communion and the Crucifixion, was painted by Jonas Bergman in 1744. The pulpit dates back to the 1640s. Notably, the church also contains miniature ships, votive offerings from local islanders. The church environment is considered a well-preserved example of wooden architecture in Finland.

name: Kuusamon Pyhän Ristin Kirkko
description:
The Church of the Holy Cross in Kuusamo is a landmark representing the town's resilience. Designed by architect Bertil Liljeqvist, it was built between 1949 and 1950 with support from the United States, replacing a previous wooden church destroyed during the Lapland War. Consecrated in 1951, the church is a basilica-type long church, 48 meters long and 18.5 meters high.

Inside, the church can accommodate approximately 800 people. The east end features a sacristy, while the west end has a gallery for the organ. The bell tower houses bells dating back to the early 1700s. The churchyard includes a memorial to the old church, incorporating the original cross from the former bell tower, and a monument to fallen heroes sculpted by Mauno Juvonen.

name: Kuusankosken kirkko
description:
Kuusankosken kirkko, located in the heart of Kuusankoski, Kouvola, is the main church of the Kuusankoski parish. Designed by architect Armas Lindgren and completed in 1929, the church exhibits architectural influences from various periods. The interior features 1250 seats in the main hall and an additional 100 in the side gallery.

The church is known for its excellent acoustics and a 45-stop organ, making it a suitable venue for concerts. The altarpiece, "Jesus in Gethsemane," was painted by Alvar Cawén, and the stained-glass windows are by Antti Salmenlinna. Gunnar Finne designed the baptismal font in the chapel. The church also has a parish hall in the basement with a piano and kitchen, accommodating 25 people.

name: Kuusiston kirkko
description:
Kuusisto Church, located on Kuusisto Island in Kaarina, is a rectangular, single-nave wooden long church. The current church was built in 1792 on a high hill, which previously housed an older church building. The church belongs to the Kaarina parish.

The church is a short-cornered log building. The altar and its frames were made when the church was completed in the 1790s, when the pulpit also got its current appearance. Pillar-decorated wallpapers were found inside the walls during a restoration in 1974.

A separate wooden bell tower was built in 1763 and renovated in connection with the construction of the church. The churchyard is surrounded by a gray stone fence. The cantor's house is located near the church.

name: Kuusjoen kirkko
description:
Kuusjoen Church, located in Kuusjoki, Salo, is part of the Salo parish. It was originally built in 1823 as a prayer room. This wooden church is a long church without a tower, featuring lower side additions to the main structure.

In 1882, a wooden belfry was added, modeled after the old Uskela mother church's belfry. The church seats 350 people. Near the church is a stone storehouse dating back to 1927. The altarpiece, depicting the Transfiguration of Christ, was painted by Alexandra Frosterus-Såltin in 1909.

name: Kuusjärven kirkko
description:
Kuusjärvi Church, located in Outokumpu, is a Neo-Gothic long church with a tower at the end, built in 1878. It was designed by county architect Ferdinand Öhman. A transept protrudes from the long sides of the church near the choir end, and a narrower and lower sacristy from the choir end. The tower ends in a spire.

The main hall has a gable roof, and the church hall has a wooden arched ceiling as an interior covering. The church was renovated in 1926, 1949, 1953 and 1979. It has seating for 660 people. The church's 12-voice organ was manufactured by Kangasala organ factory in 1915. The altarpiece, "Christ Nailed to the Cross," was painted by Eino Härkönen in 1914. Dora Jung designed the church's altar vestments, which have been supplemented with textiles designed by Hanna Korvela. The church only got electric heating in 1983.

The church is mainly used in the summer, except for Christmas events.

name: Kylmäkosken kirkko
description: Kylmäkoski Church, located in Akaa, is affiliated with the Akaa Parish. Designed by architect H. R. Helin, the church was completed in 1900 and showcases national romantic architectural features. This red-brick church has two main aisles. The altarpiece was painted by Matti Petäjä, depicting "Come to me." The church organ, built in 1933 by Kangasala organ factory, has 16 stops. The church has 300 seats. A renovation of the church's roof was completed in 2012, and an interior renovation was completed in the spring of 2014.

name: Kymin kirkko
description:
Kymin Church, located in the Helilä district of Kotka, is a beautiful neoclassical stone church completed in 1850 and consecrated as St. John's Church in 1851. Designed according to the type drawings of the Finnish Intendant's Office under C.L. Engel, it is known for its clean, simple lines. The interior features a 14-meter-high hall adorned with Bohemian crystal chandeliers and a yellow color scheme.

The altarpiece, "Jesus in Gethsemane," was painted by Berndt Godenhjelm in 1865. The church bells were made in 1736 for the Forsby ironworks church in Pernaja and later acquired by Kymi. The church also has a 43-voice organ made by Bruno Christensen & Sonner in 1991. Surrounding the church is an old cemetery founded in 1729, featuring valuable memorial monuments and a park.

name: Kytäjän kirkko
description:
Kytäjän Church, located in the village of Kytäjä in Hyvinkää, is a charming example of high-quality architecture built by a local community. Designed by Väinö Vähäkallio, the owner of Kytäjä Manor at the time of construction, it stands along the old church road leading from Hyvinkää to Nurmijärvi.

The church, completed in 1939, is a light-colored plastered building with a gently sloping tile roof. A low wing containing the parish hall and a narrow bell tower are attached to the western end. The church hall is accessed through a barrel-vaulted entrance. The north wall features round windows at the top, while tall, round-arched windows provide light to the south side.

Inside, the church hall and entrance have herringbone-patterned brick floors. The central aisle is asymmetrical due to the sacristy's location on the north side of the chancel. The altarpiece is a crucifix. The church was given to the Hyvinkää parish in 1962.

name: Kyyjärven kirkko
description:
Kyyjärvi Church is a Lutheran church building located in Kyyjärvi, Central Finland. The church was designed by architect Veikko Larkas, who used drawings of the Värtsilä church as a reference. The church was built in 1953.

It is a long church without a tower, and the roof of the main building has a steep gable. The building's tall, white plastered end walls feature slate inlays. The church also houses a parish hall as well as club and scout space. The church has seating for approximately 210 people, with an additional 70 in the parish hall. Initially, the altar had only a large wooden cross, but in 1954, a bronze replica of the crucifix from the Myllykoski church was acquired.

name: Kälviän kirkko
description:
The Kälviä Church is located in Kälviä, which is now part of Kokkola, Central Ostrobothnia. The church was built in 1905 by the Kälviä congregation. Interestingly, the site has been home to two previous churches.

Externally, the church retains its original appearance. It's a symmetrical cruciform church with beveled outer corners, representing late Gothic Revival architecture, also known as Carpenter Gothic, due to its abundant decorative motifs. The church tower has a sharp spire and lantern-like structure. Inside, the church can accommodate approximately 700 people. The altarpiece is a Golgata-themed painting from the first church, painted by Jacob Söderman in 1729. The churchyard also features a belfry built in 1804, designed by Jacob Rijf and constructed by Heikki Kuorikoski. Beside the belfry door stands a poor man statue sculpted in 1820 by Erkki Lassila.

name: Käpylän kirkko
description:
Käpylä Church, completed in 1930, represents functionalist architecture. Designed by Erkki Ilmari Sutinen, its exterior is simple. The church hall is a streamlined cube with a tower at the entrance.

Inside, the round, red-colored choir is striking. High, square windows create a temple-like atmosphere, contrasting light and shadow. Bruno Tuukkanen's paintings, "The Good Shepherd" and "The Torch-Bearing Angel," adorn the red choir wall. Aarre Aaltonen's reliefs depicting biblical scenes decorate the hall. The church also features a side building and a courtyard inspired by monastic gardens.

name: Käpylän kirkko
description:
Käpylä Church, completed in 1930, is located in the Käpylä district of Helsinki. Designed by architect Eero Ilmari Sutinen, it represents functionalist architecture with classical features. The exterior is simple, while the interior features a straightforward hall dominated by a round, red-colored choir.

Inside the church hall, artist Bruno Tuukkanen's paintings, "The Good Shepherd" and "Angel Carrying a Torch," adorn the red choir wall. Sculptor Aarre Aaltonen created high reliefs depicting biblical themes on the upper parts of the walls and a gilded plaster angel on the pulpit. The church has a 22-stop mechanical organ built in 1977. A low bell tower rises from the entrance end of the building.

name: Kärkölän kirkko
description:
Kärkölä Church, located in Pusula, Lohja, is a wooden church completed in 1842. It was built as a village church during a time when there was only a narrow path from the village to the main church in Pusula.

The altar painting, originally painted in 1941 by Eeli Jaatinen for the Terijoki Church, depicts "Jesus Calming the Storm on the Sea of Galilee." While painting the artwork in the sacristy of the Terijoki Church, Jaatinen had to occasionally take shelter in the church cellar due to the proximity of the front line. Later, the residents and former villagers of Kärkölä organized a collection to purchase the painting from Jaatinen.

name: Kärkölän kirkko
description:
The Kärkölä Church in Pusula, Lohja, is a wooden church completed in 1842. It was built as a village church when there was only a narrow path from the village to the main church in Pusula.

The altar painting, originally painted for the Terijoki Church by Eeli Jaatinen in 1941, depicts "Jesus Calming the Storm on the Sea of ​​Galilee." Jaatinen painted the picture in the sacristy of the Terijoki church, and it was only in place for one service. During the war, while painting, the artist had to flee from grenades to the church cellar. Residents and former villagers organized a fundraiser and bought the painting from Jaatinen.

name: Kärsämäen kirkko
description:
Kärsämäki church was originally designed by Carl Ludvig Engel in 1828, but it wasn't constructed until 1842. However, there is also a modern shingle church named Paanukirkko located near the site of the original church by the Pyhäjoki river. Paanukirkko was completed in 2004 and designed by architect Anssi Lassila. It's a modern church constructed using 18th-century methods.

The building consists of a timber "heart" surrounded by a black tarred shingle "coat". It was built between 2000 and 2004 with both voluntary and paid labor, with funding from the European Union. The total construction cost was 1,181,040 euros. The church has an area of approximately 100 square meters and is one of the most significant sights in the municipality, attracting thousands of tourists annually.

name: Käylän rajaseutukirkko
description:
Käylän rajaseutukirkko is a wooden church located in Käylä, Kuusamo. Designed by Olli Vahtera, it was built in 1958. It's known as a "kotakirkko" due to its saddle roof. The church hall has a single nave, with the roof replacing the side walls, where the windows are placed.

The church has 140 seats. The original organ, made by Kangasala organ factory in 1971, had 6 stops. In 1991, a new organ with 16 stops, built by Veikko Virtanen's organ workshop, was inaugurated. The wooden altar sculpture, depicting the Savior on the Cross, was made by Uuno Poikonen in 1958.

A separate bell tower was built in 1977. The church also has a sacristy next to the altar, a Sunday school hall near the entrance, and accommodation, dining, and social facilities downstairs. In front of the church is a memorial to those buried in Paanajärvi cemetery between 1934–1944.

name: Kökarin kirkko
description:
Kökar Church, dedicated to Saint Anne, is located on the island of Hamnö. The current church was completed in 1784, built on the ruins of an old monastery church. The sacristy was built in 1876, but otherwise, the exterior of the church looks the same as it did 200 years ago.

Inside, the biggest change occurred in 1912 when an organ loft was built. The current organ was installed in 1992, when the old organ was moved to the Kökar Museum. The church has several objects from Kökar's old wooden church from the turn of the 17th and 18th centuries, including a large crucifix, an alms box, an old altarpiece, and a wooden pelican that hangs above the pulpit. The current altarpiece, dating from 1803, depicts the Eucharist. A votive ship from the old wooden church, an ornate wooden pirate ship with 64 cannons, also resides here. According to tradition, the ship is a scale model of a Turkish pirate ship built by a Kökar sailor, Johans Olle. In the front of the church is also a baptismal font from the early 13th century. It is said to have been found in the wall of the monastery church.

name: Köyliön kirkko
description:
Köyliö Church is located on Kirkkosaari (Church Island) in Lake Köyliö. Originally built in 1752 as a cruciform church with a small tower, it stands on the site of Köyliö's old cemetery, surrounded by ancient pine trees.

In 1890, the church underwent renovations, including changes to the windows, exterior, and interior cladding, and the addition of a tower on the western side, designed by architect Sebastian Gripenberg.

The church's interior suffered fire damage in 1978. According to the legend of Bishop Henry's murder, peasant Lalli killed Bishop Henry on the ice of Lake Köyliö in 1156, after the so-called First Crusade. The church and its surroundings form a valuable historical and scenic landscape.

name: Laajasalon kirkko
description:
Laajasalo Church, consecrated in 2003, is mainly a wooden church building in the Laajasalo district of Helsinki. It was designed by architects Kari Järvinen and Merja Nieminen. The church's facade is clad in patinated copper sheet and horizontal boarding. The structure rests on wooden beams.

The building was awarded in 2004 for high-quality wood construction and in 2005 with the Copper in Architecture award. Laajasalo Church is one of the three churches of the Roihuvuori parish. The church is located in the Yliskylä part of Laajasalo. The church's four bells were made in the Netherlands and are programmed to play melodies from hymns according to the church year.

name: Lahden Ristinkirkko
description:
The Church of the Cross in Lahti, Finland, is the main church of the city. Designed by the renowned architect Alvar Aalto, it represents one of his last architectural achievements, completed in 1978. The church is located in the heart of Lahti.

The building's exterior showcases a minimalist and somewhat brutalist style, primarily constructed with red brick. A prominent concrete belfry extends from the roof, reaching a height of 40 meters. In contrast, the interior features bright, white walls and expansive windows that allow ample natural light. The floor plan is based on an equilateral triangle. A distinctive feature is the southern elevation, where 52 small windows form a large cross. The church is known for its excellent acoustics, making it a popular venue for concerts and recordings.

name: Laihian kirkko
description: Laihian kirkko is a wooden cross-shaped church located in Laihia, Finland. It represents early Neoclassical style and was built between 1803 and 1805. The drawings were approved in Stockholm in 1797. A distinctive feature is that the church is one of about twenty in Finland where a rooster guards the tower. Unusually, the walls are not clad, but the interior surface consists of beautifully carved logs. The church has a hipped roof, with a wooden vault rounded at the ends as an inner ceiling. It has 1200 seats. The churchyard also features a war memorial.

name: Laitilan Pyhän Mikaelin kirkko
description:
Laitilan Pyhän Mikaelin kirkko, dedicated to St. Michael, is a medieval gray stone church built mainly between 1460 and 1483. The church stands out for its colorful decorative paintings, unique in Finland. The murals on the vaults include human-faced hybrid creatures and fantastical animals not found elsewhere in Finnish church art.

Inside the church, a crucifix dates back to the 15th century, and the pulpit from the 17th century. The church has undergone several restorations, with significant work done in the 1920s and the late 1960s to restore its medieval appearance. Today, it serves as a popular roadside church, welcoming visitors during the summer months.

name: Lakeuden Risti
description: Lakeuden Risti is a church in Seinäjoki, Finland, designed by Alvar Aalto. Construction took place from 1957 to 1959, and the church was inaugurated in 1960. It is located in the Aalto Center, near the town hall and library. The church is known for its 65-meter-high bell tower, which offers views of almost the entire city and is a popular tourist attraction. The building is protected by the Finnish Heritage Agency, as is the rest of the Aalto Center. The church's hall has 1,200 seats, with an additional 124 seats in the organ loft.

name: Lammin kirkko
description:
Lammi Church is a medieval gray stone church located in the center of Kirkonkylä in Lammi. The church is dedicated to Saint Catherine of Alexandria and was built in the 1510s. The church represents a late medieval intermediary style.

Inside, the church has a 28-voice organ manufactured by the Kangasala organ factory, installed in 1967. The church has 400 seats and can be rented for various events such as weddings, baptisms, funerals and concerts.

Christianity was likely known in Lammi as early as the 11th century. The first records of Lammi Church date back to the 1420s, and the Lammi administrative district is mentioned as early as 1374. The church was damaged by fire in 1692, destroying the pulpit and part of the church archives.

name: Langinkosken kirkko
description: Langinkoski Church is located in the Metsola district of Kotka. It was designed by architect A. O. Bengts and completed in 1953. The white church building resembles a medieval stone church in shape. Inside, the church has a rectangular shape. Next to the church rises a slender belfry. The walls are made of reddish-brown perforated brick. The altar, pulpit, and seats are made of natural-colored oak. A white cross dominates the altar wall. On the left wall is a glass painting by artist Hilkka Toivola-Karpakka. The church organ has seventeen stops. The church and the adjacent parish hall are accessible.

name: Lapin kirkko
description: Lapin kirkko, located in Rauma, Finland, is one of the oldest wooden churches in the region, dating back to 1760. It is a red, wooden church with approximately 500-650 seats. The bell tower, which was initially built next to the church by the cemetery's stone fence, was moved to a small hill in the early 19th century. Inside, instead of an altarpiece, there is a window with a stained-glass painting by Ilmari Launis from 1926. The pulpit dates back to the construction year of the church.

name: Lapinjärven kirkko
description:
The Lapinjärvi Church, also known as the Swedish Church, is located in the center of Lapinjärvi. It was built in 1744 by Jakob Beckman. The church has a cruciform shape and can accommodate approximately 450 people.

Adjacent to it is the smaller Finnish Church, built in the same year. The bell tower, designed possibly by C.I. Engel, stands between the two churches. The interior features a pulpit made in 1745 by Theito, a carpenter from Hamina. The churchyard contains a burial chapel of the Gylling family and graves of other notable figures. The church is open to visitors during the summer months.

name: Lapinjärven pikku kirkko
description:
The Lapinjärvi Little Church is the smaller of the two churches in Lapinjärvi, located next to the main Lapinjärvi Church. It is a square-shaped wooden church that can accommodate around 150 people. It was previously known as the Finnish Church.

The church was built in 1744 to replace a previous church that was destroyed in a fire in 1742. The pulpit is the work of Henrik Hofvenius, a carpenter from Myrskylä.

name: Lapinlahden kirkko
description: Lapinlahden kirkko is located in the center of Lapinlahti. It's a wooden long church with a western tower, designed by architect Frans Sjöström and built between 1877 and 1880. The church has a rectangular shape with a high tower in the west end. The style features decorations inspired by Neo-Gothic and Neo-Renaissance architecture. The interior space is divided into three naves by colonnades, with a angular wooden ceiling in the middle nave. The church can accommodate 1,250 people. The church has undergone several renovations since the early 1900s, with the most recent renovation in 2002, aiming to restore its original exterior and interior colors.

name: Lappajärven kirkko
description: The Lappajärvi Church is a Lutheran church in Lappajärvi, Finland, built in 1765. Matti Honka designed the wooden cross-shaped church. The adjacent bell tower was modified in the 1840s under Jaakko Kuorikoski's guidance. The church has approximately 500 seats. An eight-sided "lantern" structure tops the roof. The statue of a poor boy near the bell tower door was restored to its current form in 1841. A church boat from Itäkylä resides in the cemetery, serving as a reminder of the congregation's summer trips around the lake before modern transportation.

name: Lappeen Marian kirkko
description:
Lappeen Marian Church, located in the heart of Lappeenranta, is a Lutheran church dating back to 1794. This wooden double-cross church was built by Juhana Salonen and is a unique architectural example, being the only surviving double-cross church from the 18th century in Finland.

Inside, the church can accommodate around 840 people. The bell tower, which stands southwest of the church, is the only purely Neo-Gothic building remaining in Lappeenranta, completed in 1856. The altarpiece, painted in 1887 by Alexandra Frosterus-Såltin, depicts the Ascension of Jesus. The church is a nationally significant built heritage site.

name: Lappeenrannan kirkko
description:
Lappeenranta Church, consecrated on August 12, 1924, was originally built as an Orthodox garrison church. The red-brick church is situated in a valuable scenic location amidst the Nikolai fortifications.

Designed initially by Russian academician Georg Kosekoff for the needs of the adjacent Russian garrison, construction began in 1912, aiming for completion by the Romanov family's 300th anniversary in 1913. However, construction halted in August 1914 when garrison units moved to the front lines of World War I.

After Finland's independence, the unfinished church became state property. In 1919, the government donated it to the Lappeenranta parish for congregational and Christian purposes. Architect Josef Stenbäck initially planned the conversion into a Lutheran church. The altar painting, "Christ on the Cross," is by Ilmari Launis from 1924. The church represents typical Neo-Byzantine style and hosts services and concerts.

name: Lappohjan kirkko
description:
Lappohjan Church is located in the village of Lappohja in Hanko. The church was originally built as a prayer house for the Evangelical movement and was completed in 1913. In the 1980s, it began to be used as a church. The congregations of Hanko rented the building from 1980 and purchased it in 1982.

The church has about 130 seats. A separate meeting room can accommodate around 25 people. In 1914, the year after its completion, the prayer house was seized by Russian troops stationed in Hanko, and in 1918, German troops took control of it. The church was rededicated in 1984.

name: Lapuan tuomiokirkko
description:
Lapua Cathedral, designed by Carl Ludvig Engel, was completed in 1827. It serves as the main church for the Lapua Diocese. The church is known for housing the largest organ in Finland, featuring 85+6 stops. An organ festival is held every other year at the church.

The church seats approximately 1,300 people. Beside the church stands a bell tower that was completed in 1730. The churchyard contains memorials, including one for those who died in the Battle of Lapua in 1809, and a memorial to the Winter and Continuation Wars sculpted by Yrjö Liipola.

name: Lapväärtin kirkko
description:
Lapväärtin church, completed in 1851, is a brick church located in Lapväärtti, Kristinestad. Designed by German-born E.B. Lohrmann, it's known as one of the largest rural churches in Finland, accommodating approximately 3000 people.

The altarpiece is a copy of Leonardo da Vinci's "Last Supper" by Erik Johan Löfgren. The church has a 34-stop organ built in 1958 by Gebrüder Jemlich. A bell tower, predating the current church and built in 1771, was moved to its present location in 1853. The church is primarily used as a summer church from May to September and is also heated for major holidays.

name: Lassilan kirkko
description:
Lassilan Church is a wooden long church located in the village of Lassila, Noormarkku, Pori. It was designed by Matti Österlund and built between 1851 and 1854. The church has a floor area of 253 square meters and can seat 250 people. The sacristy and lobby are connected to the main building as low side wings.

The tower, which culminates in a dome, is unusually located at the front of the building and houses bells dating from 1851 and 1901. The interior ceiling of the saddle-roofed main building has a wooden vault. The church has been renovated in 1894, 1920, 1924 and 1976. The altar painting depicts Jesus, John and their mother. The church's seven-voice organ was manufactured by Kangasala organ factory in 1956. Originally the church was red, but the color was later changed to light. The exterior of the church was repainted in the summer of 2004.

name: Lattomeren kirkko
description: Lattomeri Church is located in Pori, about 10 kilometers south of the city center. It was originally built as a prayer room in 1900 and consecrated as a church in 1955. The former prayer house was expanded in 1921 and 1935. The L-shaped building features a two-section bell tower, which houses club facilities on its ground floor. The bell tower has two bells, both dating back to 1921. Inside, the church hall has a wooden arched ceiling and seats for 250 people. The altarpiece depicts Peter sinking into the water and was painted in 1921. Lattomeri Church belongs to the Western Pori parish.

name: Laukaan kirkko
description:
Laukaa Church, located in the center of Laukaa village, is an empire-style wooden church designed by Carl Ludvig Engel and Anton Wilhelm Arppe. Completed in 1835, the church can accommodate 800 people. The church features early Gothic Revival elements in its decorative moldings and pointed-arch windows.

Inside, the altar painting by R.W. Ekman depicts Christ on the Mount of Transfiguration. The church organ, boasting 36 stops, was manufactured by Kangasala organ factory in 1963. A separate bell tower, constructed under Heikki Kuorikoski's direction, dates back to 1823. The church's uppermost point features a lantern, offering panoramic views.

The most recent renovation took place in 2002, including painting the church inside and out, replacing the roof, installing a fire suppression system, renovating the sacristy, and building a bridal chamber in the entrance hall. The church also houses a church museum in the basement, showcasing the history of the Laukaa parish through artifacts, images, maps, drawings, and texts.

name: Laukkalan kirkko
description: Laukkalan kirkko is located in Pielavesi. It's a brick-built long church with a gable tower, representing the Neoclassical style, constructed between 1939 and 1940. The basilica-like body of the church has a gable roof, and a gradually narrowing tower rises from its end. The side aisles are narrower than usual. The main part of the church is plastered smooth and has a sloping roof. It was designed by builder Emil Ikäheimo. The church was renovated in 1957, and it has an area of 225 square meters with seating for 200 people. The church's 12+1 stop organ was made by Kangasala organ factory in 1957. The altar painting, Jesus in Gethsemane, was painted by Hilja Karola in 1945.

name: Launeen kirkko
description:
Launeen Church, located in Lahti, is a Lutheran church designed by architect Erik Lindroos. It was originally built as a parish center in 1953, but due to the growing congregation, it was expanded in 1958 with a bell tower and a larger church hall. The building was then consecrated as a church.

The church is constructed from light-rendered brick with a reddish-brown clay tile roof. An architectural survey describes the church as representing the "subtle, intimate architecture" of the 1950s. A recurring theme inside Launeen Church is the hourglass shape, which architect Lindroos used in the altar railing and pews. The church was renovated between 2000 and 2001.

name: Lauritsalan kirkko
description:
Lauritsalan Church, also known as "Taivaan valo" ("Light of Heaven"), is located in Lappeenranta. Architects Toivo Korhonen and Jaakko Laapotti designed the church, which was completed in 1969. The church has a unique equilateral triangle shape, which symbolizes the Holy Trinity.

The concrete roof was made using the slip-forming method and incorporates a large glass section. The windows on the altar wall stretch upwards towards the church's tower. Light floods the church through the windows in the end wall and roof, creating a bright and open atmosphere. The church's architecture represents modern construction methods.

name: Lauttasaaren kirkko
description:
Lauttasaari Church, completed in 1958, is a prominent landmark on Lauttasaari island. Constructed from sand-blasted white concrete, its design emphasizes natural light, streaming in through large windows. A striking feature is the monumental staircase leading to the church, flanked by boulder walls, and an inner court adorned with a boulder in a water pool.

The church's bell tower rises 67.5 meters above sea level, dominating the island's skyline. Inside, the aisle to the choir is paved with mottled marble from Lapland. Interior architect Ilmari Tapiovaara designed the interior, lighting, and communion set. Instead of a traditional altarpiece, a wooden cross by architect Petäjä stands. The church also features a Kangasala organ with 39 stops and textiles by Annikki and Ilmari Tapiovaara and artist Hilkka Vuorinen.

name: Lavian kirkko
description:
Lavian Church, completed in 1823, is located in Lavia, Pori. It is a symmetrical cruciform church made of wood, featuring a gable tower. Juha Köhlström designed and oversaw the construction. The church was initially built without an official permit, which was granted later.

The exterior was modified in the late 19th century, with Helge Rancken redesigning the upper part of the tower. The altar painting, created in 1907 by Alexandra Frosterus-Såltin, depicts Christ's ascension into heaven. The church pews were restored in early 2012. The church also has an 8-stop organ built by Bror Axel Thulé in 1896, which was updated to a 12-stop organ in 1918.

name: Lehtimäen kirkko
description:
Lehtimäki Church, designed by Jacob Rijf, is a cruciform church completed in 1800. Located in Alajärvi, the wooden church has an equilateral, beveled shape. At the crossing of the cross-shaped structure, there's an octagonal attic topped with a tower.

Inside, the different sections of the cross have multifaceted wooden vaults, with a round dome in the center. A separate three-story bell tower, built in 1835 by Abraham Hernesmaa, was connected to the church by a solar building in 1895. The bell tower has bells from 1801 and 1877.

The church has undergone renovations, including significant work in 1947-1948, which included new heating and electrical systems, and again in 1988-1989. The church has 800 seats and represents the Gustavian neoclassicism style.

name: Lemlandin kirkko
description:
Lemland Church, dedicated to St. Bridget, is one of the oldest church buildings in Finland, located in Lemland, Åland. Archaeological excavations have revealed that a wooden church previously stood on the site of the current stone church. The nave of the grey stone church dates back to the late 13th century. A bell tower, whose original timbers were felled between 1311 and 1316, is connected to the nave on the west side.

Fine ceiling paintings from the 1290s adorn the church. A Madonna and Child sculpture carved from oak in 1327 is among the most notable works of art in Åland. The church also houses two crucifixes from the mid-14th century and other late medieval wooden sculptures. The church's altarpiece is "Christ's Ascension," painted in 1872 by Robert Wilhelm Ekman.

name: Lempäälän kirkko
description:
The Lempäälä Church, also known as St. Birgitta's Church, is a medieval greystone church located in the center of Lempäälä. It was built around 1502-1505 and is dedicated to the memory of Saint Birgitta. The church is still in use by the Lempäälä parish as a Lutheran church.

A significant change to the church's appearance occurred in the 1830s when it was expanded into a cruciform church. At the same time, quatrefoil windows were opened in each arm of the cross. The interior of the church was renovated extensively in 1895 and in the 1920s. The last major renovation was completed in 1984. The church's lighting was updated in the fall of 2003, and the old chandeliers were returned to their original places in the central aisle.

name: Lemin kirkko
description:
Lemi Church is one of the most significant wooden churches in Finland. It's a symmetrical cross-shaped church built in 1786 by Juhana Salonen. The cross arms narrow outwards and have low attic-roofed vestibules. The intersection of the cross has a small lantern with a baroque finish.

Inside, there are wooden cloverleaf vaults, and a dome in the center of the cross. The tie beams are left visible. The altarpiece, depicting the Crucifixion, was painted in 1926 by Antti Muukka, an artist from Lemi. The separate octagonal bell tower with three joints was built in 1821, burned down in 1918, and rebuilt in 1936.

name: Lemun kirkko
description: The Church of Lemu is a medieval stone church located in Lemu, now part of Masku municipality. Dedicated to St. Olaf, it was likely built between 1460 and 1480. After Lemu became an independent parish in 1404, this church replaced the Nousiainen bishop's church. The church and its surroundings are classified as a nationally significant built cultural environment. A small wooden chapel was first erected on Toijaistenmäki hill, probably in the 13th century, before the current church. The churchyard also contains a neoclassical bell tower built in 1812.

name: Leppävaaran kirkko
description:
Leppävaara Church, located in Espoo, is a Lutheran church completed in 1979. Designed by architect Olli Kuusi, it has 315 seats, with additional space for approximately 450 people when the walls to the parish hall and meeting room are opened.

The church is constructed of red brick and built on a slope. The entrance leads up steps to a semicircular courtyard. Practically the entire building is made of red brick. There is also access to the church from the parking lot in the back. The church was renovated in 2009. The church organ was manufactured in 1982.

name: Leppävirran kirkko
description: Located in the center of Leppävirta, the Leppävirta Church is a neoclassical stone church designed by C.L. Engel and was inaugurated in 1846. It is the seventh largest lutheran church in Finland with 2,000 seats. The church features a two-part altarpiece by Samuel Elmgren, rescued from a fire in the earlier church in 1834. The larger part depicts Christ's descent from the cross, and the smaller depicts the institution of the Eucharist. The romantic-style organ was made by Kangasala and has 45 stops. Six pairs of quadrangular pillars divide the interior into three naves. Next to the church is an old cemetery.

name: Lestijärven kirkko
description:
Lestijärvi Church, completed in 1827, is a wooden cross-shaped church. Building the church was a lengthy process in the 1800s due to poverty and war. Initially, Lestijärvi belonged to the congregations of Toholampi and Lohtaja before establishing its own in 1906. This lasted until 2007, when Lestijärvi rejoined the congregation of Toholampi.

The church can accommodate 400 people. The altar piece was painted by Beata Ekelund and represents the Lord's ascension. The first design for the church was drafted by Heikki Kuorikoski, but it was not approved in Stockholm. Gustaf af Sillén drafted a new plan, which also wasn't approved. The church was eventually built according to a third plan. The church's bell tower was moved to the west end during renovations in 1901.

name: Liedenpohjan kirkko
description:
Liedenpohja Church is a wooden church building in the village of Liedenpohja, Virrat. It's situated on the Isoharju ridge, approximately 20 kilometers from the center of Virrat towards Alavus.

The church was originally a school building constructed about 60 years prior to 1955. In 1955, the municipality of Virrat relinquished the building, and the local parish association decided to purchase and move it next to the cemetery on land they had acquired. Local volunteers also moved the granite foundation.

The building was converted into a church according to plans by Voipa Sulkava. The church, which has a hundred seats, was consecrated by Bishop Eero Lehtinen of Lapua on October 8, 1961. The church bell was donated in 1966. The church was electrified in 1970, switching from stoves to electric heating. The cemetery surrounding the church was established in 1950.

name: Liedon kirkko
description:
Liedon Kirkko, also known as St. Peter's Church, is a medieval gray stone church located in Lieto, beside the Aurajoki River. It was likely built between 1470 and 1480. The church is dedicated to St. Peter. In 1902, a neo-Gothic red-brick chancel was added.

The interior of the church was renovated in 2021 to create a more accessible and versatile space, suitable for both sacred events and everyday use. During the renovation, the altar was moved to a more central location, and the traditional pews were replaced with chairs to allow for different seating arrangements. In the fall of 2022, a small new section, called the "Leipähuone" (Bread Room), was completed, featuring a small kitchen and accessible restroom. New organ with 27 stops was inaugurated in 2024. The church is open to visitors during the summer months.

name: Lieksan kirkko
description: Lieksa Church is a modern church located in Lieksa, Finland, completed in 1982. It was designed by architects Raili and Reima Pietilä. The church stands on the site of a previous wooden church, designed by Carl Ludwig Engel in 1836, which was destroyed by fire in 1979; only the bell tower of the old church remains. The church features a 36-stop organ made by the Kangasala organ factory. The church's address is Kirkkokatu 1.

name: Lielahden kirkko
description: Located in Tampere, the Lielahden kirkko is a Lutheran church designed by architect Pentti Turunen. This red-brick building was completed in 1961. Before becoming part of Tampere in 1950, Lielahti belonged to Ylöjärvi. After joining Harju Parish, a parish hall was built on land purchased from the Enqvist factory, and Bishop Eelis Gulin consecrated it as a church in April 1961. The church hall has 160 seats and got a small organ in 1991, which helped to regularize worship services in Lielahti. In addition to services, the church also holds evening devotions.

name: Lievestuoreen kirkko
description: Lievestuoreen kirkko is a church building located in the village of Lievestuore, Laukaa. Completed in 1983, it is part of the Laukaa parish. The church was designed by the architectural firm Erkki Tarvainen. The main church hall can accommodate 140 people, and when combined with the cafe area, the hall can accommodate 300 people. The church features an altar relief of a stylized cross made of raised bricks on the altar wall. The church's bell tower is 18 meters high. In addition to the church hall, there are also cafe, club, and office spaces.

name: Liljendalin kirkko
description:
Liljendal Church is located in Loviisa. It's a wooden church representing the Neo-Gothic architectural style, completed in 1886. A. Boman initially designed the church, but Theodor Decker later supplemented the plans. Cost considerations led to choosing wood over gray stone for construction.

In January 1886, a competition took place, won by architect Miertiz, who then passed the task to master builder E. I. Elenius. The contract price was 22,790 marks, with the agreement that the parishioners would provide all the building materials. The old church was dismantled, and usable materials were incorporated into the new structure. During construction, services were held at Söderby school. The church was ready for inspection by October 31, 1886, and it was consecrated during a bishop's inspection on the first Advent Sunday of the same year. The church is open to visitors during the summer months.

name: Limingan kirkko
description:
The Liminka Church, completed in 1826, is a centrally emphasized, symmetrical cross-shaped church representing neoclassical style. It can accommodate approximately 850 people. Anders Fredrik Granstedt and Anton Wilhelm Arppe designed the church building, with Carl Ludvig Engel also mentioned as the designer of the tower. Heikki Kuorikoski, a church builder, was in charge of the construction, making several changes to the plans.

The church's altar painting was painted by Oskar Nylander in 1849. The older bell tower was built by Grels Norling in 1733. The church is located in the nationally valuable Liminka landscape area. The yellow-painted walls are structured by wide pilasters and windows on two floors. Inside, the church hall has whitened log walls, arched board vaults, and an intermediate ceiling dome in the crossing.

name: Liperin kirkko
description:
Liperi Church is the main church of the Liperi Evangelical Lutheran Parish. It is the fifth church in the same location, standing prominently by waterways in the central area of North Karelia.

Designed by architect Georg Theodor Chiewitz, the neo-Gothic red-brick church was completed in 1858. The construction work was overseen by master builder Johan Tolpo. The church's altarpiece, "Christ on the Cross," originates from the previous church and was painted in St. Petersburg in 1842 by artist Berndt Godenhjelm. The church's interior paintings, rich in Christian symbolism, were painted by Emil Ruokolainen in 1929.

The church houses North Karelia's oldest Zachariassen organ (1879) with 16 stops. There is a small church museum at the back. The church has seating for 1,500 people.

name: Littoisten kirkko
description:
Littoisten Church, located in Littoinen, Lieto, is a Lutheran church completed around 1890. Originally, it served as a library building for the Littoinen woolen mill workers and was converted into a church in 1910.

The church resides in a historical factory environment near the old woolen mill, on Tammikallio hill. This charming church is well-suited for baptisms, weddings, and concerts. It can accommodate about 200 people.

Littoisten Church is unique architecturally. The Finnish Heritage Agency protects the building, which explains the absence of a cross on its roof. The church also houses a gallery called Galleria Kyläkirkko and hosts art exhibitions.

name: Lohikosken kirkko
description:
Lohikoski Church, completed in 1934, stands on a hill in Lohilahti, Sulkava. Designed by architect Ilmari Wirkkala, he also created the altarpiece and paintings on the gallery railing. Tapio Wirkkala, an academician, crafted the wooden pulpit.

The church accommodates about 250 people. In 1981, a mechanical organ with eight stops, made by Hans Heinrich organ builders, was installed. Also in 1981, architect Irma Valjus designed the interior painting. The church and cemetery are located on a sandy delta deposit. Services are held approximately once a month.

name: Lohjan Pyhän Laurin kirkko
description:
The Church of St. Lawrence in Lohja is a medieval stone church and is the third largest of its kind in Finland. Constructed between 1470 and 1490, it is dedicated to St. Lawrence. The interior features remarkable murals dating back to the early 16th century, depicting biblical stories. These paintings served to educate the illiterate population with a rustic and naive style.

The church's bell tower has a stone base from the Middle Ages, with its upper part built around 1740. The tower houses three bells, the oldest of which was cast in Tallinn in 1594. The churchyard and surrounding areas contribute to its cultural significance, including the Lohja Manor and other historical buildings. The church remains an important landmark, hosting services and open for visitors.

name: Lohtajan kirkko
description: Lohtaja Church, also known as Sophia Magdalena Church, is a wooden cross-shaped church built in 1768. It is located in the village of Lohtaja, in the town of Kokkola. The church is either the fourth or fifth church in Lohtaja. The current church was built on a higher ground than the previous one so that seafarers could use it as a landmark. The church is the visual focal point of the village. The altar wall is covered by a three-part altarpiece painted by Mikael Toppelius between 1770 and 1774. Next to the tower is a poor man statue dressed as a priest called Puu-Pietari.

name: Loimaan Kaupunginkirkko
description:
Loimaan Kaupunginkirkko is a church building located in Loimaa, Finland. Completed in 1973, it serves the Loimaa parish. The church was designed by architect Reino Lukander from the Lukander & Vahtera architectural firm. The building materials are concrete and lime-sandstone, giving it a light gray exterior.

In addition to the church and parish halls, the building includes club and office spaces. The church also houses items evacuated from the Kurkijoki Church. You can also find works by Alpo Jaakola and Siiri Tanner inside the church building.

name: Lokalahden kirkko
description:
Lokalahti Church, located in Uusikaupunki, is a wooden long church designed by Johan Höckert and completed in 1763. It lacks a tower and features a three-sided choir. The church has lower and narrower side chambers on the long sides of the main room. A sacristy is located on the north end and an armory on the south end, with the entrance through the armory on the west side.

The church hall is a single nave with a boarded barrel vault ceiling, beneath which is an older board vault. The church has a surface area of 280 square meters and seats 400 people. The belfry, separate from the church, was completed in 1728, predating the current church. The altar has a crucifix from 1835, and the church also has several medieval wooden sculptures.

name: Lopen kirkko
description:
Lopen Kirkko, completed between 1885 and 1887, was initially consecrated on October 16, 1887, offering seating for 1,800 individuals. A devastating fire on All Saints' Day, November 1, 1914, left only the brick walls standing.

Reconstruction occurred based on plans by architect Ilmari Launis, who was born in Hämeenlinna, utilizing the surviving brick structure. The church was reconsecrated on March 19, 1921. The original church space was divided, with the eastern part becoming a parish hall and the western part a confirmation class hall, which was quite innovative for the time.

Artist Kaapo Virtanen created the altarpiece, depicting Jesus delivering the Sermon on the Mount. The church underwent renovations from 1984 to 1988, preserving the parish hall. The original confirmation class hall, which served as a mortuary chapel between 1950 and 1966, was converted into a music room. It houses the altarpiece by Felix Frang, which depicts the Resurrection of Christ and was rescued from the fire, as well as the church's original 1885 drawings. In 1988, a 29-stop organ manufactured by the Danish company Christensen was installed in the church.

name: Lopen vanha kirkko
description:
Loppi Old Church, also known as Santa Pirjo Church, is a wooden church likely built in the late 1660s. It is located on a high hill about 1 km from the Loppi village center. The church was named after its patron saint, Saint Bridget.

The church is a simple, shingle-roofed log building. The oldest documents of the parish, which might have revealed the church's true age, were destroyed in a fire in 1880. The last growth period of the wall logs has been determined to be 1665 and 1666. The church and church hill have been used as a burial ground in the past. The old cemetery has the Törne family monument and Sakari Pälsi's grave.

Regular church services were held there until 1805. Nowadays, an evening devotion is held in the church once a week. The location on top of a steep hill, the lack of electricity, and the absence of an organ somewhat limit the church's use.

name: Loviisan kirkko
description: Loviisa Church is a prominent neo-Gothic church in the center of Loviisa, Finland. Completed in 1865, it's hard to miss due to its location at the end of the western entrance road to the city. The church, designed by Georg Theodor Chiewitz and Julius Basilier, stands 54 meters tall, including a 4-meter-high cross. Inside, the church can accommodate around 1000 visitors. There is no altar painting, but instead a plaster copy of Bertel Thorvaldsen's Christ statue from 1839. The church is open to visitors during summer Saturdays.

name: Luhalahden kirkko
description:
Luhalahden kirkko is located in Luhalahti, Ikaalinen. The church was completed in 1934, and it was built by the Luhalahti Prayer House Association, which was founded in 1919. The church was designed by architect Bertel Strömmer, who was born in Ikaalinen. The church has been renovated at least once in 1969.

The church is a rectangular long church made of white-plastered brick. The main entrance is on the south side. The facade of the building is characterized by stepped gables. The interior of the single-nave church hall has a flat ceiling. The church has a mechanical organ with 6 voices, built by Kangasala Organ Factory in 1969. The altarpiece, "Jesus the Good Shepherd," is from 1959 and was painted by Ilmari Heinonen. The church does not have a bell tower, but it does have a church bell that is rung in the old style.

name: Luhangan kirkko
description:
Luhanka Church, also known as Luhanka Summer Church or Luhanka Old Church, is one of the largest wooden churches in Finland. Designed by architect Josef Stenbäck and completed in 1893, it represents the Neo-Gothic style. The church is located slightly off the scenic route between Luhanka and Sysmä.

With approximately 1,500 seats, the church is a popular venue for concerts. Because it lacks heating and electric lights, it is only used during the summer months. The church features an altarpiece painted by S. Danielsson in 1906, titled "Jesus Stands at the Door and Knocks". Samuli Edelmann's hymns albums were recorded in this church. There is a parking lot for cars in the churchyard.

name: Luhangan talvikirkko
description:
Luhangan talvikirkko, or Luhanka Winter Church, is located in Luhanka. It was designed by architect Einari Teräsvirta and built between 1957 and 1958. The church is a brick-built, rectangular building with a sloping roof and no tower.

At the southern end of the building, there is a community hall with a sloping roof, connected to a flat-roofed wing. The community hall can be connected to the church by opening folding doors. There are windows covered with grilles at the top of the west end of the church, and a narrow window on the north altar end. The church has seating for 150-200 people. The church does not have bells. On the side wall is the old altarpiece of Luhanka's old church, *The Institution of the Eucharist*, painted by G. F. Blom in 1846.

name: Lumijoen kirkko
description:
The Lumijoki Church is a Lutheran church in Lumijoki, designed by architect Johan Ludvig Lybeck and consecrated in 1890. The first church in Lumijoki was built around 1620. This was a pillar church, but it was demolished in 1814. The second church, a wooden cross church, burned down in a thunderstorm on June 14, 1882. The current church was built between 1886 and 1889.

The church can accommodate about a thousand people. Due to its large size, the church is called the "Cathedral of the Plains." The church was renovated in 2003, when the tile roof was replaced with copper, and the plastered surfaces were repaired and painted. In 2011, the church's windows and doors were thoroughly repaired.

name: Luodon kirkko
description: Luodon kirkko (Larsmo Church in Swedish) is a wooden church located in Luoto, Finland, representing Neoclassical architecture. Designed by Jacob Rijf, it was constructed between 1785 and 1787. The church can accommodate 700 people. The church has largely retained its original appearance. The three-part altarpiece, depicting the Crucifixion, the Holy Communion, and Angels of Heaven, was painted by Johan Gustav Hedman in 1849. The church's design was inspired by the Adolf Fredrik Church in Stockholm, which Jacob Rijf had studied. The church environment is an exceptionally well-preserved example of a late 18th-century chapel parish in the inner archipelago of Ostrobothnia.

name: Luopioisten kirkko
description:
The Luopioinen Church, also known as the Church of the Transfiguration of Christ, is a wooden cross church built in 1813 by Matti Åkergren from Ruovesi.

The two-part altarpiece depicts the taking of Jesus from the cross and the Holy Communion, painted by V.E.A. Bosin in 1846. The church hall is dominated by angels on the ceiling, the work of artist Antti Salmenlinna from 1939. The organ was built by B.A. Thule in 1890 and renovated in 2004.

Next to the church is a cemetery where 132 local men are buried. The memorial statue was designed by Kirsti Liimatainen. The church is known for its good acoustics and is a venue for many musical events.

name: Luther-kirkko
description:
Luther Church in Helsinki is a church built for the Finnish Lutheran Evangelical Association. It is located on Fredrikinkatu 42. The church is especially popular among young people, students, and families with children.

The building has a rich history, having served as a prayer house and later as a nightclub before being reclaimed by the Association. In 2016, Luther Church was nominated for the European Heritage Award. The church invites people to an open, welcoming, and prayerful community in the heart of the city, where everyone has the opportunity to get to know Jesus, regardless of their background.

name: Lutherin kirkko
description: Lutherin kirkko is a church building located in Lahti, Finland, owned by the Finnish Lutheran Evangelical Association. It's situated at Vuorikatu 37. The building was constructed in 1937. From 1977 to 2015, it was the oldest church building in Lahti. The first prayer room was built on the same site in 1917. In spring 1936, the foundation stone was laid for a new prayer room, which is the current church.

name: Lutherin kirkko
description:
Turku Cathedral is the mother church of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland and a national shrine. Consecrated in 1300, its history spans over seven centuries. It's not just a historical monument; it's a living church where services are held.

Damaged significantly in the Great Fire of Turku in 1827, it was largely rebuilt. The cathedral's tower, rebuilt after the fire, stands at 101 meters and is a symbol of the city. The interior was restored in the 1830s, with Fredrik Westin painting the altarpiece.

The cathedral also houses a small museum on the second floor, showcasing artifacts from its history. The church is open daily and welcomes visitors to explore its architecture and history.

name: Luumäen kirkko
description:
Luumäki Church is a landmark in the municipality of Luumäki, South Karelia. The current church was built between 1842 and 1845, designed by C.L. Engel in the Empire style. Before this, the previous church and bell tower were destroyed in a fire in 1839. The church is a cross-shaped church with beveled inner corners and a large dome in the center. It has around a thousand seats.

The church was renovated in 1913 according to the plans of architect Ilmari Launis. At that time, the exterior walls were clad with boarding, and the gallery behind the altarpiece was boarded up. The bell tower dates back to 1876, and the parish hall from the 1920s. The church is surrounded by two cemeteries: the Church Cemetery and the Saksala Cemetery.

name: Luvian kirkko
description:
Luvian Church, located in Luvia, Eurajoki, was built between 1908 and 1910, replacing an older wooden church. It was consecrated in 1910. The church was designed by Josef Stenbäck, and it is constructed from red sandstone quarried in Luvia. The style is National Romantic, with influences from Jugend architecture. It is a cruciform church, seating around 600 people.

The church features four medieval wooden sculptures. The oldest sculpture represents Saint Olav, dating back to the early 15th century. The Luvia Madonna, representing the Virgin Mary and Jesus, is a Gothic-style sculpture from around 1420. A sculpture of Saint Anne, depicting Mary's mother with Mary and the child Jesus, dates to the 1440s-1450s.

name: Längelmäen kirkko
description:
Längelmäki Church is a wooden church in Orivesi, built between 1770 and 1772. The church represents the Baroque style and was constructed under the direction of master builder Antti Piimänen. It is located in the former village of Hakosalmi in Längelmäki.

In 1896, the church underwent renovation, during which a new sacristy was built on the east side, and a museum room was created above it. The altarpiece was replaced with a new one painted by Feliks Frangini. The roof and gable wall were damaged by a storm in the 1820s and were repaired. Later, the windows were enlarged to bring more light into the dark interior, and the interior was painted.

name: Länsi-Porin kirkko
description: The Länsi-Porin kirkko (West Pori Church) is located in the Vähärauma district of Pori. It serves as the main church for the West Pori parish. The church was designed by architect Mikael Nordenswan and completed in 1960. It underwent a renovation in 1994. The church has approximately 200 seats. Inside, there is a baroque-style organ with 19 stops, built in 2010 by Martti Porthan.

name: Maakallan kirkko
description:
Maakallan Church, also known as Kallan Church, is located on the island of Maakalla in the Bothnian Sea. It was built in 1780 by Simon Silvén, a church builder from Kalajoki. This wooden, long church lacks a tower and has a unique octagonal shape.

The church's shingle roof is steep. Inside, the log walls of the church hall are unpainted, and the ceiling is a wooden vault. The church covers an area of 180 square meters and provides seating for 200 people. A small building intended for the priest is located next to the church. A separate wooden bell tower was constructed near the church before 1954. The church is still in use during the summer.

name: Maalahden kirkko
description:
The Maalahti Church is a wooden cross church built in Maalahti between 1828 and 1829. Charles Bassi designed it, and Heikki Kuorikoski led the construction. The church represents the Neoclassical style.

The church's attic has a tent roof, from which a small, cornice-folded cupola lantern rises. The bell tower, which is connected to the church by a connecting passage, was designed by Carl Ludvig Engel and built between 1831 and 1832. The church has a floor area of 600 square meters and seats 800 people. Alexandra Frosterus-Såltin painted the church's altarpiece, "Christ's Ascension to Heaven," in 1881. Jens Zachariassen made the church's 22-stop organ in 1969. The church underwent a thorough renovation in the 1950s, during which the pews were renewed.

name: Maaningan kirkko
description:
Maaningan Church, located in Maaninka, Kuopio, is a wooden cross-shaped church built between 1826 and 1845. Carlo Bassi, a state architect, designed the church. The church has a square base. Above it is a tower with beveled corners.

The altar painting was created by Ferdinand von Wright. Artist Finelli made the wooden reliefs. Ritva Puotila designed the wedding tapestry. Urho Lehtinen and his fellow artists painted the dome, pulpit, and gallery railings in 1937. The churchyard around the church extends to the shore like a park.

name: Maarian kirkko
description:
St. Mary's Church in Turku is a medieval stone church located in the Maaria district. It is one of Finland's oldest medieval stone churches, dating back to the 1300s. The church's limestone paintings from the 15th century are of significant cultural and historical value, featuring symbolic and magical themes that are rare in Finnish church art.

The church houses valuable artifacts, including a wooden crucifix from the 14th century and an altarpiece made by a Lübeck artist. The ceiling is covered in secco drawings, created when the church was built in the late 15th century. The church grounds are relatively small, nestled against a road and some housing.

name: Maksamaan kirkko
description:
Maksamaan Church is a wooden cross church located in Maksamaa, Vöyri, built in 1824. The drawings were made at the Intendentinkonttori in 1822, and Heikki Kuorikoski constructed the church. The central cube of the church, with its pyramid roof, rises as a tower-like structure higher than the arms of the cross.

The church represents Neoclassicism with its gables and roof moldings. The interior is covered by a wooden vault, with a domed vault in the center of the cross. The church was renovated in 1897, 1904, 1933 and 1961-1962. A separate three-story bell tower was built in connection with the older church in 1783, it was raised and moved next to the new church in 1824. The bells are from 1749 and 1783.

name: Malmin kirkko
description: Malmi Church, designed by Kristian Gullichsen and completed in 1981, serves as the main church for the Malmi parish. The church is located near Kirkonkyläntie and the Malmi hospital. The route to the sheltered inner courtyard is through the bell tower. A significant renovation was completed to modernize the church technically and functionally. During the renovation, 80,000 bricks were used to re-lay the facade, some of which were laid in challenging patterns. The roof of the music hall is said to resemble the Vyborg Library.

name: Manamansalon muistomerkkikirkko
description:
The Manamansalo Memorial Church is an open-air church built in 1959 to commemorate the 400th anniversary of the Oulujärvi parish. It is located on the northeastern tip of the island of Manamansalo in Vaala. The church stands on the site of Kainuu's first church, which was in use from 1559 to 1585.

Architects Tuomas Väyrynen and Eero Huotari designed the church. The memorial includes a narrow, open bell tower with a copper roof and a wooden structure set on a concrete base. The outdoor church has an altar, a pulpit-like lectern made of concrete, a wooden communion table, and benches with seating for about one hundred people. A large metal cross stands on the altar, with a view of Oulujärvi's Rusilanlahti bay in the background. Services and devotions are held in the church during the summer.

name: Marian kirkko
description: Marian Church in Hamina, Finland, also known as Saint Mary Church, is located at the coordinates 60°34′12.4″N 27°12′06.52″E. It is a notable landmark in the city. The church's architecture reflects a blend of historical styles, contributing to its unique appearance. The church serves as a vital place of worship and a center for community activities. Its presence enriches the cultural landscape of Hamina. The church is an important religious and historical site.

name: Martinkirkko
description:
