Martin's Church (Martinkirkko) is located in Turku, Finland. It serves as the main church for Martin's parish, established in 1921. The church got its name in honor of Martin Luther. It was inaugurated on November 12, 1933, coinciding with the 450th anniversary of Luther's birth. Architects Totti Sora and Gunnar Wahlroos designed the building in the Functionalist style.

The church has a basilica-like construction. The interior has three aisles, and a barrel-vaulted roof. The altar wall features a large "al secco" painting depicting Jesus' crucifixion, created by artists Einari Wehmas and Karl Ingelius. The churchyard has parking spaces and is reachable by public transport.

name: Marttilan kirkko
description: Marttila Church, known in Swedish as S:t Mårtens kyrka, is located in Marttila, in the region of Southwest Finland. The wooden church was built in 1765 under the direction of church builder Antti Piimänen; his son Mikael Piimänen also participated in the construction. The church represents the Southwest Finnish long church type, featuring small transepts and a bell tower-like western tower. The altar painting is by Robert Wilhelm Ekman. Near the church are the ruins of a medieval stone sacristy. Stones from the sacristy were used in the foundation of the current wooden church. A statue honoring heroes, created by sculptor Aarre Aaltonen in 1946, stands near the church.

name: Masalan kirkko
description: Masalan Kirkko, also known as St. Matthew's Church, is located in Masala, Kirkkonummi. Consecrated on February 13, 2000, it stands as the first new church in Finland of the new millennium. Designed by architect Erkki Pitkäranta, the church's architecture and art incorporate both holiness and a connection to nature. The art inside is a collaboration between Pitkäranta and artist Jan-Erik Andersson. This modern church is relatively small, containing a church hall and other parish facilities.

name: Maskun kirkko
description:
Masku Church is a medieval stone church, likely constructed between 1490 and 1510. Dedicated to John the Baptist and Saint Ursula, it stands as one of the oldest parishes in Western Finland, with the Masku parish first mentioned in 1234. The church features a single nave with four vaults, adorned with 17th-century frescoes.

Inside, the pulpit, dating back to 1642, is a war trophy from the Thirty Years' War. The church also houses medieval artifacts, including a crucifix and a Silesian altarpiece. An organ, built in the neo-gothic style, was added in 1885. Near the church lies Humikkalan kalmisto, an Iron Age burial ground.

name: Matteuksenkirkko
description:
St. Matthew's Church (Matteuksenkirkko), also known as the Itäkeskus Church, is located in Helsinki, near the Itis shopping center. Designed by architects Veli-Pekka Tuominen and Stefan Ahlman, it was completed in 1985. The church is a red-brick building and was named after the Evangelist Matthew.

Inside the church, the altar wall features a brick composition called "Heaven's Gate" and a cross-shaped ceramic work by sculptor Anna-Maria Osipow. The altar crucifix was created by sculptor Arvo Siikamäki, and the textiles were designed by Immi Halsti. The church also houses an organ with 22 stops, made by Kangasalan Urkurakentamo. The church serves various congregations and hosts services in multiple languages.

name: Maunulan kirkko
description:
Maunulan kirkko, also known as Petruskyrkan in Swedish, is a church building located in Maunula, Helsinki. The church primarily serves the Swedish-speaking Petrus parish but also hosts activities of the Oulunkylä parish. Designed by architect Ahti Korhonen, it was completed in 1980.

Inside, the wooden-clad altar wall features a copper and wood crucifix by sculptor Heikki Nieminen. The interior design was created by interior architect Olavi Hänninen. Textile artist Airi Snellman-Hänninen designed the church's textiles, with the exception of the church textiles themselves, which are by Terttu Hassi. The church also features art by Sam Vanni. The church hall showcases Sam Vanni's painting "Moses and the Tablets of the Law", and the church lobby displays a sculpture called "Angel" by Aira Salosmaa. The church's three bells were made in Austria.

name: Meilahden kirkko
description:
Meilahti Church, also known as the Church of the Good Samaritan, is located in Helsinki. Designed by Markus Tavio, it was inaugurated on February 7, 1954. This yellow-brick church building houses two church halls: Meilahti Church and Thomas Church.

The church has a rich history. In 1959, a 40-stop organ made by the Danish company Marcussen & Søn was installed, making it a popular concert venue in the 1960s and 70s. The facade of Thomas Church features a relief by Armas Tirronen called "The Good Samaritan". The church was renovated in 1997. One of the church's bells was originally intended for Vyborg Cathedral.

name: Mellilän kirkko
description:
Mellilä Church is a church in Mellilä, Loimaa. It is located by the Niinijoki river, a couple of kilometers upstream from the center of Mellilä. The church was built in 1824–1825.

The church is a wooden, gable-towered cross church. The altarpiece was painted by Edwin Lydén in 1912. The memorial to the heroes of Mellilä Church was designed by sculptor Jussi Vikainen in 1951. The upper part of the tower of the simple-style church is polygonal. The church has about 300 seats.

name: Merijärven kirkko
description:
Merijärvi Church was built in 1781. The church was designed and constructed by Simon Silvén, a church builder from Kalajoki. However, the original designs were modified at the Stockholm Office of the Superintendent and were finally approved by King Gustav III.

The construction took place between 1779 and 1781, and the church was inaugurated on July 8, 1781. The altarpiece, depicting Christ on the Cross, was painted by Jeremias Alin in 1877-1878. The first altarpiece was painted at the end of the 18th century by church painter Thomas Kiempe and is now located on the south transept of the church. The church's bell tower was built in 1799 and designed by Sven Westman from the Stockholm Office of the Superintendent.

A fire on Christmas Day in 1973 damaged the interior of the church so severely that all the interior paintings, the heating system and the lighting had to be renewed. The church was renovated and painted in 2004. In the same year, the church tower was painted and its base was tarred.

name: Merimaskun kirkko
description:
The Merimasku Church is a wooden cross church dating back to 1726. It's located on the main island of Otava in the former municipality of Merimasku, now part of Naantali. The church is painted red and the roof is covered with wood shingles.

The Finnish Heritage Agency has listed the church environment as one of the nationally significant built cultural environments in Finland. The first church in Merimasku was built of wood in 1648, but the current church was built after the Great Wrath, in 1726, and is the sixth oldest wooden church in Finland that is still in continuous use.

name: Messukylän kirkko
description:
Messukylä Church is a Lutheran church in Tampere, Finland. It is the newer of the two churches in the Messukylä district. The brick church was built to replace the old Messukylä Church, which was in poor condition, and was completed in 1879. It was designed by Theodor Höijer.

The church has a rectangular shape with a tower at the end and a transept protruding from the middle of the main building. A polygonal chancel, surrounded by a low polygonal sacristy, extends from the altar end. The exterior walls are structured by buttresses and very tall arched windows, which bring light into the church hall and the galleries. The architectural style represents late Gothic Revival. The church has central heating and seats for 790 people. The altarpiece, dating from 1888, is called "Canaanite Woman" and was painted by Alexandra Frosterus-Såltin.

name: Messukylän vanha kirkko
description: The Old Church of Messukylä is a medieval grey stone church located in the Messukylä district of Tampere. It is the oldest building in Tampere. Surrounded by tall spruces, the church features a green lawn in front. Popularly known as "Mikko" after its patron saint Michael, the church welcomes visitors during the summer months. From June 1st to August 31st, 2025, it is open from Wednesday to Sunday, 12 PM to 6 PM, with a guide available on-site.

name: Metsolan siunauskappeli
description:
The Metsola Chapel is a chapel located in the Metsola district of Lohja. The chapel was completed in 1956 and was designed by architect Erik Bryggman. Bryggman died before the chapel was completed, and his daughter, interior architect Carin Bryggman, completed the plans. Carin Bryggman and her husband, interior architect Uolevi Nuotio, designed furniture and lighting for the chapel.

The pitched-roofed Metsola Chapel is situated on a slope and has a low wing building that houses storage for the deceased. The wing building has a grass roof. The chapel is painted light with lime paint. Originally, the building had coke heating, but in the 1970s and 1980s it was connected to district heating, and minor room alterations were made. A bell tower, which was part of Bryggman's original design, was not built in the 1950s but was finally completed in 2002.

name: Metsäkansan kirkko
description:
Located in the village of Metsäkansa in Valkeakoski, the Metsäkansan Church is a rectangular long church built in 1938 of plastered brick. The church's altar recess separates from the choir end, narrower than the body of the building. A low wing building protrudes from the other long side, and there is a large roof rider on the entrance gable.

The high windows are arched, except for the side window of the altar recess. The exterior roofs are gable roofs, and inside there is a wooden pitched roof. The church was donated and built by Mining Counselor Emil Aaltonen for his native village. The church was designed by architect Jaakko Tähtinen. Aaltonen also donated the church's organ, altarpiece and the bells of a separate bell tower. The prayer room association, founded to acquire the church, donated the church to the parish in 1972.

name: Metsämaan kirkko
description:
Metsämaan kirkko is a wooden church located in Metsämaa, Loimaa. It was built in 1777, even though permission for its construction was not initially granted. The church's chancel was added in the 1860s. The church represents 18th-century wooden church architecture and can accommodate around 350 people.

The church has undergone renovations, including the restoration of the old altarpiece in the 1990s and the repair of a collapsed stone wall in the cemetery in 2017. The tower has a distinctive onion dome. The churchyard is surrounded by an old gray stone wall.

name: Miehikkälän kirkko
description:
Miehikkälä Church was built between 1879 and 1881. Designed by architect Ludvig Isak Lindqvist, the architecture combines Gothic Revival and other late 19th-century styles. The church was constructed primarily through volunteer work, with bricks made from clay near the church hill.

The church features uncovered brick and a tower above the main entrance. Its hall is covered by a barrel vault and divided into three naves. The altar painting, "Descent from the Cross," is by Väinö Hämäläinen (1930). Urho Lehtinen created the decorative paintings, including symbols of the Gospel writers on the ceiling.

Major renovations occurred in 1927 and 1963. The original organ (1895) was replaced in 1980, retaining ten registers and the facade. The cemetery is near the church, including a section for fallen heroes.

name: Mietoisten kirkko
description:
Mietoisten Church is a grey stone long church located in Mynämäki. It was built between 1641 and 1643, commissioned by Henrik Klausson Fleming, the lord of Lehtinen Manor.

The church was expanded in 1724 with a sacristy and a wooden vestibule, and again in 1829 when the church was lengthened. The current bell tower was added in 1818-1819. The interior is a single-nave barrel-vaulted space. The current Art Nouveau interior dates back to 1911 and is designed by architect Ilmari Launis. The churchyard is surrounded by an old stone wall.

name: Mikael Agricolan kirkko
description:
Mikael Agricola Church is a Lutheran church located in the Punavuori district of Helsinki, Finland. It was built between 1933 and 1935 and designed by Lars Sonck. The style is mainly functionalist. The church is named after Bishop Mikael Agricola.

The red brick church has a 97-meter-high tower. The church is open to visitors on weekdays and during services. The church hall has a crypt in the same building, which can be used for various church events and family celebrations. The church is one of the churches in the Helsinki Cathedral Parish.

name: Mikaelinkirkko
description:
Mikaelinkirkko, located in Turku, Finland, is a remarkable church that dominates the western part of the city's skyline. This early 20th-century neo-Gothic structure, designed by Lars Sonck, is named after Archangel Michael. The church features a striking red-brick facade and steely gray spires.

Inside, the church boasts elegant interiors, including Winter War-era window paintings that shimmer under the lights. The altar and pulpit are crafted from Finnish soapstone. In 2002, a new organ, created by Swedish experts, was installed. The art nouveau paintings and the soapstone altar contribute to a cohesive and wonderful design aesthetic.

name: Mikaelinkirkko
description:
Mikaelinkirkko, also known as St. Michael's Church, stands as a symmetrical landmark in Vantaa, having been built in 1956. Constructed with redwood and a concrete base, it embodies a modernist architectural style. The church serves as a central hub for the local Mikaeli Parish.

In contrast to some older churches, Mikaelinkirkko offers a more contemporary aesthetic while providing a space for worship and community gatherings. Its design focuses on clean lines and functional spaces, catering to the needs of its parishioners. It stands as a testament to the evolving nature of church architecture and its integration within modern urban environments.

name: Mikkelin pitäjänkirkko
description:
The Mikkeli Parish Church, formerly known as the Mikkeli Countryside Church until 2013, is a wooden church located in Mikkeli. Designed by architect Charles Bassi, it was completed in 1817. It is one of the largest wooden churches in Finland, featuring a double-cruciform design, essentially two crosses superimposed. The altarpiece is a copy by Amélie Lundahl of Pierre-Paul Prud'hon's painting depicting Christ on the Cross.

The churchyard includes an octagonal bell tower representing the East Finnish tower style, constructed in 1815. A war graves area with a bronze memorial statue is located southeast of the church. To the northwest is a still-active cemetery, and to the southwest, a stone granary from 1848 has been converted into the Suur-Savo Museum.

name: Mikkelin tuomiokirkko
description:
Mikkeli Cathedral is the main church of the city of Mikkeli and the bishop's church of the Diocese of Mikkeli. Designed by church architect Josef Stenbäck, the church was built of red brick in 1896–1897. It represents the Gothic Revival style and is one of the main achievements of the Neo-Gothic church architecture in Finland.

Located on Ristimäki hill, the site was previously used by a rifle battalion. The interior was renovated in the functionalist style in the 1950s. The altar painting "Jesus on the Cross" was painted by Pekka Halonen. The church tower is 64 meters high.

name: Mommilan kirkko
description:
Mommilan kirkko is a wooden church located in Hausjärvi, completed in 1904. Originally, it was built as a prayer room for the Mommila Manor.
Alfred Kordelin, who bought the manor in 1903, finalized the construction and obtained church rights for it in 1905.
The church was designed by Emil Olander in the Carpenter Gothic style and built by Vihtori Olander.
It features a long church layout with a low tower and a roof ridge turret.
The church can accommodate approximately 150 people.
Kordelin bequeathed the church to the Lammi parish in his will.
The church has been renovated a few times, including a major renovation in 1959, when it was modernized. In 1987, it was restored to its original appearance.
A building completed in 1912 in the churchyard currently serves as a parish hall.

name: Mouhijärven kirkko
description:
The Mouhijärvi Church, located in Sastamala, is a red-brick church designed by Pehr Johan Gylich and completed in 1858. It is a cross-shaped church with a tower at the end and a low, multifaceted pyramid roof in the center. The church belongs to the Sastamala parish.

The first prayer room in Mouhijärvi was established in the late 1500s, but its exact location is unknown. The second church was located on the Selkee Manor grounds. It was demolished in 1878, and its logs were used to build Mouhijärvi's first public school in Uotsola. The current church was built in Haavoistenmäki in Mustianoja and was consecrated in 1858. The altarpiece, depicting Christ on the Cross, was painted by Felix Frang in 1918. There is a cemetery, war hero graves and a memorial to those left in Karelia near the church.

name: Muhoksen kirkko
description: Muhos Church is the oldest wooden church in Finland that has been preserved almost without expansions and is in regular, year-round use. It is rectangular long church in style. The current church was completed no later than 1634 and is the third church in the area. The canopy above the pulpit is decorated with wooden sculptures believed to have been made in Germany and brought to the church during the Thirty Years' War. The interior features a magnificent altarpiece by Emanuel Granberg from 1778, depicting Moses and the Brass Serpent. The church has pews that can accommodate a congregation of five hundred.

name: Mukkulan kirkko
description:
Mukkulan Church, located in the Mukkula area of Lahti, is a church belonging to the Central Lahti Parish. It was built in 1993 and designed by Arkkitehtityö Oy Juhani Boman. The material used resembles hand-struck brick.

The church hall has seating for 200 people, and a community hall behind a movable wall provides additional space if needed. The altar wall has symbolic meaning, with narrow windows framing a structure that encloses the sacristy.

The church textiles were designed by Kirsti Rantanen. The church features a renaissance-style organ built by Kangasala organ factory, with 15 stops. The organ is inspired by the Nauvo positive organ, the oldest organ in Finland.

name: Multian kirkko
description: Multian Church is located in Multia, in the region of Keski-Suomi. Originally a wooden cross church completed in 1796, it underwent a major renovation in 1900, transforming it into a long church with a tower at the end. During this renovation, it was said that only the floor planks and parts of the exterior walls remained from the original church. The altar and sacristy were moved, and the church's tower is located in the eastern part. The church was renovated and reopened on October 1, 2023. The current brick-red color of the church is its original color.

name: Munkkiniemen kirkko
description:
Munkkiniemi Church, located in Munkkiniemi, Helsinki, was completed in 1954. Before the Munkkiniemi parish became independent in 1961, it served as a side church for the Huopalahti parish. The church was designed by architect Pauli Salomaa and is constructed of concrete and brick.

The church hall has a stepped floor that descends and narrows from the main door towards the altar. Above the altar is a skylight, the light from which is a central element in the otherwise minimalist church hall. The entrance to the church is unique, as you enter the church hall under a votive ship. The church is currently undergoing renovations, expected to be completed in 2026, to improve accessibility and energy efficiency.

name: Munkkivuoren kirkko
description:
Munkkivuoren kirkko is a church building located in Helsinki, right next to the Munkkivuori shopping center. The church is part of the Munkkiniemi parish. The building also includes a parish hall, and a separate bell tower with three bells dating back to 1963.

Designed by architect Olavi Kantele, the church was completed and dedicated in 1963. In 1967, the Munkkivuori parish became independent from the Munkkiniemi parish, but the two were rejoined at the beginning of 2011. The church was renovated in 1997.

Inside the church, you can find Åke Hellman's altar mosaic, "Fiat voluntas tua" (Thy will be done), which was completed in 1965. The church also has a 30-stop organ, designed by Kantele in collaboration with the Kangasala organ factory. The organ was inaugurated in October 1965.

name: Munsalan kirkko
description:
Munsala Church is a stone church located in Munsala, Uusikaarlepyy. Construction of the gray stone church began in 1777, and it was inaugurated in 1792. The church is a cross-shaped church with a tower at one end and a chancel at the other.

The church is especially known for its organ, which is the oldest church organ in Finland, built by Ericus German in 1736. The altarpiece is made by J. E. Lind and depicts the Holy Communion and the Crucifixion. Next to the church is a separate bell tower built in 1745.

name: Muonion kirkko
description:
The Muonio Church was built in 1817 and inaugurated in 1822. The church was designed by Charles Bassi. It's a semi-cruciform church. The altar painting, titled "Jesus Among Folk," was painted by Anton Lindfors and depicts a rainbow within a fell landscape.

During the Lapland War, the withdrawing German army burned most of the village down, but Muonio Church was one of the few buildings that survived. The churchyard also contains a war memorial designed by artist Veikko Aalto. The church is open to visitors during the summer.

name: Muroleen kirkko
description:
Murole Church, located in Ruovesi, was designed by architect Lauri Autero and built between 1928 and 1932. It's a wooden long church featuring a gable tower. A sacristy protrudes from the corner of one of the long sides near the altar end.

The building has a hipped roof at the altar end, interior walls with exposed logs, and a gently rounded ceiling. The three-section gable tower resembles a traditional belfry, and its bell dates back to 1933. The church covers an area of 270 square meters and can accommodate 350 people. The exterior was renovated in 1979. Lennart Segerstråle painted the altarpiece "Jesus in Gethsemane" in 1951. Near the church is a memorial chapel built in 1933.

name: Mustasaaren kirkko
description: Mustasaari Church, originally built as the Vaasa Court of Appeal, is located in Old Vaasa. Designed by Carl Fredrik Adelcrantz, the building was completed in 1776. After the great fire of Vaasa in 1852, the building was converted into a church for the Mustasaari parish. Carl Axel Setterberg redesigned the interior, adding vaulted ceilings while preserving the exterior. The church is a significant example of early Gustavian architecture in Finland. Inside, some items were saved from the old church, including chandeliers from the 1700s. Today, Mustasaari Church serves both the Finnish and Swedish parishes, hosting services and events.

name: Mustion kirkko
description:
The Mustio Church is a wooden church that was built in 1761 as a factory church. It belongs to the Church Association of Raasepori and is actively used. The current church was built under the direction of master builder Johan Tammi in 1761, when the old church was destroyed. The church bells and pulpit were moved from the old church to the new church.

The belfry outside the church dates back to 1778. The church can accommodate approximately 150 people. The church is open by appointment or during concerts and events. The church is located near Mustio Manor.

name: Muuramen kirkko
description:
Muurame Church, designed by Alvar Aalto, was completed in 1929. It represents a transition in Aalto's style from Nordic Classicism to Functionalism. The church has a single-aisle design and a campanile-style belfry, influenced by Aalto's honeymoon trip to Italy.

The white church and its bell tower are visible from a distance. The interior was renovated in 2016 to restore its original color scheme, featuring bright blue and red ceilings and dark gray fixtures. The rose garden in the courtyard was also restored during the renovation. The altar painting "Peter and John Healing the Cripple" was painted by William Lönnberg in 1930.

name: Muurasjärven kirkko
description:
Muurasjärvi Church is located in the village of Muurasjärvi in the municipality of Pihtipudas. The church was completed in 1963, partly through voluntary work, and was designed by architect Esko Laitinen. The church was renovated and expanded in 1987. Next to it is a cemetery founded in the 1930s.

The church building is a long church without a tower, covered by a sloping shed roof. The church's organ was made by Hans Heinrich in 1970. Services are held there once or twice a month. In addition to being a place of worship, the church also has club facilities where the parish day care center operates once a week.

name: Muuruveden kirkko
description:
Muuruveden Church, located in the former municipality of Juankoski, in Kuopio, is a grey granite church designed by Josef Stenbäck. It was built between 1901 and 1904. The church can accommodate 1,200 people and its floor area is 690 square meters.

The walls of the church are painted with several Bible verses according to Stenbäck's design. Above the altar are the words "Given for you for the forgiveness of sins". Instead of an altarpiece, there is a crucifix. The church bells date back to 1903. In the churchyard, there is a war hero statue by E. Halonen, which is Finland's first war hero monument dating back to 1919.

name: Myllykosken kirkko
description:
Myllykoski Church is a brick church located in Myllykoski, Kouvola. It belongs to the Anjalankoski parish of the Kouvola parish association. The church was designed by architect W.G. Palmqvist and completed in 1936. Its interior resembles the Jämsänkoski church, also designed by Palmqvist.

The church hall has fixed benches for approximately 400 people. The altar is located in the choir area, which is a few steps higher than the church hall floor. The altarpiece was painted by artist Martti Ranttila. The 45-meter-high tower is topped with a neon cross, a request by Rudolf Walden.

name: Myllypuron kirkko
description:
Myllypuron kirkko is a church building located in Myllypuro, Helsinki, completed in 1992. The church belongs to the Herttoniemi parish. The building was designed by architects Anja and Raimo Savolainen.

Besides the church hall, the building includes facilities for clubs for different age groups, offices for employees, a library, and an apartment for the caretaker. The church hall and lobby are high spaces. A separate bell tower has 14 church bells. The altarpiece is a stained glass window called Lux aeterna by Carolus Enckell. The library features a relief of Christ on the Cross by Ville Vallgren. The church building also has oil paintings by Enckell, as well as a crucifix and relief by pastor Veijo Vatka. The organ, built by Veikko Virtanen, has 16 stops. Myllypuron kirkko has occasionally offered overnight stays for the homeless.

name: Mynämäen kirkko
description:
Mynämäki Church, also known as St. Lawrence Church, is located in the municipality of Mynämäki in Southwest Finland. It is the second largest medieval stone church in Finland. The church is dedicated to Saint Lawrence and Saint Eric.

The medieval church is one of the most impressive in the countryside. A massive tower structure was planned for the west end. Henrik Fleming's and his wife Ebba Bååt's grave monument is one of the finest examples of Baroque sculpture in Finland. The church was first mentioned in surviving documents as a parish in 1309, and the church was located in the village in the middle of the same century.

name: Myrskylän kirkko
description:
Myrskylä Church, officially the Myrskylä Evangelical Lutheran Church, is the third church built in the municipality. Located in the center of Myrskylä, near Lake Kirkkojärvi, the wooden church has a cross-shaped floor plan. The wooden bell tower stands separately, a few meters from the church building.

The church was completed in 1824. The bell tower predates the church, having been completed in 1772. The church environment, with its granaries and parsonages, has been preserved in its 19th-century form. The church hill is dominated by the wooden church and bell tower from the early 1800s, the surrounding churchyard with red granite memorials, two granaries by the roadside, and the former vicarage opposite the church in the middle of the garden. The altarpiece, depicting the Sermon on the Mount, was painted by Dora Wahlroos in 1897. The church has exceptionally fine large crystal chandeliers and numerous burial coats of arms.

name: Myyrmäen kirkko
description:
Myyrmäki Church, also known as the Church of Light, is a Lutheran church located in Vantaa, Finland. Designed by architect Juha Leiviskä, it opened in 1984 and is celebrated for its unique architectural style. Light plays a key role in the church's design, reminding visitors of God's presence.

Besides the main church hall, the building includes a chapel, two parish halls, the parish office, and facilities for children's and youth activities. The main church hall can accommodate 450 people, and with the parish halls, it can hold over 700. The church was renovated between 2019 and 2023 to address interior climate issues and improve the building's technology and usability.

name: Männistön kirkko
description:
Männistö Church, officially the Church of St. John in Männistö, is a Lutheran church located in the Saarijärvi residential area of Kuopio. Completed in 1992, it was designed by architects Juha Leiviskä and Pekka Kivisalo, who won a competition for its design in 1985.

Leiviskä aimed for a vibrant interaction between small and large, low and high, closed and open, and shadowy and bright elements in his design. The building is architecturally significant, especially its interiors. Inside, foyer spaces lead to a large church hall, culminating in the altar wall. According to Leiviskä, daylight is the most important building material of the church hall. Light creates varying indirect reflections, most visible during morning services. The appearance of the spaces changes throughout the day depending on sunlight and cloud cover.

name: Mäntsälän kirkko
description:
Mäntsälä Church is located in Mäntsälä, Finland, and was completed in 1865 and consecrated in 1866. The church was designed in the Intendent Office by architects Ernst Lohrmann and Jean Wik.

Architecturally, it is a long church with a western tower. Inside the church, you can find a chandelier from the church of Koivisto, and the altarpiece is "The Adoration of the Shepherds" painted by Bernhard Reinhold in 1861. The church also features burial coats of arms of four noble families strongly linked to the local manor culture.

The church was last renovated in 1991, when a large gilded bronze chandelier, which had adorned the Koivisto church since 1903, was donated to the church by the Koivisto Society. Outside the church, there is a war graves area and a memorial made by Professor Heikki Varja, "The Karelian Maiden", in memory of the dead remaining in Karelia. The church also has a memorial to both sides of the 1918 Civil War.

name: Mäntyharjun kirkko
description:
Mäntyharju Church, completed in 1822, stands as the second-largest wooden church in Finland and the largest built with the "lamasalvos" technique, a type of log construction. Architect Charles Bassi initially planned for a capacity of nearly 6,000 people, but the final design accommodates around 1,700.

The church features an altarpiece painted by Berndt Godenhjelm, depicting the Ascension of Jesus. The bell tower was completed in 1819. The church's current organ, built in 2008, represents the early Romantic style of Nordic organ building, with 38 stops, two manuals, and a Barker machine. The organ reflects the style of the church's first organ from 1876.

name: Mäntän kirkko
description:
Mänttä Church, completed in 1928, was designed by architect W. G. Palmqvist. The church represents primarily Nordic Neo-Baroque style and can accommodate approximately 450 people. Its floor plan is cross-shaped. The bell tower reaches a height of 37 meters, while the church hall's dome is 13 meters from the floor.

The church is adorned with art, featuring an altarpiece by Alwar Cawén, a stained-glass window by Eric Ehrnström, and 35 wooden sculptures by Hannes Autere. The altarpiece depicts Mary and the Child Jesus surrounded by sheep. The stained glass windows on either side of the altarpiece are also by Cawén. The stained-glass painting of the organ balcony was designed by Eric O. W. Ehrström.

name: Naantalin kirkko
description:
Naantali Church, dating back to the medieval ages, is a historic landmark and an integral part of Naantali's skyline. Built between the 1460s and 1480s, it originally served as the church for a Catholic Bridgettine monastery. The church is the only remaining structure from the convent and is the second-largest medieval stone church in Finland after the Turku Cathedral.

The magnificent baroque tower, completed in 1797, is a captivating sight. Today, besides being a popular tourist attraction, it serves as the center of the Naantali parish. Concerts and guided tours are frequently organized. The most recent renovation took place in 2011-2012, where the lighting, interior, altar, and textiles were repaired.

name: Naarvan rajaseutukirkko
description: Naarvan rajaseutukirkko is a wooden church located in the village of Naarva in Ilomantsi. It was designed by architect Toivo Pelli and built in 1958. The church is a "long church" without a tower. The altar features a wooden crucifix sculpted by Sulo Leppänen. The church has seating for 120 people. A separate bell tower was constructed in 1971. The church belongs to the Ilomantsi Evangelical Lutheran parish. The church's area is 161 square meters.

name: Nakkilan kirkko
description:
Nakkila Church is a Lutheran church in Nakkila, Finland, showcasing Functionalist architecture. Designed by Erkki Huttunen and completed in 1937, it is considered a significant example of modernist churches in Finland.

The church is built with rendered brick and features concrete support columns, tall narrow windows, and a striking bell tower. The interior has a simple design with a wooden crucifix above the altar instead of a traditional altarpiece. Strong colors in the choir and baptistery, along with green pews and Taito Oy lamps, characterize the modernist interior. The saw-tooth ceiling in the nave is clad in wood for acoustic reasons. The church has been preserved almost entirely in its original form, with only minor interior changes.

name: Nastolan kirkko
description:
Nastola Church, completed in 1804, is a wooden cross church. Its belfry was originally built before 1760 and moved to its current location in 1804. Matias Åkergren from Ruovesi was responsible for building the church.

The church regularly hosts services, events, baptisms, and weddings and can accommodate 550 people. The church underwent a renovation completed in the spring of 2001, and the facade was renovated in 2019. The church is accessible by wheelchair from the Town Hall side entrance, and there is an accessible toilet in the lobby.

The church parking area has 20 parking spaces. Currently, there are plans to repair the shingle roof of the Nastola Church between 2025 and 2026.

name: Nauvon kirkko
description: Nauvo Church is a medieval gray stone church located on a hillside on Storlandet, Nauvo's other main island. The three-nave hall church is dedicated to St. Olaf. The church was likely built between 1430 and 1450. The church's north wall features a replica of Leonardo da Vinci's Last Supper, painted by R.W. Ekman in 1850. Simple builder's paintings decorate the church, with medieval and 17th-century lime paintings mainly on the vaults. Northwest and northeast of the church are bone rooms built in the 18th century. The belfry, completed in 1751, stands on a hill northwest of the churchyard.

name: Neulamäen kirkko
description:
Neulamäen kirkko is a church building completed in 1993, located in the Neulamäki district of Kuopio. It combines a church and a parish hall, situated between Neulamäki school and shopping center. Carl-Johan Slotte designed the church.

The church hall has 240 seats, or 340 when combined with the cafeteria. A stained glass window in the hall depicts the five wounds of Christ, designed by Hannu Konola. The church hall has an organ and a piano. Neulamäki Church belongs to the Alava parish of Kuopio.

name: Nilsiän kirkko
description:
The Nilsiä Church, located in Nilsiä, Kuopio, was completed in 1905 and consecrated in 1906. It was designed by Josef Stenbäck. The church represents National Romanticism with Neo-Gothic features and can accommodate 1,200 people.

A unique characteristic is its quartz construction, sourced from Tahkovuori, making it the only church in Finland built of this material. The tower has a stone-covered spire, while the rest of the roof is made of sheet metal.

Inside, the altar features Juho Rissanen's 1907 painting, "The Way of the Cross," depicting Jesus on the way to Golgotha, using local people as models. The churchyard also contains a memorial to Paavo Ruotsalainen.

name: Nivalan kirkko
description:
Nivala Church, also known as the Church of the Holy Heart, is located in the village of Nivala. The wooden cross-shaped church was designed by Simon Jylkkä-Silvén and was built in 1803. It can accommodate approximately 600 people.

Originally, the bell tower was separate from the church, but in 1874, it was moved and connected to the church's main entrance. The church's exterior maintains a simple and solemn appearance, and a recent renovation revealed beautiful details, including decorations with the theme of Jesus's sacred heart. The altar painting depicting the crucifixion was painted by A. Vendelin in 1875, and Lauri Välke painted the suffering-themed paintings on the choir wall in 1952.

name: Nokian kirkko
description:
Nokia Church is the main church of the Nokian parish. Designed by C.L. Engel and completed in 1837, this brick church represents the Neoclassical style. It is modeled after the Pantheon in Rome, featuring a full circle shape and a dome covering the entire church.

The church has undergone several renovations. A major repair was carried out in 1973–1974 under the direction of architect Seppo Rihlama. During the same renovation, Kangasala's organ factory built the current 32-tone pipe organ. The most recent renovations were completed in 1996, when the floor was renewed.

The gray limestone floor in the main hall symbolizes the earth, the blue dome represents the sky, and the orange stripe at the junction of the walls and ceiling represents the boundary between time and eternity. In the church's basement there is a church museum.

name: Noormarkun kirkko
description:
Noormarkku Church is a stone church in Pori, Noormarkku, completed in 1933. It was built on the same site as the old Noormarkku church, which was destroyed during the Civil War in 1918. In addition to the church and cemetery, the area also has a bell tower with an onion dome dating back to 1757.

The church was built in the medieval style between 1931 and 1933 with donations from Ahlström Oy. The drawings were made by Armas Lindgren. The church, built of Noormarkku granite, has seating for about 500 people. The church was renovated in 1989 according to the plans of architect Carl-Johan Slotten. In 2002, the Finnish Heritage Agency took over the protection of the single-nave church built in the medieval Finnish style.

name: Norrskatan kirkko
description: Norrskata Church is a wooden long church located on the island of Norrskata in Korpo, Parainen. It was built between 1932 and 1934 and lacks a tower. The church was renovated in 1951-1952 and 1967-1968. The church's six-voice organs were made by Jens Zachariassen in 1895 for Houtskari, from where they were moved to Norrskata in 1954. The belfry, built the following year, was designed by architect Ernst Adolf Nordström, and its bell dates back to 1954. The church also features a votive ship model, inspired by the brig Giro, built in 1868 in Norrskata. The altarpiece was chosen based on a competition organized by the islanders, with Axel Haartman's painting depicting Jesus preaching from a boat on Lake Genezaret winning.

name: Nousiaisten kirkko
description:
The Nousiainen Church is a medieval stone church located in Nousiainen, Finland. It is believed that several generations of wooden churches existed on or near the site, alongside the Hirvijoki River, since the 12th century. The first mention of the Nousiainen Church in contemporary sources dates back to 1232. The remains of Bishop Henry were moved from Nousiainen Church to Turku Cathedral in the 1290s.

Originally designed with two naves, the plans were altered during construction, resulting in a three-nave church with cross vaults. Simple square brick pillars support these vaults, adorned with paintings, likely from the 1430s, rediscovered in 1936 under layers of limewash. The church has undergone renovations and restorations in 1377, 1770, 1786, 1847, 1901, 1936, and 1967-69.

name: Nuijamaan kirkko
description:
Nuijamaan Church is located in Lappeenranta, in the Nuijamaa district. Designed by Tarja Salmio-Toiviainen and Esko Toiviainen, it was built between 1947 and 1948. Notably, it was the first reconstruction church built after the war. The church is a wooden long church without a tower.

The building's frame consists of six Cremona arches, which are visible as supporting structures in the walls. The church hall has a single nave, and the interior cladding and ceiling are brown-stained wood. A separate bell tower on a stone base, with a high shingled intermediate ceiling similar to the church's hipped roof, was built next to the church a year later. The altar sculpture "Descent from the Cross" was created by sculptor Armas Tirronen.

name: Nummen kirkko
description:
Nummen kirkko is a neoclassical greystone church, completed in 1822. It is located in Nummi, Lohja. Abraham Niklas Edelcrantz created the blueprints for the church in 1807 at the Royal Intendant Office in Stockholm.

The church has a cross shape and a tall bell tower on the eastern side. The roof of the bell tower features decorations including a weather vane with the sun and moon, three crosses, and a flaming sun, symbolizing God's righteousness. Before the current greystone church, there was a wooden church in the 17th century; its stone sacristy is now used as a mortuary. The old pulpit of Nummen church dates back to the 1640s.

name: Nummijärven kirkko
description:
Nummijärvi Church is a wooden church located in the village of Nummijärvi, in Kauhajoki. Construction began in 1929 after the government granted the villagers land and building materials to build a cemetery and prayer room. Architect Matti Visanti designed the church, which was completed in 1934.

The church is divided into two parts. The church hall is rectangular, with a lower wing housing the sacristy and a parish hall that can be opened to expand the church hall. The church features a curved wooden vault and white-painted log walls. The altar composition includes an altarpiece and the letters alpha and omega. A separate bell tower stands near the road, resembling a Swedish-style trestle tower. The church embodies the villagers' dedication to having their own church.

name: Nurmeksen kirkko
description:
The Nurmes Church is the fifth church in Nurmes' history, built between 1893 and 1896. It's located on Kirkkokatu 17. The church, designed by Frithiof Mieritz and J. Westerlund, is built with red brick in the late Neo-Gothic style, aiming for a cathedral-like appearance. It has a western tower that reaches 55 meters. Including the cross, the tower's total height is 60 meters.

Inside, the church seats approximately 2,200 people, making it one of the largest churches in Finland by seating capacity. The altarpiece, "Christ on the Cross," was painted by Väinö Hämäläinen in 1913. The church also features a 41-stop organ, built by Hans Heinrich in 1976, and stained-glass windows in the choir area, painted by Ilmari and Seppo Launis in 1934. The church has been renovated in 1930 and 1962.

name: Nurmon kirkko
description:
Nurmo Church, located in Seinäjoki, Southern Ostrobothnia, is a wooden cross church completed in 1779. It's situated in the Nurmo church village, near the banks of the Nurmo River. The church was constructed by Antti Hakola and later completed by his son, Kaapo Hakola.

The churchyard includes a chapel built in 1928, now used for storing the deceased, and a bell tower. The graveyard surrounding the church has been expanded several times. Inside the church, accessibility is provided with a lift at the left entrance and an accessible toilet at the rear of the church hall.

name: Närpiön kirkko
description:
Närpiö Church is a medieval stone church located in Närpiö. It was likely built around 1550-1555. The church, used by the Närpiö parish, was later expanded into a cross-shaped church. Six tombstones from the 17th century have been preserved inside the church.

The altarpiece, painted by the Swedish church painter Pehr Hörberg in 1803, depicts the crucifixion. The church's most unique artifact is a crucifix from the 15th century. The pulpit dates back to the 1730s. The bell tower, completed in 1757 under the direction of Matti Honga, represents the Ostrobothnian Renaissance style.

The church and its 151 church stables, along with the museum-preserved parish hall, create a unique historical church environment in Finland. The oldest part of the white-rendered stone church was built in 1435. The church has been rebuilt several times, including in 1555, when Bishop Mikael Agricola rededicated it.

name: Olarin kirkko
description: Olari Church is located in Espoo, Finland. Completed in 1981, it was designed by architects Simo and Käpy Paavilainen. The church provides seating for 485 people in the main hall, with additional space in the meeting room. The building also includes facilities for the Swedish-speaking parish of Espoo and a club building. Next to the church is the Gräsa urn grove. Inside the church is a baptismal tree called "You are the branches", where each baptized child receives a branch with their name and baptism date. The tree reflects the architecture and color scheme of the church and altar.

name: Olaus Petrin kirkko
description:
Olaus Petrin kirkko is a church located in Etu-Töölö, Helsinki. It belongs to the Swedish-speaking Olaus Petri congregation. The congregation was founded in 1922, and until 2007, it was part of the Church of Sweden. After 2007, it became part of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland. However, the congregation still serves Swedish citizens residing in Finland.

The church was completed in 1932 and was designed by architect Ture Ryberg in the Functionalist style. The church also has a parish hall, a library, and a parsonage. Due to its good acoustics, concerts are held in the church, and the Sibelius Academy also uses it.

name: Oravaisten kirkko
description:
Oravais Church is located in the municipality of Vöyri. The church was built between 1795 and 1797. The drawings were made in 1793 at the over-intendent's office in Stockholm. Carl Rijf, a church builder from Pietarsaari, was in charge of the construction.

The church is a neoclassical wooden church in the shape of an equal-armed cross. An octagonal tower topped by a dome rises from the center of the cross. The altar paintings, "Crucified" and "The Eucharist," were painted by Johan Erik Lindh in 1819. The pulpit was made in the 1790s. There is a wooden belfry built in 1927.

name: Orimattilan kirkko
description: The Orimattila Church is a granite-built cruciform church completed in 1866, designed by Jean Wik. Constructed between 1862 and 1866 in the Empire style, its bell tower was finished in 1851 and elevated in 1932. The tower houses four church bells, one located on the ground floor. The church is the fourth for the Evangelical-Lutheran parish of Orimattila. The stones for the church walls were quarried from Niemenkylä. It is a three-aisle church, featuring a wooden barrel vault in the central aisle and flat ceilings in the side aisles. Originally, the side aisles had galleries, providing seating for 1,700 people, but they were removed in 1932, reducing the capacity to 1,200. The altar painting, "Come to Me," was painted by Erik Johan Löfgren in 1874.

name: Oripään kirkko
description:
Oripään Church, located in Oripää, Southwest Finland, belongs to the Pöytyä parish. Constructed in 1821, this wooden church has a cross shape and a tower. Designed under Charles Bassi at the Intendent Office, its style is neoclassical and rather modest. The church has been well-preserved, maintaining its original appearance.

The pulpit dates back to 1675 and originates from the previous church. The oldest church bell is from 1750. Emil Rautala painted the altarpiece in 1929. A stone fence surrounds the church and cemetery, with a wooden gatehouse that is likely as old as the church itself. The Finnish Heritage Agency has designated the church as one of the significant built cultural environments in Finland.

name: Oriveden kirkko
description:
Orivesi Church serves as the main church for the Orivesi parish. It is a gathering place for weekly services, funerals, weddings, and baptisms. The current church was constructed in 1958, replacing an older wooden church that had burned down. Designed by architects Kaija and Heikki Siren, the "Kaarikirkko" (Arch Church) was consecrated in August 1961.

The church can accommodate 800 visitors. There is a ramp at the outer doors for disabled access, but wheelchair users may need assistance on the ramp. A birchwood abstract altar sculpture, "Golgata's Rock," was created by Kain Tapper. Dora Jung designed the church textiles, and Bertel Gardberg created the candlesticks and collection bag stands. The 39-stop organ, made by Kangasala organ factory, was completed in 1961. Next to the church stands a baroque-style, double-jointed wooden bell tower with an onion dome, built in 1780 by Matti Åkerblom. The bells in the tower date back to 1781 and 1826.

name: Oulaisten kirkko
description:
Oulaisten kirkko is a church located in Oulainen, Finland. The wooden church was originally built in 1753 under the direction of Matti Honka. The church's bell tower was constructed in 1758.

In 1882, the building's form was modified, and the church received a new stone foundation, entrance halls, and a tower. Erik Westzynthius the Younger decorated the church with murals between 1779 and 1782. The altar painting is from 1931 and was painted by Väinö Blomstedt.

name: Oulujoen kirkko
description: Oulujoen kirkko is located southeast of the city, near the Oulujoki river. It's one of the few wooden churches in Finland built in the Jugendstil style. The church was built in 1908, with architect Viktor Sucksdorff completing the plans in 1905. The building materials were donated by parishes and locals along the Oulujoki river. A unique aspect of the church is the altar construction, which unusually combines the pulpit and organ above it, differing from Lutheran traditions. The church is part of a nationally significant cultural environment, with a rectory built in 1899 that includes a church cottage, stable, and granary.

name: Oulun tuomiokirkko
description:
Oulu Cathedral is located in the center of Oulu and serves as the cathedral of the Diocese of Oulu. The church's current appearance is designed by Carl Ludvig Engel in 1832.

The stone walls of the church are from 1777, but the wooden parts were destroyed in the Oulu fire of 1822. The church represents Engel's neoclassical style, featuring straight lines, light surfaces, marbling, and gilding, creating a festive and dignified atmosphere.

Originally named Sofia Magdalena's Church after the wife of King Gustav III, it was designed by Daniel Hagman. The cathedral can accommodate approximately a thousand people and remains a recognizable landmark and a popular tourist destination.

name: Oulunkylän kirkko
description:
Oulunkylä Church, completed in 1972, serves as the main church for the Oulunkylä parish in Helsinki. Designed by architect Heikki Castrén, it's a multi-functional building with brown brick facades. 

Inside, the church has a versatile space, including a main hall, parish hall with kitchen facilities, and a music room. The church also houses the parish office. A wooden sculpture by Raimo Heino, titled "Minä se olen" ("It is I"), adorns the altar wall, depicting Jesus' arrest in Gethsemane. The church also features a 32-stop organ made by the Kangasala organ factory, along with a concert grand piano and a harpsichord.

name: Oulunkylän puukirkko
description:
Oulunkylä Wooden Church, formerly known as Oulunkylä Old Church until January 2024, is a church building belonging to the Oulunkylä Parish in Helsinki. It was originally built in 1905 as a prayer room for the Evangelical Association. The construction of the wooden church was partly done through volunteer work by the people of Oulunkylä.

In 1919, when the Oulunkylä parish was founded, the prayer room was converted into a temporary church. The parish later purchased it in 1950 and it served as the main church until 1972, when a new church was built. Since then, this charming wooden church has been a popular venue for baptisms and weddings. The altar features a bronze relief depicting Jesus blessing children, created by the Swedish sculptor Harald Sörensen-Ringi in 1909.

name: Oulunsalon kirkko
description:
Oulunsalo Church, located in Oulu, Finland, is a Lutheran church. This wooden church, completed in 1891, showcases a Gothic Revival style, designed by architect Julius Basilier. It stands as the third church in the area, replacing one destroyed by fire in 1882 caused by lightning.

The church features a long nave and a tower at the western end. Adjacent to the church is a cemetery with a memorial to the first church built in 1665. Inside, the church has a light and airy feel due to the high, wedge-shaped windows. The altar table is from the previous church.

name: Outokummun kirkko
description:
Outokummun kirkko is a church located in Outokumpu, Finland. Originally, after Outokumpu became a vibrant mining community, there was a great need for meeting spaces for spiritual activities, and after many phases, a new combined church and community center was completed in 1955. The church was inaugurated on April 3, 1955.

The design work was started by architect Bertel Liljeqvist, and after his death, the work was continued by architect Samuel Salvesen. The church has 450 seats. The building also includes a parish hall and various club and office spaces. A renovation was completed in the church in the summer of 2000, designed by architect Aulis Jääskeläinen. New church textiles were designed by Hanna Korvela, who was born in Outokumpu. In 2007, the church's downstairs facilities for activities and offices were renovated.

name: Paaterin kirkko
description:
Paaterin kirkko is a church located in Vuonislahti, Lieksa, approximately 27 kilometers from the center of Lieksa. It was designed by sculptor Eva Ryynänen and completed in 1991. The wooden church is Ryynänen's largest work.

During the summer, the church hosts services, weddings, baptisms, funerals, concerts, and other events. The altar is made from the root of a large tree. Paateri, where the church is located, was Eva Ryynänen's home and farm. Today, Paateri is a popular tourist destination and part of the Pielinen Museum. In addition to the church, visitors can explore Eva and Paavo Ryynänen's artist home, studio, and a gallery cafe.

name: Paattisten kirkko
description:
The Paattinen Church is located in Paattinen, Turku. It is a wooden church built in 1909, designed by Helge Rancken. The church belongs to the Paattinen parish. The church was renovated in 1983, restoring it to its original appearance.

The church is a cross-shaped church with beveled inner corners. The current church contains beams from the old church, which was built in 1696. The bell tower is even older, dating back to 1813. The altarpiece, a replica of Heinrich Hofmann's "Christ in Gethsemane," was painted by Vihtori Ylinen in 1920. The church also features a bridal crown from 1943 available for brides getting married in the church.

name: Paavalin kirkko
description:
St. Paul's Church, also known as Paavalinkirkko in Finnish, is a Lutheran church in the Vallila neighborhood of Helsinki. Designed by Bertel Liljequist, the red brick church was completed in 1930 and dedicated in March 1931.

The church can accommodate 800 people. It was once called "the most beautiful church in Helsinki". The church suffered damage during the Winter War, and traces of this can still be observed on one wall and the pillars at the main entrance. Above the main entrance, a statue depicts Paul the Apostle holding a sword, referencing his traditional martyrdom. The door handle features a cross, anchor, and heart, symbolizing faith, hope, and love.

name: Paavolan kirkko
description:
Paavolan church is a white wooden cruciform church located in the village of Paavola. It was built in just 66 days by Matti Honka from Kokkola and was inaugurated in 1756. The church got its name from the Swedish Princess Sofia. It is built near the location where the old Pehkola church stood, which was built without permission in 1691.

The bell tower, representing the Ostrobothnian Renaissance style, was completed in 1759. The church was renovated a hundred years after its completion, in 1856. A more thorough renovation took place between 1955 and 1958, when the church was electrified. The church has 500 seats.

name: Padasjoen kirkko
description: The Padasjoki Church is a brick-built long church with a tower, representing classicism. Construction of the church began in 1926, and it was consecrated in 1928. W. G. Palmqvist designed the church. The altar painting was rescued from the fire that destroyed the previous church in 1924. Also, chandeliers, wall sconces, altar candlesticks, and the pulpit book cover were saved from the previous church fire. Some coffins with bodies, dating back to the 1700s, located under the church, were also destroyed in the fire.

name: Pallivahan kirkko
description:
Pallivahan Church is a sacral space located in the Pallivaha parish center in Turku. It's situated in the Kärsämäki district, near highway 9, at the corner of Paltantie and Kaerlantie. It is one of the two churches belonging to the Maaria parish.

The building was completed in 1968 and designed by architect Pekka Pitkänen. The church's organ was built by Kangasala Urkutehdas.

The parish center has been renovated since 2012, but increasing moisture damage has been discovered, leading to the building being taken out of use. Instead of additional renovations, demolition is now being considered. The church does not have a traditional bell tower; instead, two bells cast in Austria are located above the church hall.

name: Palokan kirkko
description:
Palokan Church is located in Palokka, Jyväskylä. It was designed by architect Antti Eskelinen and completed in 1978. An extension to the church was designed by architect Jorma Teppo and completed in the summer of 1999.

The church has 350 seats when the church hall and church square are combined into one space. Connected to the church hall is a children's area with glass walls. The church also has a cafe that can accommodate 40 people for dining. Downstairs, there is a fireplace room for about 35 people and youth and day-care club rooms. Children have their own entrance and lobby downstairs. The church textiles were designed by Aino Kajaniemi.

name: Palosaaren kirkko
description:
Palosaari Church, originally built as a prayer room in 1910, is a stone Jugendstil church in Palosaari, Vaasa. It was designed by architect Alfred Wilhelm Stenfors. The church's tower, located to the side of the main entrance, was heightened in 1935 according to Stenfors's drawings.

Inside the church, the stained glass windows depict scenes from the life of Jesus, including his birth and baptism. The church also features a 30-stop organ made by Urkurakentamo Veikko Virtanen. The chandelier dates back to 1925 and was produced in an art workshop in Helsinki. Next to the church is a parish hall designed by architect Sulo Kalliokoski in 1968.

name: Paltaniemen kuvakirkko
description:
The Paltaniemi Church, also known as the Picture Church, is located in Paltaniemi, which is now part of Kajaani. This wooden church was completed in 1726 and is known for its impressive ceiling and wall paintings. These paintings depict scenes from the Old Testament to the Passion of Christ.

One of the most famous paintings is "The Last Judgment" above the main door. A significant portion of the depiction of hell's torments was later painted over due to its disturbing nature. The church is open to visitors during the summer. The Kalevala memorial stone is located at the church gates, symbolising the connections between Kainuu and Karelia.

name: Paltamon kirkko
description: Paltamo Church is the main church of the Paltamo parish, consecrated on August 4, 1946. Building the church during the post-war period was a great display of strength from the parishioners. The white-rendered brick church was designed by architect Ilmari Launis. It is a three-nave hall church. The main entrance is on the east end, and the choir area is on the west end. The bell tower rises directly above the main entrance. The church bell originates from the Konevitsa Monastery. The parish bought the approximately 900 kg bell, cast in 1875, after the war. The altarpiece was painted by Toivo G. Tuhkanen, who was born in Paltamo. Completed in 1947, the altarpiece depicts the ascension of Christ. The organ, made by Kangasala organ factory, was installed in the church in 1950. The church seats 400 people in its current configuration.

name: Panelian kirkko
description: Panelia Church is located in the village of Panelia, in the municipality of Eura, Satakunta, Finland. It was built as a prayer room in 1909 by the villagers themselves and designed by builder O. Salonen. The building material used was natural stone blocks quarried from Turajärvi granite. The church tower was completed in 1950, the same year the prayer room was consecrated as a church. The parish has been operating in Panelia Church for decades, but the church is still owned by the Panelia Prayer Room Association, which is rare in Finnish parish life. The first church was built in 1692, but it was destroyed in 1714.

name: Paraisten kirkko
description:
The Church of Parainen is a medieval stone church, one of over seventy medieval gray stone churches in Finland. The first written mention of the church is from June 6, 1329, in the Black Book of Turku Cathedral. However, it is unlikely that this refers to the current stone church. No documents about the church's construction phases have been preserved.

The church's construction history is exceptional. Initially, a low chancel was built, which was demolished at some point in the 15th century. The sacristy connected to this low chancel remained outside the church's east wall and later became the Agricola Chapel after an expansion. The church was last restored in 2011.

name: Parikkalan kirkko
description:
Parikkala Church is a wooden double-cross church. The drawings were approved in the Senate on March 9, 1813, and were created by state architect Carlo Bassi. The church was built between 1813 and 1817, on the same site as two previous churches. Construction was led by builder Matti Salonen.

In 1907, a 31-stop organ was acquired from the Kangasala organ factory. The altarpiece, depicting the Transfiguration of Christ, was donated in 1880 by Anna Lindfors, a chimney master's widow from Parikkala living in St. Petersburg. The painting was created by a Russian artist named Grevizevskij. The church has 1200 seats.

name: Parkanon kirkko
description:
The Parkano Church was built in 1800 by Salomon Köhlström, a church builder also likely responsible for its design. It was inaugurated in 1805, along with the adjacent cemetery, which has since been expanded.

The altarpiece dates back to 1839 and was painted by Henrik Grönlund. The church acquired its first organ in 1894. A second organ was inaugurated in 1949, incorporating parts from the Hiitola Church organ that had been evacuated to Parkano. The current organ, built in 1977, has 21 stops and was made by Urkurakentamo Hans Heinrich.

The interior was renovated in 1993, aiming to restore the church to its 1890 appearance with modern updates. In 2014, all the floors, including the organ loft, were replaced.

name: Pattijoen kirkko
description:
Pattijoki Church, also known as the Chapel of Silence, is located in Raahe, and was designed by Josef Stenbäck. Completed in 1912, this church is constructed of concrete and brick and is rendered white. The architectural style reflects Jugendstil influences. The church has a steep, gable-shaped cement tile roof.

The building features a long church design with a tower at the end and transverse gables protruding from the altar end, lower than the main roof ridge. A relatively large tower is topped with a slender, steep spire. The church seats 250 people and covers 250 square meters. Inside, a wooden altar sculpture depicting Golgotha originates from Germany. A unique feature is the pulpit's location on the right side of the church hall, facing the altar.

name: Pedersören kirkko
description:
Pedersöre Church is a medieval stone church located in Pietarsaari. Despite its name, it's no longer in the municipality of Pedersöre due to area annexations. The church is one of the oldest in Ostrobothnia.

The medieval church was expanded in the 1780s and is considered one of the most significant buildings of Gustaviana stone architecture in Finland. The layout is a cruciform stone church with a tall, pointed tower in the west end and a Doric portico in the east end. The windows, other openings, and outer corners are emphasized with rustic plastering. The sacristy is between the eastern and northern crosses. The interior has a continuous plank vault, and the walls are articulated with pilasters and a triglyph-equipped entablature.

name: Pelkosenniemen kirkko
description: The Pelkosenniemi Church is a wooden long church located in Pelkosenniemi, completed in 1929. It was designed by architect Yrjö Sadeniemi and represents 1920s classicism. The church has a gable tower. It survived the Lapland War without being destroyed. The altar painting, depicting Christ being taken down from the cross, was painted by Aale Hakava in 1954. The church organ has ten stops and was moved to Pelkosenniemi Church in 1962. The church has seating for 300 people and has disabled access.

name: Pellon kirkko
description: The Pellon Church is located in Pello and was built between 1950 and 1953. It was primarily funded with the support of Lutheran churches in the United States and was consecrated on August 16, 1953. The church was designed by Antero Pernaja and is cottage-like in style. The interior consists of a church hall and a small parish hall. Next to the church is a separate bell tower. The church hall can accommodate 350 people. The altarpiece, "The Second Coming of Jesus", is an oil painting on canvas by Aale Hakava from 1953. The church also features stained glass.

name: Pengonpohjan kirkko
description:
Pengonpohja Church, also known as Pengonpohjan rukoushuone, is located in the village of Pengonpohja in Ylöjärvi. Construction began in 1893 and was completed in 1898 through community effort. A sewing society has supported the church since 1925. The Ylöjärvi parish currently owns it.

The church was initially a rectangular long church without a tower, featuring a narrower and lower sacristy at the altar end. It has undergone renovations in 1928, 1938, and 1962, and can seat 250 people. In 1954, an open-walled bell tower was built next to the church to house a bell from the Kaukonen Church.

The altar painting, donated by the sewing society in 1928, was painted by Anna Sahlstén and depicts Matthew 11:28. The church also has a harmonium. The prayer house is not in use during the winter season, between October and Easter.

name: Perhon kirkko
description:
The Perho Church, completed in 1903, is located in the municipality of Perho. It is the second church on the same site in Jängänharju. The first church was built in 1782. The current wooden church is a cross-shaped church owned by the Perho parish.

The church is a unique example of wooden architecture from the turn of the 19th and 20th centuries, featuring a style reminiscent of villa architecture. The hipped shingle roof is topped with a high tower. The altar painting, titled "Christ of the Wilderness," was painted by Ilmari Virkkala in 1938. The belfry was constructed in 1799 and renovated in 1840. The heroes' cemetery and its memorial were designed by sculptor Ilmari Wirkkala.

name: Pernajan kirkko
description: Pernaja Church, located in Loviisa, is a medieval stone church dating back to the 15th century, likely built between 1410 and 1440. Dedicated to St. Michael and St. Erik, it stands on the site of an earlier wooden church, with mentions of a church existing there as early as 1352. The church features a three-nave structure, a weapon room, and a sacristy. In May 2023, a fire caused smoke damage to the church, but cleaning began in early 2024. The interior is well-preserved, and the church is open during the summer.

name: Perniön kirkko
description: Perniö Church, dedicated to St. Lawrence, is a medieval stone church located in the village of Perniö. It was likely constructed between 1460 and 1480. The church features a three-aisle structure, with vaulted ceilings adorned with paintings from the late 15th century. These paintings were covered with whitewash starting in 1667 but were revealed and restored in the early 1900s and then again in the 1960s. The altarpiece was painted in 1703. The current pulpit, representing the Neo-Gothic style, dates back to 1865. The belfry dates back to 1746. The church has seating for 550 people.

name: Perttelin kirkko
description:
Pertteli Church is a medieval stone church located in Salo. It is dedicated to St. Bartholomew. The church was likely built in the early 1500s, with the armory added in 1750 and the sacristy in the 1820s. The church windows were enlarged in 1881.

The separate wooden bell tower's oldest parts date back to the 1720s, and it received its current neo-Gothic appearance in 1889. The tower was damaged by fire in 1888 but was rebuilt the following year. The church is located in a scenic spot within the Uskelanjoki cultural landscape. The altar is framed in the neo-Gothic style.

name: Pertunmaan kirkko
description:
Pertunmaa Church is a wooden church with a short tower, located in Pertunmaa, Finland. It was constructed in 1929 based on the designs of master builder Matti Vihonen. The church has a seating capacity of 400 people and occupies an area of 400 square meters.

Interestingly, the church was partially built using logs from the old Hartola church, maintaining a similar shape. The tower incorporates the belfry of the Hartola Church, but with a modified design featuring three floors and a lantern topped with a tent roof. The church's two bells were sourced from a former Russian military church in Mikkeli in 1924.

The building has rounded windows at the ends and pilasters at the corners, and the exterior ceilings are saddle-shaped. Inside, there is a wooden arch, and the inner walls retain a log surface. The church underwent renovation in 1958. The altarpiece, depicting "Jesus blessing the children," was painted by Albert Carlsson.

name: Peräseinäjoen kirkko
description: The Peräseinäjoki Church, also known as St. Paul's Church, is located in Peräseinäjoki, Seinäjoki. It is the second church of the parish, completed in 1892, after the old church was demolished. Designed by county architect Ivar Aminoff, the wooden cross church features three galleries and seats for approximately 1000 people. The sacristy contains a votive ship from the late 1800s, a model sailboat donated to the church, which is a rare sight in an inland church. The ship, named Teekla, was restored by Matti Laine, and is believed to have been made by Johan Jaakonpoika Valkava. The church is open to visitors during the summer.

name: Petolahden kirkko
description: Petolahden kirkko is a wooden cross-shaped church built in Petolahti, Maalahti, in 1805. Twelve local farmers built the church at their own expense and without permission. The church represents the classical church building style of the 1800s. A tower is located at the top of the cross center and was added during later repairs. The roof is a traditional shingle roof. A separate two-story bell tower was built in connection with the church in 1832, featuring classicism, but an empire-style cut-off pyramid top rising from the domed roof. The church has 350 seats. Isac Österholm painted the altarpiece "The Crucified" in 1861. The church's nine-voice organ was manufactured by Kangasala organ factory in 1974.

name: Petäjäveden kirkko
description:
The Petäjävesi Old Church is a wooden church in central Finland, built between 1763 and 1765. It represents a unique architectural tradition in eastern Scandinavia, blending Renaissance ideas with older Gothic elements. The church was constructed by local people, with Jaakko Klemetinpoika Leppänen as the master builder.

A bell tower was added in 1821 by Leppänen's grandson. The church's design features a cross-shaped floor plan and a high roof. Inside, the pulpit, pews, and chandeliers are hand-carved from pine. After a new church was built nearby, the old one was abandoned for a time but was later recognized for its historical and architectural value. Today, it is a UNESCO World Heritage site and is used for services in the summer.

name: Petäjäveden vanha kirkko
description:
Petäjäveden Old Church is a wooden church located in Petäjävesi, about 30 kilometers from Jyväskylä. It was built between 1763 and 1765 by local builders, led by Jaakko Klemetinpoika Leppänen. In 1994, UNESCO added the church to its World Heritage List as a unique example of the long tradition of Nordic wooden church architecture and log construction.

The church is a cruciform church, and a belfry connected by a corridor was added in 1821. The interior is cross-shaped, with the arms tapering outwards in a false perspective. The walls and vaults are unpainted, with red paintwork only on the cover strips of the vaults. The altar painting, depicting the Holy Communion, is from 1843. Today, the church is still used in the summer for services, weddings, and concerts and attracts around 14,000 visitors every year.

name: Pieksämäen Uusi kirkko
description: Pieksämäen Uusi kirkko, or the New Church of Pieksämäki, was completed in 1968 and serves as one of the churches in Pieksämäki. Initially built for the town parish, an extension was added in 1986. The church provides seating for 420 people in its main hall. Besides religious services, the building hosts various smaller events. It also includes club rooms and a sports hall. Gunnar Uotila created the altarpiece, and the church features an organ made by Juhani Tuomi's organ factory. The architects Keijo Ström and Olavi Tuomisto, both students of Alvar Aalto, designed the church. The church is located near the main street of Pieksämäki, Keskuskatu, opposite the Pieksämäki high school.

name: Pieksämäen vanha kirkko
description:
The Old Church of Pieksämäki is located on Pappilanmäki and serves as the main church of the Pieksämäki parish. It's one of the oldest churches in the Diocese of Kuopio still used for worship. The church was built in 1753, being the third church building on the same hill. The belfry is even older, dating back to 1746 and is the oldest building in Pieksämäki.

August Sorsa, a builder from Kiihtelysvaara, constructed the current cross-shaped church. A notable feature is the paintings by Mikael Toppelius, including a portrait of vicar Paul Krogius and images of prophets and disciples on the gallery railings. The pulpit features paintings of Reformation figures Martin Luther and Philip Melanchthon.

name: Pielaveden kirkko
description:
Pielaveden kirkko is a large wooden long church with a tower, representing the Neo-Gothic style, built in Pielavesi in 1878. It was designed by the provincial architect Ferdinand Öhman.

The church features lower and narrower transepts that diverge from the sides of the nave in the middle, and a polygonal choir at the altar end. A renovation was carried out in 1990 according to the plans of Aulis Jääskeläinen, during which the church's electric heating and interior were renewed, and the church was painted. The altarpiece is a glass painting by Urpo Vainio, Christ is Risen, from 1956.

name: Pielisensuun kirkko
description:
Pielisensuu Church is located on top of Niinivaara hill in Joensuu. It serves as the main church for the parish of the same name. The church was designed by architect Veikko Larkas and completed in 1960. It is a high-roofed, rectangular building made of brick and reinforced concrete. A small bell tower sits at the top. The church is 36 meters high.

Inside, the church hall can accommodate 450 people, some of whom can sit in the organ loft. There are two parish halls, with the upper hall accommodating 95 people and the lower hall accommodating 45 people. The church also houses several club rooms and offices for employees. The original altar textiles were designed by textile artist Dora Jung. The altar features a large cross and a mosaic wall symbolizing the days of human life. A wooden sculpture "Good Shepherd" by sculptor Eva Ryynänen is located in the church's pulpit.

name: Pietarsaaren kirkko
description:
The church in Pietarsaari is known as Jakobstads kyrka in Swedish.
It's a wooden cross-shaped church located in the center of Pietarsaari.
It is one of the earliest cross-shaped churches in Finland.
The sacristy, an extension of the eastern arm of the cross, was built in the 1770s.
Inside, the pulpit made by carpenter Magnus Holländer in 1774 and the altarpiece painted by Frans Gabriel Westenberg in 1788 are notable.
The fine brass chandeliers were donated by the town's burghers in the 1690s to the first church of the parish.
The bell tower, built in the Ostrobothnian style, was constructed in 1742.

name: Pihlajamäen kirkko
description:
Pihlajamäen kirkko is a church building located in Pihlajamäki, Helsinki. It belongs to the Malmi parish. The church was designed by architect Esko Korhonen and was completed in 1976. The brick church has three floors and is designed for multiple uses.

The church hall has seating for 250 people, and when combined with the parish hall, it can accommodate up to 500 people. The church is also known for its altarpiece, a wooden relief of Christ's suffering by Tapio Junno, which caused controversy when it was first installed. The church also has a mechanical organ made in 1977.
