name: Pihlajaveden kirkko
description:
Pihlajaveden kirkko, also known as Pihlajaveden Old Church or Wilderness Church, is a wooden church located in Keuruu.
It was built between 1780 and 1782.
The church was designed by the famous church builder Matti Pärnä-Åkerblom.
Initially, the community only had permission to build a simple prayer room, but driven by enthusiasm, they constructed a proper church.
The church has a long nave with a bell tower on the west end, topped with a shingle-covered onion dome typical of Åkerblom's style.
Inside, the church is rather plain, without paintings, but it has original floors in the vestibule and sacristy.
One of the unique features is the shadows of people on the walls, a reminder of the churchgoers from centuries past.
Surrounding the church is a graveyard enclosed by a stone fence.
The church is now a popular wedding venue and concert location during the summer.

name: Pihlajaveden vanha kirkko
description:
Pihlajavesi Old Church, also known as Pihlajavesi Wilderness Church, is a Lutheran church located in Pihlajavesi, Central Finland. It is called the Wilderness Church because of its secluded location in a forest.

Constructed between 1780 and 1783, it was designed by Matti Åkerblom, a notable church builder. The church is made of timber, featuring exposed logs on both the exterior and interior. An integral bell tower sits above the entrance at the western end.

Initially, the church was built without formal permission, leading to complaints. However, it was eventually consecrated in 1787. After a new church was built in Pihlajavesi in 1870, the old church fell into disrepair and was scheduled for demolition, but it was rediscovered and renovated in the 1920s. The Finnish Heritage Agency protects the church as a nationally significant cultural site.

name: Pihlavan kirkko
description:
Pihlavan kirkko is a church located in the Pihlava district, in the Meri-Pori area of Pori. It serves the Meri-Pori parish. The church was designed by architect Olaf Küttner and completed in 1957. It was last renovated in 1993.

The church has a main hall that can accommodate 200 people and an additional hall for gatherings that can accommodate 70 people. The church also has mechanical organs with 11 stops. Services are held every Sunday at 10:00 AM.

name: Pihtiputaan kirkko
description:
The Pihtipudas Church is a wooden cross church located in the municipality of Pihtipudas. Completed in 1783, it stands as the oldest church building still in use in Central Finland. The church was designed by Simon Silvén, a well-known builder of the time.

Initially, the church had log walls and was painted red, featuring small windows and no galleries. The pulpit was originally from the Viitasaari church. A major restoration took place in 1991–1992, designed by architect Matti Leibner, aiming to restore the church's appearance closer to its 1874 renovation. During this renovation, new technology and social facilities were installed in the interior.

name: Piikkiön kirkko
description:
Piikkiö Church is a late Gothic stone church located in Piikkiö, Kaarina. The current church was built in 1755 next to an older church building. The church's design is attributed to Samuel Berner.

Inside, the single-nave church hall is covered by a wooden barrel vault. The walls are smooth, plastered, and painted in light colors. The altar is adorned with a large drapery composition. The interior features mainly date back to the 1700s and are exceptionally well-preserved, including a rare, long, and narrow side gallery on the south wall.

The belfry, situated on a rock north of the church, was built in 1810. The churchyard has been expanded several times and includes a yellow-painted brick burial chapel built in 1819 by the owner of Pussila Manor.

name: Piippolan kirkko
description:
Piippola Church is a wooden cross church located in the village of Piippola in Siikalatva. The church was constructed between 1768 and 1770 under the direction of Simo Jylkkä. It was inaugurated on New Year's Day in 1771 and named the Church of Magdalena after the then-crown princess.

The church can accommodate approximately 300 people. The altarpiece was painted by Kaarlo Metsävainio in 1910. The church has undergone several major renovations. In 1888, the round-arched doors and windows were given a Gothic appearance. The church tower houses a church museum.

name: Pirkkalan kirkko
description:
Pirkkalan Old Church is located in Pirkkalankylä. It was built in 1921, when Pirkkala and Nokia were separated. The church was designed by architect Ilmari Launis and has 175 seats.

There is also a newer church in Pirkkala that was built in 1994. It has a modern look, designed by Simo and Käpy Paavilainen, and has 300 seats, or 500 when expanded. Next to the church is a building with club facilities.

name: Pirkkalan vanha kirkko
description:
Pirkkalan Vanha kirkko, or the Old Church of Pirkkala, is located in Pirkkalankylä. It was built in 1921 when Pirkkala and Nokia were separated. The church was designed by architect Ilmari Launis and has 150 seats.

The church's history dates back to the 1200s when a church was already located in the same area. The current building was consecrated on July 3, 1921. In 1937, the church was painted according to the plans of artist Uuno Alanko, who also created the altarpiece. A fire damaged the interior of the church badly on Christmas Eve in 1945, and the church was renovated the following year. Uuno Alanko repainted the altarpiece entirely during the restoration. The church was renovated again in 1972, when it received heating, was repainted inside, and the organ was replaced.

name: Pirttikylän kirkko
description:
The Pirttikylä Church is located in Pirttikylä, Närpiö. It belongs to the parish of Närpiö. The church was completed in 1783 and was designed by builder J. Elfström, who also designed the churches of Raippaluoto and Sulva. The Rieger organ factory made the organ in 1933.

The Pirttikylä Church is a wooden long church with a gable tower. The neoclassical wooden church has a long church shape with a western tower. The choir end is folded. On the long sides, on the choir end, protrude an entrance hall and a sacristy. The top floor of the dome-ended tower is pilastered. The facades are articulated by a strongly profiled roof list, pilasters and arched windows.

name: Pispalan kirkko
description:
Pispalan Kirkko, located in Ala-Pispala, Tampere, is a fascinating blend of architectural styles from different eras. It is part of the Harju parish. The church serves as a place where locals are confirmed, get married, and attend services. The current church was built in 1971 as an extension to the parish hall, after the original wooden church was destroyed in a fire in 1968.

Inside the church, you'll find a wooden medieval crucifix and an intricately carved pulpit dating back to 1660. These items were originally part of the Harju chapel church. The church has a spacious and asymmetrical main hall with an organ on the right side. The furnishings are flexible, adapting to various events. The church has 330 seats and two altarpieces.

name: Pitäjänmäen kirkko
description:
Pitäjänmäki Church is located in Helsinki, in the Pitäjänmäki district. It was completed in 1959, initially as an auxiliary church for the Huopalahti parish. Later, it became the main church of the Pitäjänmäki parish when the parish became independent in 1966.

The church was designed by architects Eija and Olli Saijonmaa. The facades of the church are made of brick, and the bell tower rising above the roof is made of concrete. When completed, in addition to the church hall, two parish halls, club rooms, and the pastor's office, there was also a gymnasium. During a renovation in 2005–2006, an intermediate floor was built in the gymnasium, providing office space upstairs and youth facilities downstairs. The building was also expanded with a stairwell and elevator. The church's organ is a 17-voice mechanical organ.

name: Pohjan kirkko
description: The Church of Pohja, dedicated to the Virgin Mary, is a medieval stone church situated in Raasepori. It was likely constructed between 1475 and 1480, although a wooden church may have existed on the site around 200 years prior. The oldest historical artifact in the church is a wooden sculpture depicting Madonna and Child, possibly dating back to the earlier wooden church. The churchyard serves as the final resting place for Hélène Mannerheim, mother of Marshal Mannerheim. Klaus Fleming, a Governor of Finland, reportedly died near the church in 1597. The church has undergone renovations, including one in 2001 that significantly updated the lighting.

name: Pohjaslahden kirkko
description:
The Pohjaslahti Church, located in Mänttä-Vilppula, was completed in 1931 and designed by architect Kauno Kallio. Bishop Jaakko Gummerus consecrated the church on July 17, 1932. Representing 1920s Classicism, the plastered brick church features a gable roof and a tower at the end.

A narrower, rectangular sacristy protrudes from the altar end, shorter than the main body. The tower, which narrows in steps with a sloping roof, ends in a gable roof. The church has been renovated several times, and its surface area is 386 square meters with seating for 400 people. The altar painting, depicting Jesus with his disciples in Gethsemane, was painted by Urho Lehtinen in 1932.

name: Polvijärven kirkko
description:
The Polvijärvi Church is located in Polvijärvi and serves as the main church for the Outokumpu and Polvijärvi parishes. It's a wooden long church with a gable tower, built between 1879 and 1881, designed by county architect Ferdinand Öhman. It replaced an earlier church on the same site from 1847 that was deemed unusable due to construction errors.

Extensive renovations were carried out in the 1950s, during which artist Lauri Välke painted the altar wall and the decorative paintings on the gallery railings. Before the 1950s, the church had already been repaired in the 1910s. Another renovation took place in the 1980s, when the wood fiberboards on the walls were painted white and the stove heating was replaced with electric heating. The church has three bells in its tower, dating from 1847, 1910 and 1947.

name: Pomarkun kirkko
description:
The Pomarkku Church was built between 1914 and 1921, based on plans by Ilmari Launis. The church represents late National Romanticism in style. The gray granite church has a rectangular shape with two opposing, lower entrance wings. At the choir end, there is a separate, low sacristy. At the opposite end, there is a small bell tower.

Inside, the three-aisled church hall has a concrete vault. Unusually, the pulpit is located above the altar. The altar fresco depicts the moment of Jesus' death on the cross, surrounded by symbolic images related to the history of salvation. The church is a unified work of art, complete with the altar fresco and rich decorative paintings.

name: Pomarkun vanha puukirkko
description:
Pomarkku Old Church is a wooden church completed in 1802. The design and construction were done by local peasants, including Heikki Lintula. It is a copy of the old church of Kauvatsa, designed by Per Wilhelm Palmroth, except for the shape of the tower. The church's exterior walls were clad with boarding in 1838.

Inside the church hall, the altar and pulpit are exceptionally located on the north wall. The church is a well-preserved example of an early 19th-century wooden church. After the new church was built in 1921, the old church was intended to be demolished, but the idea was abandoned. Today, the Finnish Heritage Agency supports the maintenance of the church, and it is only used in the summertime.

name: Pornaisten kirkko
description: The Pornaisten kirkko is a stone church located in Pornainen, Uusimaa. It was designed by architect Ilmari Launis and completed in 1924. The church is built from local granite and has three naves. It can accommodate around 250 people, making it a popular wedding venue. A separate bell tower, built in 1834, burned down in 1993, leaving only the stone foundation. The church was consecrated on October 5, 1924. The church organ is a mechanical organ with 12 stops, manufactured by Kangasala organ factory. Behind the altar is the "Wanha sali" (Old Hall), renovated in 2007, which can be used for coffee after the service or for continuing a baptismal party. The women of the area wove linen to make money to buy a bell for the church.

name: Porvoon tuomiokirkko
description:
Porvoo Cathedral is a medieval stone church dating back to the 1400s, though a wooden church existed on the site even earlier in the 1300s. It is located in the Old Town of Porvoo. The church has been damaged or destroyed by fire several times throughout its history, including incidents in the 16th, 18th, and 21st centuries.

Despite these setbacks, the cathedral has been rebuilt and restored, and it remains an important landmark and a popular venue for worship, concerts, and weddings. In 1809, Porvoo Diet was held in the cathedral, during which Emperor Alexander I confirmed Finland's autonomy. Today, it serves as the main church for the Porvoo Finnish Parish and the Diocese of Borgå.

name: Posion kirkko
description:
The Posio Church was initially built as a prayer room between 1926 and 1927 without formal drawings, through communal work by the men of Posio. It is located about three kilometers southwest of the Posio center. In 1952–53, the church underwent thorough repairs under the direction of master builder Nestori Jäming and was consecrated on August 21, 1953, by Bishop Väinö Malmivaara.

The latest renovation took place in 1966, designed by architect Aarre Holttinen. The church's altar furnishings were renewed in 2011. Next to the church, a bell tower was completed in 1957, designed by architect Paavo Riihimäki. In 2011, a chapel was added to the churchyard, including a farewell room, a mortuary, and public restrooms. A walking path around the church's shore was completed in 2012.

name: Pudasjärven kirkko
description:
The Pudasjärvi Church, completed in 1781, is a cruciform church located in the village of Pudasjärvi. It is the third church built on the same site on the shore of Lake Pudasjärvi. The church can accommodate approximately 700 people. Johan Gustav Hedman painted the altarpiece in 1825.

The church's bell tower has three floors and features the only known outdoor paintings by Mikael Toppelius, dating back to 1765-1766. The graveyard surrounding the church is enclosed by a 1370-meter-long wooden fence. Within the graveyard, there is a memorial to those who fell in the Civil War, as well as the grave of Josephus Palmannus, the first vicar of Pudasjärvi, and his family.

name: Puijon kirkko
description:
Puijon kirkko is a brick church located in the Puijonlaakso district of Kuopio, Finland. It was designed by architect Seppo Ruotsalainen and built in 1977. The flat-roofed church is taller than the surrounding buildings. It also features a campanile-style bell tower.

The entrance to the church is in the middle of the building, opposite the altar. Tall windows above the entrance let light into the church hall. The sacristy is at the end of the church hall, to the right of the entrance. The church has seating for 300 people, with an additional 100 seats available when the doors to the parish hall are opened. The altar relief, titled "Tulkaa minun tyköni" (Come to Me), was designed by pastor Matti Komulainen in the 1970s. The church's 24-stop organ was made by Kangasala organ factory in 1977. In the churchyard is a stone angel statue "Angelus Domini" designed by sculptor Arvo Siikamäki.

name: Puistolan kirkko
description:
Puistolan kirkko is a church located in Helsinki, specifically at Tenavatie 4, 00760 Helsinki. The parking address is Kasukka, 00760 Helsinki. You can contact the church by phone at 09 2340 4425 or by email. It is part of the Malmi Parish.

The church hosts various events, including praise and worship dance for adults, a handicraft and weaving club for small groups, a family café for children and families, moments of peace and prayer, and musical events. The church also provides services and support.

name: Pukkilan kirkko
description: Pukkila Church was built in 1814 by the famous church builder Mats Åkergren. The second church of Pukkila, located in the Porvoo River Valley, stands on a small hill. The wooden church is an unequal-armed, internally chamfered cross church. Above the main entrance rises a bell tower resembling a belfry, the bells of which date back to the 18th century. The center of the cross of the body of the house is decorated with a roof rider. In July, the church is open on Sundays. The first church in Pukkila was built in 1606, about a kilometer north of the current church.

name: Punkaharjun kirkko
description:
The Punkaharju Church, also known as the Apostle Thomas Church, is located in Punkasalmi, Savonlinna. It was inaugurated on New Year's Day in 1923. The church was designed by builder R. Rouhe from Savonlinna.

Inside, the altarpiece depicting Apostle Thomas was donated by And. Auvinen Corporation and painted by Martta Helminen in 1927. The church's first organ was made by Kangasala organ factory for the 10th anniversary of the Punkaharju congregation. The current organ with 15 voices dates from 1973 and was built by organ builder Hans Heinrich.

A significant renovation was completed in 2000, extending the church hall by about five meters, adding a glass corridor as an entrance hall, and placing the bell tower in connection with the church. Artist Maire Pyykkö designed the stained glass windows for the side windows of the church choir. After the renovation, Bishop Voitto Huotari rededicated the church and named it the Apostle Thomas Church.

name: Punkalaitumen kirkko
description:
Punkalaitumen Church is a wooden cross-shaped church painted in brown tones, standing on a church hill. The church was built in 1774. The current altarpiece was painted by Alexandra Frosterus-Såltin in 1888 and depicts the Transfiguration of Christ.

The church's organ was made by Hämeen urkutehdas in 1984 and designed by Pentti Pello. The churchyard has parking, and the church itself is accessible. The church provides diverse services like worship services, weddings, and funerals and hosts community events and concerts.

name: Puolangan kirkko
description:
The Puolanka Church was completed in 1954 and designed by architect Olavi Sortta. A distinctive feature is its high, arched, and bright ceiling. The lighting is indirect, shining from the white ceiling, and wood is prominently featured around the edges of the church. The altar painting, created by Paavo Tolonen in 1982, depicts Jesus calling and addressing various people, who respond in different ways, emphasizing Jesus's presence in the midst of life.

The church has a reasonably large parking area. It is wheelchair accessible via a ramp, and the altar table is also accessible. There is an accessible toilet with a baby changing table in the church lobby. The church has seating for approximately 350 people. The old church was destroyed by fire in 1949, caused by lightning.

name: Purmon kirkko
description:
Purmo Church is located in the village of Sisbacka, in the municipality of Pedersöre. It primarily serves the Swedish-speaking congregation of Purmo for services, ceremonies, and concerts. Built in 1772, the church is a symmetrical cross-shaped building with a small tower. The bell tower, completed in 1775, stands separately.

Inside, the church accommodates around 450 people. The altar, featuring Corinthian columns, the railing and altar tables date back to the 1810s and resemble the altar in Ähtävä Church. The pulpit is a copy from Pedersöre Church, made in the early 1800s, and the altarpiece was painted by Johan Gustav Hedman. The current organ was installed in 1969, reusing the facade from the previous one.

name: Pusulan kirkko
description:
Pusulan kirkko is a wooden church located in the village of Pusula, in the municipality of Lohja, Finland. Designed by Carl Ludvig Engel, it was constructed in 1838. The church features a neo-Gothic style.

Soon after its completion, structural issues emerged due to the roof's weight. Consequently, the roof was lowered by eight meters during repair work carried out in 1858-59. The altarpiece inside the church was painted in 1921 by Felix Frang. The wooden bell tower next to the church was built in 1763, predating the current church building itself. The church has a seating capacity of 750.

name: Puumalan kirkko
description: The Church of St. John the Baptist in Puumala is a wooden double-cruciform church. It was built between 1830 and 1832. The simple, beautiful church and old cemetery are prominent features of Puumala village. The church was consecrated in 1832, and it was renovated most recently in 2006-2007. The church has seating for over 1000 people, and the organ loft houses a 36-register organ. The separate wooden bell tower dates back to 1806. The churchyard also contains a war veterans' memorial designed by Armas Tirronen in 1959. The annual "Sounds of Saimaa" music festival is held at the church in July, taking advantage of the building's acclaimed acoustics.

name: Pyhtään kirkko
description:
Pyhtää Church is a medieval stone church located in Pyhtää. It was built around 1460 and is dedicated to Saint Henry. The church is one of the best-preserved medieval churches in Finland, retaining its original architectural form.

Inside, you can find original medieval vaults and murals, as well as wooden carvings. The windows feature rare brick detailing. The altarpiece "Christ at Emmaus" was painted by Auguste Joseph Desarnod and donated to the church in 1848.

The church's west end is more ornately decorated than the east end, featuring a large cross composition with decorative recesses, ribbons, and quatrefoil patterns. The bell tower was constructed in the 1820s, and in 1998, the church received a new 21-stop organ.

name: Pyhäjoen kirkko
description:
The modern Pyhäjoki Church was completed in 1977, designed by architect office Karvala & Silvennoinen. This is the third church in Pyhäjoki. The first one was built in the 16th century. The candle chandeliers and baptismal font from the first church still adorn the present church.

The previous church, designed by C.L. Engel and completed in 1844, was destroyed by fire in 1974 after being struck by lightning. The current church combines modern architectural style with a sacral atmosphere. Inside, a tile relief called "Ten Virgins" by sculptor Kari Juva decorates the wall of the bright church hall. The bell tower, built in 1736, still serves the parishioners. A traditional pauper statue rescued from the burned church also stands in the current building.

name: Pyhäjärven kirkko
description:
Pyhäjärvi Church is located in Pyhäjärvi, Northern Ostrobothnia. The current church was completed in 1897, designed by architect Odert Sebastian Gripenberg. It's a wooden cruciform church.

The previous church, completed in 1790, was destroyed by a lightning strike in 1895. Construction of a new church began on the same site, but it burned down in the fall of 1896, nearing completion. The present church was built according to the same drawings as the one that burned.

The altarpiece was painted by Ilmari Wirkkala in 1945, depicting Jesus on the Cross with people from different nations gathered at the foot. The old wooden cross that was on the altar has been placed behind the painting.

name: Pyhämaan uhrikirkko
description:
The Pyhämaa Sacrifice Church, located in Pyhämaa near Uusikaupunki, is a wooden long church built between 1647 and 1652. It is one of the best-preserved 17th-century churches in Finland. Adjacent to it is the newer Pyhämaa Church, completed in 1804.

The Sacrifice Church is renowned for its unique paintings by Christian Wilbrandt from 1667, a significant part of Finnish 17th-century art history. These well-preserved paintings adorn the ceiling and walls of the church hall, depicting biblical scenes and baroque-inspired images. The church has a rectangular shape with a triple-folded altar end. Originally, it was known as a place where people prayed for help, and those who survived hardships made donations to the church.

name: Pyhämaan uusi kirkko
description: The New Church of Pyhämaa is a grey stone long church with a gable tower, built next to an old sacrificial church. The church was constructed according to drawings made by the Swedish Office of the Superintendent in 1795 and was completed in 1804. The roof is a gable roof. Originally, the church tower had an open lantern, but it was renovated in 1908 in the Neo-Gothic style, ending in a spire and four small corner towers. The interior ceiling of the church hall is a low, wooden barrel vault. Behind the eastern altar is a sacristy and a priest's chamber with a gallery above them. The church represents typical Swedish office architecture from the late 1700s and early 1800s and is architecturally modest.

name: Pyhän Andreaan kirkko
description: St. Andrew's Church is located in the Kaakkuri district of Oulu. This modern, red-brick church was built between 2003 and 2004. Architect Janne Pihlajaniemi from Arkkitehdit m3 Oy designed the church. The church hall can accommodate 500 people. The floor mosaics and window patterns are designed by graphic artist Lauri Rankka. Textile artist Tiina Toivola created the church textiles. The church includes a church hall and a gallery, two parish halls, a youth work space, offices, and early childhood education facilities.

name: Pyhän Jaakobin kirkko
description: Pyhän Jaakobin kirkko, also known as St. James's Church, is located in Paimio, Southwest Finland. The church is owned by the Parish Association of St. James. It is a red-brick, long church built on a grey stone base in Hevonpää between 1926 and 1928. The current church was consecrated in 1929. The church that previously stood in its place was destroyed in a fire in 1909. The church was designed by Lars Sonck. At the northern end of the gable roof rises a roof rider ending in a spike. Parking spaces are available in front of the church.

name: Pyhän Katariinan kirkko
description: Pyhän Katariinan kirkko (St. Catherine's Church) is a medieval stone church located in the Nummi district of Turku. The first written record of the church dates back to 1309. The current grey stone church was built in the 1440s and 1450s. Inside the church, you can find late medieval crucifixes, paintings by Jonas Bergman from 1759-1760, a pulpit from 1654, and vault paintings from 1470-1490 by the Kalanti school. Also notable are Hannu Konola's glass altarpiece "Gentle Maria" from 2000, a fresco of Catherine of Siena from 1480, and a wooden sculpture of Catherine of Alexandria from the 14th century. The churchyard also features three walled burial chapels.

name: Pyhän Kolminaisuuden kirkko
description:
The Holy Trinity Cathedral in Oulu is the main church of the Oulu Orthodox Parish and the cathedral of the Diocese of Oulu. The Diocese of Oulu was founded in 1980 and is one of the three dioceses of the Orthodox Church of Finland.

The church building was designed by architect Mikko Huhtela and completed in the summer of 1957. A large part of the old iconostasis icons came from the Ägläjärvi church in Korpiselkä, which remained in ceded Karelia.

The church is located at Torikatu 74. Live broadcasts of services held at the Holy Trinity Cathedral in Oulu can be found on the YouTube channel of the Orthodox Parish of Northern Finland.

name: Pyhän Kolminaisuuden kirkko
description: The Holy Trinity Church in Kempele, Finland, consecrated on August 8, 1993, can accommodate 420 people. Designed by the architectural firm Jorma Teppo Oy from Oulu, the church features stained glass art created by Pekka Jauhiainen, an artist also from Oulu. It serves as a focal point for the Kempele parish, offering various services and activities. The church provides a space for worship and community gatherings.

name: Pyhän Luukkaan kappeli
description:
The Chapel of St. Luke is located in the Linnanmaa district, within the University of Oulu area. It serves as the university's own church, but also welcomes all residents of the surrounding area as one of the churches of the Tuira parish. The chapel was completed in 1988 and designed by architects Seppo Kähkönen and Markku Kuhalampi.

The building is known for its relatively rare, round-bottomed church hall which can accommodate around 200 people. In 2003, it was expanded with two parish halls and a club room. A chamber concert by Oulu Sinfonia will take place in the chapel on January 18, 2025.

name: Pyhän Mikaelin kirkko
description:
St. Michael's Church, known as Pyhän Mikaelin kirkko in Finnish, is located in Vehmaa, Finland. It is a medieval stone church, likely built in the 15th century, though some parts may be older. The church is dedicated to the Archangel Michael.

The church's architecture reflects typical features of late medieval Finnish churches. Inside, you can find medieval murals. The church and its surroundings provide a glimpse into the religious and cultural history of the region. It stands as a testament to the area's long and rich past.

name: Pyhän Ristin kirkko
description: The Church of the Holy Cross is located in Rauma, Finland, and it's the main church of the Rauma parish. Originally built by Franciscan friars in the early 16th century as part of their monastery, it stands as a significant historical landmark in Old Rauma, a UNESCO World Heritage site. The church is known for its medieval stone construction and houses impressive ceiling and vault paintings from the 16th century that depict the biblical history of salvation. The church is open every day of the year and is a popular spot to visit.

name: Pyhän Sydämen kappeli
description: The Chapel of the Sacred Heart is located in Kallio, Helsinki, at Kirstinkatu 1. This Art Nouveau chapel belongs to the Finnish Lutheran Evangelical Association. Architect Vilho Penttilä, a member of Nyström-Petrelius-Penttilä architectural firm, designed it. The chapel was consecrated in 1906. It is known for the 146 hearts painted on its walls and windows. The chapel also has a community that regularly holds communion services. A thorough renovation took place in 1992, revealing old ceiling paintings and restoring stained glass. Inside the chapel, you can find a central aisle, a central altar, a pulpit, and a lectern. There is also a Setterqvist organ, originally built in 1890 for Dagsberg Church in Sweden.

name: Pyhän Tuomaan kirkko
description:
Pyhän Tuomaan kirkko, located in the Puolivälinkangas district of Oulu, is a church belonging to the Tuira parish. Designed by architect Juha Leiviskä, it was built between 1974 and 1975. The church's design draws inspiration from 17th and 18th-century wooden churches and late Baroque churches in Southern Germany.

The church is named after the Apostle Thomas and was consecrated by Bishop Hannes Leinonen on St. Thomas Day, December 21, 1975. The main church hall has a seating capacity of 330 people, and there are also two parish halls in the building. The altar and choir area feature a 23-stop organ. The altarpiece and other paintings are by artist Hannu Väisänen, who also designed the church textiles.

name: Pyhän Yrjön kirkko
description:
St. George's Church, located in Mariehamn, Åland, is the town's church. It stands out as the most recent church in Åland, inaugurated in 1927 and designed by Lars Sonck. This red brick church is situated in the center of Mariehamn, along the main streets, making it easily accessible.

Inside, the church features ornamental ceiling decorations and stained glass windows depicting saints and apostles. The altarpiece illustrates the life of Jesus, from birth to resurrection, complemented by stained glass portraying the Holy Family and apostles, all crafted by Bruno Tuukkanen. The church also houses Åland's largest organ, boasting 37 stops. One of its three bells originated from the Bomarsund fortress's orthodox church, seized as spoils of war in 1854 and later returned to Åland.

name: Pyhännän kirkko
description: Pyhäntä Church is located in Pyhäntä, Finland, and was completed in 1909. The church was designed by architect W. A. Tötterström. The construction was led by builders J. Jäväjä from Haapajärvi and Samuel Eskola. Funds for the church's construction were collected from Lutheran churches. The long church with a tower represents a rare Kalevala-inspired national romantic Art Nouveau style without a separate belfry. Church bells acquired from Germany in 1907 are located in the bell tower above the entrance. The church is also accessible via an accessible ramp. Inside the church, there is a mission candle holder, and in the churchyard, there is a "Flame of longing" candle monument in memory of those buried elsewhere.

name: Pyhärannan kirkko
description:
The Pyhäranta Church is a massive grey stone church designed by Josef Stenbäck, built between 1907 and 1909. Its style represents National Romanticism. The church's floor plan is in the shape of a short-limbed cross. The bell tower is located off the central axis. Inside, the church has concrete vaults. The altar is in the northern arm. The church has seating for 700 people.

There have been two earlier churches on the site, built in 1690 and 1758. The altarpiece, "Christ on the Cross," was painted by Ilmari Heinonen in 1939. The church organ was made by Kangasala organ factory in 1936. A model of the ship Port Caledonia, which sank in 1924, is displayed in a glass case inside the church. In 2009, the Finnish Heritage Agency defined Pyhäranta Church as one of the nationally significant built cultural environments in Finland.

name: Pyhäselän kirkko
description:
Pyhäselän kirkko is a Lutheran church located in Hammaslahti, Joensuu. It was inaugurated on August 19, 1928. The architecture of the church is influenced by functionalism and can accommodate approximately 450 people.

The church has two organs, the older one located in the organ loft and the newer one, completed in 2000, on the floor level. The altarpiece is a glass painting by Fritz Hilbert titled "Christ the Prince of Peace". In 1997, stained glass windows designed by Sulo Saikkonen were installed. The church also has a sound system and is accessible by wheelchair via a ramp, although there is a high threshold at the exterior doors.

name: Pylkönmäen kirkko
description:
Pylkönmäki Church is a wooden church located in Pylkönmäki, Saarijärvi. It was built in 1860 under the direction of Jaakko Kuorikoski as a prayer house and was consecrated as a church in 1864. In 1927, the church was extensively renovated based on Alvar Aalto's plans, including exterior and interior boarding. Aalto's design included vertical boarding on the exterior walls, and the top of the tower was lowered and a rooster was placed there instead of a cross.

Inside the church, the interior walls are covered with horizontal boarding. The altarpiece, painted by Matias Annala in 1941, depicts Jesus' Last Supper. The church also has an original pulpit carved by Taavetti Pajunen.

name: Pälkäneen kirkko
description:
Pälkäne Church is a brick-built cross-shaped church designed by architect C.L. Engel and constructed between 1836 and 1839. The altarpiece, depicting Jesus in Gethsemane, was painted in 1841 by professor P.E. Limnell from Stockholm.

In the churchyard, there is a war graves area where 165 fallen heroes from Pälkäne, who died in the Winter and Continuation Wars, are buried. The memorial stone was designed by architect Bertil Strömmer. A memorial stone for those who remained in Karelia, called "The Book of Life," was erected in the churchyard in 1961. The church museum preserves old artifacts of the parish.

name: Pääskylahden kirkko
description: Pääskylahden Kirkko is located in Savonlinna. It was built in 1957 for the growing industrial community. The church was designed by city architect Kauko A. Tuominen. The altar's stained-glass window is made by artist Antti Salmenlinna. The church organ was built for the 20th anniversary in 1977. The interior of the church was completely renovated in 1998. The original red brick altar wall was whitewashed, and the brightness of the church was increased by renewing the windows. The benches were replaced with individual chairs. The renovation was designed by architect Hannu Kylliäinen. The church also has a parish hall and several club rooms.

name: Pöytyän kirkko
description: Pöytyä Church, located in Pöytyä, Southwest Finland, is a wooden cross-shaped church constructed in 1793. It was designed by Carl Christoffer Gjörwell and built by Mikael Piimänen. The church was dedicated to King Gustav IV Adolf of Sweden, who was only 14 years old at the time. There is a memorial plaque on the outer wall of the church above the main door, commemorating this dedication. The churchyard features a rare old wooden fence with passages. The Pöytyä Church environment is one of the nationally significant built cultural environments defined by the Finnish Heritage Agency.

name: Raahen kirkko
description:
Raahe Church, also known as the Church of the Holy Trinity, is the largest church in the Raahe region. Completed in 1912, it stands where a wooden church built in 1653 once stood, until it burned down in 1908. Designed by Josef Stenbäck, the red granite church represents National Romanticism with Jugend elements.

Its tower reaches 56 meters high and is visible from the sea, once serving as a beacon for sailors. The interior has 580 seats. Services are held every Sunday at 10 am. The granite stones were mostly quarried from the islands off the coast of Raahe. The chandeliers inside resemble ship railings, fitting the character of the old maritime town.

name: Raippaluodon kirkko
description: The Raippaluoto Church, also known as the Kustaa Aadolf Church, dates back to 1781. It's a wooden long church with a steep roof and no tower. The altar structure and pulpit were moved from St. Mary's Church in Old Vaasa in the 1840s, which saved them from the fire in 1852. The church holds services of the Finnish Parish of Mustasaari, especially during Christmas and Easter, and also ecclesiastical services such as weddings. The church was designed by Johan Elfström in 1778. Inside, visitors are often surprised by the walls, which lean noticeably southward. The separate bell tower is in the Ostrobothnian Renaissance style and was built in 1783.

name: Raision kirkko
description:
Raision Church is a medieval stone church located in Raisio, Finland. It's one of the oldest churches in Finland, with construction dating back to the early 16th century, although some sources suggest even earlier origins. Legend says that giants named Killi and Nalli built the church but had a dispute with the priest about payment.

The church is dedicated to St. Martin. Inside, you can find potentially the oldest gravestones in Finland and the first Finnish-language Bible from 1642. The churchyard also features the Chapel of Glory, a unique structure with a covered area that remains unfrozen.

name: Rajamäen kirkko
description: Rajamäki Church, located in Nurmijärvi, is a unique example of functionalist-influenced neoclassical architecture. Built in 1938 by Alkoholiliike Oy for its employees, it was later donated to the Nurmijärvi parish in 1985. The church tower, a landmark in Rajamäki, stands at 48.11 meters tall, topped with a seven-meter cross. During the Winter War, the tower served as an air surveillance post for the local Lotta Svärd organization. The church has a large, round Christ window to the right of the altar. The church also features facilities for a day-care center and a parish hall that can accommodate around 50 people. The church itself has a capacity of 350 people.

name: Rantasalmen kirkko
description:
The Rantasalmi Church was originally built in 1904, designed by architect Josef Stenbäck, showcasing a late-Gothic architectural style. However, in June 1984, it was struck by lightning and severely damaged by fire. The remaining walls were used as the foundation for a new church designed by architect Carl-Johan Slotte.

The rebuilt church was inaugurated in 1989. Inside, where the altarpiece would typically be, there is an artwork designed by Pauno Pohjolainen. The church also features an organ with 41 stops, constructed by Veikko Virtanen's organ factory in 1990. The church is the fifth one in the parish, which was established in 1578. The church tower has three bells that chime, representing God's protection in different life situations.

name: Rantsilan kirkko
description:
The Rantsila Church is a wooden cross church completed in 1785, designed by church builder Simon Silvén-Jylkkä. It is the second church of the Rantsila Evangelical Lutheran parish. The church's current appearance reflects a renovation from the turn of the 20th century, incorporating Jugendstil influences.

Inside, the altarpiece, a triptych by Mikael Toppelius from 1788, dominates the altar wall. The paintings depict the Crucifixion, Resurrection, and Gethsemane. Toppelius also decorated the pulpit in 1794. The church has a traditional bell tower, which is older than the church itself and was moved to its current location in 1785. A new, over two-meter-tall poor man statue, carved by Toni Iskulehto, was placed next to the church's bell tower and dedicated in 2012.

name: Ranuan kirkko
description: Ranua Church is located in the center of Ranua, near Lake Ranuanjärvi. This small, wooden cross-shaped church was designed by architect Jarl Eklund and was consecrated on June 7, 1914. It has seating for 338 people. The altarpiece, painted by Matti Visanti in 1951, depicts "The Second Coming of Jesus." In the churchyard, there is a monument to the heroes called "Not death but life", made by sculptor Kalervo Kallio, and a memorial to those who died in evacuation, "Crying Stones", by artist Erkki Salmela. The churchyard also contains the graves of 138 war heroes.

name: Rautalammin kirkko
description:
The Rautalampi Church, completed in 1844, is one of the largest wooden churches in Finland. Designed by architect Carl Alexander Engel, it's architecturally unique. The church is located in a prominent position on a small hill in the center of the village.

The rectangular long church has short transepts and lower rooms in front of them. Pillars supporting the galleries divide the church hall into three naves. The central nave is as wide as the choir and higher than the side naves. A square tower with lanterns rises from the center of the low-pitched roof. The church is adjoined by a large cemetery.

name: Rautavaaran kirkko
description: Rautavaara Church is located in Rautavaara, Northern Savonia. The current church was built in 1982, designed by Sakari Aartelo and Esa Piironen. It was erected to replace the previous church that was destroyed in a fire in 1979. The original church, designed by Carlo Bassi, was built between 1825 and 1864 and could accommodate about 1,000 people. The current church is smaller, with seating for 460. The church houses an 18-stop organ made by Tuomi organ builders. The altar sculpture "Korven Kristus" is made by artist Anu Matilainen from Iisalmi. The old cemetery is located southeast of the church. The belfry, which dates back to 1888, survived the fire.

name: Raution kirkko
description:
Raution Kirkko is a church located in the village of Rautio in Kalajoki, Finland. It belongs to the Kalajoki parish. The wooden church was designed by Simon Jylkkä-Silvén and completed in 1800. Building the church was one of his last projects before he drowned in the Kalajoki river.

The church is a cross-shaped church. The current altarpiece, named "The Good Shepherd", was painted by Hans Håkansson. Previously, the altarpiece was "The Crucified," painted by Thomas Kiempe in 1804. Next to the church is a three-tiered bell tower, likely built around the same time as the church itself. The tower has a bell from 1807. The church went through renovations in 2024.

name: Reisjärven kirkko
description:
The Reisjärvi Church, also known as Elisabet's Church, is located in Reisjärvi, Northern Ostrobothnia. The wooden church was completed in 1820, designed by Anton Wilhelm Arppe, though influenced by earlier plans of Heikki Kuorikoski. It stands on the site of an earlier 17th-century church.

Initially built in the Neoclassical style, the church underwent significant renovations in 1900, gaining a Neo-Gothic appearance. The interior features approximately 700 seats. The altarpiece, depicting the Transfiguration of Christ, was painted by Arthur Heickell in 1913. The church organ, with 16 stops, was manufactured by Kangasala organ factory in 1981. A separate bell tower complements the church.

name: Rengon kirkko
description:
The Rengo Church, also known as St. James's Church, is a medieval stone church located in Hämeenlinna. Built in the late 15th century, it's distinguished by its rare octagonal floor plan, a unique feature among Finnish medieval churches. Dedicated to Apostle James the Elder, it was a known pilgrimage site in the Middle Ages.

In the 17th century, the church fell into disrepair, with its vaulted ceiling collapsing and walls partially crumbling. However, in 1783, the ruins were demolished and rebuilt on the same foundation. The church houses numerous artifacts from the 18th and 19th centuries, including altar textiles and candlesticks. The tower contains a bell from 1800 and another from 1981, with the oldest bell (likely from 1511) located in the Härkätie Museum.

name: Reposaaren kirkko
description:
Reposaari Church, located in Reposaari, Pori, is a wooden church completed in 1876. It resembles Norwegian stave churches. The church's blueprints were ordered from Stockholm, but the designer is unknown. Originally, it was a simple wooden structure suitable only for summer use, but it was modified for winter use in 1902.

The altar painting, depicting "Jesus awakening the sleeping disciples as the betrayer approaches in Gethsemane," was installed in 1906. The churchyard features a memorial to the torpedo boat S2, which sank in 1926, and war graves. The church was renovated in 1928, with architect Josef Stenbäck overseeing the interior changes. The church and bell tower were last painted externally in 2020. The hexagonal church and octagonal bell tower make it a unique landmark.

name: Revonlahden kirkko
description:
The Revonlahti Church, located in Siikajoki, Finland, is a wooden cross-shaped church completed in 1775. It is part of the Raahe parish. Jaakko Suonperä was the master builder of the church. A bell tower, completed in 1782, stands next to the church.

The altar painting and other murals in the church were created by the renowned church painter Mikael Toppelius in 1821. Revonlahti Church was Toppelius' last work; he died in December of the same year at the age of 87. The church has a steep shingle roof and six-paned windows. In 1957, the church underwent a thorough renovation, during which central heating and electric lights were installed.

name: Riihimäen varuskuntakirkko
description:
The Riihimäki Garrison Church, completed in 1913, was originally an Orthodox church for the Russian garrison. After Finland's independence, the church was stripped of its religious symbols and used as a warehouse for decades. The towers were torn down and the icons disappeared.

In the late 1950s, the Ministry of Defence leased the church to the Riihimäki parish, and it was renovated largely through volunteer work. In 1960, it was reconsecrated for both the garrison and the parish. The church has excellent acoustics, making it a popular concert venue. In 2023, the church was decommissioned, Christian symbols were removed, and the building was transferred to Defence Properties.

name: Riistaveden kirkko
description:
Riistaveden Church, located near the Kuopio-Joensuu highway, serves as the main church for the Järvi-Kuopio parish. Designed by architects Eino Pitkänen and Harry W. Schreck, the plastered brick church was completed in 1934. It features a long nave with a western tower and a sacristy at the eastern end.

Inside, the church has a single-aisle hall with light-colored plaster and concrete vaulting. The altar is adorned with a crucifix sculpted by Elis Reinilä. In front of the church stands a large bell, cast in St. Petersburg in 1914. The church has undergone renovations in the 1950s and 1961, and the bells date back to 1976. The church seats 200 people.

name: Ristiinan kirkko
description:
Ristiina Church is a wooden cross church located in Ristiina, Mikkeli. It was completed in 1775, with Eskil Collenius serving as the master builder. The altarpiece was painted by Alexandra Såltin.

Originally, Ristiina became an independent parish in 1649, and the first church was built that same year by Kristiina Katariina Brahe, the wife of Peter Brahe. The current church replaced the old one in 1775 due to its poor condition and small size. In 1843, the church was expanded with rectangular sections built between the cross arms. Today, the church can be considered a double cross church. It was thoroughly renovated in 1997. The war hero cemetery's memorial was unveiled in 1951 and designed by sculptor Ilmari Wirkkala. The church has 780 seats.

name: Ristijärven kirkko
description:
The Ristijärvi Church is a wooden cross-shaped church located in Ristijärvi. It was built in 1806-1807 based on drawings by Gustaf af Sillén. The church has a square tower in the center of the cross. The sacristy protrudes from the altar gable and is lower than the cross arms.

The current altarpiece, "Christ Crucified," was painted by Toivo Tuhkanen in 1956. The old altarpiece from 1807, painted by Carl Petter Elftröm, is located in the choir. The bell tower was built separately in 1840, led by Jaakko Kuorikoski, because the church tower couldn't withstand the weight of the bells. The church is the oldest operating church in Kainuu.

name: Roihuvuoren kirkko
description:
Roihuvuoren Kirkko, completed in 1970, is the main church of the Roihuvuori parish in Helsinki. Architect Lauri Silvennoinen designed the church. Most of the building materials came from Finland, except for the large windows from Germany and the church bells from Austria. The hexagonal shape of the church is inspired by baptismal chapels from the 3rd century.

Inside the church, the main hall features a Star of David on the ceiling. In addition to the main worship space, there is a chapel for baptisms, a parish hall, and other facilities. The church hall covers 430 square meters and can accommodate up to 600 people. The altar is adorned with a stained glass artwork called "Circulum Vitae" (Circle of Life) by Reino Hietanen, and the baptismal chapel features a mosaic by Uuno Eskola called "Christ on the Cross".

name: Rovaniemen kirkko
description: Rovaniemi Church, completed in 1950, stands as a landmark of the reconstruction era in Rovaniemi. Designed by Bertel Liljequist, it replaced the church destroyed during WWII. A dominant feature is the huge altar fresco, "The Source of Life," created by Lennart Segerstråle in 1951, depicting the human heart with the struggle between good and evil. The church seats 850 people and also hosts concerts throughout the year. A red neon cross on the tower serves as a distinctive symbol. The church is open daily during the summer and Christmas seasons, and at other times by appointment.

name: Ruhtinansalmen kirkko
description: The Ruhtinansalmi Church is located in Ruhtinansalmi, Suomussalmi. It is a wooden, long church without a tower, designed by Esko Laitinen and built in 1968. The church has a flat roof that rises towards the altar end. In the side spaces, which are lower than the main room, there is a sacristy and a parish hall that can be connected to the church hall. The church has seating for 180 people, and the adjacent parish hall can accommodate 60 people. There is a cross-shaped stained glass window on the altar wall. The church also features a crucifix sculpted by Eeva Ryynänen. The five-voice organ was made by Urkurakentamo Tuomi in the same year as the church construction. The church's area is 143 square meters. Currently, the church is out of use.

name: Ruokolahden kirkko
description:
Ruokolahti Church is located in the town center of Ruokolahti, in southeastern Finland. It is the main church of the Ruokolahti parish. The wooden cruciform church combines Empire and Neo-Gothic styles. Completed in 1854, it is actually the fourth church to stand on the site. The church was designed by Ernst Lohrmann in 1852.

The belfry predates the current church by 100 years, constructed in 1752. The altarpiece is a 1915 painting by Alexandra Frosterus-Såltin, titled "Christ on the Cross". The church is featured in Albert Edelfelt's famous 1887 painting, "Women outside the Church at Ruokolahti." Finnish veteran Simo Häyhä is buried in the church graveyard. The church and belfry are protected by the Finnish Heritage Agency.

name: Ruotsinpyhtään kirkko
description:
The Ruotsinpyhtää Church, also known as Strömfors Church, is located in Loviisa. This unique cultural treasure is located in the heart of Strömfors Ironworks. The octagonal wooden church, representing Neo-Gothic style, was built in 1770-1771, making it the oldest central church in Finland.

Initially, the church was tar black, but it received its current light color in a renovation in 1898, when Neo-Gothic elements were added. The church's greatest treasure is the altarpiece "Resurrection" painted by Helene Schjerfbeck in 1898. The church was designed by lieutenant colonel Olof Glansenstjerna.

name: Ruoveden kirkko
description:
Ruoveden kirkko, also known as Sofia Magdalenan kirkko, is located in the Ruovesi village. It was built in 1777-1778 and inaugurated on August 25, 1778. The church was designed and built by Matti Åkerblom.

The cross-shaped church can accommodate 1,100 people. The church features a hipped roof with a flèche. Inside the church, there is an altarpiece "Christ's Transfiguration" painted by Bernhard Reinhold, which was acquired from Paris in the 19th century. The church also has a 28-stop organ from 1968 and another 6-stop organ from 1969.

The bell tower, built in 1772, was initially located elsewhere but was moved closer to the church after its completion.

name: Ruskon kirkko
description:
Rusko Church is a medieval stone church located in Rusko, Finland. It's among the smallest stone churches in Finland. The single-nave church hall features star vaults built on shield arches and pilasters, resembling the vaults of Turku Cathedral. The barrel-vaulted sacristy is older than the main building.

Inside, there are two medieval brick altars, the main altar on the east wall and a side altar on the north side, likely dedicated to Mary. The interior is partially from a restoration in the 1920s. The church has pews, side benches in the choir, and a cupboard clock donated in 1781. The red-painted bell tower to the southeast dates back to 1744. The churchyard also includes a gray stone fence and a wooden granary built in 1874.

name: Rymättylän kirkko
description:
Rymättylä Church, dedicated to St. Jacob, is a medieval stone church in Naantali. The oldest part, the vestry, dates back to the 1300s, when a wooden church stood there. The stone church was built in the late 1300s or early 1400s. Inside, the church hall maintains a traditional atmosphere, showcasing Renaissance features in its paintings, artworks, and decor.

A series of paintings depicting Jesus' suffering and death encircle the church. The church has medieval wooden sculptures, including three of St. Jacob. The exterior architecture is unique as the west end is almost three meters lower than the east end due to the sloping hill. A large roof rider rises in the middle of the steep shingle roof.

name: Ryttylän kirkko
description: Ryttylä Church is located in the village of Ryttylä in Hausjärvi. The church was completed in 1961. The church hall is used for religious events and concerts. The Kangasala organ factory built the 9-stop organ. The church hall can accommodate about 100 people, with an additional 30 people in the organ loft. The church also has a piano. The premises are also suitable for handicapped people. The Ryttylä scouting group also gathers in the church.

name: Rääkkylän kirkko
description:
Rääkkylä Church is located in Rääkkylä and was built in 1851. The church is a symmetrical cross church designed by Ernst Lohrmann at the Intendent Office and built by Theodor Johannes Tolpo. It is one of the churches of the Central Karelia parish.

The church has 1200 seats. A two-story tower is connected to the church, and a lower sacristy protrudes from the altar end. The church has high windows, arched at the tower's second floor and ends, and flat-topped elsewhere. The church's two bells are from 1851. Inside, the church features wooden vaults and a dome in the center.

The church's timbers are from Pyssysalo, the window glass originally from Sortavala, and the roof sheets from St. Petersburg. A copper roof was installed in 1984.

name: Saaren kirkko
description: Saaren kirkko is a beautiful brick church designed by Ilmari Launis, completed in 1934. It is located in the village of Saari, near lake Iso-Rautjärvi. The church can accommodate 700 people. One of its special features is the altarpiece painted directly onto the wall by Laila Järvinen, depicting Christ's ascension and considered one of the largest in Finland. The church also has a Rieger organ with 17 fixed and 3 transportable stops. In 2008, the deteriorated brick cladding of the outer walls and the church's chimney were repaired.

name: Saarijärven kirkko
description:
Saarijärvi Church is the main church of the Saarijärvi parish. The current church, built between 1846 and 1849, is the third church in the same location. It represents the so-called Engel churches, designed by A.F. Granstedt, who worked in the Finnish Intendant's Office led by C.L. Engel.

The church is considered a masterpiece of its time. A significant feature is its 18-meter diameter dome, which is remarkable for a wooden church. The church has undergone renovations, including one in 1997-98, which carefully examined all structures. The interior features a gilded sun symbol at the top of the lantern, symbolizing Christ's resurrection.

name: Sahalahden kirkko
description: The Sahalahti Church is a wooden Empire style church completed in 1829, located in Kangasala. The drawings were made under the direction of Carl Ludvig Engel. It is believed that folk drawings were used as a basis. In 1843, a belfry designed by state architect E. Lohrman was completed and connected to the main building. The church has approximately 550 seats. The church was renovated and restored between 1999 and 2002. The altarpiece, painted by Aleksandra Såltin in 1896, is called "Come to Me". The churchyard has a memorial stone at the site of the previous churches. The organ was built in 1889.

name: Saksalainen kirkko
description:
The German Church in Helsinki, also known as the Tyska kyrkan, is located in the Kaartinkaupunki district. Completed in 1864, it was designed by Harald von Bosse and C.J. von Heideken and represents Neo-Gothic architecture. A distinctive tower, designed by Josef Stenbäck, was added in 1897.

The church suffered a fire in 1958, leading to renovations that preserved the exterior but significantly altered the interior, including the addition of a reinforced concrete ceiling. Further renovations and expansions took place between 1997 and 2001, with Juha Leiviskä and Rosemarie Schnitzler as architects.

Today, the German Church is a popular wedding venue and concert space. It is protected as a valuable building and serves as a central point for the German-speaking community in Finland.

name: Sallan kirkko
description:
Salla Church is located in Salla, Finland. The church was built between 1948 and 1950, with the help of the Lutheran congregations of Denmark. The church represents the reconstruction of Lapland after World War II and combines the shape of late medieval Finnish stone churches with ideals and materials of modernism.

Architects Eero Eerikäinen and Osmo Sipari designed the building. The church hall covers 630 square meters and has seating for 600 people. The tower is 35 meters high. The bronze altar relief was designed by sculptor Aimo Tukiainen. Next to the church is a parish hall, completed in 1980, designed by architect Matti Leiber.

name: Saloisten kirkko
description:
Saloisten Church, also known as St. Olaf's Church or the Church of All Saints, is located in Raahe, in the former municipality of Saloinen. The church was completed in 1932 and was designed by builder J. Karvonen. It stands on the site of a previous church.

Inside Saloisten Church, medieval images of saints and a cabinet dating back to the 15th century have been preserved, rescued from the fire of the previous church. The belfry, dating from 1783, is said to have been designed by King Gustav III. The church accommodates approximately 300 people. The church also has two altar cabinets and wooden sculptures that have been preserved since the Middle Ages.

name: Salokunnan kirkko
description: Salokunnan kirkko is a church building in Sastamala, designed by architect Timo Penttilä. The church was completed in 1960. It is known for its red brick and wood construction. The church hall has a wedge shape, narrowing towards the altar end. Instead of a traditional altarpiece, there is a simple wooden cross on the altar wall. A large window behind the altar offers a view of the surrounding nature. The church also has a low wing building with parish work spaces and apartments. The church and the adjacent cemetery are part of nationally significant built cultural environments inventoried by the Finnish Heritage Agency.

name: Salon kirkko
description: Salon kirkko, or Salo Church, is located in Salo, Finland on Kirkkokatu 7. It was built in 1894 and designed by architect G.E. Ekestubbe. There is also the Chapel of the Holy Cross which is part of the Orthodox Parish of Turku. It is a Karelian-style log chapel built in 1989 and consecrated in memory of the Holy Cross on September 9, 1990. Arvo Happo, a parishioner from Salo, designed the chapel based on old traditions and also made the woodcut decorations. Margit Lintu painted the icons.

name: Salpausselän kirkko
description:
Salpausselän kirkko is a Lutheran church located in Lahti, Finland, completed in 1972. Designed by Helmer Löfström, the yellow-brick church is characterized as a simple, low building. Its various sections form a rectangular courtyard.

A design competition was held in 1967, won by Kristian Gullichsen's team, who emphasized economy, adaptability, and modernity. However, the final design was created by Woldemar Baeckman and Helmer Löfström, whose plans were finalized in 1971, even though they initially placed third in the competition. The church hall has 300 seats, and the parish hall has about 100 seats. The church is used for various events, such as baptisms, weddings, and memorial services.

name: Saltvikin kirkko
description:
The Saltvik Church, located in Saltvik, Åland, is dedicated to Saint Mary. The stone church replaced an earlier wooden church. The nave dates back to the latter half of the 14th century, possibly the 1370s, while the tower dates back to the 1380s. A baroque-style upper section was added to the tower in the mid-18th century.

Inside the church, notable features include a pulpit from 1832, an altarpiece designed by Robert Wilhelm Ekman from 1862, and a painting from 1659 depicting Saint George and the Dragon. The church also has a baptismal font from the 13th century and a triumphal crucifix from the same century. The vaults have paintings dating back to the 17th century and there are also several funerary coats of arms. Traces of Viking-era house foundations have been found around and under the church.

name: Sammaljoen kirkko
description:
Sammaljoki Church, located in Sastamala, Finland, is a wooden church designed by Ilmari Launis and completed in 1924. It's the second church in the village of Sammaljoki, situated on a hill in the center of the village along the road from Vammala to Urjala. The church features a gable tower and a long church design where the central part of the frame room rises higher than the side aisles. A narrower section behind the side aisles at the altar end houses the church's sacristy and parish hall.

Inside, the central nave has a hipped roof from the altar end, while the side aisles have shed roofs. The upper windows of the central nave are octagonal. The church's interior ceiling is flat throughout. The church was renovated in 1950. The altar features a sculpture by Paavo Hakala depicting Christ on the Cross. The church bells originate from a Russian garrison church in Hämeenlinna.

name: Sammatin kirkko
description:
Sammatin kirkko is one of the oldest wooden churches in Finland that is used throughout the year. It was built in 1754-1755 under the direction of Mickel Göransson. The church is a modest long church that has survived fires.

Next to the church is a separate bell tower built in 1763. The church has about 220 seats and is surrounded by an atmospheric cemetery. Elias Lönnrot, known for his work with the Kalevala, is buried in the churchyard; the altar painting was donated by him. The church is a popular roadside church, offering a peaceful and historically significant site.

name: Sammonlahden kirkko
description:
Sammonlahden kirkko is a church building located in Lappeenranta, Finland. Designed by local architects Riitta and Kari Ojala, it was completed in 1992 and is part of the Sammonlahti parish. The church is named after a verse in the Psalms, "Virvoittavien vetten tykö" which translates to "By the refreshing waters".

The church and its associated parish center are constructed using concrete, red brick, and grey granite from Ristijärvi. The main hall is circular, with the altar in the center. A simple Andrea's cross serves as the altarpiece, allowing natural light to enter the hall. Dominant colors inside the hall are blue and green. The church also features a glass and granite artwork by Brita Flander behind the altar and an angel sculpture by Anna-Maria Osipow in the entrance hall. The church organ, built in the year of the church's completion, represents the North German style.

name: Sastamalan kirkko
description:
The Church of St. Mary in Sastamala is a grey stone church built in the late 15th century. It is located in Karkku, which was the center of ancient Sastamala. Before the stone church, there may have been several wooden churches and the Chapel of St. Luke on the same site. A part of St. Luke's chapel still forms a section of the northern wall of the church.

The church was renovated in the 1960s, and the wooden floor was replaced with a painted floor in 1977. The medieval interior includes a well-preserved 13th-century stone baptismal font and a collection of wooden sculptures. The wooden bell tower was constructed at the end of the 18th century, based on designs from Stockholm. The church is known for its excellent acoustics and is a popular concert venue, especially during the Sastamala Gregoriana festival. It also serves as a roadside church, welcoming travelers.

name: Sauvon kirkko
description:
Sauvo Church, also known as Sauvon kirkko in Finnish and Sagu kyrka in Swedish, is a medieval stone church located in Sauvo, Finland. Constructed between 1460 and 1472, it stands as one of the largest medieval parish churches in Finland. The church was dedicated to St. Clement of Rome.

Inside, the church has a well-preserved interior featuring mural paintings from the 15th century and medieval artifacts such as the altar, a crucifix, and a tabernacle. The church boasts seating for over 700 people in pews dating back to the 17th century, and its decor spans various periods from the 13th century to the present day. A military cemetery is located at the church.

name: Savitaipaleen kirkko
description:
Savitaipale Church is the seventh church in Savitaipale, Finland. The current church, completed in 1924, was designed by Josef Stenbäck and is built from rapakivi granite. The stones were quarried from Viuhovuori in Kaskeinkylä. The church has about 700 seats.

The altarpiece, painted by Felix Frang, depicts Jesus in the Garden of Gethsemane. In 1939, Johan Fagerström donated stained glass windows made by Forsell. The original 20-stop organ from 1926 was replaced in 1979 with a 33-stop organ made by Hans Heinrich. The church is located in the center of Savitaipale, on top of a hill.

name: Savonlinnan tuomiokirkko
description:
Savonlinna Cathedral is the main church of the Savonlinna parish. It was built between 1874 and 1878 and designed by architect Axel Hampus Dalström in the Gothic Revival style. The church has a seating capacity of 800-1000 people.

Originally, it became a cathedral in 1896 when the Diocese of Savonlinna was founded, serving as such until 1925 when the bishop's seat was moved. During the Winter War in 1940, the church suffered damage from bombing and was later restored. The interior features a glass painting called Paradise's Four Streams above the altar. The church also boasts a 45-stop baroque organ.

name: Savonrannan kirkko
description: The Savonranta Church is a wooden church located in Savonranta, Savonlinna. It was built between 1862 and 1863, designed by architect August Boman. The church is a gable-tower long church and can accommodate approximately 600 people. The first service in the church was held on the first Advent Sunday in 1863. The altarpiece, depicting "Jesus on the Cross", was painted by Niko Makkonen in 1903. The church has undergone several renovations, the most recent of which was completed in 1987, where the interior and exterior received new colors. Before the church was built, services were held in a storehouse.

name: Savukosken kirkko
description:
The Savukoski Church is a wooden long church without a tower, built in 1956 and designed by Paavo Riihimäki. It served as a border church from 1950 to 1997 when the Pelkosenniemi parish formed its own border district.

The rectangular church has a gently sloping hipped roof, and the main entrance protrudes from one of the long sides, lower than the main body of the building. Initially, the church consisted only of the church hall and a residential wing. In 1986, the building complex was expanded into a parish center with a parish hall, offices, and activity rooms.

The church has a surface area of 112 square meters and seats 150 people. The church's 7-voice organ was manufactured by Kangasala organ factory in 1976. A separate bell tower and its bell date from 1958. Connected to the church is Urpo Kärri's spatial work "The Way of the Cross," and in the parish hall is Ulla Holmström's weaving work "Hourglass."

name: Seilin kirkko
description:
Seili Church, also known as Själö Church in Swedish, is a wooden church located on the island of Seili in Nauvo, Finland. Constructed in 1733, it stands on the site of a previous wooden church, Saint George's Church, which was moved from Turku in 1624. The church is a unique building due to its history.

Originally, the island of Seili served as a hospital for leprosy patients. A separate enclosed space within the church was designated for those afflicted with infectious diseases, like leprosy, to prevent the spread of illness to other members of the congregation. This section had its own small altar and entrance, which is now closed. Today, the church functions as a museum and is open to visitors during the summer.

name: Seutulan kappeli
description:
Seutulan kappeli, also known as Königstedt chapel, is located in Vantaa. It was built in 1925 on land belonging to the Königstedt manor through voluntary work. The chapel is a small, rectangular, wooden church with a gable roof. In 1964, it was transferred from the Ripukylä prayer house association to the local parishes.

The chapel has a lower and wider community hall and residential wing protruding from the altar end of the main building. A high-peaked roof turret adorns the low tower. The windows are segmentally arched. The church received a four-stop mechanical organ built by Kangasala organ factory in 1969. The artist of the altarpiece, painted in 1964–65, is unknown. A bell cast in the Dutch Pettit & Fritsen foundry was installed in 1985, for the chapel's 60th anniversary.

name: Sieppijärven kirkko
description:
Sieppijärvi Church is located in the village of Sieppijärvi, in the municipality of Kolari. It belongs to the parish of Kolari. The church was designed by architect Kaj Englund and completed in 1956.

The church is spacious and rectangular in shape, known for its excellent acoustics. It can accommodate approximately 450 people. In 1977, an organ with 8 voices, manufactured by Kangasala organ factory, was installed. Renovations in 1986 added a modern kitchen and parish hall. The altarpiece, painted by Lauri Välke in 1956, depicts a scene from the Sermon on the Mount, specifically Matthew 5:5: "Blessed are the meek, for they will inherit the earth." The painting portrays Jesus with his disciples in prayer.

name: Sievin kirkko
description:
The church in Sievi is the fourth church in the municipality, completed in 1861. It's located in Haikolankylä, specifically on Jussinpekanmäki hill, chosen so that the bell tower would be visible from afar. The church was designed by architect L.I. Lindqvist.

Stylistically, the church represents 19th-century long churches, though it is a cross church. The church bells, acquired in 1729, are still used to call people to worship. The church's surroundings have maintained their traditional appearance. Inside, above the main entrance, is a Veikko Virtanen organ built in 1977. The altar painting is from 1913, painted by A. Heinckell.

name: Siikaisten kirkko
description:
Siikaisten Church is a wooden long church with a gable tower and cross arms, built in 1888-1889. It represents the Neo-Gothic style. The church was designed by acting county architect K.V. Reinius and the master builder was David Lönnroth.

The church has seating for approximately 1,200 people. The altar painting, "The Crucified," was painted by Ilmari Launis in 1911. The previous church in Siikainen burned down after being struck by lightning. The current church was built on the site of the old church from wood obtained from the municipality's own forests. The topmost floor of the church tower is octagonal. The sacristy is located at the altar end of the building and is lower than the main space. There are decorative consoles under the eaves of the church. The facade is vertically boarded.

name: Siikajoen kirkko
description:
Siikajoki Church, built in 1701, is one of the oldest cruciform churches in the Ostrobothnia region. The first house of worship was built in 1589, but it was burned down by Russians in 1591. A new sanctuary was built in 1600 on the same site. That building was removed to make way for the current church, constructed in 1701.

The church's floor, roof, and pews were renovated in 1765. Jaakko Suonperä built the pulpit in the same year. The church was repaired in 1852 according to Johan Oldenburg's plans, giving it its current form. A cupola-covered tower rises in the center of the church. Mikael Toppelius created decorative paintings inside in 1771-1772, including the altarpiece depicting Gethsemane and decorations on the pulpit.

name: Siilinjärven kirkko
description:
Siilinjärvi Church, also known as the Church of Christ's Coming, is a red-brick building located in the center of Siilinjärvi. Designed by Peko Väänänen, a local from Siilinjärvi, it was inaugurated on December 23, 1923, and has 550 seats. The church is known for its paintings and colors, which depict life events and Bible stories of major Christian holidays like Christmas and Easter.

Artist Bruno Tuukkanen created the decorative paintings. The altar painting, "Christ on the Cross," was designed by Sulo Honkanen and painted with Santeri Salokivi for the church's 10th anniversary in 1934. The church also features a 26-stop organ made by Urkurakentamo Tuomi in 1980. Next to the church is a war cemetery.

name: Siipyyn kirkko
description: The Siipyy Church, located in Kristiinankaupunki, was designed by Erik Kråkström and built in 1972, the final year of the municipality's independence. The church is octagonal and constructed of brick and wood. The otherwise flat-roofed church has a slanted roof section in the center. The interior ceiling follows the shape of the exterior roof. The church hall can be connected to both the parish hall and a separate serving room. The church covers an area of 410 square meters and has seating for 350 people. The wooden altar sculpture, "Cross Between Sails," was also designed by Erik Kråkström. The church's 14-stop organ was manufactured by Hans Heinrich in 1972. Next to the new church stands the bell tower built in 1831 for the previous church, which was destroyed in a fire in 1969; its bells date from 1786, 1846, and 1862.

name: Simpeleen kirkko
description:
Simpeleen kirkko, located in Simpele, Rautjärvi, is a church belonging to the Ruokolahti parish. Completed in 1933, it was designed by Elsa Arokallio and Elsi Borg. The church exemplifies the impact of industrial communities on church architecture.

The building features a simple, whitewashed facade with a prominent gable tower that serves as the entrance. The chancel is narrower and lower than the rectangular nave, which is divided into a high central aisle and two lower side aisles. The altar painting, donated by Yhtyneet Paperitehtaat Oy and created by Alvar Cavén, depicts a family praying for their work in a field. The stained-glass windows, also donated by the company, portray parishioners at work in a paper mill. The war memorial north of the church includes a stone wall with plaques bearing the names of the fallen and a bronze relief by Eila Hiltunen.

name: Simon kirkko
description:
The Simo Church is located in Simoniemi village. It was designed by Ernst Bernhard Lohrmann and completed in 1846. The church represents the late Empire style and is a rectangular long church without a tower. It is 28.5 meters long and 15.5 meters wide.

The altarpiece, "Jesus on the Cross," was painted by Esaias Svanberg in 1847. It depicts the crucified Jesus with Mary and John mourning. Near the church stands a wooden bell tower built in 1773 by Heikki Väänänen, representing the Ostrobothnian Renaissance style. Between the church and the bell tower lie the war heroes of Simo from the Winter and Continuation Wars.

name: Sipoon kirkko
description:
Sipoo Church, also known as the New Church, is a red-brick building designed by Theodor Decker in the Neo-Gothic style. Consecrated in 1885, it was built because the Old Church of Sipoo became too small for the growing congregation in the 19th century. The Finnish and Swedish congregations of Sipoo both use the church.

Originally, the altar wall was open, but it was later walled up to conceal a new heating system. In 2001, geothermal heating was installed, which allowed the altar wall to be restored to its original appearance. The church hall was also repainted to match its original colors. The first organ was acquired in 1890. The current organ, a Danish Marcussen & Søn mechanical organ from 1951, was the first Neo-Baroque organ in Finland.

name: Sipoon vanha kirkko
description:
