Sipoon vanha kirkko, also known as St. Sigfrid's Church, is a medieval gray stone church located in Sipoo. It was built in the 1450s and stands as one of Finland's best-preserved medieval churches in its original form.

The church is a popular wedding venue during the summer months, and services are also held there. The designer of the church is unknown but is referred to as the Master of Pernaja. Its architecture differs from other medieval stone churches in Finland, as its chancel is built with three naves, while the rest of the church has two.

Inside, the walls and vaults are decorated with 15th-century paintings in red and black. A pillory and a "shame bench" from the 17th and 18th centuries can also be found within the church. The church's bell tower, originally made of wood, was rebuilt in stone in 1811.

name: Sippolan kirkko
description:
Sippola Church is a red-brick church located in the village of Sippola, in Kouvola. Designed by architect C.J. von Heideken, it was built between 1878 and 1879 and represents the Neo-Gothic architectural style. The church has undergone renovations in 1903 and 1927.

The church can accommodate approximately 1,000 people, including the galleries. The altarpiece, depicting the Transfiguration of Christ, was painted by Aleksandra Såltin from Turku and placed in the church in 1887. Two of the four bells in the church tower date back to Sippola's earlier church, built in the 1700s. The two larger bells were donated in 1911. Today, it functions as the main church of the Anjalankoski parish.

name: Siuntion kirkko
description:
Siuntio Church, also known as St. Peter's Church, is a medieval stone church located in Siuntio, Finland. It was likely constructed between 1460 and 1489. Before the stone church, a wooden church probably stood on the same site from the beginning of the 15th century.

The church has a three-nave structure divided by three pairs of pillars, which support the star vaults of the central nave and the Andrea cross vaults of the side naves. The church was ravaged by fire four times throughout its history. In 1786, Siuntio Church was the first rural church in Finland to acquire its own organ. The current organ was made in Germany in 1971.

name: Siuron kirkko
description:
Siuron kirkko is a church building in the village of Siuro, Nokia. Originally built as a prayer room in 1910, it was designed by builder Heikki Tiitola. The prayer room was constructed on donated land, with the timber provided by the Finnish Forest Administration.

In 1938, the building was renovated into a church, officially becoming a church of the Nokia parish in 1956. This wooden long church is noted for its Jugendstil architecture, also displaying characteristics of the Neo-Gothic style.

A major renovation in the 1980s, designed by Jaakko Nieminen, transformed the church hall into a multi-purpose space. It can now easily be furnished as a concert hall, dining area, or function room. The churchyard is situated on Siuronkallio hill by Lake Kulovesi, and has a belfry that offers great views.

name: Snappertunan kirkko
description: The Snappertuna Church, located in Raseborg, is a wooden cross-shaped church originally built in 1689. It underwent extensive renovation in 1797, during which the roof was raised. The bell tower next to the church dates back to 1776. Inside, the church features paintings made in the early 1700s by Gustaf Graan on the railings of the western and northern galleries. The altarpiece depicting the crucifixion is from 1841, and the church organ with nine stops was made in 1884 by Gustav Norrman from Tallinn. The memorial to the heroes in the churchyard was unveiled in 1948 and was designed by architect Arne Rancken.

name: Sodankylän kirkko
description:
Sodankylä Church refers to two churches. The old church is one of the oldest wooden churches in Lapland, built in 1689. King Charles XI funded its construction. It is a rectangular, pillar-supported church, typical for the region. The interior features a wooden vault from the 1700s, and the altar and pulpit are original.

The newer grey stone church, completed in 1859, stands northeast of the old church. Emperor Nicholas I approved its construction, with drawings later approved by Emperor Alexander II. Ludvig Isak Lindqvist designed it, and Ernst Lohrmann suggested a taller wooden tower. The church is simple in design due to the stone material. The altar is in the north end of the church hall.

name: Sodankylän vanha kirkko
description:
Sodankylä Old Church is a wooden church dating back to the 17th century. Located near the Kitinen River, it stands as one of Finland's oldest preserved wooden churches. Built in 1689, the church represents a blend of medieval architectural traditions and the style of timber construction common in the Pohjanmaa region.

The interior is characterized by unlined and unpainted surfaces. Exterior renovations in the 20th century employed traditional methods, including hand-split planks and blacksmith-forged nails. The walls are constructed from horizontal logs, extending to the gables. Inside, a pair of support pillars are situated in the center of the side walls.

With a seating capacity of approximately 120, the church is still actively used for weddings and smaller religious ceremonies, and is a popular wedding venue during the summer.

name: Soinin kirkko
description: The Soini Church is a wooden church built in 1793. In front of the church's bell tower stands what is believed to be the only old poor woman statue ("vaivaisakka") in Finland and possibly the world. Near the churchyard, there is a Path of Silence (Hiljaisuuden polku), which is freely accessible. The path is about 400 meters long, with signs containing Bible texts and history related to the churchyard in Finnish and English. The church is accessible for people with disabilities from the back entrance, and the Soini parish (Soinin seurakunta) takes care of the church.

name: Somerniemen kirkko
description:
Somerniemen kirkko is a wooden church located in Somero, on the shore of Lake Painio. The church was built in 1813, based on drawings from the Intendentinkonttori. It's a rectangular long church without a tower, featuring a sacristy on the north side and an entrance hall on the south side.

The altar painting, created by an unknown artist, depicts Christ in Gethsemane and the Holy Communion. The church also has a wooden bell tower built in 1749, housing bells from 1746 and 1889. The churchyard also contains a memorial to those who died in the wars.

name: Someron kirkko
description:
The Church of Somero is a neo-Gothic long church made of red brick, designed by Georg Theodor Chiewitz and completed in 1859. It is located on Kirkonmäki in Somero. Inside the church, there are 1500 seats. The church organ was made in 1880 by J.A. Zachariassen's organ building workshop.

The walls are structured by stepped support pillars, and large window fields are in between. The tower of the copper-roofed brick church is approximately 43 meters high. The altar painting, "Christ's Transfiguration," was painted by Erik Löfgren from Turku. In 2021, there was an attempted arson at the church.

name: Sonkajärven kirkko
description:
The Sonkajärvi Church, also known as Pyhän Toivon kirkko (Church of Holy Hope), is one of the two churches in the Sonkajärvi parish. It was built between 1909 and 1910 and designed by architect Josef Stenbäck. The church was consecrated on November 6, 1910.

The church is constructed from black and grey granite sourced from Sonkajärvi. It features a long church design with an asymmetrical floor plan. The interior walls are made of brick, and the vaults are made of concrete. Originally, the surfaces were plastered and limewashed in grey with reddish decorative motifs. The church's interior was repainted in 1969 and underwent a thorough renovation between 2000 and 2002.

The churchyard includes a cemetery area that was expanded in 1921. The war heroes' graves are located in front of the church. The monument to the war heroes is a sculpture by Hannes Autere from 1957.

name: Sotkamon kirkko
description:
Sotkamo Church is the fifth church in the Sotkamo parish's history. It is located near the center of Sotkamo, on the shore of Lake Sotkamojärvi. The wooden church was designed by architect Johan Oldenburg and built in the late 1860s during a severe famine, and it was consecrated in August 1870. The church represents a late Renaissance style with Neo-Gothic details.

During the Winter War, in March 1940, the church was hit by two bombs dropped from an airplane. One bomb failed to explode, but the other shattered 60 window panes and damaged the altarpiece. The altarpiece was painted by Severi Falkman. In 1996, a new mechanical organ was installed, representing Flemish Baroque tradition.

name: Sottungan kirkko
description: Sottunga Church, dedicated to St. Mary Magdalene, is a notable landmark on the island. This small, red wooden church, built in 1728, replaced an older church that was destroyed in a fire. It is considered the smallest wooden church in Finland. The church features a wooden bell tower, constructed in 1770 and renovated in 1802, located across the road from the church itself. The altar painting was created by P. Berggren in Stockholm in 1845. The church is located close to the harbor and a nature trail, making it a popular attraction for visitors.

name: Soukaisten Pyhän Perttelin kirkko
description:
Soukaisten Pyhän Perttelin kirkko is a wooden long church located in the village of Soukainen, Laitila. It was likely built in the 1700s, originally standing in the village of Valko. The church has undergone several renovations, including around 1800, and in 1847 and 1896. A low armory-like space was later built in front of the western end of the church, and a bell tower with the year 1847 on its vane stands on the ridge of the western end. Instead of bells, a horn was used in the church in the past.

A rather extensive renovation was carried out in 1932. The church building was boarded and painted red in 1965, the intermediate ceiling was renewed, and new benches were brought from Laitila's St. Michael's Church. A shingle roof was made to replace the earlier shingle roof in 1969. The church is dedicated to St. Bartholomew.

name: St. Jacobs kyrka
description:
St. Jacobs Church is located in Lauttasaari, Helsinki, and it shares a building complex with the Lauttasaari Church. Both churches have their own sanctuary and parish hall. The building complex surrounds a courtyard on three sides, with a bell tower in the middle. The sanctuaries are on opposite sides of the courtyard, connected by a parish wing.

Architects Maija and Keijo Petäjä designed the church complex, which was completed in 1958. The facade is made of sandblasted white concrete. St. Jacobs Church is used by the Johannes parish and has approximately 250 seats. The church features a 12-stop organ built by Robert Gustavsson of Sweden and a crucifix by sculptor Viktor Jansson instead of an altarpiece. The church also has three bronze bells.

name: Sukevan kirkko
description:
Sukevan kirkko is located in Sukeva, Sonkajärvi. It was originally built as a prayer room in 1934, and later consecrated as a church in 1956. Architect Esko Laitinen from Kajaani designed the modifications for the church. Between 1962 and 1963, the building was thoroughly renovated according to Laitinen's plans. A bell tower was built on the north side of the church in 1963.

The church has a single nave and a rectangular floor plan, with a seating capacity of 250. The altar and sacristy are located at the southern end. The interior was renovated and painted in 1985 based on plans by architect Osmo Sillman from Kajaani. The altarpiece was painted by T.G. Tuhkanen from Paltaniemi and placed in the church in 1956. The church has a gabled roof, and its log frame is clad with yellow horizontal weatherboarding. The side walls feature large, six-paned windows with white frames.

name: Sulkavan kirkko
description:
Sulkava Church is a double-cruciform church located in the village of Sulkava. It was built in 1822, designed by the Italian-born architect Charles Bassi.

The church's location by Lake Saimaa reflects the historical importance of waterways for the parishioners. The oldest known church on the site dates back to 1653. The current church can accommodate 1000 people. A unique feature inside the church is the set of permanently turned candleholders. The sexton's desk is also noteworthy, from which the sexton led the congregation's church singing until 1892. The church received its first organ in 1892.

The bell tower next to the church is the oldest surviving building in Sulkava, built in 1770.

name: Sulvan kirkko
description:
The Sulva Church, located in Mustasaari, Finland, is a wooden long church representing Gustavian neoclassical style, built between 1783 and 1786. Johan Elfström designed the church, which lacks a tower. The building features two narrow annexes of the same height as the main body, positioned on the central axis. The roof of the main building is hipped at the ends, with a small roof lantern. Horizontal-boarded pilasters articulate the exterior walls, and the windows are round-arched. Inside, a wooden barrel vault serves as the ceiling. The church has undergone several renovations throughout the years.

A separate wooden belfry, designed by Carl Axel Setterberg, was constructed in 1870 and houses bells dating back to 1726 and 1858. The church has a floor area of 343 square meters and can accommodate 700 people. The church boasts a four-part altar piece considered one of the most significant works of folk baroque wood carving in Finland.

name: Sumiaisten kirkko
description:
Sumiaisten Kirkko, located in Sumiainen, Äänekoski, is a wooden church with an octagonal shape. The current church was inaugurated in 1890 and was designed by Theodor Granstedt. This replaced an earlier church built in 1802, retaining its octagonal form. The pulpit is from the old church.

Inside, the church features neo-Gothic style elements. The altarpiece depicting the Resurrection was painted in 1901 by Vidolfia von Engström-Ahrenberg. The church also has a tapestry woven in 1881 by Carolina Maria Lagus, and an "Organ" themed wedding tapestry donated by the Sumiainen Women Farmers in 1963. The bell tower, built in 1851, houses two bells.

name: Sundin kirkko
description:
Sund Church is a medieval stone church located in the municipality of Sund in Åland, Finland. It was built in the late 13th century or at the latest before 1310, and is dedicated to John the Baptist. The church tower and armory were likely built at the end of the 14th century, while the sacristy dates back to the mid-15th century.

Inside, the church has been well-preserved. Wall paintings of Saint Margaret, Catherine of Alexandria, and an anonymous male saint date from the early 14th century. The altarpiece, featuring Mary and the baby Jesus in the center, was made in the 1430s or 1440s. The church gives a somewhat fortress-like impression due to its sturdy construction. The stone part of the church tower is 22 meters high, and its floor area is the second largest in Finland after Turku Cathedral.

name: Suodenniemen kirkko
description:
The Suodenniemi Church, located in Sastamala, was completed in 1831. The brown wooden church was designed by Charles Bassi and Anton Wilhelm Arppe. Initially, the church was a cross-shaped building without a tower.

Later, in 1839, a three-part Empire-style tower designed by Carl Ludvig Engel was added. The windows of the main building and the tower are arched. The church has played a role in Finnish history, including during the Civil War and the Second World War, when it housed an air surveillance station.

name: Suolahden kirkko
description: Suolahden kirkko is located in Äänekoski. It was designed by architect Georg Henriksson and built in 1940. The church represents late functionalism and is made of plastered brick. Unusually, the tower is located on the corner of one of the long sides of the building. The church has 322 square meters of space and can accommodate approximately 350 people. The church also houses the Äänekoski parish's church museum. The altar painting, "Come to me, all you who labor and are burdened, and I will give you rest," was painted by Alf Danning in 1954, but he died during the process, and his student completed it. The painting depicts a local landscape.

name: Suomenlinnan kirkko
description:
Located in the Suomenlinna sea fortress in Helsinki, the Suomenlinna Church was originally built in 1854 as an Orthodox garrison church for the Russian military. It had five towers with onion domes.

After Finland gained independence in 1917, the church was converted into a Lutheran church. During the renovation, the onion domes were removed, the main tower was made rectangular, and the small domes were covered. The walls were plastered smooth, giving it a simpler appearance that better suited the fortress architecture.

The church still functions as a lighthouse for ships entering Helsinki. It is a popular wedding venue and hosts concerts and other events. Services are usually held on the first Sunday of the month and on holidays.

name: Suomenniemen kirkko
description:
The Suomenniemi Church is a wooden church located in Suomenniemi, Mikkeli. It was designed by A. H. Dalström and built in 1866, representing the Neo-Gothic style. The church has a symmetrical cross shape with a polygonal roof turret in the center. It can accommodate approximately 600 people.

Near the church stands a bell tower, constructed in 1777, housing two bells from 1778 and 1780. The church's current 16-stop organ was made by Urkurakentamo Tuomi in 1983. The altar painting, "Jesus Blesses the Children," was painted by Hannes Malin in 1924. Originally, the church was heated by stoves, which are still present in the church hall.

name: Suomusjärven kirkko
description:
Suomusjärvi Church is a wooden cross-shaped church located in Suomusjärvi, Salo. It was built between 1847 and 1849, designed by architect E.B. Lohrmann, and constructed by carpenter I. Lindström. This is the third church building in the area. The first one was built in 1635.

The altar painting, created by R.W. Ekman in 1866, depicts Christ on Golgotha, with a sleeping baby Jesus at the bottom holding a crown of thorns. The pulpit was made in 1897 by H.J. Stenroos from Turku. The bell tower was constructed in 1750 by Jaakko Härkä. The church has seating for 560 people and represents classicism and Empire styles.

name: Suomussalmen kirkko
description:
The Suomussalmi church is located in the Suomussalmi village. It is a long, single-nave church made of concrete and brick, built in 1950 according to the plans of architect Onni Ermala. It does not have a tower. Connected to the church is a parish hall, and in the basement of the hall, there is a day-care center.

The previous church was destroyed in the Winter War on Christmas Eve in 1939. The new church was built with the help of American Lutheran congregations and the Church of Sweden. Artist Bruno Tuukkanen painted the altar secco, depicting the earthly stages of Jesus' life, and the stained glass of the baptismal chapel. Sculptor Jooseppi Manninen made the wood carvings of the pulpit and the apostle figures at the entrance. The church's two bells come from the Kurkijoki church.

name: Suonenjoen kirkko
description:
Suonenjoki Church, completed in 1865, was designed by architect Ferdinand Öhman. It's a wooden long church with a tower and a short transept. The church is 33 meters long, 23 meters wide and 10 meters high, while the tower reaches 37 meters.

In the late 1800s, the church received cladding both inside and outside, was painted, and equipped with stove heating. Major renovations in 1955-56 significantly altered the church's appearance. During renovations in 1993-95, the exterior paint was restored to its originally presumed color and the interior aimed to reflect a 1920s style. The altarpiece, painted by Helena Westling in 1884, depicts Jesus on the cross.

name: Suoniemen kirkko
description: Suoniemen kirkko is the oldest church in Nokia, Finland, completed in 1803, with a separate bell tower built in 1820. This unique, light-colored wooden church is a popular destination for excursions and weddings. Inside, the atmosphere is inviting with soft brown benches and water-green walls, complemented by an ornate pulpit. A highlight is the 12-stop organ, constructed by Bror Axel Thulé, installed in 1903. The altar painting, depicting Christ's crucifixion, was created by Felix Frang in 1903. Near the church is a loan warehouse from 1860, now a museum, and a former autopsy room used until the 1950s.

name: Sysmän kirkko
description: Sysmän kirkko, also known as the Church of St. Olaf, is a medieval stone church located in Sysmä. It is believed to have been built in the early 16th century, around 1520, and is dedicated to St. Olaf. The church was originally a long church but was transformed into a cruciform church in the 1830s, based on designs by Carl Ludvig Engel. The bell tower and adjacent burial chapel were completed in 1845. The church is situated near Lake Päijänne. The altar crucifix dates back to the medieval times. The churchyard has an old cemetery.

name: Syvänniemen kirkko
description:
The Syvänniemi Church, located in Syvänniemi, Karttula, Kuopio, was designed by Johan Victor Strömberg and built in 1925. It is a long church made of brick and concrete, featuring a tower and a triple-chancel. Adjacent to the chancel is a sacristy, which is lower than the rest of the church. The tower is located at the entrance end, and the bells date back to 1925.

The church's hall has a gable roof. It was renovated in 1950. The church covers an area of 420 square meters and can seat 500 people. The altarpiece, depicting Christ on the Cross, was painted by Arthur Heickell in 1911. The church's 14-stop organ was manufactured by Kangasala organ factory in 1926.

The church is used during the summer and Christmas seasons, and is a popular venue for weddings and concerts. A war memorial stands next to the church in memory of the 11 fallen heroes.

name: Säkylän kirkko
description: Säkylä Church is a wooden church in Säkylä, consecrated in 1776. The church was built by Antti and Mikael Piimänen. Heikki Klemetti, who wrote about church builders of the 17th and 18th centuries, considered Säkylä Church one of the most beautiful achievements in Finnish architecture. The exact date of the church's consecration is August 4, 1776. The church underwent extensive renovation and interior renovation in 2011–2012. The church is also called the Church of Gustav III, because he had given permission for the construction of the church. The Säkylä Church war hero statue is a work by sculptor Jussi Vikainen from 1951.

name: Särkisalon kirkko
description:
Särkisalo Church, located in Särkisalo, Salo, is a wooden long church built in 1760. It's a rectangular, towerless structure. A sacristy, lower and narrower than the nave, is attached to the north side of the church, with a similarly sized armory on the south side. A small wooden-walled vestibule was added to the west end in 1858. All parts of the building have steep gable roofs.

The altarpiece, painted by Alexandra Frosterus-Såltin in 1897, depicts Jesus and children. Above the altarpiece is a radiant, black-painted wooden cross. The pulpit was made in 1869. The organ loft was built by carpenter Juhana Backman in 1760, and Karin Mascitti-Slotte painted images of the apostles on the mirrors in 1961. The church's stained-glass windows, also by Karin Mascitti-Slotte, date from 1958. The separate wooden bell tower was constructed between 1761 and 1762. The church can accommodate 230 people.

name: Säräisniemen kirkko
description:
Säräisniemi Church is an idyllic wooden cross-shaped church completed in 1781. It is located in the old municipal center of Säräisniemi in Vaala, in a beautiful landscape near Lake Oulujärvi. The church can accommodate approximately 500 people, and it is a popular church for weddings.

The church was built to replace the Manamansalo church, which was destroyed during the Russo-Swedish War in the 16th century. Next to the church, sheltered by trees, is a cemetery with old, ornate tombstones. There is also a war graves area in the cemetery, commemorating the villagers who fell in the Second World War. The stone foundation of Säräisniemi Church is made of beautifully folded gneiss, which was quarried from nearby Pirunkalliot.

name: Säyneisen kirkko
description:
Säyneinen Church, completed in 1939, is located in the village of Säyneinen, Kuopio. It was designed by Sakari Honkavaara and Esko Suhonen, and represents the romantic style of functionalism of the 1940s. Instead of an altarpiece, there is a cross, but in 2002 the restored old altarpiece was returned to the church hall.

The church also has a parish hall. Originally, Bishop Eino Sormunen admired the parish hall as the first in his diocese to be built in connection with the church. The church has undergone several renovations, including interior painting in 1981, exterior painting in 1985, and renovations to the parish hall floor and walls in 2000.

name: Säynätsalon kirkko
description:
Säynätsalo Church, located in Jyväskylä, was designed by architects Armas Lindgren and Bertel Liljeqvist and completed in 1927. The church features a gable tower and a long church design, with a small parish hall in the side aisle. The building material is brick with a rendered surface.

The bell tower's spire has a Baroque influence, and unusually, it features a rooster above the cross at its highest point. Light pink shades were a popular choice for churches in the early 1900s. The interior is surprisingly elegant and atmospheric. The altarpiece was created by painter Hanna Rönnberg, and the hall contains several stained-glass windows by painter Antti Salmenlinna. The wooden crucifix is the work of sculptor Gunnar Finne. The artistic decoration of the church hall was also contributed by painter Paavo Leinonen and decorative artist Antti Salmenlinna. The hall has seating for 350 people.

name: Sääksmäen kirkko
description:
Sääksmäki Church is a medieval stone church located in Sääksmäki, Valkeakoski. It was likely constructed between 1495 and 1500. Originally, the church had numerous valuable sculptures, of which two remain: Saint Olaf from the early 14th century and Saint James from the 1490s.

In the mid-19th century, the church was expanded into a cruciform structure but suffered a fire on Easter in 1929. During the fire, the wooden upper part of the belfry built in 1766 was destroyed. However, the altarpiece painted by R.W. Ekman in 1848, communion dishes, and old church textiles were saved.

After the fire, the church was rebuilt according to architect Kauno S. Kallio's plans, and the side naves were removed to restore the church to its original medieval size. The ceiling and wall paintings in the rebuilt church were created by artist Kalle Carlstedt. The church was last restored between 1998 and 1999.

name: Taalintehtaan kirkko
description:
Taalintehtaan Church, located in Kemiönsaari, was built in 1921-22 by the local Methodist-Episcopal congregation. After twelve years, Baron Wrede, one of the owners of the Taalintehdas ironworks, purchased the church and offered it for rent to the Evangelical-Lutheran congregation. The church was consecrated as Evangelical-Lutheran in 1934, and the congregation bought the church in 1978.

The church is constructed from slag bricks, which were made from the waste of the Taalintehdas iron furnace. Karl Andström designed the church. The church's bell tower was inaugurated at the church's 25th-anniversary celebration. The church has good acoustics and is used as a concert venue. The organ has nine voices and was built in 1967 by Hans Heinrich. The altar painting is by Axel Haartman.

name: Tainionkosken kirkko
description:
Tainionkoski Church is the main church of the Imatra parish and the oldest church in Imatra, Finland. It was completed in 1932 and consecrated on July 8, 1933. The church was designed by architect Yrjö Vaskinen. The church's organ was installed in 1938.

From the 1940s, a crucifix was located where the altarpiece is now. In 1997, it was replaced by an oil painting by Kristiina Uusitalo. The crucifix is currently on the side wall of the church hall. The style of the church is mostly 1920s classicism. A unique feature is its pulpit, which, unusually, is located on the right side of the altar when viewed from the church hall.

name: Taipalsaaren kirkko
description:
Taipalsaari Church is a symmetrical cross-shaped church originally built in 1754. While the exact architect is unconfirmed, it's believed to be Eskil Collanus. It was expanded and modified between 1845 and 1847, according to drawings made at the Intendentinkonttori. The church has a flat ceiling in its wings and a cupola supported by columns in the center.

The church seats 800 people. The 18-stop organ was manufactured by Kangasala organ factory in 1977. The altar features a framed metal cross, a crux nuda. An altar painting was previously in the church, but it was moved to the Vyborg Provincial Museum in the 1890s, and its fate is unknown. Currently, a golden cross and the text "Behold, the Lamb of God" are in place of the altar painting.

name: Taivalkosken kirkko
description: The Taivalkoski Church was designed by architect Kauno Kallio in 1932 and consecrated in August 1933. The church, located in the Taivalkoski church village, is of the neoclassical style and has approximately 400 seats. The altar painting, "Jesus in Gethsemane," was painted by Väinö Tiger in 1934. The churchyard is open during events and as a roadside church in the summer. Services are held on Sundays, and other religious events, musical performances and church services are also organized there. The current church is the second one in the region. The first church was destroyed in a fire in 1925.

name: Taivassalon kirkko
description:
Taivassalo Church, dedicated to the Holy Cross, is a medieval stone church located in Taivassalo. It's an architecturally distinctive building constructed in the 15th century, likely between 1425 and 1440. The church is situated on the island of Kirkkosaari in the Turku archipelago.

Inside, the church features a 14th-century crucifix considered a Finnish national treasure and believed to be the work of the Liedon master's school. The church walls are adorned with extensive paintings, the earliest of which date back to the 1400s. The church's builders collected natural stones from the surrounding areas, mainly reddish-brown granite. A war memorial dedicated to those who fell during 1939-44 stands in front of the church.

name: Tammelan kirkko
description:
Tammelan Church is a grey stone church, the oldest part of which was built in the early 16th century. As the population grew, the church was expanded to its current size between 1781 and 1785. The patron saint of Tammela Church is St. Michael, whose statue is located on the left wall of the church.

The church has seven wooden sculptures, the oldest of which date back to the 16th century. The altarpiece depicting the Transfiguration of Christ was painted by court painter R.W. Ekman in 1860. The pulpit was donated by Lord of Saari Manor, Councillor of State, and Admiral Lorenz Creutz in 1670. The baptismal font is made of pine and carved from a single tree felled in 1626 or 1627. The church is currently undergoing renovation, expected to last from September 2024 to June 2025.

name: Tammisaaren kirkko
description:
Tammisaari Church, originally a small wooden church, saw its construction initiated by Count Axel Leijonhufvud in 1589. His younger brother, Moritz Leijonhufvud, completed the construction in 1600. The initiative to build a stone church was taken in 1651, and it was completed in 1680. However, a fire in 1821 destroyed the church, and the current church was completed in 1842.

The church has been restored between 1957-1959 and 1987-1990. Tammisaari Church houses valuable items, including a communion chalice from 1631 and a Bible from the 1600s that belonged to vicar Sigfrid Aronius Forsius. The church organ dates back to 1843 and was donated by knight Bernt Erik Ingberg. The organ was built by Anders Thulén. The church, built of gray stone, seats approximately 550 people.

name: Tammisalon kirkko
description: Tammisalo Church, located in the Tammisalo district of Helsinki, was completed in 1966 and designed by architect Lauri Silvennoinen. The red-brick church has a separate bell tower. In 2022, the Roihuvuori parish council decided to relinquish the church due to the economic situation, and it was transferred to the property department of the Helsinki Parish Union at the beginning of 2023. A bell, designed by the artist and sculptor Sigurd Wettenhovi-Aspa and cast in Paris in 1894, is located in the church's belfry. The church has been an important place for local organisations and events.

name: Tampereen tuomiokirkko
description:
Tampere Cathedral, originally known as St. John's Church, is a Lutheran church in Tampere, Finland, and serves as the seat of the Diocese of Tampere. Built between 1902 and 1907, the cathedral showcases the National Romantic style, designed by Lars Sonck.

The cathedral is renowned for its symbolic frescoes, created by Hugo Simberg between 1905 and 1906, which once incited considerable controversy. Simberg's works include versions of "The Wounded Angel" and "The Garden of Death." Another notable feature is the altar-piece, painted by Magnus Enckell, depicting the resurrection of people from all races. The exterior is marked by the use of light gray Uusikaupunki granite and a picturesque arrangement of volumes, including three towers of varying heights.

name: Tampereen vanha kirkko
description:
Tampereen Vanha Kirkko, or Old Church of Tampere, is a wooden cross-shaped church located next to Keskustori square. The church was commissioned in 1825 and designed in the neoclassical style by Carlo Bassi. It is one of the oldest buildings in central Tampere.

The church is mainly used by the Swedish-speaking Lutheran parish of Tampere, and English-language services are also held there. It is a popular church for weddings, and the interior was restored to its original appearance in the 1950s. The altarpiece, depicting Gethsemane, dates back to 1831 and was painted by R.W. Ekman. The pulpit, in the Empire style, was designed by Aleksander Engel, also in 1831. The city's first park was planted around the church in 1835.

name: Tapiolan kirkko
description: Tapiola Church is a Lutheran church located in the Tapiola district of Espoo, Finland. Designed by architect Aarno Ruusuvuori, this modernist concrete building in brutalist style was opened in 1965. With a seating capacity of 600, it is the largest church in Espoo. The church is open to visitors, and the parish actively uses the space. In Tapiola Church hall there are most seats of all the churches in Espoo.

name: Tarvasjoen kirkko
description:
Tarvasjoki Church, located in Tarvasjoki, Lieto, is a wooden long church with a tower. It was built in 1779 by Mikael Piimänen. Over time, the church has been repaired and modified. The interior design is mainly from 1916, while the exterior architecture dates back to the 1870s.

The church is situated on a ridge in the cultural landscape of the Paimionjoki and Tarvasjoki branches, along Kyröntie road in the center of Tarvasjoki. The Tarvasjoki Church and its surrounding area are part of the nationally significant built cultural environment of the Hämeen Härkätie. The church and cemetery are regionally valuable buildings or built environments in the regional plan.

Originally, the church was unheated. In 1897, stoves were installed in the church hall and sacristy. During the 1916 renovation, the church was insulated. The stoves were removed during the 1969-1971 renovation, and electric heating was installed. The church has had electric lighting since 1933; before that, lighting was provided by oil lamps and candles.

name: Taulumäen kirkko
description:
Taulumäki Church is the main church of the Jyväskylä parish, located in the Taulumäki district. Designed by architect Elsi Borg, it was completed in 1929 and is considered one of the most significant examples of monumental architecture of the 1920s classicism in Finland.

The church is also known as the "Church of Angels" because of the numerous angel paintings found inside, with a total of 24 angel figures. The interior features frescoes by Paavo Leinonen, and an altarpiece by Eero Järnefelt that was rescued from the fire that destroyed the previous church. The over 30-meter-high bell tower is a landmark, and the church is a popular venue for weddings and confirmations.

name: Teerijärven kirkko
description:
The Teerijärvi Church, located in Kruunupyy, Finland, is a wooden cross-shaped church built in 1774 by Matti Honga. It was extensively renovated in 1877 by Jaakko Kuorikoski. The church represents late classicism and features an octagonal central cube topped with a dome lantern.

The church's interior has a wooden vault. The church has a surface area of 418 square meters and approximately 600 seats. The church organ was made by E. F. Walcker & Co. in 1941.

The bell tower was initially built in 1701 and moved to its current location when the church was constructed. It acquired its present appearance mainly in 1852.

name: Teijon kirkko
description:
Teijon Kirkko, located in the village of Teijo in Salo, is Finland's smallest stone church. It was built in 1829 by factory owner Robert Bremer as a thank you for the predicted flood not happening.

The church features a simple and unadorned exterior, while the interior is bright and spacious. The church can accommodate around 100 people.

Over the years, the church has experienced both joyous and sorrowful events in the local community. In 1972, a severe fire destroyed the roof structures, and the tower bell fell in front of the main door. The church and cemetery faced a forced auction due to bankruptcy in 1999 but were bought by villagers. The Ministry of the Environment has designated the church and granary as national cultural heritage sites. Today, Teijon Kirkko is a significant part of Teijo's ironworks village's historical and cultural heritage. In summer, it serves as a roadside church.

name: Teiskon kirkko
description:
Teiskon kirkko is a wooden church located in Tampere, specifically in Teisko, Finland. It stands on a hill by Lake Kirkkojärvi and is surrounded by a cemetery. The church is the third one built for the Teisko parish and was completed in 1788, although it was inaugurated in August 1787 while still under construction, due to the poor condition of the previous church. Matti Åkerblom, a well-known church builder, designed it.

The church is characterized by its cross-shaped floor plan with beveled inner corners. This design, along with a spacious vaulted ceiling, contributes to the church's airy feel. The bell tower was added ten years later by Åkerblom. Today, Teisko Church is part of the Messukylä parish.

name: Teljän kirkko
description:
Teljä Church is located in the Uusikoivisto district of Pori and was completed in 1973. The church was designed by Olaf Küttner. It serves as the main church for the Teljä parish.

The church is a popular venue for concerts. The church organ was manufactured in 1975 and has 34 stops, electric action, three manuals and a pedal. The appearance of the organ was designed in cooperation with Küttner's architectural office. The organ case is made of red beech, like the rest of the church's interior. The altar sculpture depicting the baby Jesus is made of red pine by Eva Ryynänen. The church acquired a Steinway grand piano in 2003.

name: Temmeksen kirkko
description:
Temmes Church is a wooden church located in the village of Temmes, in the municipality of Tyrnävä. It belongs to the Tyrnävä parish. The church was originally built between 1766 and 1767 as a prayer room, based on the decision and at the expense of the villagers of Temmes and Kärsämä, without approved drawings. According to tradition, it was designed and built by Antti Louet.

The church is one of the last support pillar churches built in Finland. These types of churches were common in the Ostrobothnia region in the 17th century. The church has a western tower that is partially embedded in the main building. Inside, the walls are made of exposed logs painted yellow. The barrel vault ceiling is painted blue. The three-part altarpiece was painted by Carl Christoffer Stadig in 1847. Next to the church gate stands Finland's largest "vaivaisukko", a wooden alms box statue.

name: Temppeliaukion kirkko
description: Temppeliaukio Church, also known as the Church of the Rock, is a Lutheran church in Helsinki, Finland, located in the Töölö neighborhood. It was designed by brothers Timo and Tuomo Suomalainen and opened in 1969. The church is built directly into solid rock. The interior has 750 seats and is often used as a concert venue due to its excellent acoustics. The area where the church is located was originally reserved for a church in 1906, but construction didn't begin until later. The church is a popular tourist attraction, with approximately 850,000 visitors in 2018. In the summer, it welcomes about 10,000 visitors daily.

name: Tenholan kirkko
description:
Tenhola Church, likely dedicated to Saint Olaf, offers visitors an interesting journey through centuries, starting from the 12th century. The stone church was built in the 13th and 14th centuries. High octagonal pillars divide the church hall into three naves and five traverses. The sacristy, built at the eastern end of the north wall of the church, is part of a wooden church, likely built before the 13th century.

The stone base of the bell tower, like the staircase (mortuary) north of the church, which is connected to the wall surrounding the churchyard in the 14th century, formed the entrances to the churchyard in the Middle Ages. The church has about 450 seats.

name: Tervakosken kirkko
description:
Tervakoski Church, also known as the Little Church of Tervakoski, is a wooden church built in 1936 in the village of Tervakoski, Janakkala. The Tervakoski Little Church Association, founded the previous year, initiated the project. The Tervakoski paper mill supported the construction by donating logs from the Toiva Manor's old drying barn. Architect Jarl Eklund designed the church, and local villagers built it through communal work.

Hilbert from Helsinki, a professional decorator, completed the interior decorative paintings. In 1939, the paper mill constructed a bell tower and donated it to the association. Gösta Serlachius, a patron of the arts, donated an altarpiece painted by Georges von Swetlick in 1937. The church received a 450 kg church bell from Oskari Vaara, the director of the Napiala Leather Factory. The church came under the ownership of the Janakkala Parish in 1973.

name: Tervon kirkko
description:
Tervo Church, completed in 1925, is located in Tervo. The church was designed by architect Ilmari Launis. The interior paintings are by artist Mauno Paananen.

The church is made of red brick, partially plastered. It is a short-armed cross church with a semicircular apse extending the choir area. Stylistically, the church represents historicism, which was common in Finland in the 1920s. The asymmetrical floor plan and decorative paintings reflect national romanticism. The church also features Romanesque and Gothic styles, as well as classical columns and pilasters.

name: Tervolan kirkko
description: Tervola Church refers to three different churches within the Tervola parish. The Old Church, dating back to 1687-1689, is one of Finland's best-preserved 17th-century churches and serves as the main church during summer and for Christmas. The Great Church, also known as the New Church, was constructed between 1861 and 1864 and is the largest church in Lapland. Due to high heating costs, it was decommissioned in 1950, but Christmas services still take place there. The third church is located in the Parish Center and can accommodate 150 people, or up to 400 when the adjacent hall is connected. This church features an altar wall made of local Loue marble and a stained-glass window called "The Gate of Tears".

name: Tervolan seurakuntakeskuksen kirkko
description: Tervola's parish center was completed in 1974 and was designed by the architectural firm Risto Jämsä. In the parish center, there is a hall consecrated as a church, which serves as the parish's main church from the beginning of September to the end of May. The church accommodates 150 people, but the parish hall, separated by a folding door, can be connected to the church hall, in which case the church can accommodate a maximum of 400 people. The church has an 8-voice organ made by Urkurakentamo Tuomi. The altar wall is made of local Loue marble. The western window wall features a stained glass work called "Gate of Tears" designed by artist Hilkka Toivola in 1976.

name: Tervolan vanha kirkko
description:
Tervolan vanha kirkko (Old Church of Tervola) is one of the three churches belonging to the Tervola parish. Constructed between 1687 and 1689, it stands as one of Finland's best-preserved 17th-century churches. It is a so-called pillar church. The church was decommissioned in 1865 after the construction of the Tervola main church.

It was renovated and reopened in 1950. Currently, the old church serves as the parish's main church during the summer months of June to August. It is also used during Christmas and Holy Week. The church has seating for approximately 200 people. The pulpit was crafted by Johan Skogh from Tornio in 1733 and painted by Nils Olofsson Ahlboom in 1735. The two-part altarpiece was painted by Johan Gustav Hedman from Oulu in 1832.

name: Tesoman kirkko
description:
Tesoman kirkko is a church located in the Tesomajärvi district of Tampere. Designed by architect Olavi Suvitie, it was built in 1977-1978 using concrete and brick. The church serves as both a place of worship and a multipurpose facility, hosting activities for children and adults.

The church hall can be expanded by incorporating the confirmation class and parish hall, accommodating up to 350 people. The altar features a relief by Laila Pullinen titled "Now we see in a mirror dimly, then face to face." The church also has a 12-stop organ made by Kangasala organ factory. The church bells are inscribed with the phrases "God is love" and "He who has ears, let him hear". Tesoman kirkko is protected for its architectural and cultural-historical significance.

name: Tiistenjoen kirkko
description:
Tiistenjoki Church is located in the village of Tiistenjoki in Lapua. The first church in Tiistenjoki was completed in 1915, but it burned down in 1941. The war delayed the construction of a new church. Men at the front promised that those who survived would first erect a monument to their fallen brothers and then build a new church.

The current wooden church was completed in 1953 and was designed by builder Eero Ojaniemi. The altarpiece was painted by Kaarlo Lamminheimo. The church has 550 seats. The church and the adjacent parish hall are owned by the village church association, which is supported by the parish. The church is open to visitors and those seeking peace in the summer.

name: Tikkakosken kirkko
description:
Tikkakoski Church, located in Tikkakoski, Jyväskylä, is a stone church designed by county architect Olavi Kivimaa in 1957. The church has seating for 300 people. It is a long church with a gable roof and no tower, featuring a red-brick gable triangle at the end and slate inlays on the lower parts of the walls.

Inside, the ceiling is a flat, sloping structure. An adjacent building houses a parish hall and vestry. The church's organ, boasting 10 stops, was manufactured by Kangasala organ factory in 1959. Originally, the church's floor area was 232 square meters, but the parish facilities connected to it have been expanded on a couple of occasions. A glass painting designed by artist Lauri Ahlgrén in 1977 can also be found in the church. The church was renovated in the summer of 2024.

name: Tikkurilan kirkko
description:
Tikkurila Church, consecrated in January 2021, stands in the heart of Tikkurila, Vantaa. The new church replaced the old one built in 1956. It serves as the home church for both the Tikkurila Parish and the Swedish Parish of Vantaa. The church also houses the administrative offices and joint parish work of the Vantaa parishes.

The architecture features a distinctive design, with a towering corner reaching 20 meters. The interior emphasizes natural materials like brick, wood, and concrete, creating a warm and inviting atmosphere. The church hall is adaptable for various uses and includes a cafe, family space, meeting rooms, and a courtyard. Accessibility has been a key consideration in its design.

name: Tirvan kirkko
description:
Tirva Church is a beautiful wooden church located in Kouvola, Finland. It's a popular venue for weddings, christenings, and other church events. In addition to Christmas, Easter and Midsummer services, the church also holds a traditional service for the "Martat" (a Finnish women's organisation) in the spring. The atmospheric church features electric organs.

The Tirva Prayer House Association was founded in 1924. The owner of the Tirva factories donated the land for the church, and an old cottage building was purchased from Ingria to be used as construction material. The church was erected through volunteer work and consecrated in the autumn of 1932. Many local residents have contributed greatly to the village church over the decades. The church's furnishings, including the altarpiece, chandelier, and textiles, were mainly donations. The altarpiece "Jesus Blesses Children" has nine bullet holes from the Finnish civil war in 1918. The church has a capacity of 200 and services are held approximately once a month.

name: Tohmajärven kirkko
description: Tohmajärvi Church is located in Kirkkoniemi, Tohmajärvi. Completed in 1756, it stands as the oldest wooden church in North Karelia. The church is a symmetrical cross-shaped building that can accommodate approximately 650 people. The separate, shingle-roofed belfry was completed in 1760. In 2006, the church's sound system was renovated. The churchyard also contains a war graves area, a memorial stone, and a guard statue, as well as memorial stones for Bishop Eino Sormunen and other figures.

name: Toholammin kirkko
description:
The Toholampi Church is the third church in Toholampi. The previous churches were located on the shore of Lake Kirkkojärvi. The current church was built in a new location about three kilometers upstream of the Lestijoki River, on Kettukangas.

Designed by county architect Carl Axel Setterberg, the wooden church was completed in 1861. Stylistically, Toholampi's long church with a gable tower is neo-Gothic. The altar painting, The Institution of the Eucharist, was painted by Johan Backman in 1761. The painting was originally painted for the church that preceded the current church.

Visitors can admire the "strawberries" on the church's ceiling and the green coloring of the ceiling. The designer was inspired by the biblical Feast of Tabernacles. The choir paintings depicting angels carrying the sacraments are by artist Ilmari Wirkkala. The decorative glass in the choir windows comes from the House of Knights in Helsinki. The church's organ loft dates back to 1906.

name: Toivakan kirkko
description:
Toivakka Church, belonging to the Jyväskylä parish, is located in Toivakka. This long church with a tower at the end was built between 1879 and 1882, based on the plans of architect L.I. Lindqvist. The bell tower was completed earlier in 1871. Stylistically, the church represents the Neo-Gothic style.

The church is situated on Syrjäharju, from where its tower stands out along the main road through the church village. It was renovated in the 1920s under the direction of architect Alvar Aalto, who also designed church furnishings. Aalto's designs included the church's previous ceiling paintings, chandelier, pulpit decoration, two wrought iron candlesticks, lamps and candles.

In 1973, Pellervo Lukumies, an artist from Toivakka, painted the church's distinctive ceiling paintings. The paintings, which depict Jesus dressed in modern clothes, among other things, are now a tourist attraction for Toivakka, based on pop art, the Bible, and Kalevala.

name: Tornion kirkko
description:
Tornio Church, also known as Hedvig Eleonora Church, is a wooden church built in 1684-1686 in the center of Tornio. The builder and designer was Matti Härmä. It is the most magnificent example of the Lutheran church space and Caroline Baroque shaped during the 17th century in Finland, with its fixed interior and paintings. The bell tower is the only remaining representative of the Gothic-style tower type in the country.

The church is the largest of the preserved support pillar churches. The church has a tower that is half-timbered into the western end. The shingle roof is rhombus-patterned. The upper part of the high octagonal tower spire, which served as a sea mark for the town's merchant citizens, was built with round windows in 1694 for King Karl XI's visit. The horizontal weatherboarding and white color of the exterior walls date from the 1870s.

name: Tottijärven kirkko
description: Tottijärvi Church is a wooden church located in Nokia, Finland. The church was completed in 1841 and consecrated on January 1, 1842. It represents the late Empire style. The church was designed by architect J.E. Gustavsson. A separate bell tower, built in 1773, stands in the middle of the cemetery. The church bells date back to the 1770s. The current pulpit comes from the old church. The altarpiece is from 1854, and the organ was built in 1896. The church was thoroughly renovated between 1949–1955. The church has a seating capacity of 380.

name: Tuiran kirkko
description:
Tuira Church is located in the Tuira district of Oulu. It was originally built as a prayer room and consecrated for that purpose on August 25, 1916. The building was designed by Harald Andersin, a county architect of Oulu, and represents National Romanticism architectural style.

In 1966, Oulu implemented a division of parishes, and Tuira was separated into its own parish, at which point the prayer room was consecrated as a church. At the same time, expansion work on the church began, and was designed by architect Mikko Huhtela and completed in 1967. From 1988 to 1992, the church was renovated and the church hall was restored. The renovation work was designed by architects Ulla and Lasse Vahtera. The church hall can accommodate 240 people. The stained glass paintings in Tuira Church, "The Birth of Christ" and "The Ascension of Christ", are by the artist Paavo Leinonen. The simple, unadorned crucifix is made by sculptor and painter Martti Tarvainen.

name: Tuohikotin kirkko
description:
The Tuohikotti Church is a wooden church designed by builder Anton Lehto, located in the village of Tuohikotti, which is now part of Kouvola. It was built with donations from the local prayer house association and support from the congregation, and it was consecrated on October 24, 1926.

The altar painting, "Jesus in Gethsemane", was painted by Arvi Malmivaara. The church's artifacts, textiles and church bells were donated by local sewing societies. The church has seating for 200 people in the main hall and another 50 in the side hall. The side hall has a kitchen. The church has both an organ and an electric piano. The church was renovated in the 2000s, mainly through community volunteer work.

name: Tuomaankirkko
description:
Tuomaankirkko, originally known as Tomas Church, was initially the church for the Swedish-speaking congregation. In 1954, two church halls were completed, one for the Finnish-speaking congregation named Meilahti Church, and one for the Swedish-speaking congregation named Tomas Church. Since 2014, Tomas Church was handed over to Meilahti parish and renamed Tuomaankirkko.

Architect Markus Tavio won the design contest. The church building also features a relief of the Good Samaritan by sculptor Armas Tirronen. The bell tower houses a bell originally intended for the Vyborg Cathedral. The church interior can accommodate 250 people.

name: Turengin kirkko
description:
Turengin kirkko is a church located in Turenki, in the municipality of Janakkala. It belongs to the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland and is part of the Janakkala parish. The church building, along with the adjacent parish building, was designed by architect Keijo Petäjä and inaugurated in November 1965.

The church has undergone significant changes and renovations since its original construction. A major renovation was completed between 2007 and 2010, designed by architect Kari Tuominen and Keijo Kalteva. The church was reopened for Christmas in 2009. The main hall seats about 130 people, with an additional side hall providing space for around 160 people total. The parish hall can accommodate approximately 100 people.

name: Turkansaaren kirkko
description:
Turkansaari Church is located in the Turkansaari Open-Air Museum in the Madekoski district of Oulu. The church dates back to 1694 when it was built as a chapel. For a long time, the church was unused and was dismantled and sold as a warehouse for fishermen.

In the early 1920s, Östen Elfving found the missing church and bought it. In the winter of 1922, the church was moved back to its original location in Turkansaari. Since information about the original interior had not been preserved, Turkansaari Church had to be rebuilt using other similar small churches from the late 17th century as models. The exterior door and hymn board leg came from the dismantled Enontekiö Markkina Church. The pulpit model was borrowed from the old Sodankylä Church.

The church is a popular wedding venue and hosts services in the summer. It can accommodate about 120 people.

name: Turtolan kirkko
description:
Turtolan Church is the second church of the Pello parish, built between 1950 and 1953. It was mainly funded by the support of Lutheran churches in the United States and the Church Board. The stone building replaced a large wooden cross church (1819-1944) that was destroyed in the war. The church was consecrated on August 17, 1953, a day after the consecration of the Pello church.

Located in the village of Turtola, the church has seats for 220 people. The church also displays the chandelier of the old Turtola church, which former Prime Minister Kaarlo Castrén, who was born in the Turtola parsonage, donated with his brothers in memory of their parents in 1932. In front of the church is the Pello war cemetery and a memorial statue. The altar painting of the church has the same theme as the old church, Jesus on the Cross. The church was designed by architect Jalmari Lankinen.

name: Turun linnan kirkko
description:
Turun linna's church, located within Turku Castle, is a Lutheran church originally established in 1706. It was converted from the castle's Great Hall, which Duke John had used as a banqueting hall in the 16th century. The church has been rebuilt to reflect its 18th-century appearance after a fire in 1941.

The church interior includes royal boxes added in 1775 and a Marcussen & Søn organ from 1964. Today, the Turku Museum Centre manages the church, renting it out for religious ceremonies, concerts, and other events. The church can accommodate 240 people and is a popular venue for weddings and baptisms.

name: Turun tuomiokirkko
description:
Turku Cathedral is Finland's national shrine and the main church of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland. It is located in the city of Turku, on the banks of the Aura River. The cathedral was consecrated in 1300 and received its final form in the 15th and 16th centuries.

The cathedral represents several different architectural styles, including Romanesque, Gothic, and Neo-Gothic. Inside the church, there are 90 walled burial chambers. The cathedral has been damaged by fire or other means more than 20 times throughout its history.

The Turku Cathedral Museum, located on the south gallery of the church, takes visitors deep into history, all the way back to the 13th century.

name: Tuuloksen kirkko
description:
Tuulos Church, dedicated to St. Bridget, is one of Finland's smallest medieval gray stone churches. It was likely originally built as a manor church for the Sairiala estate. Construction began in 1478 by Knut Posse, the then-owner of the manor.

The church is estimated to have been completed by 1520, and it received its current appearance in 1950. Next to the church stands a three-tiered, onion-domed bell tower, built by Martti Jaakonpoika in 1780. Inside the church, there is a wooden sculpture of St. Bridget dating back to the 15th century. The church is surrounded by cultivated land, and the Sairiala/Kylänjoki shore meadows and fields.

name: Tuupovaaran kirkko
description:
Tuupovaara Church, located in Joensuu, is a wooden long church with a gable tower, constructed in 1902 according to plans by J. V. Mäkinen. A low, rectangular sacristy protrudes from the choir end of the main building. At the corners of the tower and the main building, there are small hipped-roof projections. The upper part of the tower is polygonal and ends in a high pyramid spire. The church bell dates back to 1901.

The church has high windows and a decorative strip running around the bottom of the eaves. It was renovated in 1930 and 1968 and has seating for 800 people. The church's 13-stop organ was built in 1878 by Jens Zachariassen and donated in 1952 by Julius Ernvall. Veikko Virtanen renovated the organ in 1970. The church's altarpiece, "Resurrection," was painted by Eino J. Härkönen in 1942.

name: Tuusniemen kirkko
description: Tuusniemi Church is located in the center of the Tuusniemi village. The church was built in 1869 after the previous church was destroyed in a fire. It is a rare, vertically planked long church, designed by Ernst Lohrmann in 1864 and built by Mikko Karjalahti in 1869. The church has 820 seats. The altarpiece was painted by pharmacist J. W. E. Petersén, who lived in Tuusniemi in the 1920s. The current 20-voice organ was built in the church in 1990. The bell tower next to the church was built in 1818. During the summer, the church serves as a road church.

name: Tuusulan kirkko
description:
Tuusulan kirkko is a wooden cross church located by Lake Tuusula. It is one of the oldest wooden cross-shaped churches in the Helsinki region, completed in 1734. It's believed that the church was designed by a local peasant, Erik Hannula.

The church has a simple interior, featuring stained glass paintings and an altarpiece painted by Johan Asplund in the 1850s. The churchyard serves as the final resting place for notable figures like Aleksis Kivi and Pekka Halonen. Today, the church remains active throughout the year and is a popular venue for weddings, especially during the summer.

name: Tyrnävän kirkko
description:
Tyrnävä Church is located in the village of Tyrnävä. The wooden church, representing Neo-Gothic style, was designed by architect F. W. Lüchow from Oulu. Construction began in 1873, and the church was consecrated on October 2, 1881.

The church has a western tower and a rectangular main hall with a short, wide transept. It has 750 seats and a floor area of 300 square meters. The previous church on the site was destroyed in an arson attack in 1865. A new bell tower had already been built in 1762 to replace it.

name: Tyrvännön kirkko
description: Tyrvännö Church is located in Hattula. The wooden cross-shaped church was built between 1796 and 1801, officially consecrated in 1803. Matti Åkerblom served as the master builder. The church's interior has a Jugend style from the renovation in 1902. The altarpiece, "Christ in Gethsemane," dates back to 1853. The church bells are older than the church itself, dating from 1704 and 1709, moved from the old Lepaa church. The church has a gray stone fence, a cemetery, and a brick gate building.

name: Tyrvään kirkko
description:
St. Olaf's Church in Tyrvää is a late medieval stone church located in Sastamala, on the shore of Lake Rautavesi. Originally built between 1510 and 1516, it was tragically destroyed by arson in 1997.

The church was rebuilt by volunteers between 1997 and 2003. While the exterior maintains the appearance of the original medieval church, including its shingle roof, the interior was redesigned. The interior was designed by Ulla Rahola, working with the National Board of Antiquities, aiming to recapture the pre-fire ambiance, with influences from the 17th and 18th centuries. The interior features artwork by Kuutti Lavonen and Osmo Rauhala, with Rauhala also creating paintings for the pulpit.

name: Tyrvään Pyhän Olavin kirkko
description:
Tyrvään Pyhän Olavin kirkko, also known as the Old Church of Tyrvää, is a late medieval stone church located in Sastamala, on the shore of Lake Rautavesi. It was built between 1506 and 1516.

The church has a rich history, including a fire in the early 1600s and abandonment in 1855 after a new church was built. In 1997, it was devastated by arson, but was rebuilt between 1997 and 2003. The reconstruction garnered national attention and was largely funded by donations and volunteer work.

The interior features paintings by artists Kuutti Lavonen and Osmo Rauhala. The church is a popular venue for weddings and baptisms and is considered an important cultural site.

name: Täktomin kappeli
description:
Täktomin kappeli is a church building located in the village of Täktom in Hanko, Finland. It was completed in 1920. Originally, it was built as a private Catholic burial chapel by Carl Vilhelm Gylphe for his daughter Lucie Vera, who died at the age of two. In 1936, it was transferred to the ownership of the Hanko Lutheran parish and consecrated as a church later that year.

The chapel was designed by architects Armas Lindgren and Bertel Liljequist. It is a long church made of brick with a tiled roof. The chapel's style incorporates Gothic elements, although the tower hints at Baroque influences. The chapel suffered damage during the Hanko lease period in 1940–1941 and was repaired in 1949. Today, it is a popular venue for weddings and baptisms and can accommodate 60 people.

name: Törnävän kirkko
description:
Törnävä Church, located in Seinäjoki, was the first church in the Seinäjoki parish. Interestingly, it was originally constructed in 1827 by the Russian state as a gunpowder storeroom for the Östermyra gunpowder factory. Later, the parishioners, led by factory director G. A. Wasastjerna, converted it into a church, which was completed and consecrated in August 1864.

The church's architecture is largely Gothic in style, featuring tapering windows and doors, and a highly decorative pulpit and altar. The tower is unique, as it was originally the watchtower of the gunpowder storeroom. In the churchyard, the gate post of the old stone wall holds an offering box made by the blacksmiths of the Östermyra steel factory. The church has a seating capacity of 450 in the hall and 50 in the gallery.

name: Töysän kirkko
description:
Töysä Church, located in Alavus, Finland, is a wooden cross-shaped church. Construction was completed in 1800, although the tower wasn't finished until 1824. Yrjänä Lepistö from Kuortane designed the church.

The church can accommodate around 700 people. The altarpiece, painted by Väinö Hämäläinen in 1908, depicts "Jesus and the sinful woman." The church has undergone several renovations, with a significant one in 1896 and the latest major renovation in 1982. The church also has an organ with 20 sound registers, which was acquired in 1983.

name: Töölön kirkko
description:
Located at the southern end of Topelius Park, Töölö Church is a light pink building representing 1920s classicism. Completed in 1930, its architecture draws inspiration from Italian rural churches and Renaissance architecture. The altar wall features a partial sketch of "Eternal Life," a mural left unfinished due to the artist's death. A wooden crucifix, specially made for Töölö Church in Oberammergau, known for its Easter plays, adorns the altar.

Architect Hilding Ekelund designed the church. The building was originally planned to be a parish building and was officially dedicated as a church when Töölö became its own parish in 1941. Above the entrance, you'll find a concrete relief, "Heavenly Feast" by Gunnar Finne. The foyer showcases Gunnar Forsström's glass paintings and a mural by Paavo Leinonen.

name: Ullavan kirkko
description:
The Ullava Church is located in Kokkola, in the central village of the former municipality of Ullava. Ullava became a chapel parish in 1797 and became completely independent from the parent parish of Kälviä in 1904. Since 2006, it has been a chapel parish belonging to the Kaustinen and Ullava parish. The octagonal support pillar church, chamfered at its ends, was built in 1783.

The Ullava Church and bell tower form a well-preserved ecclesiastical environment of a small Central Ostrobothnian chapel parish formed in the late 1700s. The church has undergone several renovations, including one in 1900 led by Lauri Heikki Kuorikoski, during which three vestibules with saddle roofs and a lantern tower were added. The separate, tall, three-section bell tower stands southwest of the church and was built in 1793.

name: Ulrika Eleonoran kirkko
description: Ulrika Eleonora Church is located in Kristinestad and it's one of the most significant landmarks in the town. It also serves as a popular wedding church during the summer. Representing the oldest building stock in the town, the wooden church showcases coastal architecture, complete with votive ships hanging from the ceiling. The shipbuilding expertise is evident in the curved interior ceiling structure. The churchyard includes an old cemetery where members of prominent town families are buried, as well as the town's war graves. A few services are held annually, with many people choosing Ulrika Eleonora Church as a venue for summer weddings.

name: Ulvilan kirkko
description:
The Ulvila Church, also known as St. Olaf's Church, is a medieval stone church in Ulvila, Finland. Constructed between the 15th and 16th centuries, it stands as one of Finland's most significant and well-preserved medieval gray stone churches. Dedicated to Saint Olaf, it is the only remaining vestige of the medieval town of Ulvila.

Inside, the church features unique arches and pilasters, a rarity among Finnish medieval stone churches. The exterior gable decorations are also among the first of their kind in Finland. The sacristy was completed first in 1495, followed by the nave around 1500, and finally the armory around 1510. Today, the church hosts services, weddings, funerals, and concerts and can accommodate up to 300 people.

name: Ummeljoen kirkko
description:
Ummeljoen Church is located in Kouvola, in the former village of Ummeljoki. The space is used for clubs for all ages, memorial services, baptisms, and family celebrations.

There are seats in rows for 60 people and table seating can be arranged for 40 people. The facilities include a piano and a kitchen with a commercial dishwasher, coffee maker, kettle, microwave, and two refrigerators. There is a steep ramp for disabled access.

Ummeljoen Church was built in 1903. The Young Christian Association built the church themselves through voluntary work. The money for the construction of the village church was obtained from bazaars and donations. The building was handed over to the Anjalankoski parish in 1951.

name: Urjalan kirkko
description:
Urjalan church, located in the village of Laukeela, was built in 1806. It is a cross-shaped church with a western tower. The original plans were made by Martti Tolpo, a church builder from Vihti. The church's current appearance dates back to the 1860s when it was renovated, representing early Neo-Gothic style adapted to wooden construction. The renovation was designed by Carl Albert Edelfelt, an architect from the Hämeenlinna province.

Inside, the church has a barrel-vaulted ceiling. The altarpiece, depicting Christ rising from the grave, was painted by J. Sandberg. The church also features chandeliers donated by local manors. The churchyard includes a family burial area and a war veterans' memorial.

name: Uskelan kirkko
description:
Uskelan Church is a church in Uskela, Salo. It is located on a high hill next to the Salo regional hospital. The current church was completed in 1832, designed by C.L. Engel, a famous architect of his time. The church is a single-nave long church with a sacristy and armory.

The hill where Uskelan Church is located is an old church site. A small stone church, St. Anne's Chapel, was built there around 1440 for the Salo Chapel Parish, which was demolished in 1830 for building materials for the new church. The altar painting depicting the Resurrection of Christ was painted by court painter R.W. Ekman in 1849, and the pictures of the choir window arches by Urho Lehtinen in 1932. The 33-voice pneumatic organ made by Kangasala organ factory dates back to 1936. The church can accommodate about a thousand parishioners.

name: Utajärven kirkko
description:
The Utajärvi Church is a significant wooden church, built in 1762. It represents a style known as a support-pillar church; there are only a few remaining examples of this design in Finland. The church's structure is made of logs, a construction method that allowed for long and sturdy buildings.

Inside, the altar features a painting of Christ's resurrection. The church has approximately 285 seats. The current pipe organ was installed in 1981. The churchyard also contains a war veterans' cemetery, a local history museum, and an old tar boat. The church is located west of the Utajärvi municipal center, near Highway 22.

name: Utran kirkko
description:
Utran kirkko, completed in 1895, is the oldest church building in the Joensuu area. It is a distinctive wooden church that was built during the prosperous times of the Utran sawmill and glass industry. Utran residents initiated the building, and factory owners donated the land, construction wood, and most of the construction costs. The architect is not entirely confirmed, but it's believed to be Thomas Bamford, an English engineer who headed the local sawmill company.

The church is one of only three vertical plank churches in Finland and the only one where the construction method is visible. The church is mainly used in the summer, hosting services, concerts, and weddings. The altar painting is Veikko Lappalainen's "Jesus Blesses Children".

name: Utsjoen kirkko
description:
Utsjoki Church, located in northern Lapland, Finland, is the northernmost church in Finland and the European Union. Designed by Ernst Lohrmann, it was constructed from grey stone between 1850 and 1853. The church has about 230 seats and covers an area of 170 square meters.

The Utsjoki Church, along with the parsonage, old sacristy, and church huts, forms the northern part of the nationally significant Utsjoki River Valley landscape, classified as a national landscape on the shore of Lake Mantojärvi. These restored church huts of various ages make the area a unique historical church environment in Finland. The altar painting, "Resurrection," was painted by Aukusti Koivisto in 1924.

name: Uudenkaarlepyyn kirkko
description:
The church of Uudenkaarlepyy is located in the region of Ostrobothnia. Dedicated to Saint Birgitta, it was inaugurated in 1708, though the pulpit and altar weren't completed until the 1750s. Assessor Elias Brenner designed the church. Daniel Hjulström, a Swedish painter, painted the altarpiece and decorated the vaults of the interior ceilings and the draperies surrounding the windows. The vault features King Fredrik I's monogram amidst clouds and trumpet angels. The church also has one of Finland's oldest organs, built by Anders Teliin in 1768. Next to the church is a bell tower built in 1702.
The wooden church is one of the largest and oldest wooden churches in Finland.

name: Uudenkaupungin vanha kirkko
description:
The Old Church of Uusikaupunki, also known as Nystads gamla kyrka in Swedish, is located in Uusikaupunki, Finland. It was constructed between 1623 and 1629. The church was established after King Gustav II Adolf founded Uusikaupunki in 1617, leading the townspeople to desire their own church. Initially, the long church had a few small windows, a dirt floor, and no intermediate ceiling.

Over time, the townspeople renovated the church. In 1643, a low intermediate ceiling was added, and two church bells were acquired. In 1713, during the Great Northern War, Russian forces used one end of the church as a granary while the other end remained in use for worship. The church has never burned down, and most of its artifacts are from the 17th century.

name: Uukuniemen kirkko
description:
Uukuniemi Church is located in the village of Uukuniemi in the municipality of Parikkala. The wooden cross church was built in 1793 and consecrated in 1797. It is one of three churches belonging to the Lutheran parish of Parikkala.

The altarpiece, depicting Christ on the Cross, was painted by Mikko Kiljander in 1883. The church has 600 seats. The current mechanical organ has 18 stops and dates back to 1982. Near the church, across the road, stands a separate bell tower built in 1853. During the winter season, church services are mainly held at the Uukuniemi parish hall. In the summer, the church hosts services, concerts, and other events.

name: Uuraisten kirkko
description:
Uuraisten kirkko is a wooden cross-shaped church located in Uurainen, Central Finland. It was built in 1905 on the site of the previous church. The church was designed by builder J. Wigren, with architect Yrjö Blomstedt also involved in the construction phase.

Blomstedt's influence is particularly evident in the building's National Romantic details and ornaments. The church is known as the "Church of Open Hearts" because it contains over a thousand heart-shaped wooden carvings. The bell tower was built earlier, in 1882 and designed by architect Alfred Cavén. The most recent renovation of the church was designed by architect Tuija Ilves.

name: Vaajakosken kirkko
description:
Vaajakoski Church is the church of the Vaajakoski parish, designed as a parish hall by architect Armas Lehtinen. It was officially opened on Annunciation Day in March 1954. The church was renovated in the early 1980s. An extension, which doubled the size of the church, was designed by architects Jussi Kantonen and Tuija Ilves in 2001.

The church building is a long church without a tower, built of brick and concrete and rendered in a light color. During the extension, artist Saila Blomkvist's artwork "Tree of Life" was placed in the parish hall. The church received new church textiles as a 50th anniversary gift, designed by textile artist Aino Kajaniemi. For Christmas 2008, the church received a nativity scene carved from wood by artist Kari Kärkkäinen from Juva and a raku work "Escape to Egypt" by artist Ritva-Sofia Lintunen. On the church altar is a cross made by sculptor Juhani Saksa.

name: Vaalan kirkko
description: Vaala Church, located near the center of Vaala, was originally designed by architect Dag Englund as a parish hall and was built in 1961.
