Later, in 1988, it was expanded and renovated based on the plans of architect Matti Leiber, at which time the bell tower was also constructed. The church has a surface area of 346 square meters and can seat 400 people. The altar features a wooden cross. The church's 14-stop organ was manufactured by Kangasala organ factory in 1961. The extension includes a parish hall, pastor's office, facilities for children's and youth work, and offices.

name: Vaalijalan kirkko
description:
Located in Nenonpelto, Pieksämäki, within the Vaalijala competence and support center, Vaalijalan Kirkko primarily serves the center's residents, but welcomes everyone to services, concerts, and events. This steep-roofed church was built in 1958, designed by Aulis Blomstedt.

A notable feature is the altarpiece by Armas Hutri, made of 45,000 pieces of pine. The artwork spans the entire width of the altar, measuring 1.8 meters high and 9 meters long. Virtual tours are available to familiarize people with the church space.

name: Vaasan kirkko
description: Vaasan kirkko (Church of Vaasa) is a red-brick, Neo-Gothic church located in the center of Vaasa, Finland. Designed by Carl Axel Setterberg, the church was inaugurated in 1862, although it was not fully completed until 1869. A tall tower stands on the main entrance side, and the roof is made of light green sheet metal. One of the most famous of the three altarpieces is Albert Edelfelt's "The Adoration of the Shepherds". During the summer, it serves as a road church.

name: Vahdon kirkko
description:
Vahdon Church, located in Vahto, Rusko, is a wooden long church built in 1803. It was designed at the Stockholm Office of the Superintendent. In 1837, the exterior of the church was renovated with the addition of a bell tower on the west end and another vestibule on the south side.

The lower part of the old bell tower is used as a storage area. The church has rectangular windows, a vaulted ceiling, and vaulted balconies above the sacristy. The interior was renovated in 1999, revealing paintings on the gallery edges. The exterior was painted in 2003. The altar painting, depicting the Resurrection, is by Teodor Schalin from 1906.

name: Valkeakosken kirkko
description:
Valkeakoski Church was designed by architect Veikko Larkas and completed in 1969. It was the last of fourteen churches designed by Larkas. The rectangular stone church has low walls and a steep pitched roof. A lower sacristy is connected to the church. The church covers an area of 850 square meters and has seating for 1000 people, including the church hall and gallery.

The entrance end is clad in light tiling and has a high stained-glass window, as does the altar end. Inside, the ceiling beams are exposed. The wooden pitched ceiling rests on them and the wall pilasters, the spaces between the pilasters are entirely windows. The church's 39-stop organ was made by Kangasala organ factory in 1969. The altar painting "Blessing Christ" from 1969 is by Mikko Vuorinen, as are the stained-glass windows. A separate concrete bell tower, 35 meters high, was built at the same time as the church.

The church has been used extensively as a concert venue, and has hosted several Finnish and foreign artists. However, the church has been vacant since 2018 and has caused the Sääksmäki parish a total of 400,000 euros in costs over five years. In March 2018, the Kirkkovaltuusto decided to demolish the church and sell the church site.

name: Valkeakosken kappelikirkko
description:
The Valkeakoski Chapel Church, designed by architect Pekka Saarema, was built in 1958 in connection with the Valkeakoski cemetery. The rectangular church has no tower. The church's floor area is 450 square meters and it has 200 seats.

The side walls and roof of the church merge together. The gables are smooth triangular surfaces with high, stepped glass mosaic windows. The main entrance to the church is in a building section protruding from one side of the main body. The 12-stop organ was made by Kangasala organ factory in 1960, and the facade of the organ was designed by Pekka Saarema. The glass mosaics of the altar are made by artist Mikko Vuorinen. The church was renovated in 2011.

name: Valkealan kirkko
description: Valkealan kirkko is located in Kouvola. The church was designed by Armas Lindgren and Bertel Liljeqvist, and it was inaugurated in 1927. It is the fourth church to stand on the same site. The first church was built in 1631. The church that stands today is a plastered brick church with a tower, representing the long church style. Inside the church, there are decorative paintings by Antti Salmenlinna depicting biblical themes, and a Calvary group made by Gunnar Finne on the choir beam. The altar painting is "Descent from the Cross" by A. G. Thitz, dating back to 1819. The wooden bell tower next to the church was completed in 1782.

name: Valtimon kirkko
description:
The Valtimo Church is a wooden cross-shaped church with a gable tower, completed in 1901. It is located on a ridge by the small Lake Valtimo. The church represents the Neo-Gothic style. The tower above the entrance has three floors and four gables. The windows are in two zones.

The interior reflects the renovation of the 1930s, including wooden gallery sculptures and the current altarpiece, "The Crucified," painted by Eino J. Härkönen. The church has a total of 34 different images and reliefs. The reliefs depicting the evangelists are made by J.O. Raja-aho, and other images, except for the altarpiece, are by Urho Lehtinen. The church has a 32-stop pneumatic organ built by Aarne Wegelius and the Kangasala organ factory.

name: Vampulan kirkko
description: Vampula Church, located in the former municipality of Vampula, which is now part of Huittinen, is a wooden church constructed in 1894. It was designed by county architect F.H. Rancken and represents a 19th-century ornate nickel style. The church tower reaches a height of approximately 30 meters. It is considered a beautiful building, inside and out, and is a notable landmark in the area. In 1590, four householders built a small log church at their own expense. This first sanctuary is used as a motif for the municipality's coat of arms, which depicts a cross and four nails as a metaphor for the builders.

name: Vanajan kirkko
description:
Vanajan Church, located in Hämeenlinna, is a grey stone church dating back to the 15th century. It is one of the smallest medieval churches in Finland. Distinctive features include large cornerstones and brick-built gables. A unique aspect is the external pulpit on the west end, once used to preach to those gathered on the church grounds.

Inside, the single-nave church has ring-vaulted ceilings. The church's art treasures include a triptych altarpiece from Antwerp dating to the early 16th century. The church also features a baroque-style organ built in 1988. The churchyard includes a family grave chapel and a stone-built belfry designed by Josef Stenbäck.

name: Vanha kirkko
description:
The Old Church of Helsinki, completed in 1826, is the oldest church in the central part of the city. Designed by Carl Ludvig Engel, it was originally intended as a temporary structure while the Helsinki Cathedral was under construction.

The church is located in the Old Church Park, which served as a cemetery before the church was built. The park is also known as "Plague Park" because victims of the 1710 plague were buried there.

Featuring a neoclassical style, the wooden church has simple Doric pillars, gables, and a delicate bell tower. The interior is decorated in white and pastel colors. The church is a popular venue for weddings and other family events, and it belongs to the Helsinki Cathedral Parish.

name: Vantaan Pyhän Laurin kirkko
description: The Church of St. Lawrence in Vantaa is the oldest building in Vantaa and the entire Greater Helsinki area, dating back to around 1450. It serves as the main church for the Tikkurila Parish. The church features an external bell tower next to the front of the building, which was rebuilt in a Gothic Revival style after being destroyed in 1893. The bell tower includes two bells and a flèche topped with a cockerel weather vane. The Church is one of the most popular wedding churches in Finland. The church is located at the end of Vantaa's old church road in the village of Helsingin pitäjän kirkonkylä.

name: Varissuon kirkko
description: Varissuon kirkko is a church building located in Turku, Finland, belonging to the Turku Katariinanseurakunta parish. The parish center was completed in 1981, and the bell tower in 1997. The church was consecrated in 1997 by Archbishop John Vikström. It was designed by Arkkitehtitoimisto Laiho, Pulkkinen & Raunio. The church is known for its modern architecture and red brick exterior, blending into the surrounding urban landscape of Varissuo. Today, Varissuon kirkko is one of the two churches of the Turku Katariinanseurakunta, the other being St. Catherine's Church. The church is also known as a multicultural and diverse community center.

name: Varkauden pääkirkko
description:
Varkaus Main Church was designed by architect Martti Paalanen and completed in 1939. It is the main church of the Varkaus parish. The church has 1,100 seats. The nave is 17 meters high and 45 meters long, narrowing towards the chancel.

A significant work of art is the altarpiece "Thy Kingdom Come," painted by Professor Lennart Segerstråle in 1953-54. Its area is 240 square meters, and it is considered the largest altar fresco in the Nordic countries. The church tower is 35 meters high. The church also has an octagonal stained glass painting, "Road to Emmaus" designed by Paalanen and made by Y. Forsström. The church houses a rare organ of romantic style with 50 registers and 4 transitional registers. The organ was made by Kangasala Organ Factory.

name: Varpaisjärven kirkko
description:
The Varpaisjärvi Church, designed by Josef Stenbäck, is located in the village of Varpaisjärvi in Lapinlahti. Completed in 1904, the church is constructed of grey granite and features brick vaults.

It is a tower-bearing, cross-shaped church with an asymmetrical floor plan, reflecting national romanticism in its design and the use of local materials. The church also has round, Jugend-style semicircular windows. Inside, there is an organ loft at the rear of the church hall. The organ, built in 1936, has 19+3 stops. The church has 1,100 seats and an area of 390 square meters. The Varpaisjärvi Church is the second largest stone church designed by Josef Stenbäck in Finland.

name: Vartiokylän kirkko
description:
Vartiokylä Church, completed in 1958, is located in the middle of the Vartioharju residential area in Helsinki. Designed by architect Pekka Laurila, it is one of Finland's oldest multi-purpose churches. Upon completion, it was a sight that people came to see from further away as well.

The church includes a church hall, kitchen, parish hall, gymnasium, and club and meeting facilities. The altar crucifix is made by Gunnar Uotila, and the painting "Under the Protecting Sky" is by Jarmo Mäkilä. The church's 16-voice organ was made by Gemlich in East Germany. The church was renovated in 1999–2000, when the altar was detached from the wall and the furniture was lightened.

name: Vaskion kirkko
description:
Vaskio Church, located in Halikko, Salo, is a unique church in Finland, owned by a private support association. A prayer house association was founded in 1906, and they built a new prayer house next to Kuttila public school in 1908. In the late 1920s, there was a project to make Vaskio an independent parish, so the prayer house was renovated into a church, and land was acquired for a cemetery. However, the independence project failed, and the prayer house remained as it was. A bell tower was built next to the church in 1967.
The cemetery was inaugurated in the autumn of 1958. The construction of the cemetery gave rise to the idea of consecrating the prayer house as a church. After renovations, Vaskio Church was consecrated on Marian Day in 1959. At the same time, the prayer house association changed its name to the Vaskio Church Support Association.

name: Vehkajärven kirkko
description:
Vehkajärvi Church is a small, wooden, long church without a tower, located in the village of Vehkajärvi in Kangasala. It was built in 1841 according to drawings by local carpenter Benjamin Hellén. The church is maintained by the Vehkajärvi Prayer Room Association, and the churchyard has Finland's first war hero cemetery.

The church has about 150 seats. The two-part altarpiece, Crucified and Transfiguration of Jesus, was painted by Otto Berggren. The five-voice organ was manufactured by Kangasala organ factory in 1936. The church was renovated in 1931, when it was rededicated. The wooden, separate bell tower dates from the 1840s. Services are held there once a month.

name: Vehmaan kirkko
description:
Vehmaa Church, also known as St. Margaret's Church, is a medieval stone church located in Vehmaa, Finland. It was built between 1425 and 1440. The church is dedicated to St. Margaret, who is also featured on the coat of arms of Vehmaa. The church's bell tower, designed by the Finnish Office of the Intendant, dates back to the 1820s.

The church has been well-preserved in its medieval state, with only a few additions made in later times, such as the support pillars from the 18th century. The interior features a Baroque pulpit from the 17th century. The first organ was built in 1889, with the current one, featuring 22 stops, made in 1957. The churchyard includes burial chapels.

name: Vehmersalmen kirkko
description: The Vehmersalmi Church, located in Vehmersalmi, Kuopio, was designed by Josef Stenbäck and completed in 1919. It's a plastered brick church featuring a tall steeple and a high pitched roof. The church can accommodate 600 people. The altar is adorned with August Ripatti's painting "Jesus in Gethsemane." Stylistically, it represents late Art Nouveau, with an asymmetrical floor plan reflecting national romanticism. Details such as brick decorations showcase historicism. During the summer, the church serves as a Road and Waterway Church.

name: Veitsiluodon kirkko
description:
Veitsiluoto Church, located in Kemi, is a Lutheran church designed by architect Veikko Larkas and completed in 1957. This church represents a simple architectural style, characterized by its lack of a tower and side aisles. Adjacent to the main church area is an additional wing that houses functional spaces.

Inside, the church features an 18-stop organ built in 1958 by Kangasala organ factory. A notable artwork within the church hall is a wood relief titled "Pilgrims," created in 1967 by sculptor Taisto Martiskainen. The church's cross is a St. Peter's cross. The building serves not only as a place of worship but also as a community center. However, recent reports indicate it has been out of use due to issues with the sewage system, requiring complete repair.

name: Velkuan kirkko
description:
Velkua Church, also known as St. Henry's Church, is a wooden long church dating back to 1793. It is located on the island of Palva, in the former municipality of Velkua, now part of Naantali. The church is dedicated to St. Henry and is the only church in Velkua's history.

The church received new bells in 1813, as the previous ones had been hidden or looted by the Russians. One of the bells later broke and was replaced in 1880. At the turn of the 20th century, a major renovation was carried out, which included building an organ loft and paneling the log walls. The Finnish Heritage Agency demanded the removal of the organ loft, which was done in 1964. In 1982, the church was electrified, and the wood-burning stove could be removed.

The Velkua church landscape, which includes Velkua Church and Velkua village, has been defined as a nationally significant built cultural environment.

name: Vesannon kirkko
description:
Vesannon Church is a wooden cross church located in Vesanto, Finland. It was designed by county architect Carl Ziegler and built between 1856 and 1857.

The church has a symmetrical design and a tower at the end. The tower bells date back to 1857 and 1907. The center of the church is emphasized by a polygonal attic with a cone-shaped roof. The sacristy protrudes from the end of the choir, and the arms have pediments. The windows are straight-topped. The interior ceilings of the arms are flat wooden ceilings, and in the center is a wooden dome supported by columns.

The altar painting, "Calling Jesus," is Russian. A soldier found it discarded in 1941 and brought it to the church. Near the church fence is a stone sculpture symbolizing the development of a mustard seed into a large tree. The church was renovated in 1905, 1922, 1952, 1995 and 2005–2006. The church has a surface area of 556 square meters and has seating for 650 people.

name: Vesilahden kirkko
description:
The Vesilahti Church is a yellow wooden church built in 1802. It is located along the old road, Rautialantie, that runs through the village of Vesilahti. The Klaus Kurki road that crosses Vesilahti passes by the church.

Inside, the church has space for around 900 people. During the summer, it is open on weekdays from 9 AM to 3 PM, and at other times by appointment. Services are held on Sundays and holidays at 10 AM. The church is also used for weddings, funerals, memorial services, and concerts.

The Vesilahti parish is over 650 years old. The church has medieval artifacts and metal crosses.

name: Vetelin kirkko
description: Veteli Church is located on the other side of the Perhonjoki river from the Veteli town center, at the northern end of the idyllic Torppa village road. The current church, the third in order, was built by Erkki Kuorikoski in 1843, and the bell tower by Jaakko Kuorikoski in 1859. The altar painting was painted by Johan Backman in 1751 for the previous church. The church is a central church with equal arms, designed by the Intendent Office. Above the attic of the Empire Church rises a dome ending in a lantern. At the ends of the wings, there are pediments, and the windows with small panes are flat-topped. The churchyard is surrounded by a stone fence. The church's 27-stop pneumatic main organ was built by Kangasala Organ Factory in 1939.

name: Vetokannaksen kirkko
description:
Vetokannaksen kirkko, located in Vetokannas, Vaasa, was built in 1961. Gösta Bergman designed this church, which resembles a traditional Finnish "kota" or Lappish hut, but without a tower. Vasa Kyrkliga Stiftelsen owns the church, and it is leased to the Vetokannaksen kirkon ystävät association.

The church's architecture includes a low sacristy extending from the choir corner and a residential wing and sports hall on the opposite end. The entrance is through the residential wing. The triangular ends of the main building reach the ground, as do the roof's support structures. The church is 305 square meters and has seating for 160 people. The 10-stop organ was made in 1969 by Hans Heinrich, and the altar features a cross.

name: Viekijärven kirkko
description:
Viekijärvi Church, located in the village of Viekijärvi in Lieksa, was completed in 1911. The wooden church was designed by builder A.E. Ollilainen, who based his design on the Kurkijoki Church by A.F. Sjöström.

The church has almost 1000 seats. This Gothic-style building is 40 meters long and 25 meters wide. The church tower reaches a height of 40 meters. The bell tower has two steel bells cast in Bochum in 1910.

A special feature is the original Friis brothers' ovens, which were used to heat the church. In 1972, the heating was electrified. The altarpiece, painted in 1945, depicts Jesus on the cross. The church's organ was designed by J. Pohjanmies and built by Kangasala organ factory.

name: Vieremän kirkko
description:
Vieremä Church, completed in 1919 and designed by architect Ilmari Launis, is located in Vieremä, North Savonia. The wooden church has 860 seats. A renovated birch alley leads to the church, which stands on a hill.

The church building is a long church with a gable roof, with a lower transept on one side and a bell tower at the end. In the lower part of the transept is a parish hall and next to it a sacristy, the upper floor is the gallery of the church hall. The church bells are from 1919. The altar wall is dominated by a Rosetti window with crosses and symbols depicting the holy trinity.

name: Vihannin kirkko
description:
The Vihanti Church, officially the Sofia Magdalena Church, is located in Vihanti, Raahe. The current church was built in 1784, during the reign of King Gustav III, and named after his wife, Sofia Magdalena. It was designed by Simon Silvén from Metsäkylä, Kalajoki.

Originally, the church had a shingle roof, which was replaced with a shingle roof in 1882 and a sheet metal roof in 1909. A thorough renovation was carried out from 1958 to 1961, which included renewing the foundations, installing thermal insulation and vertical boarding on the exterior walls, and installing new pews and a heating system. The altar painting and pulpit were also restored. The most recent repair and painting work was done in 1983–1984, according to plans by architect Matti Leiber, restoring the church and bell tower to their original red color. The interior was also updated, and the lighting was completely renewed. The bell tower, representing late Renaissance style, dates back to the first church in 1752.

name: Vihdin kirkko
description:
Vihdin Church, designed by Antti Piimänen, was completed in 1772. The church has experienced several misfortunes, including being struck by lightning in 1818, which destroyed almost everything flammable, including the original organ and altarpiece. It was rebuilt according to designs by Carlo Bassi and reopened in 1822. Lightning struck again in 1846, causing similar damage, and the church was repaired and reopened in 1848.

A thorough renovation took place in 1928-29 under architect K.S. Kallio, giving it a more 1920s style. The wooden vaulted ceiling dates from this renovation, as do the ceiling paintings in the choir and the paintings of historical figures on the front of the organ loft by Paavo Leinonen and Antti Salmenlinna. The church has a unique cross shape with the tower connected to the main body.

name: Viikin kirkko
description:
Viikin kirkko, consecrated in 2005, is a modern wooden church located in the Viikki district of Helsinki. Designed by architect Samuli Miettinen from JKMM Architects, it exemplifies contemporary Finnish wood architecture, favoring domestic materials in its construction.

The church features diverse spaces for modern parish life, including a church hall and smaller meeting rooms for youth and children. The main hall can accommodate around 200 people, expandable to 400 by incorporating an adjacent hall. The exterior is clad in aspen shingles, and the interior showcases exposed wooden beams, creating a warm, inviting atmosphere reminiscent of Finnish forests. The church integrates sustainable materials and construction methods, minimizing its environmental footprint.

name: Viinijärven kirkko
description:
Viinijärvi Church, designed by architect Veikko Larkas, was constructed in 1953 using brick and wood. It's a long church without a tower, located in Viinijärvi, Liperi. A separate bell tower was built in 1960, followed by a parish hall wing in 1965.

The church has a rectangular shape, low walls, and a steep gable roof, representing a popular 1950s architectural style reminiscent of medieval stone churches. The church spans 250 square meters and provides seating for 350 people. The 13-stop organ was manufactured by Urkurakentamo Tuomi in 1974. The altarpiece was painted by Ida Silfverberg and originally belonged to the Pälkjärvi Church.

name: Viinikan kirkko
description:
Viinikka Church, consecrated on May 29, 1932, is located in the Viinikka district of Tampere. Designed by Yrjö Waskinen, its 50-meter tower is a recognizable landmark. Bishop Jaakko Gummerus called it a "weekday church" because it was the first Finnish church building to combine a church hall, youth club facilities, and a parsonage under one roof. The completion of this church is considered the beginning of church youth work.

The church's decorations reflect the style of the 1930s. The evangelists with their symbols are painted on the ceiling by the decorative painters Eino Kauria and Eino Rapp. The floor features stone mosaic squares depicting animal figures, flaming hearts, and ancient decorative motifs, including swastikas. In 2006, Viinikka Church was protected, and according to the National Board of Antiquities, it is one of the first examples of a solution where parish work spaces, the parsonage, and the church form a unified whole.

name: Viitasaaren kirkko
description: Viitasaari Church is a Lutheran church located in Viitasaari, Finland. The church has approximately 550 seats. The church is open to visitors during the summer months as one of the road churches, between June 24th and August 2nd. During this time a guide is present to help. In the front part of the church there is space reserved for wheelchairs. The church is owned and operated by the Viitasaari parish.

name: Viljakkalan kirkko
description: The Viljakkala Church is located in Ylöjärvi. It was designed by C.L. Engel and built between 1840 and 1842. The interior was renovated and restored in 1989, when the organ was also replaced. The exterior was repainted in 1993. The church is known for its good acoustics. The church has a church museum that is open by appointment. The modestly articulated church is one of the few wooden, early 19th-century empire-style long churches.

name: Vilppulan kirkko
description:
Vilppula Church, completed in 1900, is a wooden long church with a western tower, designed by architect Georg Schreck. The church combines Gothic and Art Nouveau styles. Originally, the pulpit was located in the middle of the altar wall, accessible directly from the sacristy.

A renovation in 1969 moved the pulpit to the side of the choir, and Pekka Halonen's altarpiece, depicting Christ on a mountain road, was placed on the altar wall in its original location. The altarpiece had been in the church since 1907. The church is located near the Vilppula cemetery, which was established in 1894.

name: Virolahden kirkko
description:
Virolahden Kirkko, located in Virolahti, is a wooden cross-shaped church. It was built between 1765 and 1768 under the direction of Tuomas Ragwaldinpoika Suikkanen, a well-known church builder from Ruokolahti. The churchyard features a medieval stone sacristy.

The design includes cross arms that narrow towards the ends. Inside, the altar is adorned with Oskar Paatela's painting from 1914 depicting Christ's burial. A notable decorative element is the hourglass motif carved in wood on the altar, balconies, and pews. A church ship, donated by the Pitkäpaasi Society, hangs from the ceiling. The current church bells are designed by architect Veli Klami and were built in 1958.

name: Virtain kirkko
description: The Virrat Church is a wooden cross-shaped church located in Virrat. It was built between 1772 and 1774 by the renowned church builder Antti Hakola. The bell tower, connected to the church, was completed a couple of years later in 1776. The church has been renovated several times over the years, both inside and out. The interior was thoroughly renovated in 1884 according to the plans of architect Gustav Kuorikoski. The oldest of the church's three bells dates back to 1657. The altarpiece was painted by Aleksandra Såltin in 1897 and depicts Jesus appearing to Mary Magdalene on Easter.

name: Virtasalmen kirkko
description:
The Virtasalmi Church is located in Virtasalmi, Pieksämäki. The current church was built in 1978, after the previous church, built in 1876, was destroyed in a fire in 1976. Architect Olavi Reima designed the church.

The church incorporates local materials, most notably Ankele dolomite limestone in its walls, floor, altar, and pulpit. The dolomite's colors come from iron, chrome, and magnesium impurities. The roof is made of wood shingles. North of the church, the foundation stones and a fountain mark the site of the old church's altar. The church has an 18-stop organ built by Hans Heinrich, and the bells were cast by Koninklijke Eijsbouts Klokkengierij in the Netherlands.

name: Virttaan kirkko
description: The Virttaa Church, located in Virttaa, Alastaro, was completed in 1845. The church was designed by Carl Vettervik and was mainly built through the communal work of the villagers. The villagers also donated items to the church, such as communion cups, chandeliers, and candlesticks. The cross-shaped church has approximately 250 seats. Originally the church was red. The graveyard surrounding the church was established in 1827 on land donated by Tuomola. The altar painting was painted by Jonas Bergman and was previously located in the old Loimaa church. The pulpit, built in 1782, was also purchased from Loimaa.

name: Voikkaan kirkko
description:
Voikkaa Church is a wooden church located in the Voikkaa district of Kouvola. Originally built as a prayer room in 1925 based on Volmari Forsberg's designs, it was converted into a church in 1961 according to Veikko Larkas's plans.

The church is a stylish and bright wooden structure where regular services and other church events are held. In the church's wing, there are facilities for children's and adults' clubs, as well as a youth center used in cooperation with the city's youth services. The church hall seats 430 people, and table seating can be arranged for up to 100 people if needed. The separate bell tower was completed in 1959.

name: Voikosken kirkko
description: Voikosken kirkko is a wooden church located in the village of Voikoski, near the border of Kouvola and Mäntyharju. The church is part of the Kouvolan seurakuntayhtymä (Kouvola Parish Union). Services and other events are held in the church a few times a year, mainly during the summer. In Valkeala, villages were incorporated in 1917 to form the Kuusankoski parish. Kouvola became a separate parish in 1921. There are five churches in the parish: the main church in Valkeala, the church in Tuohikotti, and the churches in Vuohijärvi, Tirva, and Voikoski.

name: Vuokatin kirkko
description: Vuokatin kirkko is located in Vuokatti, Sotkamo. It was completed in 1985 as a multi-purpose building and consecrated as a church in 1990. The building was designed by Arkton-Suunnitteluryhmä Oy from Oulu. In addition to the church hall, the premises include a club room, kitchen facilities and an office. The interior design features mainly white-painted wood and red brick. The church also has an organ built originally in 1976, that was moved to Vuokatti church in 2005. Services are held every other Sunday at 12:00, and devotional moments during holidays. The premises are also suitable for family celebrations.

name: Vuokin kirkko
description:
Vuokin kirkko is a church located in Vuokki, Suomussalmi. It is a wooden, single-nave long church without a tower, designed by Arkkitehtuuritoimisto Lappi-Seppälä and Martas Oy and was consecrated in 1954.

A separate wooden bell tower, open at the bottom and supported by four pillars, was built in 1966. The church property includes the church hall, a parish hall with a kitchen, the bell tower, and a former deaconess's residence. The parish hall, built later, can accommodate 60 people and has a well-equipped kitchen. The church itself has 100 seats. The church underwent renovations in 1974.

name: Vuolijoen kirkko
description:
Vuolijoen kirkko is the only grey stone church in Kainuu, located in Vuolijoki, Kajaani. It was built between 1905 and 1906 by architect Josef Stenbäck, who also painted the altarpiece with his wife, a replica of Edvard Gebhard's "The Last Supper."

The church represents National Romanticism and Art Nouveau styles. It can accommodate approximately 400 people and has a 13-stop organ made by Kangasala organ factory in 1965. The church was consecrated on January 1, 1907, as the Church of the Coming of Christ. The stones for the church were sourced from Honkamäki and nearby fields. The windows feature an onion dome design, symbolizing the flame of the Holy Spirit.

name: Vuosaaren kirkko
description:
Vuosaari Church, completed in 1980, is situated on a wooded knoll on Satamasaarentie road. Large windows facing west bring nature and the changing seasons into the church hall. Following medieval tradition, the gospel can also be "read" through images: a concrete relief covering the altar wall depicts the stages of Jesus' life.

The church also includes the Marielund Chapel, which was opened in 2006. The church houses the parish office, a parish hall, work, meeting and club rooms, and a children's church called Pikku Majakka (Little Lighthouse). The church hall seats 300 people. The church and the Marielund chapel were designed by architects Pirkko and Arvi Ilonen.

name: Vuosaaren Merimieskirkko
description:
The Vuosaari Seafarers' Church is located in the Vuosaari harbor in Helsinki, serving primarily seafarers. It shares a building with the Seafarers' Service Office.

The church aims to promote the well-being of seafarers. The location is near the Gate House and Hansa Terminal, providing easy access for those working on ships. ARK-house architects Oy designed the Vuosaari Seafarers' Center building. The Seamen's Mission has several locations in Finnish ports, and welcomes visitors from over 30 countries every year.

name: Vårdön kirkko
description: Vårdö Church, dedicated to St. Matthias, is a stone church located along the old post road. Its history clearly dates back to the Middle Ages. The chapel has somewhat unusual proportions, featuring a narrow tower with a disproportionately large roof. In 1804, it was decided to rebuild the church tower in stone according to drawings by Tempelmann, but something went wrong during the construction, resulting in the asymmetrical appearance. The parish considered further alterations too expensive. The church was built in the 15th century. Opposite the church is the Vårdö prayer room built in 1915.

name: Vähänkyrön kirkko
description:
The Vähänkyrö Church, located in Vaasa, Finland, is a symmetrical cross-shaped church built in 1803 by David Olander. The drawings were designed by Olof Tempelman in 1786. A notable feature is the four-sided tower with its lantern, which was added in a 1937 renovation, deviating from the original plans.

The neoclassical church bears resemblance to the Alatornio Church. Inside, the church has a wooden vaulted ceiling, while the exterior is clad with copper roofing. The round-arched windows are arranged in groups of three, topped with shallow pediments, and the masonry imitates rustication. Inside the church is a 20-voice organ, made in 1962.

name: Väinölän kirkko
description:
Väinölä Church is located in the Väinölä district of Pori. It was completed in 1956 and designed by architect Keijo Valli. Originally built as a parish hall, it doesn't have official church status.

The church has been renovated twice, in 1985 and 2019. The latest renovation included new technology, surface structures, an elevator, and redesigned spaces. The church features a church hall for 160 people and a parish hall for 64.

Services are held every Sunday at 4 PM in cooperation with the Finnish Lutheran Evangelical Association. The church hosts various parish activities, including clubs, circles, and choirs. It also provides space for a deaconry worker's appointment-based reception and has facilities for youth in the basement. Additionally, there is an apartment for short-term emergency accommodation.

name: Värtsilän kirkko
description:
Värtsilä Church is located in Värtsilä, Tohmajärvi. It's a wooden long church without a tower, designed by architect Veikko Larkas and built in 1950. The church was constructed to replace the old Värtsilä Church, which was left on the Soviet side after territorial cessions. Donations from both domestic and foreign sources made the construction of the church possible.

The church occasionally hosts services and other activities. The church hall is no longer in winter use; instead, the parish hall connected to the church is used. The church has undergone renovations in recent years, such as exterior painting. The church's 12+2 stop organ was made by Kangasala organ factory in 1952. The altarpiece, "The Crucified," was painted by an unknown Russian artist and brought from the former Värtsilä Church.

name: Västanfjärdin kirkko
description:
Västanfjärd Church, located in the village of Västanfjärd, Söderlänning municipality, is a notable wooden church dating back to 1760. It represents a significant example of church building during that era. The church's design incorporates a cruciform plan and features a relatively short, three-story bell tower.

Inside, the pulpit and altar are combined, a design choice that reflects the architectural trends of the time. The altarpiece, painted by Robert Wilhelm Ekman in 1867, adds artistic value to the church's interior. Carl Fredrik Blomstedt renovated the church in 1888, contributing to its preservation. Västanfjärd Church stands as a testament to the region's history and architectural heritage.

name: Västanfjärdin vanha kirkko
description:
The old church of Västanfjärd is dedicated to Saint James. It's located in the southern part of Kemiönsaari. The red wooden church sits on a slope at the end of a narrow bay.

The church has had at least two predecessors. The current church was built between 1759 and 1760 by Isak Olin, a master builder from Turku. It's an octagonal building with a simple interior. A bell tower was erected next to the church in 1763. In the 1990s, the church and bell tower received new roofs and were painted with red earth paint. The church is currently closed for renovations during the summer of 2025.

name: Väärämäen kyläkirkko
description:
Väärämäki village church is located in Kitee, in the former municipality of Kesälahti. It's a unique church, assembled from four military barracks and moved to its current location near the Väärämäki cemetery in 1955. The barracks served as the main church of the parish from 1943 to 1950, after the original church was destroyed in bombing during the Continuation War. The structure of the barracks could not be altered significantly, but the windows were allowed to be enlarged.

The church has approximately 150 seats. The altar painting, "Ascension of Jesus," is by Alexandra Såltin and was brought from the Sakkola church, with the same theme as the destroyed church's altar painting. Services are held there about once a month.

name: Vöyrin puukirkko
description:
Vöyri wooden church is the oldest wooden church still in use in Finland. It is located in the municipality of Vöyri in Ostrobothnia. The church was originally built in 1626 as a single-nave church with pillars. In 1777, it was expanded into a cruciform church.

The most famous work of art in the church is a crucifix, which was carved by an unknown artist probably in Lübeck around 1375–1400. The oldest objects in the church include an altarpiece made in Lübeck in the late 15th century, likely brought as spoils of war from Germany in the 18th century. Under the northern wing of the wooden church are the ruins of a medieval stone sacristy, discovered in excavations in 1958.

name: Ykspihlajan kirkko
description:
Ykspihlajan Church is located in Ykspihlaja, Kokkola. The church was designed by architect Aarne Nuortila and was consecrated in 1968. The red brick church is the second largest church in old Kokkola.

The church is used by the Finnish congregation of Kokkola. During the renovation of Kokkola Church, services of the congregation are held in Ykspihlaja Church. Otherwise, services are held about once a month. In addition, various spiritual events are organized in the church. The church has a church hall and a congregation hall for about 80 people, club rooms and apartments.
The church also has a 15-stop organ built by Kangasala organ factory.

name: Ylihärmän kirkko
description: The Ylihärmä Church is a wooden, 24-sided cruciform church located in Ylihärmä, Kauhava. It belongs to the Kauhava parish. A small, onion-domed bell tower rises from the center of its shingle roof. The construction of the church began in 1785 without an official building permit to save time. The building permit was granted in 1786 for the half-finished church, which was already 14 cubits high. The church was completed in 1787, designed and built by Kaapo Hakola. A separate neo-Gothic bell tower was built in 1828, designed by C.L. Engel. The church floor was renovated in 2002, and the church was completely renovated in 2013–2014. The church is surrounded by an old war cemetery designed by J.S. Sirén. The old vicarage and parish magazine are also located near the church.

name: Yli-Iin kirkko
description: Yli-Ii Church, located in Yli-Ii, Oulu, was completed in 1932. The church was designed by architect Yrjö Sadeniemi. The wooden church represents the Neoclassical style and features a gable tower. Inside the church, the altarpiece, depicting the crucified Christ, was painted by Aukusti Koivisto from Oulu and forms the center of a triptych. Stained glass paintings, titled "Lupaus" (Promise) and "Kaipaus" (Longing), adorn the altar windows. These were created by Veijo Muroke and portray biblical themes set in the Yli-Ii landscape. The church has a 12-stop organ that was built in 1984. A war memorial is located near the church.

name: Ylikiimingin kirkko
description:
Ylikiiminki Church is a wooden cross-shaped church, likely completed in 1786 and designed by Jacob Rijf, a master builder from Pietarsaari. It seats 550 people. The church is considered one of the most significant churches in the Oulu region.

The church represents neoclassical style. A distinctive feature is the star atop its tower instead of a traditional cross or rooster. Inside, the altar features a painting of the crucified Christ by Gustav Holmqvist, who also created the pulpit. The church has undergone several renovations, with a major restoration completed in 1986 to return it to its original appearance. The original coloring of the interior was restored during conservation work in the 1980s, when the shingle roof was also renewed.

name: Ylimarkun kirkko
description:
The Ylimarkku Church, known as Övermarks kyrka in Swedish, is located in Ylimarkku, Närpiö. It's a wooden, cruciform church with chamfered corners, built between 1875 and 1878. Theodor Granstedt designed the church. The crossing of the church features a four-sided lantern built upon a prism-shaped cone.

Inside, a panel ceiling is supported by wooden pillars. The church has been renovated several times. The separate, wooden Neo-Gothic bell tower was constructed in 1876, housing bells from 1771, 1884 and 1897. The church has a seating capacity of 1200 people. The altar painting, depicting Golgata, was painted by Axel Haartman in 1933. Initially, the exterior walls were yellow, but in 1967, architect Krister Korpela changed the coloring to two shades of violet with white corner boards and grey-blue decorations.

name: Yliskylän kirkko
description: Yliskylä Church is located in Salo, specifically in Yliskylä, Perniö. The wooden church has a simple elongated shape covered by a steep roof. The sacristy and armory, narrower and lower than the main body of the church, are connected to the main building. The choir windows feature stained glass designed by Elsi Borg in 1926. A separate three-part bell tower was erected between 1778 and 1780. The churchyard is surrounded by a gray stone fence, and an old wooden bridge crosses the Perniö River near the church. The current church is the third to stand on the site. It was built between 1753 and 1756 by Johan Jacob Kijk, owner of the Teijo ironworks.

name: Ylistaron kirkko
description:
Ylistaro Church, located in Seinäjoki, is the third church built for the parish. Completed in 1850 and consecrated in 1852, it stands as one of the first examples of early Gothic Revival architecture in Finland. Designed by state architect E. Lohrman, the stone and brick construction boasts a 52-meter tower.

Inside, the vaulted church features a large arch window above the altarpiece by Adolf von Becker, depicting the Transfiguration of Christ. Galleries are located on two levels on both sides, providing a seating capacity of 2,500 after renovations in the 1970s. Known locally as "Komia kirkko" due to its impressive size, it is the third largest church in Finland.

name: Ylitornion kirkko
description:
Ylitornio Church was built in 1940. The Winter War, which started before the church was completed, slowed down the construction work. As men went to the front, most of the construction work was left to women. For this reason, the church is called the Women's Church.

The church was designed by architect G.A. Wahlroos, and Kustaa Räihä was the master builder. There are 550 seats in the church. The church was consecrated on July 14, 1940. The bell tower dates back to the old church, built in 1819, and is probably the oldest building in Ylitornio. The altarpiece was painted by J. Hedman in 1818. In the churchyard is a memorial to the heroes sculpted by Kalervo Kallio, called "Praying Mother".

name: Ylämaan kirkko
description:
Ylämaa Church is a notable granite church located in Ylämaa, Finland. Completed in 1931, it stands as a prime example of the granite architecture typical of the region, as Ylämaa is known for its granite deposits. The church was designed by the architect Atte V. Willberg.

The interior of the church features a simple yet elegant design, complementing the robust exterior. Its construction marked a significant achievement for the local community, showcasing the skilled craftsmanship in granite work. Ylämaa Church remains an important landmark and a place of worship, reflecting the cultural and architectural heritage of the area.

name: Yläneen kirkko
description:
Yläne Church, located in Pöytyä, Finland, is a wooden church completed in 1782, designed by Mikael Piimänen. Dedicated to St. Olaf, it stands on the site of a former chapel built in 1663. The red-painted, wooden long church features high walls and a steep shingle roof reminiscent of medieval churches. The bell tower, integrated as the western tower, includes an octagonal bell chamber topped with a bulbous dome.

The churchyard, enclosed by a high stone fence, and the leafy surroundings contribute to the scenic dominance of the church. Although the interior has been renovated several times, the exterior has remained true to its original design. A vicarage, built in 1877, is located a few hundred meters away. The church, cemetery, and vicarage complex is designated as a nationally significant cultural environment.

name: Ylöjärven kirkko
description:
Ylöjärvi Church has always been the focal point of the landscape and the most valuable building in the area. Even during periods of strong growth and construction, it has maintained its central position. The church is truly "in the middle of the village" in Ylöjärvi, proclaiming unchanging and eternal values as times change.

The Ylöjärvi Church was completed in 1850, replacing the old wooden church that burned down in 1842. The current Empire-style church is a symmetrical cross-shaped church with a western tower and beveled inner corners. Opposite the tower, on the eastern or altar end, is a sacristy that is lower than the rest of the building.

The church has undergone various repairs, improvements, renovations and restorations over the course of more than 150 years since its completion. The most recent renovation was carried out in 1996-97. The floor area of the church building is approximately 700 square meters and the volume is 9000 cubic meters.

name: Ylösnousemuskappeli
description:
The Ylösnousemuskappeli, or Resurrection Chapel, is located in the Turku Cemetery and was designed by Erik Bryggman. Construction began in 1939 and was completed in 1941. The chapel blends elements of Italian folk architecture, Finnish stone church traditions, 1920s Nordic classicism, and functionalism.

The chapel is designed to integrate with its natural surroundings. Inside, a large hall features a continuous glass wall, allowing light filtered through the pine forest to illuminate the space. The chapel is full of layered symbolism, with sandstone reliefs and sculptures by Turku artists Jussi Vikainen and Ennu Oka. It's considered one of the most beautiful chapels in the Nordic countries and a prime example of late functionalism in Europe, also having good acoustics and a Finnish organ from 1958.

name: Ypäjän kirkko
description:
Ypäjän kirkko, located in the center of Ypäjä, is an 800-seat Jugendstil church built between 1901 and 1902. The church was designed by Henrik Helin and Aleksander Nyström. The altarpiece, "The Crucified," was painted by Gabriel Gotthard Sweidel in 1811, and in 1939, Urho Lehtinen's "Adoration of the Magi" was added to the lower part of the altarpiece.

The church's ceiling features a light installation resembling a starry sky, added during renovations in the 1990s. The organ, made by Kangasala Organ Factory, has 18+3 stops and dates back to 1940. There is also a globe candelabrum, crafted in 1981 at the Ypäjä agricultural schools' blacksmith workshop. The old church was a wooden cross church built in the 1550s.

name: Ähtärin kirkko
description:
Ähtäri Church, the fourth church of the parish, was completed in 1937 and consecrated on November 7th of the same year. It is a traditional long church with a tower, designed by architect Bertel Liljeqvist. The church offers seating for 650 people and is a good venue for concerts, featuring a 35-stop organ built by Hans Heinrich organ builders in 1983.

The church is located in the old center of the parish village. The altarpiece was painted by Vilho Sjöström in 1906.

name: Ähtävän kirkko
description:
The Ähtävä Church, known in Swedish as Esse Church, is a wooden cross-shaped church located in Ähtävä, which is now part of Pedersöre municipality. Completed in 1770 and inaugurated in 1771, it was originally named Magdalena Sofia Church after the queen consort Sofia Magdalena and King Gustav III's sister, Princess Sophia Albertina, though this name was later forgotten.

The church features a separate bell tower and a small tower at the crossing of its roof. The interior is considered exceptionally fine, with the altar in its original position at the corner of two cross arms, opposite the pulpit. The altar table, railing, and pulpit are a mix of late Baroque, Rococo, and Neoclassical styles, crafted in the 1810s by local carpenters and adorned with wood carvings and gilding. The altarpiece, painted by Gustaf Erik Hedman, depicts the Crucifixion and the Last Supper, and is a copy of an earlier work.

name: Äänekosken kirkko
description:
The Äänekoski Church, designed by architect Erkki Kantonen, was completed in 1973. It was built to replace a wooden church that was destroyed in a fire in 1968. The church is constructed from red brick, wood, and glass, representing modern church architecture of its time.

The building has a bright interior. Some items were saved from the old church, including the pulpit, church bells, three granite slabs in the yard, and stained glass paintings by artist Urho Lehtinen on the side wall, depicting New Testament stories, such as Christ blessing five loaves and two fishes, and Christ opening the eyes of a blind man. The church was renovated in 2012, including the construction of a parish center.

name: Ämmänsaaren kirkko
description:
The Ämmänsaari Church is located in the center of Suomussalmi. It was consecrated in 1967 and designed by Suunnittelu Oy Niemelä. The church is a rectangular, towerless brick building with a transverse, inwardly folding outer roof.

Inside the church, the altarpiece was painted by Irja Juntunen, who was born in Suomussalmi, in 1979. The church's 14-voice organ was made in 1968 by Tuomi and Co. organ builders. The church has seating for 300 people.

The church is part of the Ämmänsaari parish center, which also includes a parish hall built in 1977. The parish hall hosts the parish's own activities, as well as private celebrations and events. The space can also be rented for meetings.

name: Östersundomin kirkko
description:
Östersundom Church is located in Helsinki, it used to belong to Sipoo before 2009. The church is Helsinki's oldest. The wooden church was built in 1754, construction began in 1753. It features a tower, low walls, a high roof, and a long church design. The interior has angular wooden vaulting.

Originally, a prayer room was built in Östersundom in the late 17th century for the residents of the archipelago. The church was thoroughly renovated in 1895, receiving a new bell tower. Central heating was installed in 1912, and electric lights in 1948. In 2003, the electrical installations were renewed, and the church was painted inside, and its name was changed to Östersundom Church.
